The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

div.p: THE WAY TO TRVE HAPPINESSE.
Deliuered in XXIV. SERMONS vpon the BEATITVDES.
By ROBERT HARRIS, B. in Diuinity, and Pastor of Hanwell.
ALSO, A TREATISE OF THE NEVV COVENANT; Set forth Sermon-wise, on EZECHIEL the XI. By the same AVTHOVR.
div.q: TITVS 3. VER. 8. This is a faithfull saying, and these things I will that thou affirme constantly, that they which haue beleeued in God, be carefull to maintaine good workes, these things are good and profitable vnto men.
div.p: LONDON, Printed for Iohn Bartlet, and are to be sold at his shop in Cheape-side at the Gilded Cup. 1632.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
THat which miscarrieth in the first, is seldom corrected in the second & third concoction. This J finde true in a review of these Notes. At the first, they were raw and indigested, forged in a cold and dull heart, vttered by a weake broken man, who hath his hands full with himselfe, his owne infirmities and temptations, and deliuered to a people, who neither could nor
would expect more from him, than naked truths and honestie. Thus it fared with them whilst they were mine. From my mouth, they fell into the hand of an able man, but his shame-fac'd (J may not say blush-full) modesty was too hard for his abilities, and by this meane they wanne nothing in this second digestion. Now how the Printer (in point of distribution, and in a third place) hath done his part, thou wilt easily find. Meane while, all that J can say about so poore a businesse is this: Jf thou finde any benefit by any thing heere, I am made (for I hold doing good the best preferment) If otherwise matters sort not to thy liking, blame not me, who promise nothing, and print (I am sure) as vnwillingly, as thou canst reade. The Lord (whose power triumphs
in mans weaknesse, goe along with them and vs both, and keepe vs from trifling, whilest Indocti coelum rapiunt, whilest others run away with grace and glorie, as that good man once, Amen.

div.head: The Printer to the Reader.
div.p: BY reason of the Authours absence and badnesse of the hand, diuerse faults haue escaped vs in the first Sermons, which are partly thus corrected for the present, till they shall be further reuewed by the Authors selfe hereafter.

A TREATISE OF THE Nevv Couenant: DELIVERED SERMON-VVISE UPON, EZECHIEL 11. Vers. 19, 20.
By ROBERT HARRIS, Pastour of Hanwell, Batchelor of Diuinity.
div.q: PSAL. 51.10. Create in mee a cleane heart, O God, and renew a right Spirit within me.
TITVS. 3. Vers. 9. But stay foolish questions and Genealogies, and contentious, and brawlings about the Law, for they are vnprofitable and vaine.
div.p: LONDON, Printed by I. B. for Iohn Bartlet, and are to be sold at his shop, at the Signe of the gilt Cup, in Goldsmith-Row in CHEAPSIDE, 1632.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
THou wilt thinke thy time lost, and thy selfe wronged, if thou shouldst not find here what thou seekest for, I'll therefore deale plainely, and doe as I would be done by: First, if thou be a verbalist, and standest vpon composures, here's nothing for thee: First, my Auditory was partly very learned, and so aboue words; partly very plaine, and so below them: Secondly, my selfe am both vnable, and vnwilling to stand on phrases, that, because I am clogg'd with ignorance, age, businesse; this, because I finde, that of those poore things of mine, the plainest haue taken best hitherto: Thirdly,
the Scribe who tooke them from my mouth in the Church, Master Iohn Trapp. hath beene, contrary to my hopes, and his owne worth, superstitiously modest, else had it been easie for him to haue cast a better coate vpon these ragged meditations, and rather enlarged then abridged them. And so much for that, if thy pulse beat that way. Now, secondly, if thou be a Questionist, spare thy paines; I neuer thought the Pulpit a fit place for brawles and disputes, to stirre controuersies there (yet flagrant) is but to spread them, and therefore, notwithstanding the opportunity which my Text and some mens surmises of mee,Apostolicae Doctrina expositio est falsae doctrinae optima refutatio. Cassand consultat. as if I were somewhat warping, gaue mee, I declined polemicalls, so farre as I could, and contented my selfe with positiue truths, the best confuters.

Truely, (Reader) I am not priuy to any priuate opinion, were I, that opinion which bred in me, should be buried with me too; two studies my heart abhorres, to wit, studium partium, and studium nouarum rerum: If I can study the truth first, and the peace next, I haue as much learning as I desire, as for credit, my highest ambition is that of his, viz. that my name may be Christian,Pacia. and my surname Catholique: wanton wits may please themselues in more ayerie walkes, sure I am of two things: First, that the most wise and learned of all sorts,Vide Amamā in oration de barbarie in his Antibar. cry downe this luxuriancy in young wits, and call them another way: And secondly, that they who know most, say least, and the maine sticklers in most controuersies, are the men, who least vnderstand where the question inter partes sticks. Lastly, if (in the third place) thou wonderest why I would giue way to the publishing of things so ordinary, in an age so learned,
let this suffice, I feared Bellarmines feare,Vide Bellar. de scriptor Eccles. 2. Sermons of godly mourning. Alphon a Castro aduers. haeres. Abortire coactus sum. &c. being plainly told, that, if I would not publish them, others would, and I had reason to thinke so, because I am already serued so, for, whereas I had conceiued something vpon Mathew 5. two of the younger brethen are taught to speake, before the elder be borne. Hence this anticipation, and (as one calls it) abortion. I haue said, now vse thy liberty.

p.hi: The things handled in this ensuing Treatise deliuered Sermon-wise, are chiefely these:

list.item:
1 IN generall, is shewed from the Text, what our poore condition is, when God first lookes vpon vs in fauour.
2 How farre forth the Lord hath engaged himselfe by Gouenant to vs.

2 In particular, the causes of the grace spoken of in the Couenant are handled, as
1. the materiall (whereof Onenesse, Newnesse, Softnesse of heart)
2. the formall:
3. the efficient:
4. the finall, &c.

div.p: As for that obiection, how this couenant can be applyable to vs Gentiles, which was deliuered to the Iews; It needes no answer, for in Christ, Iew and Gentile are all one, they make but one spouse, and haue one and the same ioynture or dowry; but for this, let the weake read the Epistles to the Romans, Galatians and Hebrewes 8. &c. and he shall easily finde, that euery beleeuer is of Abraham, is Israel, is the Circumcision, as Saint Paul speakes, Phil. 3.3.

div.head: A TREATISE OF THE COVENANT OF GRACE.

epigraph.q: And I will giue them one heart, and I will put a new spirit within you, and I will take the stony heart out of their flesh, and will giue them an heart of flesh.

div.p:
WE haue already spoken of the Natures, & office of the Lord, Christ. Now we come in such order, as we haue propounded to our selues, to speake of the Couenant it selfe, made with Christ in the behalfe of all his members. This Couenant is deliuered in this present Chapter. One parcell thereof being contained in the words of the Text.
Before God had vndertaken for the outward estate of his people; here he vndertakes for their spirituall estate; where we haue to obserue: 1. The parties betweene whom this couenant is smitten. 2. The articles of agreement, or the matter vndertaken: For the first of these, 1. The party vndertaking is God, who is heere brought in by the Prophet Ezekiel, as on • entring into couenant that he will giue them all spirituall and sauing grace. 2. The parties with whom he couenants, and these are his Israel, whom he had chosen out of all Nations to be a people to himselfe, as before he tells them. These be the parties that concurre in this Couenant. Secondly, you haue heere the matter vndertaken by God, and that is to bestow sanctification, or sauing grace vpon them. And this grace is set forth in the Text by all the causes of it. First the Efficient, and that is (as is said) God (I will put a new spir • t within you, and I will take, &c.) Secondly, the materiall cause, or the matter wherin this holinesse promised standeth, and that is deliuered in three particulars: 1. He will giue them (one heart) 2. a (new heart) 3. a (soft heart) a heart of flesh, insteed of an heart of stone. Thirdly, the formall cause, or the manner how hee will bestow these blessings; he (giues) this heart, he (puts) it within them, he takes away from them the stony heart, and giues them a heart of flesh. Lastly, we haue here the finall cause, or the end wherefore God will doe all this for them, viz. That they may walke in my Statutes, and keepe my Ordinances and doe them, &c. Thus you see who vndertakes, and what he vndertakes.

Before we come to handle the particulars propounded, and as it were to breake into the bowels of the Text: Let vs consider of these two generals. First, how, and in what case the Lord findes his people, when hee comes to make couenant with them. Next, how farre-forth hee vndertakes for them, not onely in outward blessings, out he promiseth them spiritualls too, as to change and mend the heart, that is, all his inside, for the heart is the chiefe part of man, the very fountaine of life, and of all morality whatsoeuer. For the first, wee see how God findes man disposed, when he first comes vpon him with saluation, hee is quite out of order, out of ioynt, a meere confusion. And that is the first thing we would commend to your consideration.

That man is in a very ill case of himselfe for his soule, his spirituall estate is very miserable,
Doctr. Man spiritually considered, is of himselfe most miserable, 1. Proued by Testimony. the frame of his heart is quite out of frame, till God comes to ioynt it. For proofe hereof, we haue Gods own testimony, Gen. 6.5. at such time as he came to feele mans pulse, and to looke into his inside, he saw that euery imaginatiō of the thoughts of his hart was only euill continually. Look vpon man in his inward disposition, in the immediate operations of his spirit, his imaginations, desires, purposes, are all euill and onely euil, and euill euery day, as the Lord there testifies. And thus we see it, in this present Scripture we now goe vpon. When God comes to doe a cure vpon the heart of man, hee finds it first parted into may diuisions, many turnings and windings euery way, &c. All these must be pared off, and
the heart turned the right way, being made one heart, and so pitcht vpon God the right obiect: 2. he findes it an old heart, rotten and totterd, and therfore promiseth to put a new spirit into man. 3. he findes him sicke of the stone, hee will take out the stony heart out of their flesh, and giue them an heart of flesh. So that the heart of a man by nature, till it is renued and changed, is a diuided heart, a rotten and corrupted heart, as stony as any flint whatsoeuer: Thus is he for his inside here described.

2. illustrated and amplified by comparison▪The holy Ghost proceedes yet further in other places to shaddow it out by many comparisons: As Ezek. 16. the whole Chapter throughout, and especially in the beginning, the estate of a man in his pure Naturals (as they say) is set out by the condition of a child new-borne. Now you know what thing a child is, when he is new come into the world, an impure thing, a poore, silly, impotent thing, that vnderstands little, and is able to do nothing to help it selfe. Thus it is in the natural birth, and thus it is also with euery man in his spirituall condition: he is a creature, shiftles, helples, maim'd, impure, loathsom, &c. In other places, the holy Ghost goes further, and compare natural man not to a child, but to a very beast, that like as it was with Nebuchadnezzar, so it is with euery mothers sonne by nature, he hath the shape indeed of a man, but the heart, of a beast: so saith the Prophet Ieremy. Euery man by his owne vnderstanding is brutish, And Iob. 11.12, Vaine man (saith Zophar there) would faine be wise, and so esteemed, though man newborne be like a wild asses colt. He is wild, and therefore
vnteachable; he is like a colt, and the colt of an asse, and the colt of a wild asse. Euery word hath its weight to set forth the miserable estate of a naturall man; Nay, the holy Ghost, not onely compares man to a beast, but makes him euen a compound of all the malignities of all hurtfull creatures: he partakes something of the lion, and somthing of the leopard, and something of the aspe, and something of the woolfe, (as we haue shewed you heretofore out of Esay.) Nay hee stayes not there, but goes further and compares man, in regard of spirituals, to a dead man, Ephes. Ye which were in trespasse and sinnes, &c. Now what is a dead carcasse but an vgly sight, a deformed thing especially if you look within it, there you shal find nothing but gore and blood and filth, and all manner of abomination. Nay further he is compared in holy Scripture, to a sepulcher, painted tombe, which containes not one, but many dead men: within it is nothing but darknes and confusion, and out of it comes nothing but stench and contagion. Thus the holy Ghost shewes by comparison,3 by effect. what man is in his naturall estate for his inside. He doth yet further acquaint vs herewith by that appeares in his outside. How should one iudge of the tree, but by that wich it beares? how of the sap but by the fruits? Now for this, hearken to our Sauiour, Matth. 15.19. Out of the heart, saith he, proceed euill thoughts, murders, adulteries, fornications, thefts, false witnesses, blasphemies. These are the things that come from within, from the inside of a man, and breake out in his life and conuersation. Looke
to the body of a man, and that you shall see subiect to blaines and sores of all sorts, which what do they else but speak what matter is within; the corruption of the soule doth, as it were, peepe out through the sores of the body. Looke againe to the liues of men; and there you shall discerne blasphemy in some, Atheisme in others, Adultery in others, &c. All these doe plainely euidence, what man is of himselfe.4. by the contrary medicines and prescriptions. Lastly, looke on such Lawes as God hath made against sinnes, there you shall see lawes against murder, lawes against adultery, lawes against blasphemy, &c: you shall find prohibitions of vnnaturall sins, of nameles abhorred sins, and all to acquaint vs with that depth of wickednesse that is found in mans heart; for from the ill natures and manners of men sprang vp all these good Lawes. Yea, the Lord makes Lawes against those sinnes, which a heathen law-giuer held it needlesse, as against parricide, because hee thought that none could bee so inhumane as to fall into so foule a wickednesse, yet the Lord forbids it, so by his medicine he does vs to know what are our dispositions: he forbids Atheisme, to tel vs that we haue Atheistical natures, murder and adultery, because we haue murderous and adulterous natures, &c. All this serues to shew what is within. For our further vnderstanding of the point, wee will enquire into these three things. 1. In what sense man is said to bee corrupt.3. further explicated. 2. How far forth he is corrupted. 3. Whence it comes, and what is the reason of it. For the first, we must tell you that man cōmeth vnder a threefold
consideration or capacity. 1. In regard of his naturall disposition and endowments, as we vse to consider him in Philosophy. 2. as we take him in a politicke state, as a member of the commonwealth. 3. in a spirituall sense, as he is taken in Diuinity. In this place we consider him not as the Philosophers describe him; for so, we yeeld him to be a noble creature, endued with vnderstanding, with a reasonable appetite, with affections capable of diuine obiects, with apprehensions and operations suitable to his nature, being able to compare, connect, discourse, deduct, to remember, and performe other noble parts and actions. Thus if you take man in genere entis, as they say, as he is Gods Creature, the work-manship of his hands, there is nothing amisse in him, as he comes from God. Neither doe we consider him here, in a ciuill sense, as, that he is of such a state, such a descent, such authority in the common-wealth, endued with such and such morall vertues, &c: for in this respect wee giue him his due according to his place and condition, religion makes not a confusion, but a distinction of persons according to their degrees and orders. Therefore wee dismisse these two considerations of man for present, not medling with him as he is set out by naturall or morall Philosophers, but as he is taken by Diuines, as he referres to God, to Gods Image, to Gods Law, &c; and in this sense, we say that man is in a very poore and miserable condition.
The second Quaere is, how far forth man thus taken is to be faulted?

For answer to this: If you speake of Goodnesse first, he is depriued of all Good, not naturall or morall, but spirituall, I meane, there is no sauing goodnes in him at all: There is no vnderstanding left in him, no knowledge of heauenly things, no loue or feare of God, which is spirituall, he hath made forfeiture of all these in his fall by Adam. Next, he is depriued, not onely of all actuall goodnes, but 2. of all ability to recouer himselfe. 3. of all willingnesse to be restored. 4. lastly, (which is the height of his misery) bad though he be, yet he would faine seem good, he would be accounted wise, though he be brutish, and as a wild asse-colt. Thus for goodnes, he is voyd of all, he is depriued of the Glory of God, as saith the Apostle. Next, forbadnes, he is prone to all wickednesse, though neuer so abominable. Euery man ('tis true) is not a murtherer, euery man is not a theife, euery man is not a drunkard or adulterer, but euery man hath an adulterous nature, a drunken nature, an adulterous, an atheisticall nature, and may bee drawne at some times to an high degree of these detestable euils, he hath the seeds of all sin in himselfe, and not so only, but he hath also a disposition to cherish and foment these sins, these seeds of sin, according to that of Eliphaz, Iob, 15.15, 16. Behold, he puteth no trust in his Saints: yea, the heauens are not cleane in his sight: How much more abominable and filthy is man, which drinketh iniquity like water? As the fish that liues by the water, sucks it in: so doth man euen feed vpon corruption, he drinkes it in, as a fish doth water.

Thirdly, though he be thus enclined to all euill, yet he will acknowledge none, he will needs seem to be godly, when he is godlesse, and would be reputed full of all goodnesse, when indeed he is empey of grace, and full of all corruption.

But the third thing wee haue to enquire of, is, whence miserable man is brought to so bad a passe, as hath beene spoken? and here hee must blame none but himselfe, for the euill that is befalne him: For the diuell could not compell him to sinne, much lesse did God any way necessitate him: it was mans owne doing alone, by his owne wilfull disobedience in breaking the commandements of God, he forfeited all sauing goodnesse, and drew vpon himselfe all euill and misery. And thi • is the vnhappy condition of all the sonnes of Adam, who being a publike person, his sinne was publike, and the infection thereof common to all his wretched posterity. Hence is it, that there is in euery one the seed and spawne of all sinne, a disposition to euery wickednesse, Reas. which euill disposition is daily drawne into act, partly by the actiuity of mans nature, partly by the connaturalnesse of sin with him, and partly by the power, that now since the fall Satan hath ouer man.

First▪ I say, it is by reason of the excellency and act • uity of mans nature. Hee was made of God, the most noble creature of all, and according to that of the Philosopher, the best things corrupted are m • de worst; man being depraued, of the best of Gods creatures, becomes the worst. Hee hath by nature a working spirit, that neuer lies still,
which as now, being without the guidance of sauing grace, runnes wilde, as it were, and wanders out of the right way, like a clocke out of order, the faster it strikes, the worse; like a Coach without a guide, the faster it runnes, the worse; like a Ship without a Pylot, the swifter it is, the worse; So mans soule since the fall, the faster hee goes, the further he erres from the right way.

Secondly, it proceeds from the connaturalnesse of sinne with man, it is become euen a part of himselfe, as if he were transformed into it, I mean it in a morall, not natural sense, for it goes with him, whersoeuer hee goes, it eates with him, it sleepes with him, &c. It is in man, as in its owne place, hence it troubles him not, he groanes not vnder the burthen of it, an Element in its own place waighes not.

Thirdly, man is made thus miserable, by being put (by Gods iust iudgement vpon him for his sinne) vnder the power and tyranny of Satan, who inspires him with all wickednesse, and leads him captiue at his pleasure, so that hereby mans wickednesse is become more then humane, euen diabolicall, according to that of Iames, chap. 3.15. The wisdome of the flesh is not only earthly, and sensuall, but euen diuellish also. Mans wit is now diabolicall, and himselfe ready and apt to commit such foule sins as a man of himselfe would neuer doe, but that the diuell doth act and edge him.
You see by this time, my brethren, how ill it stands with a man in his naturall estate and condition. There are diuers inferences to be made of this point.

And first it serues, to discouer the miserable Vse. 1 pride, and delusion of all carnall persons, that beare themselues in hand, that they are better then others, and that their inside is the best part of them, whereas you see by this point, that the worst piece of a man is in the midst, and that his heart, and whole frame of his imaginations, is altogether euill continually; yet vaine men will not sticke to boast of the goodnesse of their hearts, and that although they are not booke-learned, &c. cannot talke and discourse of this and that, or remember a Sermon as soone as others can, yet they meane as well as the best,Mans pride confuted, 〈…〉 by m derne Christ •… who most cry out of the •…
side. and they haue as good hearts as any of them all. They loue God aboue all, and their neighbour as themselues, and what can any man doe more? O miserable delusion, that men should not onely stand out before men in this manner, but euen dare to appeale to God in his name, that though they want these, and these trappings and accoutrements of ostentation, yet hee know • s their hearts to be good to him-ward. Lo, here is the very height of error and delusion: here sinne & Satan do euen exceed themselues, either in impudency, if knowing their own wicked inside they dissemble it, or else in selfe-deceit, if they know it not. This is certaine, that the inside of a man is altogether poysoned and depraued: witnesse those that can best iudge of the point, that doe most obserue themselues, that are of the quickest to • ch and liueliest apprehensions, Gods dearest seruants, with whom there is nothing more frequent, then continually to complaine of their inside, they are
sicke at heart, their principall trouble lyeth at the heart. The pride, reuengefulnesse, hypocrisie, the wicked naughtinesse of their hearts, this is it that tires them most, and euen makes them cry out in the words of the Apostle: O wretched man that I am, who shall • eliuer mee from the body of this death? Lo, thus it is with the best Christians, they haue more adoe with their owne hearts, then with all the world againe, and are more put to it to resist corruption, then to deale with all their other enemies whatsoeuer.

2. Ancient Physicians in the world.2. If you consult the best of those wee read of in holy Scripture, we shall find them crying out of their hearts, as Dauid, Psal. 43. Why art thou cast downe my soule, and why art thou disquieted within mee? Dauid was a man of an excellent spirit, and yet all his busines lay at home, he was most of all troubled with himselfe, and therefore it is that in another place, he cryes out: Lord, cleanse mee from my secret sins, Psal. 19. This was Dauid. The like you may see, if you consult his sonne Salomon. Who can say, his heart is cleane, saith he, though a man may wash his hands, and make all faire for the outside, yet no man can deny, that hath gotten any insight into himselfe, but that his heart is foule and filthy.

3. By Diuine, test, in the 1. Prophets.3. Consult with the Prophets, and they will assure you the same thing. The heart of man, saith Ieremy, is deceitfull, aboue all things, and desperately euill, 2. and the Son of God. who can know it? Ierem. 17. If you will heare the iudge himselfe speake, he tells you, Mathew 15. that from within a man, commeth euill thoughts, theeuish thoughts, murtherous thoughts, adulterous
thoughts, blasphemous thoughts, &c. Nay, will you heare God himselfe determining the point? you haue heard it already, Gen. 6. The whole frame of the imaginations of the heart of man is onely euill, and that all the day. Thus you haue heard what these can say to the point, that are best able to iudge of it, therefore here is the height of all pride and error, and misery too, that man being so blinde, so bad, so farre out of the right way, and euen so starke naught as he is, hee seeth it not, he feareth not, but being deade, takes himselfe to be aliue, and which is the height of misery, hee is stuft vp with selfe deceit and conceit, both at once.

As this Doctrine discouers the vnhappinesse of Vse. 2 ignorant persons, that ouerweene themselues: so it may serue in the second place, to humble vs all (euen the best in the Church) in the sight, and sence of our miserable estate by nature.

First, if we looke vpon man as he is in himselfe, till God vndertake the oute of him, the Lord hath made a full description of him, in that fore-mentioned, and so often alledged place. Gen. 6.Gen. 6. expounded. Euery imagination of mans heart, is altogether euill continually. Heere the wickednesse of mans inside is set forth by all the dimensions, the bredth, length, and depth of it. 1. For the breadth and latitude, it is said, that the whole frame, the whole platforme, the whole piece of mans inside is euill, (as it were easie to shew in the particulars, • f time would giue leaue.) If you looke to his vnderstanding. First, mans minde is stuft vp with conceit and deceit, with error and pride, being subiect to blindnesse,
more then humane; for the diuell so sits in mans heart and blinds it, that hee hath not the heart of a man in him, as that Wise-man acknowledgeth, Pro. 30. Take the experience of it, when you will: deale but with men a little in worldly businesses in things of this life, in affaires secular, and they will tell you a very sensible tale, and answer to very good purpose: but turne your talke awhile to things spirituall, and you shall heare them speake as if they were not reasonable creatures, or had not common sense in them, so vnskilfully wil they here quit themselues. And what wee say for the vnderstandings of men, the same is true also of their memorie which like vnto a grate retaineth that which is lothsome and vnusefull, but lets goe that that is sweete and seruiceable. Of this you may make the same tryall, as of the former. Tell a man a tale of any thing worldly, that pertaines to this present life, hee can goe along with you in euery thing, and rehearse the whole discourse after you againe to a tittle: but bring this man to the house of God, set him vnder a Preacher, that handleth the word of God neuer so plainly, powerfully, methodically, yet he cannot carry away one sentence hardly of the sermon: so that a man would wonder what shift such a one can make to forget all, and not to remember, no not one of those lessons that haue beene deliuered, but that if you meet him at the Church doores, and demand of him what he hath learned, hee can remember nothing at all. Wee may say as much for the will and affections, which stand all quite
crosse and contrary to God. The will is nothing else but peruersenesse and peeuishnesse, ready to stand against that which God commandeth, in that very name, because God commands it. It is reason enough to men, therefore to loue a thing, because God hates it, and to hate a thing because he loues it. Thus into what part or roome soeuer of the soule you looke, nothing is to be found but rottennesse and corruption, disorder and confusion. Thus you see what a bredth of wickednesse there is in mans heart: Followes next the depth of it, when the Lord saith, mans thoughts and imaginations of his heart are euill, indefinetly, that is, he is subiect to all manner of euill: by nature euery man stands subiect to murder, subiect to adultery, blasphemy, and what not? And as his thoughts are euill, so it is said they are onely euill, without the mixture of any good therewithall. True it is, there are found in man, some naturall principles, some cōmon notions, but it is a very disputable question, whether they are to be ranked & reckoned among rudera or rudimenta, i. e. whether they belong to the old rubbish or to a new foundation: certainly, how euer it is, man hath in him by nature no good thing that tends to saluation, nothing that will doe him that good. These princples in speech tend rather to a common good, that men may liue safely vpon earth, than any personall, priuate good to helpe a mans selfe to heauen. The imaginations and thoughts of mans heart are eutll, and onely euill: there is the depth of his wickednesse.

3. Consider a little of the length and continuance of it, as it is there described by God, the imaginations of his heart are onely euill, and that continually, euery day, or all the day (as the word may be rendred) there is not an houre in the day or a minute in the houre, wherein mans heart is not deuising of euill, it attends him in all whatsoeuer he does, wheresoeuer he goes, when he lyeth downe at night, sinne lieth downe with him, when hee wakes againe, sinne wakes with him, when he trauels, it goes along with him, when he dines, it sits downe with him, when he comes to Church, sinne beares him company, yea, it comes with a man to the Lords Table, yea, into the pulpit too, doe what he can to the contrary, it dogs him at heeles in all his wayes; mingles with all his prayers, runnes along in his best seruices, all which (for the matter) may bee good and commendable, but for the manner, there is a tainture of sinne in all his actions. Thus you haue seene that the whole frame of mans heart by nature is naught, starke naught, wholy naught, only naught, euery day and all day naught.
But 2 how is it with him, when God giues him his grace, and regenerates him.

Surely, then the matter is much amended with him, but yet there still remaines in him that which may humble and pull him downe, whether you looke to euill or good. First, he stands strongly inclined still to euill, the dregs of his old disease, of his former distemper, do yet still sticke by him, and he is disposed to it, being cured but in part.
See this in Dauid: who would euer haue thought that so many afflictions, which hee had suffered, so many mercies as he had receiued, so many vows as he had made, so many parts of holy Scriptures as he had penned, &c: that after all this, so many dregges of adultery, of treachery, of murder, should haue beene left remaining in him? and yet when Dauid remits his strict watch, and holds not so euen a hand ouer his owne heart, how fouly doth he fall, how shamefully doth he sinne against the Lord? In him you see the seedes of all euill are left in the best of Gods children, and are apt to breake out. And secondly for good, all that the regenerat man doth, is imperfect, it fares with him as with a crazy, weak man, that is new come out of his sicknes, euery small matter distempers him. He findes it a very hard matter to raise vp his heart to a little heate in that which is good, and what adoe is there to hold it when he hath it? How easie a thing is it to slacke his pace, to remit of his heate before it bee well kindled. And for his performances, how faint and feeble do they come from him, his prayers are cold, his purposes vnsettled and vncertaine: now he will, and now againe he will not, one while he hath a good motion in his mind, and anone he is quite off againe, he lets goe his hold, his deuotions flag, &c: like the strings of an instrument, which, set in it neuer so good tune, lock it vp, when you haue don, neuer so safe, yet when it comes next to be vsed, you must tune it anew, and straine vp the strings again, else you will haue no good musick: And so it is
with the heart of a Christian, he must be euer dealing with it, if he would haue it kept in any good frame, for he can neuer finde it, as he left it: now perhaps it is in good plight, and anone quite off the hookes, set quite backward, so that a man must begin againe with it to raise it vp to the former pitch. Oh let the due consideration of all these things layd together, make you humble and low in your owne eyes, mercifull to other offenders, and thankfull to God, and to Christ, for affording vs such meanes, and such medicines to amend vs.

Vse. 3 Is it so, that mans inside is thus bad, as hath been shewed? Learne we all from hence what to do for our selues, and what for our friends. For our selues first, labour to get a better heart, a better inside. Most people are all for the outside, to haue their faces faire, their skin smooth, &c: but let vs learne to beginne at the right end, to get the heart made good, this is the source and spring of all our actions, therefore make that cleane first; to what purpose is it to wash the bucket, so long as the spring is foule: Behold, the heart is the fountaine, the wel-spring of all, therefore begin there, if you desire to haue your outside good, your conuersation cleare. The heart is the chiefe part of a man, it is Gods roome, where he abides, his bed-chamber, where hee lodges. Yee are the Temples of the holy Ghost, saith Paul. Now a neate man would haue his court lye clean, much more his ha • , his parlour, but most of all his bed-chamber, the heart is Gods bed-chamber, therefore giue all diligence to get
a new heart, a cleane heart. This you are not able to doe of your selues, for the heart is like that stable, the Poet speakes of; it is an infinite worke to cleanse it of all those thoughts, euill lusts, euill dreames, &c: wherewith it is pestered. Therefore you must goe to him which is both the heart-maker, and the heart-mender, and that is God alone, as here in the text. I will giue you a nea • heart, and I will renew a right Spirit within you, I will doe it. None but God can come at the heart: none but his medicines can effect the cure: none but the father of Spirits can alter and renue our spirits. To him therefore must we runne and pray in the words of Dauid, Create in me a cleane heart, O God, &c; intreate him to vndertake the cure, carry his owne couenant to him, and say, Lord, here is thine own promise, the bargaine thou hast made with mee, and confirmed often to mee in the Sacrament, &c:

Secondly, you must waite vpon God in the vse of his owne meanes and ordinances. Wherewithall, saith Dauid, shall a young man, (whose heart is vainest and foulest) cleanse his wayes? by taking heed thereto according to thy Word, Psal. 119.9. It is the Word that cleanseth our inside, therefore we must bee carefull to reade it, heare it, lodge it in our hearts, apply it close to our consciences, and then it will heale our hearts. Hence is it that the word is cōpared to leauen, which a woman takes and puts into three peckes of meale, and it leaueneth the whole lump: so the word must be hid in the heart till it haue seasoned it. This the Apostle Iames exhorts to, setting it
forth by another comparison, Chap. 1.20. receiu (saith he) the engrafted Word that is able to saue your soules. A graft that is set into a stocke, altereth the nature thereof: so the heart when the word is stockt, grafted, and, as it were, moulded thereunto. But wee can stand no longer vpon this.

Secondly, learne hence what to doe for your friends too, you that be parents, first, see what is to be done for your children. It is your great care for most part, to haue them for the outside, proper, fine, well featured, sightly, but the worst part in them is the heart, and there you must beginne, if you would haue them doe well. Folly is knit vp, Prou. 22.15. saith Salomon, in the heart of a childe, but the rod of correction, &c. There is a heape of folly, a bundle of corruption in the heart of a child. How shall wee come at it now, and get it out. First, pray to God to doe a cure vpon them. Secondly, bring them to the ordinances. Thirdly, whet Gods Law vpon them at home. Lastly, giue them all due instruction, shew them all good example, correct them also, as there is neede, and thus shall you fetch out their folly, saith Salomon, So heere is a lesson for you Magistrates: Doe you see what a thing man is in himselfe? There is in euery one by nature, the seeds of treason, the seeds of rebellion, the seeds of murther, and of all kinde of wickednesse, which seeds will certainely break out into the lips and liues of men, if you labour not by your authority to represse it and keepe it in. Man is a wilde and wicked creature of himselfe,
if he be not held vnder. Your townes, your diuisions, your shires will be all ouer-runne with Atheisme, with popery, with murther, whoredome, blasphemy, if you bestirre you not in labouring to restraine them. Indeed, it is not in your power to take corruption out of mens hearts, but it is in your power to keepe it in, and confine it: For which cause it is, that Magistrates are in Scripture phrase, called Lords of restraint. (So the originall hath it) because they are to keep sinne out of mens tongues and hands, though they cannot keepe it out of their hearts. Yea, as fire in the Ouen is best quenched by smothering and shutting of it vp, so is sinne much quailed by restraint.

The like wee may say to the Ministers: The heart is the worst part in a man, what should wee of the Ministery therefore do, rather then by applying all good medicines thereunto, to labour the cure of it, dealing still with the heart as much as may be in all our discourses. And first with our owne hearts: for, hee that will deale with other mens hearts to purpose, must first practice vpon his owne, try the medicines vpon himselfe, wh • ch he desites should proue effectuall to others. Water will ascend no higher then it descends: and words will hardly come to the heart, which come not from the heart. Secondly, leuell at the heart of the hearers, like as when a man would strike his enemy dead, he aymes not at his legges or feet, but bendeth the stroke at his heart. I deny not, but you may profitably cut out some branch of sinne,
to inueigh against, or take some particular sinne, as drunkennesse, swearing, lying, or the like to deale with all: and vsually this takes best with our common hearers, who are much affected herewith, but the maine businesse lyes about the heart, with it must we be dealing, if we meane to doe good, for there is the fountaine of all sinnes. And therefore like as if I would fall a tree, it is not my next course to get vp to the top thereof, or to lop off the branches, but I must hew at the root, and so with the same labour, the whole tree would be ouer-turned so is it here, go to the root, originall sinne, and the bed thereof, mans heart.

Vse. 4: Comfort to such poore soules as vpon sight of the euill of their inward man, are cast downe and discouraged thereat, and are ready to thinke there are none so bad as themselues. There are two things whereof I would aduertise euery afflicted conscience, thus deiected in the sense of his owne naughtinesse. First, that you smother not your doubts and temptations out of an opinion, that euer, body would hate you, cry shame on you, spit in your face, and detest you, in case you should vtter and disclose those darke, hideous and horrible thoughts that are in your heart. Secondly, take heed you thinke not your case to be singular. (as vsually Satan would perswade men) as if there were neuer any such person so bad as your selues, so haunted and troubled with wicked thoughts, as you are. Beleeue it, there is no temptation so hideous, but the diuell dare offer it to the best of Gods people: yea, to our Sauiour Christ himselfe,
whom he shamed not to trouble with temptations to presumption, to diffidence, to couetousnesse, to Idolatry, yea, to that monstrous Idolatry, as to dethrone God his Father, and to set vp the diuell for God, by falling downe and worshipping him. What euil thoght is it then thou art pestered with that neuer man had? though they be thoughts of blasphemy, thoughts of Athisme, thoughts of Idolatry, diuellish thoughts; Satan is so shamelesse, that he may, and will offer it to any man, though neuer so holy and high in Gods fauour. Therefore neuer say thy case is singular, that art thus troubled, and thinke not thou art alone herein; I tell thee, the same may be my case, or any ones in the Church: For by nature, there is neuer a better of vs. Wee are all cut out of the same cloth, the sheeres onely going betweene, therefore neuer hold thy state desperate, whateuer thy malady be, but runne to the Physician for cure, who vndertakes here in the Text to giue spirituall, as well as outward blessings, grace, as well as goods, I will giue you one heart, and I will put a right spirit into you, &c. carry all thy hellish, hidious, diabolicall thoughts and temptations to him be they as black as hell, be they as bad as the diuell, bring them to him, and intreat him, to set all right and straight within you, and to bring your hearts to a better point, according to his couenant.

THese words, (as you haue heard already) are part of that couenant that God strikes with his Church, containing the spirituall part of it. He had vndertaken for temporall things before, and now he tels them what he will doe for their soules, hee will take away from them that that is naught, and put into them, insteed thereof, that that is good: I will take the stony heart out of their flesh, and will giue them, &c,

Wee propounded first, to speake of some generalls, before we come to breake open the particulars of the Text. Two things wee generally proposed Doctr. 2 vnto your consideration. First, the miserable estate of man, in respect of his inside, in himselfe considered. Next, that God vndertake to giue spirituall things as well as temporall to his Church. Grace hee will bestow on them, as well as goods, hee will mend their soules as well as their bodies and outward estates.

This is a point of great encouragement to poore Christians, deiected and cast downe in the sense of their spirituall wants and weaknesses, therefore wee will dwell the longer on it. The ground of it, you see, is that order that the Lord obserues here in his Couenant with his people. Before hee had prouided for them in outward things, vers. 17, 18. Therefore thus saith the Lord, I will euen gather
you from the people, and assemble you whither yee haue been scattered, and I will giue you the Land of Israel, God vndertakes to furnish his with spirituall blessings, and doth so note his. and they shall come thither, &c. Nay, saith he, besides all this, I will bestow spirituall good things on you too, for I will make your diuided heart to become one, and for your old heart, I will put a new spirit within you, and for your stony heart, I will giue you a soft heart, a tender heart, an heart of flesh.

Now, for further proofe of this point, it shall be needfull to obserue the degrees, whereby God proceeds in assuring vs of this truth. First, he vndertakes it. 1. By single promise. 2. By Couenant. 3. By oath. Secondly, Hee makes it good in his performance.

First, hee vndertakes it by promise,1. Promises as is to be seene euery where in the Prophets. Ierm. 31. I cannot referre you to any one verse, the whole Chapter is taken vp in it. First, hee tells them, hee would furnish them with come and wine, and oyle, with the young of the flocke, and of the herd, &c. and then, their soules shall be as a watered garden; though their hearts were naturally as a wildernesse, hee will make them as a garden, and though by nature they were dry, and voyd of any goodnesse, hee will so water them with the dew of his Grace, that they shall become sweete and fruitfull; and so hee runnes on thorow the whole Chapter. The like you may read, Ioel 2.24.25, 26, 27, 28, &c. The floores shall be full of wheate, and the fats shall ouerflow with wine and oyle: And I will restore to you the yeeres that the Locust hath eaten, &c. and yee shall eate in plenty, and be satisfied,
&c. And that done, It shall come to passe, that I will powre out my Spirit vpon all flesh, and your sonnes and your daughters shall prophecie, &c. And also vpon the seruants, and vpon the handmaids, in those daies will I powre out my Spirit, &c. The summe of all is set downe in that place, Psal. 84. the last vers. saue one. The Lord God is a Sunne and a shield, a Sun, to comfort his people, and a shield, to shelter them from euill. But what will he giue his people? the Lord, saith the Psalmist, will giue grace and glory. He will not onely giue them temporall things (as it followes there, No good thing will hee with-hold from them that walke vprightly) but hee will also bestow vpon them grace here, and glory hereafter, euen that grace that shall once be glory. Hence is it, that the Apostle concludes the point, that godlinesse is profitable to all things, hauing the promises of both liues, of temporall things for this life, and of spirituall and eternall things, for the life to come. This is Gods promise for it.

Next, in his couenant, he vndertakes it: And this is more then barely to make promise of it: For, a couenant is a bundle of promises, solemnely ratified with some seale, some solemnety and obligation. This you see here in the Text, as we haue shewed, and so likewise you may see it in the 36 of this Prophecy where the Lord strikes a couenant with his people, and first to free from al euil, both that which is painfull, and that which is sinfull: Secondly, to furnish them with a double good. 1. Temporall, as that he will multiply the fruite of the trees, and the increase of the field, that he will
call for the corne, &c. 2. Spirituall, for he will powre cleane water vpon them, and clense them from all their filthinesses, and all their Idolls; A new heart also wil he giue them, &c. he wil iustifie them and sanctifie them, and by putting his spirit into them, cause them to keep his iudgemēts, and doe them: Accordingly, also, hereunto hee hath sorted out the seales of his coueuant, both in the old and new Testament. For Circumcision sealed vp grace, as the Apostle saith of it, that it was a seale of the righteousnesse by faith, and that it sealed vp spirituall blessings,Rom. 4. appeares by that place in Deuteronomy, where the Lord saith,Deut 30. I will circumcise the fore-skinne of their hearts, and they shall keepe my commandements, &c.

So for the paschall (that other standing Sacrament of the old Church) was to them a type of Christ, (as the Apostle applies it, 1 Cor. 5. For euen Christ our passeouer was slaine for vs) sealing vp Christ vnto them, and with him all good things spirituall. And so it is in our two Sacraments answerable to these former: the washing with water in baptisme, seales vp the inward baptisme, acccording to that, He shall baptise you with the holy Ghost and with fire; it seales vp remission of sinnes, Act. 2. be baptized, saith St. Peter, there, euery one of you, in the name of Iesus Christ, for the remission of sinnes: it seales vp repentance, for which cause also it is called, the baptisme of repentance. The like wee may say also of the Lords Supper (that other seale of Gods couenant) The cup of blessing which we blesse (saith the Apostle) is it not
the Communion of the blood of Christ? the bread, which we breake, is it not the Communion of the Body of Christ? 1 Cor. 10. And therefore the bread is called the very Body of Christ, and the wine his blood, because they do truly conueigh Christ vnto vs, that as verily as wee receiue the Bread and wine in that Sacrament, we partake of the Body and Blood of the Lord Ch • ist to eternall life: Thus God vndertakes the businesse, and thus he seales it.

Lastly, he sweares it too, you haue his oath for it, in that first of Luk. vers. 73. To performe the oath which he sware to our Father Abraham, that he would grant vnto vs, that we being deliuered from the hands of our enemies, might receiue grace to serue him without feare, in righteousnesse and holinesse before him all the dayes of our life: So Esay 54.9. for this is as the waters of Noah vnto me: for as I haue sworne that the waters of Noah should no more goe ouer the earth: so haue I sworne that I would not be wroth with thee, nor rebuke thee, &c. An • this the Apostle makes vse of and presses further, Heb. 16. God (saith he) willing more abundantly to shew vnto the heyers of promise, the immutability of his counsell, confirmed it by an oath: that by two immutable things, wherein it was impossible for God to lye, we might haue strong consolation. Thus you see wha • assurance and encouragment God giues his people for spirituall things, he hath said it,2. Promised. he hath sealed it, he hath sworne it, &c: and therefore ye may beleeue it.
Quest. But what performance now?

Answ. In all ages God hath performed it to his people: Dauid prayed for a new heart, Create in mee a
cleane heart, O God, and renew a right Spirit within me; and accordingly he had it: Salomon praied for wisedome, and God gaue him a heart large as the sands on the sea-shore: so in the new Testament, the Apostles prayed, Lord increase our Faith, and it was increased vnto them▪ they call for boldnesse and courage to speake Gods Word, and the text saith, they were all filled with the holy Ghost, and spake the Word of God with boldnesse. The like we may say of all other the Lords seruants.

Now if you enquire for a reason of this dealing of God with his people, it is not in man, Ezek. 36. Thus saith the Lord God, I doe not this for your sakes, O house of Israel, but for mine own holy names sake, &c. Man is neither a working nor mouing cause of any good thing spirituall, bestowed vpon himselfe. 1. Not a working cause, for in spirituall things, it fareth with him much what as with a child newborn into the world, which being naked of it selfe, cannot doe any thing toward its owne couering, he cannot prouide himselfe of clothes, offer them to him he cannot take them; he cannot put them on or make vse of them: In like sort man comes into the world, naked of grace, and all spirituall goodnesse, neither can hee doe any thing at all, wherby to helpe himselfe to it: and when he hath it bestowed vpon him, he cannot manage it, hee cannot weild it, further than God giues direction and assistance. Neither 2 is there any thing in man to moue him therunto, there is only misery in man to moue God to shew him mercy, but for any other thing man concurres to his owne spirituall
good, but onely as a subiect, on whom God bestowes it, and in whom he works it, he is an occasion indeed, but no cause of his owne saluation: that like as that Romane answered him, that bragged, that hee could neuer haue conquered such a countrey, but for him: true said the other, if thou hadst neuer lost it, I had neuer wonne it: So here, had not man fallen from grace and state of innocency, God had neuer sent his Sonne to redeeme him. If he had not lost himselfe, Christ had neuer come to find and restore him. But if you will know the true cause hereof, you must deriue it from God himselfe, it is founded vpon his nature.

For first, he is the God of all grace, and fountaine of all goodnesse, it is no burden to him, no charge, no paines to giue grace, no more then it is for a fountaine to send forth water, he doeth it as naturally as the Sun giues light: for he is naturally good, yea, he is goodnesse it selfe, and that, you know, is communicatiue. Thou art good (saith Dauid) and doest good. Psal. 119. of his goodnes he liberally bestoweth good things vpon his people, especially spirituall good things, you see how large he is in the promise of temporals, but hee had rather be dealing (as I may so say) in spirituals. 1. because they best please him and comply with his blessed nature. 2. because they be best for vs, and will doe vs most good. 3. because his praise is more set forth in the giuing of grace than of goods, they most commend his goodnesse and studie his praise. If you that are euill (saith our
Sauior) can giue good things to your children, how much more will your heauenly Father giue his holy Spirit to them that aske it? he loues to be bestowing his spirit rather than meaner things, where he loues most.

Secondly, as he is good, so he is gracious too: that is, he works grace in vs of himselfe, without any merit or desert on our behalfe. He is the giuer of all Grace: Now he that bestowes grace, must doe it out of grace, else it is no grace. It is his grace meerely that workes any good thing in vs, grace that procures it, grace that continues it.

Lastly, he is a mighty God, able to subdue our iniquities vnto vs, able to cast out and dispossesse the strong man Satan, that roomth may be made for his spirit to seaze vpon vs, and inhabite vs. But we are the briefer here, because it is a plaine point, and needes not any large proofe: wee will hasten therefore to the application, which is the life of teaching. And so wee haue three seuerall inferences to make of this point.

And the first we addresse to those that haue not Vse. 1 yet made their choyce, haue not resolued where to place themselues, or what Master to pitch vpon, and to these let mee commend a most excellent seruice, euen the seruice of God, the best Master. You see what hee vndertakes here to doe for all that are his, and that is a mercy you must think, that so great a God should vouchsafe to vndertake and become bound to vs wretched and worthlesse creatures▪ Fathers, you know, seldome frame indentures, thereby to binde themselues what they will doe for their children, if they will be obedient,
but by right of father-hood, they challenge of them their best seruice. Lords seldome indent with their slaues for their seruice and attendance, but command it by the right they haue in them, eyther by conquest or purchase, or some other Title: And yet we see God, our Lord and Master, is content to vndertake, and indent with vs, what good hee will bestow vpon vs, if we will but bind our selues to him in obedience, he is willing to enter into bonds for our better security, to take vs, as it were, in a league of peace and of warre, offensiue and defensiue, &c. and so to enter into a kinde of familiarity with the sonnes of men: For, so you know there must be a familiarity in some degree, where contracts are made betweene any. Neyther so only doth he offer to enter into bonds, but into such bonds, as better cannot be demanded, had you to doe with the veriest sharker, or shifting fellow in a countrey. For, what can you require more possibly then hee will giue for your security? woud you haue his promise? you haue it in blacke and white; would you haue his couenant? Behold, heere it is for you; would you haue his seale, his oath, his pawne? God giues you all. Here is grace from him, and an honour to the creature, Men in matters of gratuity, will not be drawne to indent, nay, they will take it very ill in such a case, if bonds be required of them. If you will stand to their courtesie, or trust to their gentlelenesse, somthing it may be they will do, yet withall you must waite their pleasure, if not, you may chuse, they will not be bound to any thing.
But now God vndertakes by couenant, as you see, and giues such security to the creature, as he cannot tell how to demand greater.
But what is the wages hee thus vndertakes to giue those that serue him? Quest.

Exceeding great euery way: Answ. Among men the most that is vsually giuen, is meat, drinke and wages: meat, drinke and wages, this euery one will offer, it may be some will goe further, you shall haue a liuery besides, yea, some will promise their seruants besides all this, some promotion, or protection: some immunity or commodious office, it may be. But what is all this to Gods wages? He giues all this that any other Master giues, and much more: Nay, what indeed can any Master giue his seruant, if God doe not first giue it to the Master? But behold, hee doth more then all this comes to: For, hee shewes mercy to a thousand generations, of them that feare him and keepe his commandements. He maintaines not onely such as serue him, but all their houshold, yea, and all their posterity too: He bestowes vpon them temporall blessings, in another manner then man can giues them not onely food, but a stomack to it, not onely clothes, but a body to weare them, &c. He prouides for their outward estates, their good names, &c. And that which is the maine, he prouides for the soule that is mortall, immortall comforts, he giues himselfe, his flesh for meat, and his blood for drinke, and my flesh is bread indeed, (saith our Sauiour) and my blood is drinke indeed, Iohn 6. Nay, lest any man should doubt of the point, he will be his wages,
as he tells Abraham. Walke before me in vprightnesse, and then I will be thine exceeding great reward, Gen. 15. Nay, for a liuery he will giue vs his owne Image, which consisteth in righteousnesse and true holinesse, and for wages, his heauenly kingdome: For, euery seruant of his, God makes a sonne, and euery sonne an heyre, and euery heyre of God, is a coheyre with Christ, Rom. 8. the same substantiall (though not graduall) glory, the same crowne, the same kingdome, that the Lord Christ hath, he shall haue, he shall enter into his masters ioy, &c.
Obiect. Yet wee see many fall short of this large pay, who yet professe themselues to be, the seruants of God, for none commonly meet with more sorrows and troubles, haue more wants, &c.

Solu.And why is that? for the most part it is thorow their owne default, and because they are wanting to themselues, by being slack and short in Gods Seruice, whereas, if they would mend their paines, God would mend their pay, if they would alter their pace, he would alter their wages. Besides, the Lord in bestowing these outward things, hath still reference to the soules of his people, and giues other things; so as they will best comply with the happinesse of the creature: and hence it is, that hee sometimes abridgeth his seruants of outward things, for the perfecting of their better part, the soule, and the furtherance of their saluation. But otherwise, if they were but capable of these outward comforts, they should not long goe without them, according to that in the Psalme; Oh if my people would haue hearkned, if they would
haue keept my statutes, &c: how would I haue fed them with the fat of wheate, &c; as if he should say, they should not then haue wanted for any thing, either for soule or body.

Besides, you must know that in Gods regiment, in Gods house, there be diuers stations, diuers offices, and accordingly different estates and allowances. Now it is required of euery seruant, that he keepe to his owne place and station, that he doe his owne worke, and that he expect wages answerable and proportionable to his place and office. And as in the body where be many members, as euery member hath its proper vse and function, so his wages thereafter; there must be a foot, aswel as either hand or head, & for the foot, a shooe of leather is as fit, as suitable, as seruiceable, and doth euery whit as well become it, as a hat of beuer doth the head.

A suite of frize or of leather becomes some men, as well as a suite of silke or veluet doth some other; it will keepe him as warme, and doe him as good seruice, and a good credit too, as the other doth a man of greater place and estate▪ so here for men of meaner parts and abilities in the Church, an estate suitable doth best, &c: in which regard, God may and oft times doth keepe some of his people short: whereas, if they were fit in regard o • their affection and place, and when hee shall find t • em capable, they shall haue them, and in the meane time, no good thing fit for them in their station shall be kept away from them.
Oh but then sure, sith Gods wages is so good, Obiect. his worke is hard.

Answ. So many thinke indeed, that if they should giue thēselues vp to Gods seruice, they should haue but an vncomfortable and hard time of it, they should neuer see merry day more, they must bid adieu to all their comforts, and spend their time in heauines and horrour. But there is no such matter, I assure you; men are worse afraid then hurt, that conceiue thus hardly of the good wayes of God, whose wayes are wayes of pleasantnesse, and all his pathes peace. But admit it were so as these imagine, that Gods worke were hard, if his wages be answerable, a man would not refuse to vndertake it. But secondly, learne to iudge of things as they be; God is no tyrant, but an excellent Gouernour, all his commands are reasonable, and his yoke is far easier then the yoke of Satan, his work is more faire, easie, honourable. As that excellent Greek Father saith; Is not loue a lighter burden than hatred, patience than passion, &c? Is it not farre easier to be moderate than gluttonous, sober than riotous, &c? Beleeue it, grace is an easier burden than sinne: and the work of God seemes hard and difficult onely because of our corruption that cannot so well frame to it: But otherwise, were wee as we should be, there would bee no such difficulty to vs in the wayes of God.
Obiect. Yea, but we finde them difficult and vnpleasant.

Sol.This comes to passe by reason of corruption that clogge vs, which the Lord will by degrees take away, and heale vs of all our rebellious wils, where all the businesse sticks. And then for good, he will put new principles into you, new hearts,
new insides, and so though the taske of goodnesse be too hard for you of your selues, yet vndertaking it in Gods strength, you shall find Christs yoake to be easie and comfortable.

Now therefore, sith Gods wages is so great, and and his worke so easie, be content, I pray you, to haue a good Master, to accept of a good seruice, &c. Euery man must fall to one Master or other, God on the one side, o • the Diuell on the other: one of these Masters you must needs serue. Make a wise choice therefore. 1. For your selues. 2. For yours. First, binde your selues to God to become his seruants.
How should wee binde our selues vnto him? Quest.

Enter into couenant with him, to be his alone. Answ. This is a great businesse, as Iosuah tells the people, when they said, Wee will serue the Lord, for hee is our God: Yee cannot serue the Lord, saith hee, &c. Iosh. 24.

This hee said not to discourage them, but to teach both them and you, that if you will be Gods seruants, you must disdaine all other Masters, and willingly subiect your wits, your wills, your consciences, your estates, your liberties, your liues to God, renouncing all other Masters, you must hold you close to him. Now therefore, haue but one chiefe Master, euen God, pitch vpon him, and resolue to serue him alone i • holinesse and righteousnesse, as hee speakes, all the dayes of your liues. Thus for your selues.

Next, for your people, and those about you, say as Iosuah: I and my house will serue the Lord,
you cannot picke out a better Master any where, eyther for your selues, or for your children. Euery man desires to preferre his child to a good match, or to helpe him to a good seruice, where hee may haue faire and kinde vsage, square dealing, where hee may haue euery thing enough, and be put to no drudgery, &c. Behold, God is the best master, hee giues the best wages, findes the best worke, shewes best acceptance of what wee doe, he takes well, at our hands, that poore seruice that none else would accept of, hee giues also the best assistance, for he neuer sets any on worke, but he giues strength to doe it, yea, he puts his owne hand to the businesse. Therefore bee aduised to preferre your children to his seruice; you pray ouer them daily, God make you his seruants, God make you his seruants; therefore helpe to make them Gods seruants, by giuing them instructions, corrections, good example, &c. And when God offers to enter into couenant with you and yours, make vse of his offer, lay hold on the hint, as Benhadads seruants did, when the King of Israel said, Is my brother Benhadad yet aliue? they diligently obserued, and hastily catcht it, and said, Thy brother Benhadad: So when God saith, I will be thy God, and you shall be my people, make answer streight vpon it, I am thy seruant, Lord, I am thy seruant; be glad of any such motion, and readily lay hold on it, as Dauid, when the Lord promised him to build him a house, and to be a Father to his posterity, hee went into the house of God, and sate before him, thankfully embracing so kinde an offer: so let vs
doe this for our selues and ours. Vse. 3

A second vse we haue of this point to those that haue already giuen vp their names to God, haue taken his wages, doe weare his liuery, and dwell in his house, let these be exhorted neuer to grow weary of such a Master, bur to cleaue fast vnto him, and to serue him constantly, cheerfully, boldly, thorowly.

First, you must serue the Lord constantly: he is constant to you, and why should you not be as constant to him? who gaines by the seruice you doe to him, he or you? All the commodity and benefit thereof is onely your; hauing therefore the better end of the staffe, hold him fast to his bargaine. Remember that you serue the Lord on a couenant, and for terme of life: sticke close to him therefore without starting. Hee is not any way in need of you, hee neuer did you harme, resolue therefore as Polycarp, Fourescore and six yeeres (said hee, when hee was soliciced to renounce Christ and the truth) Haue I serued my Master, Christ, and he neuer in all this space did me the least harme, and should I now forsake him? I will neuer doe it: So doe you resolue to cleaue to the Lord, with full purpose of heart in an euerlasting couenant, a couenant of salt. If you were to beginne the world againe, where could make a better choyce, where could you light vpon a better Maste • , therefore loue him still, depend vpon him still, seeke him still, obey him still, doe whatsoeuer may please him, forbeare whatsoeuer may offend him, and this for euer, not being weary of well-doing,
hee is constant to you in loue and blessing, by you also to him in seruiceablnesse and obedience.

Secondly, learne to serue the Lord eheerefully, as well as constantly. He loues a cheerefull seruer, aswell as a cheerefull giuer in the matter of almes, and requires to be serued with delight and willingnesse: Hee deserues it certainely, for he giues the best wages, the best imployment, and the best encouragement, as you haue heard before. That which our owne hearts cannot thinke well, that which other men would pish at, and set light by, God will graciously accept, and bountifully reward. Now therefore, if the Apostle would haue seruants which receiue but a pound or two of wages, to goe so cheerefully about his Masters businesse, With good will doing seruice as to the Lord, and not as to men, Ephes. 6. how much more should wee to God, knowing that whatsoeuer good thing any man doth, hec shall receiue the same of the Lord, &c. Let mee speake to you therefore in the words of Dauid, to his sonne Salomon, being now on his death-bed. 1 Chron. 28.9. And thou, my sonne Salomon, know thou the God of thy fathers, and serue him with a perfect heart, and with a willing minde, &c.

Thirdly, serue the Lord boldly, valiantly: the Lord loues such as are couragious in his seruice, as on the otherside he curses those that are timorous, and fearefull, excluding them out 〈◊〉 heauen, Reu. 21. (for without are the fearefull, &c) when his people are bold in his worke, they giue him the •… lory of his power, &c. Therefore is it that he calls vpon vs so oft for courage, in the Prophets. Feare
not for I am with thee, be not dismaide, for I am thy God, I will strengthen thee, yea, I will vphold thee with the right hand of my righteousnesse, Esay 41.10. And againe, ver. 13. I the Lord thy God, will hold thy right hand, saying vnto thee, Feare not: and vers. 14. Feare not thou worme Iacob, and ye men of Israel, I will helpe thee, &c. God would haue all his people valiant. In case of danger therefore for Gods cause, say as the three children did to the King of Babel, We are not carefull to answer thee in this matter. If it be so, our God whom wee serue, is able to serue vs, he can if he will, and he will deliuer vs if it be good for vs, but if not, be it knowne vnto thee, O king, that wee will not serue thy Gods, &c. Learne to be of Dauids resolution, Psal. 119.46. I will speake of thy testimonies also before Kings, and will not be ashamed. Asham'd? why should he be ashamed? God is not a Master to be ashamed of. Let sinners blush, but let the seruants of God hold vp their heads, and beare themselues bold vpon his protection, so long as they mannage Gods businesse with Gods wisedome, with Gods m • ekenesse, &c. God is not ashamed of them, why then should they be ashamed of God.

Lastly, you must doe Gods worke throughly, sith he payes vs home, giues large wages, bestowes vpon vs all things necessary to life and godlinesse, blesseth vs with all temporall and spirituall blessings in heauenly places, all comforts for this life, and the next; he blesseth his people, both in soule and body, for the inside and outside too, he will mend all that is amisse with vs. Now therefore, serue him at all times, in all companies, in euery
duty of religion, and in all conditions of life whatsoeuer. God is a thorow master, therefore do him thorow Seruice.

Vse. 3 Encouragement and Comfort to all Gods poore seruants, that grone vnder the burden of their many wants and weakenesses, that are troubled with so many corruptions and such naughty hearts as they cannot tell what to doe by them, or to whom to turne themselues for helpe and cure: To these I bring good newes, glad tydings, there is a Physician found that will vndertake the cure, and will goe through with it. If thou canst but make good, that thou art within the Couenant, thou maiest goe boldly to God, and beg any thing of him thou standst in need of for thine inward estate. It is no more but call for what thou wantest, and it shall be giuen you: Temporall things indeed you must seeke and aske of God with reseruation, if God see it good for you, &c: but for spiritual mercies you may aske them absolutely. And like as a houshold seruant that is in couenant with his master, comes in from his work and calles for his dinner, and againe calles for his supper: when his time is out, he challengeth his wages; when he wants help, he comes in and asketh for it, yea, if other helpe be not by, he comes with pray you master lend me your hand: so may we as many as are in Couenant with God, goe to him in like manner Lord I want Faith, giue me it; I want patience, let me haue it: I finde my heart naught, and all out of order, ioynt it, mend it, &c. Thus we may safely doe, and thus Dauid did, as we
read in places of the Psalmes: Vnite my heart (saith he) to thy feare, &c: as if he should say, Lord, thou hast promised to giue me one heart; behold, I finde my heart diuided, disioynted, &c, vnite it I beseech thee: So, Be surety, Lord, for thy seruant, for good &c. As if he should say, thou hast vndertaken to cause me to keepe thy Commandements: remember thy Couenant, and cause me to goe through with thy worke. Againe, Giue vnderstanding to thy Seruant, according to thy Word. As if hee had said, thou art in couenant with me, and therfore performe thy bargaine; as thou hast allotted me work, so thou must finde me tooles wherewithall to worke: so may we goe vnto God with like words in our mouthes. Lord, giue me wisdome, giue me faith, giue me patience for the discharge of my my duty toward thee: it is a flat bargaine betwixt vs, therefore stand to it.

Secondly, as you may boldly aske spirituall things from God, so you may confidently expect them, promising your selues whatsoeuer God promiseth; for all the promises of God are yea and Amen in Christ, not onely yea, but yea and Amen, not onely firme and faithfull in themselues, but such as shall be made good to the soules of Gods people in full perfection. Hath God then promised thee pardon of sinne, sanctification, the feare of his name, faith, patience? Doe thou promise thy selfe all these things, and bee confident thou shalt receiue them, claime them at Gods hands, rest vpon him for them and thinke no otherwise, but that it will bee accomplished; faithfull is hee
who hath called you, who also will doe it. See this in Dauid, God hath spoken in his holinesse, I will reioyce therefore in his Word: I will diuide Shechem and mete out the valley of Succoth. Gilead is mine, Manasses also is mine. Ephraim also is the strength of my head: Iudah is my Law-giuer, Moab is my washpot, &c. Psal. 60.6, 7. As if he had said, Though yet I haue little enough, yet I am confident I shall haue all this, yea, it is mine already because I haue Gods Word for it, therfore it is sure enough, God saies they are mine, and I will say so too, so long as I haue gods hand to shew for it.

Obiect. Neither must you onely expect good things at Gods hand, but you must waite for them too. Many a poore Christian is much cast down at this, he hath praied, he hath sought, he hath wept, he hath done whatsoeuer hee could for the subduing of such a corruption, or for the obtaining of such a spirituall grace, and all to no purpose, he seeth it will not be.

Sol.Oh say not so, man, giue not God the lye: thou hast the promise of God, thou hast his Couenant, his seale, his oath for it, and therefore be not vnbeleeuing, Obiect. but beleeue and wait. What encouragement, what heart can I haue to wait, when I haue laboured it thus long, and nothing comes, I finde no amendment?

Sol.Vnderstand that God doth those things hee vndertakes, orderly: when he doth a cure, hee beginnes at the bottome, and so heales it vpward, and this must haue time. Besides, his cures are inuisible: it fareth here as in curing a wound in the
body, a man seeth himselfe cured, but how and when it healeth, he sees not. The Kingdome of heauen commeth not by obseruation, saith our Sauiour, but is like to a little seed cast into the ground, which that it is growne, wee well perceiue, but how or when it grew, we know not: so here, The Lord is slow in his works, but sure, sure but slow, that grace which at first was but a sparke, or as smoking flax (as our Sauiour saith) becomes afterwards a great flame a shining lamp, the broken reed a strong pillar. If a man sow or set a small kernell, he will not looke for a great tree of it presently: no more must wee for a great measure of grace, God will doe it, but you must giue him time, and leaue him still to his owne time. He seeth it fit, we should beginne with a little at once, the time will come, when he will perfect all. God will sooner or later cure all the bodily diseases and infirmities of his people, either in this life, or at death, or at the resurrection: and so hee will their corruptions also; in the meane space bee content to wait his leasure. Psal. 130. Let Israel wait on the Lord, &c. And he will redeeme Israel from all his iniquities.
Yea, Obiect. but how can I wait and looke for mercy from the Lord, when things goe backward with me, and I grow worse and worse.Solu.

The question is, whether it bee thus with thee in sense or in deed, thou maiest iudge thus of thy selfe, and yet bee out in thy iudgement. For the better any one is in deed, the worse hee is in his owne sense and esteeme: Euer the more life any
one hath, the more sense he hath, and so the more sensible hee is of his owne wants and corruptions. It doth not follow therefore, that thou art more sinnefull because thou feelest thy sinnes more, but the contrary; as no man is therefore the further off from healing, because he begins to feele his sicknesse; or a wound not likely to heale, because it smarts. Is corruption now become a greater burthen to thee then formerly? Dost thou hate it more? hast a worse opinion of it then thou hast had? dost thou prize grace more then euer, and thirst after it? then it is sure thou art on the mending hand.
Quest. But how shall I know that I am within the couenant? that I am one of those whom God hath vndertaken to cure, and to bestow vpon them these spirituall blessings?

Answr. For this, thou must looke to two things. First, see what God hath done for thee. Secondly, what thou hast done for him againe: For, something there is to be done on both sides you, know, in euery couenant.
