For the first, looke whether God hath giuen thee this one heart here promised, this new spirit, this heart of flesh insteed of thine old heart, thy heart of stone? See what affections he hath renewed in thee? hath he put his loues, his fear into thy inward parts? hath he written his lawes in thy heart? hath he giuen thee a new nature? art thou become another man then thou wast, cast into a new mould? hast thou new thoughts, new desires, new designes to set vp God alone in the making of thine own
saluation, &c? Then thou art of those with whom God is in couenant. Againe, secondly, see what thou lost for God, for thou must be working, all that are in couenant with him, according to that we read, Ezeck. 36. (I trow) after that the Lord had promised what he would doe for them, Yet I will be sought vnto for all these things, saith the Lord. Search then what thou hast done in Gods worke, doest thou warre against the flesh? subiect thy wit to Gods wisdome, thy will to Gods will, &c. Hauing such promises as these, dost thou (as the Apostle exhorteth) Cleanse thy selfe from all filthinesse of flesh and spirit, perfecting holinesse in the feare of God? 2 Cor. 7.1. then it is sure that God hath smitten a couenant with thee, and it shall be performed vnto thee.
Oh! but what is it be so, Obiect. that I haue broken my part of the couenant, and so haue giuen God liberty to euade? how then?

You must know,S • l. that God taketh not the aduantage against vs of euery petty breach, vnlesse it be some great matter, he hateth putting away, as he saith in Mal. It is between God and vs, as between husband and wife. It is not euery petty discontent or displeasure that falls out betweene them that is held a sufficient cause of separation, it must be some great offences, as the defiling of the marriage-bed, which (in regard of merit) cuts the very marriage-knot asunder, so here: The Lord will not aggrauate euery frailty, infirmity or slip of his seruants, to cast them off for the same, it must be some great breach of Couenant, as when we runne a whoring from vnder him, after lying vanities,
or when we are carried with harlot-like affections towards him, in setting more by his gifts, then by himselfe, this is that which will prouoke and cause him to withdraw. But if you pitch vpon God for the maine, though you haue many failings (as in many things wee offend all) if you can say with Dauid, Whom haue I in heauen but thee, and in earth none in comparison of thee? wee shall not be discarded. God is not as man, to doe as he doth. Men, when a seruant is grown old, and they haue had the best of him, they vsually thinke of putting him off, turning him out of the house, shifting their hand of him, when hee is once growne old and impotent, that his worke is done: Not so God, the elder a seruant is, the berter he likes him, the longer they liue together, the lother hee is to part with him.
Obiect. Yea, but yet hee requires certaine conditions of vs, that be in couenant with him, which we performe not, &c.

Sol.Yea, but in the new Couenant, God vndertakes to make vs able to performe the conditions that hee requires. Hee vndertaketh both for himselfe and vs too. Hee commands vs to haue a new, soft, one heart, and he maketh it so.
Quest. Is there nothing then to be done on our behalfe?

Answ. Yes, it is required of vs, that wee vse Gods meanes, that wee goe on in his wayes, according to that, Yet I will be sought vnto for these things by the house of Israel, Ezech. 36. When he acts vs, wee must moue; when he opens our eyes, we must see; in fine, concurre as subiects, to be wrought vpon
in his meanes and times, and then we are surely, in Couenant with God, and so in happy estate: For, Blessed is the people whose God is the Lord: Such need not want any thing of all that is within the verge of this couenant, they may call for what they will, and haue it: God hath promised you all good things, outward and inward, call for them, and they shall bee giuen you. Is any thing amisse with you? carry it to God, and say, Lord, here is thine owne Couenant, to mend my heart, &c: Oh doe it for thy names sake. And so you may be confident: for doe you thinke God is able? doe you thinke he is willing? doe you thinke hee will lye? doe ye thinke hee will foresweare himselfe? I conclude with the Apostle: In nothing therefore be carefull, but in all things make your requests knowne to God, and he will fulfill them, and fill you with peace vnconceiueable.

IN this part of the Couenant the Lord vndertakes for the spirituall part of his Church, namely, that he wil giue them, whatsoeuer grace shall be needfull, as is here set forth by all the causes thereof (as we haue hertofore shewed you) both inward and outward. For the first, wee haue heere 1 the matter deliuered in these tearmes, one heart, a new heart, a soft heart. 2. the manner, he will put it into them, he will bestow it vpon them, he will take out that which hinders, and put in that, that is wanting. These are the inward causes, and for the outward,
the Efficient first, that is God. I will giue them one heart and I will put, &c. Secondly, the finall cause is set downe vers. 20. That they may walke in my statutes, and keepe mine ordinances, &c.

Wee haue already obserued something from the words in generall: Ye haue heard what mans inside is in and of him selfe; his heart is full of turnings and diuisions, till God make it one: his heart is old and corrupt, till God refine it; and cast it into a new mould: Lastly, is hard as a stone, till the Lord is pleased to mollifie, and make it soft: Next, you haue heard, how farre God ingageth himselfe to his people for things spirituall, he hath vndertaken to furnish them with grace as well as with goods; and that not by a single promise onely, but by a solemne sealed couenant, and hath bound all this with an oath. So that here is the comfort of euery Christian, when he findeth ought amisse in his soule, he hath to goe to God, and claime the fulfilling of his promises, the performance of his Couenant.

These generals already dispactht, we come now to the words themselues, and we will beginne with the inward causes of mans Spirituall good, and first with that we called the materiall cause, sc. one heart, a new spirit, an heart of flesh.

Heart and spirit are put for the same thing, they doe but one expound the other. Man is made vp (you know) of two essentiall parts, a body and a soule, which soule vpon sundry occasions hath sundry and seuerall names giuen vnto it. In respect of the cause it is called a spirit: In respect of
its seat, it is called the heart: in respect of its naturall operation it is called the soule, and in respect of its spirituall office it is called conscience, all comes much what to one passe: Now touching this heart or spirit or soule or inside, tearme it as you please. He promiseth his people to bestow on them a threefold grace. 1. Onenesse (giue me leaue so to speake vnto you, because I haue not a fitter word at hand, whereby to expresse it) I will giue them one heart: 2. Newnesse. I will put a new spirit within them. 3. Tendernesse. I will take the stony heart out of their flesh, and giue them an heart of flesh. The thing it selfe is cleare, there is one thing onely in question touching the order, whether these three things here promised be so many seuerall steps to softnesse, or whether they bee so many steps to onenesse of heart. If w • take them this latter way, the sense is good, and stands handsomely, as thus. I will giue you one heart, and that I so doe, I will cast it a new, and that I may so doe I will melt and soften it like as one that hauing many pieces of old siluer or plate lying by him which he intends to put all into one bowle. 1. he resolues to cast it a new. 2. to that end he melts and softens it, and so lastly shuts vp all in one piece. If we take the words thus, they goe well enough; yet I encline rather to the other side, and doe iudge rather that they are three seuerall graces that are here promised and Secondly that softens, includes the rest, as if the Lord should haue said, I will make you one heart, nay more, I will make you a new heart; nay (which is more then all
that) I will make you a soft heart, a heart of flesh instead of your heart of stone. And thus I should rather chuse to take the words. 1. because they lye thus in the text. 2. because God begins to cure mans hart, in the same order that it became distempered. Man in his state of Integrity had but one heart, set wholly vpon God its proper obiect. But by his fall from God, this one heart becam. 1. a diuided hart, and 2. a corrupt heart (which state of corruption, the Scripture vseth to set forth by the name of the old man) 3. by long trading in its corrupt and sinfull courses it contracts a great hardnesse, and so becomes a stony heart. The selfe-same order God obserues in the curing of it: for 1. hee makes it to become one heart. 2. hee makes it a new heart. 3. he makes and keepes it a soft heart.

Thirdly, there is some little difference to be obserued in these tearmes, and although in some sense they are neuer separated, but euery new heart is one heart, and also a soft heart in som degree, yet are the things separable in our vnderstandings: for a man may haue some kind of one hart, that is an heart pitcht vpon one only obiect, and yet not haue a new heart: as againe, a man may haue a new heart, and yet his new heart may not be soft, but hard and crusty. So that for these 3 reasons I make choice to keepe Gods order in the text, and make them three distinct graces, yet so, as that I will not contend with any one that likes the former sense better.

The first thing then, we are here to treate of, is this onenesse of heart. I will giue them one heart
(so the words are read in the Originall) not, I will giue them another heart, as the Septuagint render it, by a mistake of one letter in the Hebrew. There is (if we will speake exactly) some little difference betweene samenesse and simplenesse, singlenesse and onenesse. Samenesse excludeth all distinction: simplenesse excludes all manner of composition: singlenesse excludes all doubling; and onenesse excludes diuision. But God vseth not to be so metaphysical in his writing, therefore hee that shall say, that one heart is a single heart, an entire heart, a simple, plaine, sincere heart, he sayes not much amisse, though that bee not home enough. The point that we commend vnto you from the words, is this: That all those that are in speciall Couenant with God, haue but one heart. Doctr. 3

This onensse of heart hath a double relation. 1, to God. 2. to men. First, all that haue interest in the Couenant of grace, doe meete and concurre in one obiect, viz. in God as their onely both materiall and formall obiect (as we vse to speake) according to that of the Apostle, though there be gods many, and lords many, yet to vs there is but one God, the Father, of whom are all things and wee in him, and one Lord Iesus Christ by whom are all things, and we by him, 1 Cor. 8.6.Christians are one hearted, as they refer to God, and to themselues next. All Gods people pitch vpon him, they iump and agree in the true God, who makes himselfe to vs, in and by his onely Sonne esus Christ, according to that in the last of Zachary, when the Iewes and Gentiles should bee made one by the comming of Christ. In that day,
saith the Prophet, when the Lord shall bee King ouer all the earth, there shall be one Lord, and his name shall be One.

2. As they are all pitcht vpon one Obiect; so they goe all vpon one motiue, they chuse God for Gods sake,Psalm. 24. as saith the Psalmist: This is the generation of them that seeke him, that seeke thy face, this is Iacob: as if hee should say; All that are the true Sonnes of Iacob, that are Israel indeed, they ayme not so much at Gods wealth, and at Gods wages, as at Gods selfe; all that they seek, is to see his face and to haue his fauour. Thus as they referr • to God, they are one.

Secondly in relation to men, Gods people • aue but one heart, whether you consider them iointly or seuerally. If you take them together, the whole Church is all but one body, one spouse, one house, Christ being the head, the husband, the chiefe corner-stone. First, they are all one in iudgement, they concurre at least in the maine, they meet in all fundamentall and generall principles, howsoeuer when it comes to particular inferences and conclusions, there appeares some difference. In matters substantiall they are all of one mind, they iudge the same thing, though they may be of sundry opinions in circumstantials, and points of lesse moment. Secondly▪ as they all agreee in iudgement, so doe they likewise in heart and affection, they pitch all vpon Christ, they haue the same ioyes, the same griefes, the same hopes, &c: in a word, they are like-affectioned one to the other: it faring with them, as with the members of the body,
wherefore if one suffer, the rest suffer also, such an vnity of affection is there among them; and that all vpon the same motiue too, for, as they are knit together in on spirit, so they proceed all by one rule, and worke all vpon the same ground; the thing that takes their affection, and drawes their eye, is grace, is truth, is goodnesse in the truth of it, as Saint Iohn speakes, 2 Epist. So secondly, if you take them seuerally and apart, euery particular Christian, as hee is but one man, so hath no more then one heart, you cannot say so of other men: For of them that are not in speciall couenant with God, one man may haue twenty hearts, according to the phrase of Scripture. But a true Christian hath no more hearts then he hath bodies: For, first, all the diuisions, all the turnings and windings of his heart, are healed by God, and he is now pitcht vpon one onely obiect: Secondly, hee is reconciled to himselfe, the parts and powers of his body and soule goe all one way, they goe together, and tend all to one marke; in a word, they are all made for God. So that euery true Christian goes but one way, so farre as hee is a Christian, as is to be seene in Dauid, Psal. 103.1. My soule, praise the Lord, saith he, And all that is within mee, praise his holy name. All that is within Dauid, shall goe this onely way: So it is also said of Iosiah, that hee serued God with all his heart, &c. All the powers of his soule met in one, and to their power went together, they were inde • de all too feeble, but they contributed their best.

Reas. Now this onenesse of heart proceeds not from the identity of the same subiect, (for some one man may haue a world of • earts, as hath bin said) but from the same causes wherein they concurre. For, they haue 1. all one father, God, which conueyes the same nature to them all. 2 One head, Christ, of whose influence they doe all partake. 3. One holy spirit, whereby they are acted: and as it is in the body, though there are many members, y • t are they all enliuened and acted by the same soule: so is the whole Church, and euery member thereof by the same spirit.

Againe, they walke all by one rule of the Word, they ayme all at one end, the glory of God in their owne saluation; they are tyed together all by the same ligaments, one faith, one hope, one loue, and all th • rest of the graces of the spirit, and hence it is, that they haue but one heart, one spirit.

Vse. 3 Is it so, that all in cou • nant with God haue but one heart? This then serues to discouer the misery and vnhappinesse of many thousands that liue in the bosome of the Church, and pretend faire to the Couenant of Grace, and yet they haue a heart, and a heart, and a heart, and a heart, and a heart, and a heart, yea, it may be they haue an hundred nd a thousand hearts in one and the same body. For the better vnderstanding whereof, we will insist awhile vpon these particulars: 1. To shew you what Onenesse is. 2. How many kindes of One there are: 3▪ the companions of it: and 4. The opposites. For the first of these; that is said to be One, that is, indiuisum a se, & diuisum ab
omni alio, vndiuided in it selfe, and diuided from euery thing else besides. In that then which is One, there is 1▪ greatest vnion with it selfe, and 2. greatest distance from all heterogenealls (as they talke) or things of another kind, and without it selfe. Thus God is perfectly one, without all composition, diuision and dependance, alteration, one essentially onenesse it selfe, in regard of his most simple nature, most agreeing with himsel • e, most distant from all things else, one intrinsecally in himselfe, and most remote from externalls.

1. For the second: There is 1. One: naturall, wh • reof wee say nothing now, so mans heart is one still. 2. One: morall, and so wee take it in this place, and in this consideration there be many hearts in one body, as on the other side, euery true Christian hath but one heart. This admits of two degrees: 1. perfect, and this is reserued for heauen, where our hearts shall goe all one way. 2. Imperfect in this life, when wee ayme at one marke, pitch vpon one obiect, &c. though wee haue our failings.

For the third thing propounded. the companions and consequents of vnion, are two. 1. Communion. 2. Separation. That which is one in it selfe, labours for communion with things like it selfe, as it separates, on the other side, from all things without, from all things that are not of the same kind. See this in those p • imitiue Christians, Acts 2. They which beleeued, were together, and had all things common but of the rest, durst no man ioyne himselfe vnto them.

Lastly, for the opposites of onenesse; They are these: 1. Vnresoluednesse, which is when a man wauereth in his minde, being not yet resolued which way to take, or what choyce to make. Thus Iames discribes him, A double minded man is vnstable in all his wayes, that is, he stands yet vnresolued, he is yet to chuse his religion, hee staggers, and wauers betweene two, not knowing to which to incline, but like a waue of the Sea, driuen with the winde, and tossed, hee is vp and downe, here and there, and knowes not how to hold any constant or settled course. Secondly, onenesse is opposed to hypocrisie and double dealing, to shewes, and appearances, to an heart and an heart. Thirdly, it is opposed to inconstancy and variablenesse. Thus, Galat. 3.20. God is said to be one, that is, one and the same, constant and vnchangeable like himselfe. Lastly, it is opposed to diuision and contention: as Acts 4.32. It is said, that the multitude of them that beleeued, were of one heart, and of one soule, &c. that is, there was perfect vnion and amity among them. So then, by all that hath beene said, you may plainely see what a one heart is. It is 1. a resolued heart. 2. A plaine heart, a single heart, when the inside and outside agree, such an heart as is no other in intentions, then it is in pretences. 3. A constant fixed heart. 4. Lastly, it is a quiet and peaceable heart Such a man as hath peace with God, and agreeth with himselfe, so as he goes all one way in Gods worship, this man may be truely said to haue one heart.

Here then are taxed all wauering and double-minded
persons. Wee will not trouble you with the Iesuites, but let them passe as men that surpasse in this kinde, hauing so many faces, so many names, so many habits, a latitude of euasions, they haue so many reseruations, so many equiuocations, so many distinctions, that in some one man of them yee may finde an hundred hearts, of whom you may say, as it was said of their father and his sonne, the one neuer spake as he thought, the other neuer thought as he spake; but let them passe. In the second place, here come such amongst vs to be censured, as are yet vnresolued in their courses, being yet to make choyce of their Religion, halting betweene God and Baal, betweene protestancy and popery; those that entertaine God and Mammon, God and Malcom too, that can speake the language, of Canaan, and of Ashdod both, that mingle and confound those things that God would haue seuered.

Thirdly, all such as are variable in their purpose, that shift, alter, and change their Religion, that are off and on, vp and downe; to day zealous, to morrow cold and backward. vnconstant, and vnstable in all their wayes. Whereunto may be added, how many can you tell, who are at open warre and defiance with God, and all that professe the Gospell of Christ.

The misery of all these kinde of persons appeares in this. 1. First, that they cannot assure themselues, that they are in speciall couenant with God: For the first thing that he giues to such is this one heart, he circumciseth the foreskinne of
their hearts, hee lops and shreds off all superfluiti • s, and vnites them wholly to himselfe, that they may henceforth goe all one way.

And secondly, in this, such persons must needs be restlesse and vnquiet: For it fareth with them no otherwise then with one that stands doubtfull between two suitors, not knowing which way to encline, and so for the time is restlesse, and as it were vpō the wrack: so here, for the hart of man is neuer at quiet, till it stay & rest it selfe vpon one center.
Thirdly, adde hereunto, that such men are euer liable to temptation, to defection, yea, and to detection too.

Lastly, they are liable to the wrath of God▪ for if any withdraw himselfe, or steale away, Heb. 10. My soule shall haue no pleasure in him, saith the Lord, nay, such as withdraw, they draw backe vnto perdition, as the Apostle saith in the same place, verse vlt. You see then the misery of all such men, though admired of the world for their great policy and deepe reaches, yet they are odious to God, and liable to destruction.

First, take notice what your heart is naturally in and of it selfe. There is a depth of wickednesse in our hearts, a bottomelesse gulfe of guile and hollownesse. Oh the deceits and crafts, the turnings and windings, the shifts and distinctions of our vile natures. No man can possibly discouer, how desperately wicked the heart of man is in it selfe. This you must see and finde by your selfe, that you haue not one heart, but a diuided heart, a double heart, a treble heart, nay an hundreth hearts in your bosomes. See now your desease, confesse and bewaile it before the Lord.

Secondly, deny your selues in each lust, in each
creature, if you would haue your heart to be one. 1. Cast out euery lust, euery sinne out of the soule: for sinne separates a man from God, from the people of God, yea, from himselfe. It racks him, teares him, diuides him a hundred wayes. 2 Rend and diuide the heart from euery creature so farre, I meane, as not to make it your treasure, for that distracteth: for where our treasures is, our hearts will be also; and so many treasure, so many hearts, now if you pitch vpon Creatures, you must need bee diuided with variety: for there is not enough in any one creature to suffice and satisfie. Take bread for example, though it feed vs, yet it will not cloath vs: cloathes though they warme vs, yet they will not feed vs: Wee must haue both food and rayment too, or we cannot subsist. Now this multiplicity of the creatures, if wee set our hearts vpon them, doth greatly hinder this Vnion; this onenes of heart we must all striue vnto. Therfore let loose all other things and cleaue fast to God, pitch onely vpon him (this is that one thing necessary) make him your portion, make him your treasure, and hauing that one treasure, it will come to passe that you shall haue but one heart; but neuer will your heart become one till you come to this to fix, and fasten all your hopes and ioves chiefely vpon God, for he can onely satisfie and support the heart; therefore see and consider his al-sufficiency and abundant goodnesse to all his peop e, how you cannot want that thing which hee will supply you with, you cannot desire ought, but he h • th it for you, &c: In a word, see him to be all in all▪ and so make choi •• of him
insteed of all. And when you are once one in that obiect, you will be also one in heart.

Thirdly, take the Couenant of grace, as here it stands recorded, and improue it. He hath promised (you see) to giue you this one heart: Take now this promise, and present it before the Lord, spread it all abroad before him (as Hezekiah sometimes did the letter of Sennacherib) and say, Lord, here I haue to shew thine owne hand for the changing of my heart: behold, I haue a double heart, change it. I haue a hollow, false, diuided heart; Oh mend it I beseech, and make it one. And here remember to pleade not the Couenant onely, but Christ also, pleade his death, his merits and obedience, &c: he died for this very end and purpose, that hauing abolished in his flesh the enmity, hee might make in himselfe of twaine one new man, so making peace. And that he might reconcile both vnto God in one body, by the crosse, hauing slaine the enmity therby, as the Apostle speaketh in 2 seueral Epistles to the Ephes. and Colos. hee died for this very end, to make all one againe. Once we were all but one, but now by sinne wee are diuided from God, diuided from the creatures, diuided from our selues: Now therefore Christ came to restore vs againe to our primitiue condition: and for this it was that he dyed, and shed his blood vpon the Crosse: which wee may safely pleade to God. The like we may say of his intercession; what pr •
ed he when he was here amongst vs? That they all may be one, as thou (Father) art in me, and I in thee: that they also may be one in vs, &c: I in them, and they in me; that they may be made perfect in one, &c. Iohn
17.21, 23. He praied you see, that we might bee one, as hee and his Father are; one here in part, and hereafter in all perfection: Sith therefore Christ died, Christ praied, Christ shed his blood for this, that we might haue this one heart, and be one with God, plead his blood, his prayers, his sufferings and mediation. And that is the 3d. meanes.

Fourthly, labour to grow vp in all sauing graces of the holy Ghost: for as sinne diuides and separates between God and vs; so true grace brings God and the creature together againe: and the more grace any one hath, the more neerely is his heart vnited to God: for grace is a ne • re tye, and hath an vniting power in it. For instance, by faith a man is not only taken off from himself, and from the creature; but is also brought to deny all, and to rely vpon the mercy and power of God alone. So by charity, a man is made to deny his owne will in all things, and wholly to subiect himselfe to the will of God. The same we may say of the rest of the graces: The feare of God expells all false feares of the creature, the care for heauen frees the heart from all inordinate cares of the world: Delight in God weanes a man from all vaine delights and pleasures of sinne, that doe distract the heart. Briefly, the more grace any one hath, the more will his head be established, and his heart vnited.

Lastly, if you would haue your heart made one you must goe all by one rule, inward, the Spirit; outward, the Word: and that secondary rule too (Conscience I meane) must be followed, so farre as it is rightly regulated, and informed by that
first rule, the Word, and when we proceed by that one rule of God, wee shall be one together.

In the last place, this point speaks a word of comfort, Vse 3 or rather of thankfulnesse to all those that find this grace in themselues, that their hearts are healed of all haltings and backeslidings, and made to become one: this is an vnspeakable mercy of God, and you can neuer be sufficiently thankfull.
But how shall I know my heart to be one? Quest.

For answer, wee might tell you, Answ. that one heart is a true heart, a good heart,Vnum, verum, honum ens, &c. that it is alwaies in realities, &c. For these are termes conuertible, and goe euer together; but for your better vnderstanding, wee will giue you three plaine notes of a heart that is one.
1. Integrity. 2. Constancy. 3. Sincerity.

For the first: when the heart is become one, a man goeth all one way, he is what he seems, he appeares what indeed he is, hee hath but one minde, one intention, one delight, one face, one tongue, in a word, hee is all but one man, all the parts and powers of his soule and body do go all one and the same way. Now therefore, when there is in a man this integrity (both for subiect, hee goes all one way, and for obiect, he aymes at Gods whole w • ll, to fulfill the same) this mans heart is one.

A second note is constancy, when a man is at all times like himselfe, one & the same, take him when and which way you wil, thogh there may be some partiall vncertainty in the subiect, yet hee is firme for the obiect pitcht vpon, namely God, in Christ.

And a third is sincerity, when a man g • es vpon one motiue, hee st • ains out all by-respects, all
selfishnesse, and lookes to the common, to a publike good, his maine ayme is the glory of God in his owne saluation.

Obiect. Oh, but may some say, here is that doth discourage mee: You say this one-hearted man is an intire man, and goes all one way; but I finde a world of diuision, and continuall combates in my soule: the flesh hales one way, the spirit another, &c.

Solu.For answer: It is to be considered, that there is a double diuision. 1. Intrinsecall, or inward, which is when the powers of the soule are at variance betweene themselues, one of them set against another.

2. Outward, when they all agree and combine within themselues, and the diuision is onely outward against a common enemy. The former of these may be found in an hypocrite, the latter is not, but in the Saints of God alone. In waging of warre, there is great difference betweene fighting against a forraine enemy, that inuades the countrey; and an intestine enemy, that is bred at home amongst vs. When a Citty is begirt with an army from other parts, the enemie spies where he may take his best aduantage; the Cittizens in the meane while,The diuision in Saints is not betweene finn and sin, sin, and nature as in others, but betwe • ne sinne and grace in the whole man. watch and make as sure as they can, euery place of the wall▪ but in a ciuill warre, it is otherwise: for then there is neighbour against neighbour, and euery one against another; so is it here. In the Saints of God, the flesh, as a common enemy, assaults all the powers of the soule, and they againe with forces conioyned, make resistance against it. It is not (as in hypocrites)
iudgement against will, conscience against affection, reason against Appetite, &c. but all the powers goe one and the same way, namely, against the common enemy.
You say, that he that hath one heart, Obiect. is a constant man: but alas! I am full of wauerings and doubting, and a great deale of inconstancy.

There is a double inconstancy. One is,Sol. when a man stands wauering betweene two different obiects. The other is that which comes after a man is resolued on the maine businesse. And this latter is found in Gods best children. They cleaue to God with full purpose of heart, they haue chosen the better part, which they shall neuer part with: And though in their executions they fall short oftentimes of their intentions, yet still they hold fast their generall purposes and aymes, although they be iogged aside sometimes, and put by, in respect of particulars.

You say, that this One-hearted man is a sincere man, aymes at the glory of God, &c. But alas! Obiect. it is otherwise with mee, for I mingle and confound businesse. I serue God indeed, but I aime at mine owne credit, profit, ease, &c.

But what is thy vtmost end thou propoundest to thy selfe? what is thy chiefe obiect?Sol. There is an vnder end that comes in onely in a second place. And though the glory of God be chiefely to be intended in all, yet it is also true, that in a second place, I may haue respect to my owne ease, profit, comfort, &c. also (For, we are bid to loue our neighbour as our selues, therefore it is certaine wee may and must loue and respect our selues and
our owne good) but so, as that the maine thing that swayes vs, must be the glory of God, and a desire to approue our selues to him. And thus it is with euery faithfull christian, howsoeuer hee may be happely carried away with some by-respects for a time, yet when it comes once to a matter of competition betweene himselfe and God, he presently lets fall credit, ease, profit, yea, he willingly lets goe life and all, rather then God, and his glory.
Obiect. Surely I haue not yet attained to this onenesse, for I am euer and anon troubled and pestered with many distractions, when at any time I take in hand to meditate, pray, or doe any good duty.

Sol.For answer you must vnderstand that there are two degrees of onenesse (as we said before) 1. Perfect; dreame not of hauing this here, it is reserued for the state of glory. 2. Imperfect, when a man is for the maine, vndiuided, pitches vpon God for his chiefe obiect, yet so, as that many things fall in to distemper and distract him, and hee is troubled with diuers and sundry cares, feares, desires, &c. that interrupt him in his course, euen then, when he would be most of all reserued to God, all which notwithstanding, so long as a man bewailes and resists them, and continues praying to God with Dauid: Vnite my heart vnto thy name, &c. they shall neuer be laid to his charge, but God will by degrees, heale all the turnings and windings of his heart, till wee all at length become one in Christ, till being one entirely, we shall be swallowed vp of eternity; Christ becomming vnto vs all in all.

div.head: OF NEVVNESSE OF HEART.

epigraph.q: And I will giue them one heart, and I will put a new spirit within you and I will take the stony heart out of their flesh, and will giue them a heart of flesh.

div.p:
MAns Heart is miserably dis-ioynted: only God can cure it, and he hath vndertaken the cure of it; of a diuided heart to make it one heart, of rotten to make it new, and of hard to make it soft. Touching onenesse of heart, we spake the last time, and haue shewed you, that all that are in speciall couenant with God, haue one heart, and but one. One in reference to God, and one in reference to themselues, both ioyntly and seuerally considered. One in opposition. 1. To an vnresolued heart. 2. To a variable heart. 3. To a double and hypocriticall heart. 4. To
a distracted and vnquiet heart, &c. But this wee haue dispatcht already.

Next, God vndertaketh to giue to his people a new heart, I will put a new spirit into you. The inward part of man, sustaines diuers names in Scripture in a diuers respect. In regard of the cause thereof it is called a spirit, in respect of the feate, it is termed, heart, in respect of it's naturall operation, soule, and in respect of it's spirituall office, it is called conscience (as before wee told you.) This inside of man, call it what you will, God will renew: where come to be considered:
1. The thing promised, I will put a new spirit within you.
2. The author, God, I will doe it.
For the first of these, that you may the better vnderstand the termes, you may distinguish eyther of spirit, or of its adiunct, newnesse.

First, Spirit, is taken in a diuers sense in holy Scripture. Sometimes it is taken for the soule, as it is opposed to the body, as in that place: The body returnes to the earth, and the spirit to God that gaue it. Sometimes againe, it is put for the faculties of the soule, as, I will sing with my spirit, that is, with my vnderstanding, 1 Cor. 14. So, I serue God with my spirit, Rom. 1.9. That is, with my Will. Sometimes againe, it is taken for the gifts and graces of the spirit, as in that of our Sauiour, Iohn 3. That which is borne of the spirit, is spirit.

Againe, you must distinguish heere of New. A thing is said to be New: 1. in regard of the matter of it, when it hath new materials; as (for instance) when a man builds an house new
out of the ground, we say. 2. In regard of the inward forme and species of it, as when (for example) I turne my gowne into a coat. 3. In regard of the outward forme and fashion of it: as when a man breaks an old boule, and casts it into a new fashion, there is the same substance as before, but there is a new figure, a new face set vpon it: And so it is to be taken here. God will renue the spirit of his people, by putting new qualities into their soules.

Secondly, the Authour of this change is God, I will put a new spirit, &c. That is, I will bestow vpon you new graces, new qualities, that whereas you are naturally void of all goodnes, hating me, and being hated of me, &c. I will put such a new frame of soule into you, that you shall loue mee, and one another spiritually. And how will he do this for them? not by extracting good qualities out of them, as if they were seminally and potentially there before, but hee will infuse and powre the same into them anew.

The words thus explained, we passe on to the point: that whosoeuer will be soundly assured, that hee belongs to the new Couenant, he must haue a new heart, a new spirit: (in a word) be must be a new man.

For the dispatch of this point, wee commend vnto your consideration, these three particulars: 1. It is simply necessary that we be renued: 2. It is possible, if wee seeke it in a right way. And 3. It is wondrous commodious and co • fortable to them that attaine to it. If it were needefull, and yet not feisable, it were a great discouragement
to a man that should reach after it: if it were possible, and necessary, but not commodious, men would haue the lesse heart to look after it: but in a concurrence of all these, when it is both necessary and possible, and commodious too, who would but striue vnto it.

Necessary it is, first, in a double respect. 1. in regard of precept: Make you a new heart and a new spirit, Ezek. 18.31. And againe, Be you transformed by the renuing of your mindes, Rom. 12.2. so Ephes. 4.22. Put off, concerning the former conuersation, the old man which is corrupt, &c. And be renued in the spirit of your minds: So likewise, Col. 3.10. In all these places he layes this vpon vs, as a charge. 2. It is necessary, as will appeare if you consider it as a meane conducing to our maine end. To be renued, is the way to the new Ierusalem. You see how God hath smitten a new couenant with you, put you vnder a new gouernour, giuen you right into a new City, to the which hee hath set this new way, so that whosoeuer treads the way thither, he must be a new creature. Hence that of our Sauiour, Ioh. 3.5. which he vttereth twice in a breath, almost (for more certainty of the thing, Except a man be borne againe, he cannot enter into the kingdome of God. So then 'tis necessary.

Secondly, it is possible too: True it is that man cannot make himselfe a new heart: but it is true also, that although hee concurre not as a cause or agent in this work, yet must he concurre as a subiect capable of being renewed: for whosoeuer is capable of Reason, the same is also capable of
Grace (For, what is Grace but Reason perfected and eleuated) and though man be vnable to renue himselfe, yet dealeth he with one that both is able, and hath also vndertaken to doe it for him: Hee that could make man at first, can with the same ease re-make him againe; he that could call light out of darknesse, can shine in mans heart, to giue the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Iesus Christ: For as there are no bounds set to Gods essence, so neither to his power. And as he is able to doe this for his people, so is hee no lesse willing to it, for he hath said it, he hath sworne it, hee hath sealed it, (as you haue heard) and therefore, sure he will not eat his word, goe from his seale, be for-sworne. So that it is possible.
Thirdly, it is commodious too: for, it brings along with it, 1. honour, 2. comfort.

For the first, it is the glory of the creature to be renued and sanctified: then the creature comes first to be glorious, when it is made new. There is nothing in the world (saith that Greek Father) so beautifull as the new creature.Nazian Man by nature is deformed, vgly, the Image of God being vtterly defaced in him, and that of Satan in the roome thereof succeedeth: but when he becomes new, he is restored in blood as it were, he returnes to his first and primitiue estate, being borne, not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, Mens humana gratiam nondum adepta, nihil aliud est fi cadauer parit: de Sacr. Bapts. but of God. 2. As it is honourable, so it is comfortable to be a new man; Indeede, what can comfort vs if wee be not so? An old man is but
the carcasse of a man, dead while hee liues. A dead man, you know, hath eyes indeed, and eares and hands, but cannot see with his eyes, heare with his eares, act with his hands, &c. No more can he that is not renued, though he hath the spirit of a man, yet is he not able to doe the act of a man, that is, of a Christiā man, he vnderstandeth not the things of God, neither indeed can, do either that or any thing else, that may answer his first creation. You haue heard some Reasons of the point. It remaines to make some vse of it: And first, is it so, that euery one in speciall couenant with God is a new man? this makes much against all those that lay claime to the new couenant, and vsurpe the seales of it, and yet are old men still, and (which is worse) care not to become new. Let these men here learne to see, 1. Signes whereby they may be discouered. 2. Their misery.

First, for Signes of an old man, these be infallible. 1. when men are drowned in darknesse and ignorance, this shewes them to be in their old estate. For, the first thing that liues in a man, is his vnderstanding; and the first degree of life that enters into a Christian mans soule, is knowledge. If therefore your vnderstanding be yet darkned, you are but old, being estranged from the life of God, through the ignorance that is in you, because of the blindnesse of your heart, Ephes. 4. This makes against very many amongst vs altogether ignorant of God, of themselues, what they are in Adam, what in Christ, being well pleased with their naturall condition, and can see nothing amisse
in themselues, and are therfore vnwilling to go out of themselues, that feel no conflicts within them, no strugling against the corrupt part, &c. and if you tell them of the new-birth, they vnderstand nothing of it, but stand as Nichodemus to our Sauiour, with how? How can these things be? &c. they cannot be brought to see any such necessity of renouation. Lo, these are old men, as appeares by their ignorance: For the first worke of the spirit in mans heart, is conuiction: He conuinceth the world of sinne, of righteousnesse, &c. and God begets vs againe by the word of truth, Iam. 1. he acquaints vs with his Word, and builds vp our iudgements in the first place, with diuine truths.

2. Another signe of an old man is, when one is not onely ignorant of goodnesse, but an enemy also to it, so as he hates and opposes it. This makes against many amongst vs, that can loue their friends and kindred well enough, so long as they are old men, but when they beginne once to be renewed and altered, though from worse to better, then they abhorre them, set against them, cast them out of their affections, &c. Thus, and thus it is with many a wicked father; so soone as euer his childe begins but to looke toward God, then out a doores with him straight, hee will owne him, and acknowledge him no longer. And as in families, so in Parishes, so long as a man will doe as the rest, sweare, swagger, drinke, reuell, &c. he shall be accounted a good fellow, a good neighbour, and the like: but when he shall refuse to runne along with them in the same excesse
of r • ot, then hee forfeits all his wits presently, loseth all his respect among his nehghbours, is held not worthy to be saluted or acknowledged. This shews them to be yet in their old estate: for whosoeuer is borne of God, and so is a new creature, he beleeueth that Iesus is the Christ, God stablisheth his iudgement in the knowledge of diuine truthes, and cures him of his ignorance; (which was the first note of an old man) and secondly, as he loueth him that begate, so he loueth him that is begotten by him, as they are deliuered together, 1 Ioh. 5.1.

A third signe of an old man, is, vnchangeablenesse in his whole conuersation. In the new birth there is euer wrought a change of the whole man. Once ye were darke, saith the Apostle, but now ye are light in the Lord, once ye were dead in trespasses & sins, but now hath God quickned you together with Christ, Ephes. 2. And in the Kingdome of Christ, Old things are past, all things are become new, the night is farre spent, the day is at hand, &c. So then you see euery new man is another man, changed and altered not from better to worse, but from euill to good, hee is translated out of the kingdome and bondage of darkenesse, into the glorious liberty of the sonnes of God. Now therefore, see you a man in whome there is no change to be discerned, as he was borne into the world wicked and sinfull, so he liues, and so also hee will dye, as holding it a disparagement to be any other man than he hath euer beene, and his forefathers before him were; this is an old man: for newnesse brings a
change, old things are past, and new come in place.

A fourth note of an old man, is, when a man contents himselfe with ciuility, or formality (at the best) in Religion. He will lead a faire and square life among his neighbours, pay euery man his owne, doe harme to none, &c. and herein he rests as sufficient to saluation. This indeed is as much as men can well require of him, and such a one may well passe heere below for a very good Citizen of this lower world, but not in that Ierusalem that is aboue, where we haue to do with a holy God, that cannot abide iniquitie, with holy Angells, with the Spirits of iust men made perfect, &c. and vnlesse we be conformed to them in some measure, there's no heauen to be had,Hebr. 1 2. For without holinesse none can see God. So our Sauiour applies this Doctrine to Nicodemus a ciuill man, and more too, for hee had some formality in him too, and yet our Sauior tels him, Ioh. 3. that Except a man be borne againe, that is, except hee become a new man, as well as a ciuill man, or a tame man, hee cannot possibly see the kingdome of God. Ciuility, (though plausible in the world) will not reach out here, and yet there be but too many amongst vs that sit downe with it. And the like we may say of formality in religion: how many are there now adaies that content themselues with it, they come to Church, heare a Sermon, receiue the Sacrament, sometimes, with the rest of their honest neighbours, and there's an end of the businesse. All their deuotion is confined to the Church, and done in the congregation mostly,
&c. Such a one was the Pharise, he came to the Temple, made his prayer, gaue almes to the poore, and payed tythes of all hee had, &c. and therefore thought himselfe in very good case for heauen: but you must be told, my brethren, that there's a power of Religion, a spirit of Religion, that God lookes after, and not a bare shew, or Carcasse. A painted man, you know, may haue all the parts of a man to see to, hands, eyes, eares, feete, &c. as well as a liuing body, but there wants a spirit to enliue and act the picture; So here an Hypocrite may, for his outside, looke like a true Christian, but he wants this new spirit here promised, and therefore hee is but the Carcasse of a Christian, what euer hee seemes to be.

Fifthly (for wee must hasten) An old man is hee that is in bondage to his owne lusts, and to this euill world, and cannot tell how, in some measure, to redeeme himselfe. This new spirit, God giues to his people,Rom. 8. is not a spirit of bondage, but a spirit of power, of might, and of sound mind,2. Tim. 1 7. saith the Apostle: and againe, the kingdome of God standeth not in words, but in power: and where the spirit of God is, there is libertie. This new nature vnties a man, sets him at liberty, makes him a free man (not altogether, I confesse, but yet so farre as hee is renewed and spirituall, so farre it makes him free) so that all such as continue slaues to their owne lusts, to the corrupt customes and fashions of this world, to their euill company, &c. so that they haue no liberty left them, they cannot chuse, if their companions
becken or lift vp the finger to them, if their sinfull pleasures & profits inuite or call vpon them, but goe and runne whithersoeuer they shall leade them, &c; this plainely shewes them to be yet in their old estate. And these are marks of such as haue no interest in the new couenant of Grace.

Next, consider their misery: And for this, ther's enough here said in the text, to proue them miserable: for they are shut out from hauing any part or portion in the new couenant, as being aliens from the common-wealth of Israel, and so strangers from the Couenant of Promise, Ephes. 4. God vndertakes not for any such, will not knowledge or own them for his &c: again, they cannot possibly doe any thing pleasing to God, as saith the Apostle, They which are in the flesh, cannot please God, but such are all those that are not renued. Nay lastly, they cannot enter into heauen: for except a man be borne anew, he cannot see, he cannot inherite the Kingdome of heauen. Lo, here's the wretched condition of all such as are old men. Let euery man enquire whether he be not such a one; and if so, let him see his danger.

Exhortation, Euery one to make diligent search Ʋse 2 into his owne estate, and sith the man is as his spirit is, therefore to enquire what spirit you are of: There is not any amongst you, but desires and would bee exceeding glad to haue God for his Father, and to be in speciall couenant with him: Now if you would be so, you must bee able to shew the Counterpane of the new couenant, this new spirit here promised, I'll giue them
one heart (saith God) and I will put a new spirit within you, &c: I will put my Lawes into your inward parts, that ye may walke in my statutes and keepe mine ordinances, &c. As if he should say, looke what things are here written in your bookes with paper and inke, the same will I write and engraue vpon your hearts and spirits. God writes onenes of heart, and he writes newnesse of heart vpon all that are within the couenant; see to it therfore that ye be new men, renued in the spirit of your minds, see that yee be able to shew new for new, the Lawe of God written in your hearts, as well as written in your Bibles, or else you are but strangers from the Couenant of Promise.

And here for your direction, see first what the Lord meaneth by a new Spirit: you are not to vnderstand God (as if hee spoke like a Philosopher physically) but morally, as it is ord narily vsed in holy Scriptu • e. There is an old man, that is, a depraued and corrupt nature, as wee come from Adam.

2. There is a New man, that is, refined, renued, as we are in Christ. The first of these, the Scripture calles Flesh: the second, it calles Spirit: so that a new spirit here promised, is nothing else but a new man, as he is renued, reformed, and refined by God. This new grace is tearmed by the name of Spirit, partly in respect of the author of it, the Spirit of God, and partly in respect of the subiect of it, for it is wrought and rooted in mans spirit. And it is called New, not in reference to our first estate, the state of integrity; but in regard of
our depraued estate, as we are lost in Adam: And so it is called new, 1 because our old corrupt estate goes before it. 2. because it is infused into vs a new by God: and 3. because it makes a man new in the whole bent of his mind, and in the whole body of his conuersation. The Author of this new Spirit is the blessed Trinity: the subiect of it man, the whole man, his spirit, soule, and body, he is renued throughout: For the order of working it in vs, it is done not at once, but successiuely, as the Apostle saith, We are renewed day by day, and changed into the same Image from glory to glory.

If these things we haue said, bee too hard for you, and surpasse your vnderstanding,Notes of new man or spirit. 1 distinctiue from Ciuil • ty. we'll make you amends with these plainer notes of a new spirit. And these are of 2 sorts. 1. Negatiue. 2. Positiue. The Negatiue notes are such as serue to distinguish it from Cognata, things that resemble and looke like vnto Newnes. There bee some things that deceiue the world, vnder the name of a new spirit, but are nothing lesse. These are

First, Ciuility (concerning which something hath beene said before.) A new nature is another thing thē ciuil honesty: for this begins from man, is busied about man, and ends in man, as hauing man for its obiect, and for its end, whereas grace respecteth God throughout.

Againe, ciuility doth but barbe and shaue the out-side (as one well saith) it doth not fetch out the rootes of sin, as this new nature doth, it alters in the roote, aswell as in the branches, and reacheth to both tables of the Law, whereas ciuility lookes onely to one.

Secondly, formality is another counterfeit of this new Spirit: This lookes to the duties of the first Table onely, and therein also no more then to outward motiues, as it performes such and such duties, because the state so commands it, because, one hath beene so bred, &c. The difference is double. 1 Formality is but a picture of true goodnes, it reformes onely the outward man, but this new nature, the inward. 2 It is a liueles thing, the formalist hath no power of religion (as a new man hath) at least in an exigent, euery lust vndermines him, euery first motion to sinne is ready to trip vp his heeles, and when it comes to a competition, earth carries it from heauen. Thirdly, a common spirit (such as may befall both the new man and the old) this deceiues many. It may befall an vnsanctified person to bee conuinced, illightned, restrained, as well as the best. The difference is this.

1. A new Spirit is vniuersal, it goes thorow the whole man, leauens the whole lump: but in the hypocrite, that which he hath is priuate and particular to certaine faculties of his soule: as conuiction is restrained to his vnderstanding; illumination to his Iudgement, restraint to his will, &c. But now this new grace is common to all the powers of the soule; it is not like a little spring, that takes beginning in some piece of ground, and ends in the same; but like the great Ocean that compasseth about the whole world, and receiveth diuers names according to the seuerall places that it washes and salutes: So this
new nature sanctifies the whole mans spirit, soule and body: as the Apostle speaketh, and receiueth seuerall names according to the seuerall parts of man on which it worketh. As it dwelleth in the head, it is called wisdome; as in the memory, faithfulnes; as in the conscience, tendernes; as in the will, subiection; as in the affections, it is tearmed, order; as in the outward man, new obedience: so it receiues diuers appellations according to the diuerse parts and powers that it affecteth. And as it is vniuersall for the subiect, so for the obiect too, for it is set against all sinne, and resolues vpon the doing of all dutie according to its light.

2. As it is vniuersall, so it is alteratiue too, it amends not the out-side onely, but seekes into the inward man, and alters that; It giues a man a new temper, as it were, and a new constitution, it makes him that was fearefull and timerous, become bold and couragious; him that was peeuish and passionate, to be of a meeke and quiet spirit, him that was dull and cold, very zealous and feruent, the simple it causeth to become wise and acute for the things of God; for instance, you shal haue a man so simple that he can scare speake reason or tell his own tale to a man, yet turne him loose to God in prayer, or to men in the confession of his faith, and he will do excellently, be able to goe an end, as we say, being fluent in his tearmes, and expressing himselfe in good manner, far beyond many a greater scholler that cannot come neare him.

Thus this new spirit, though it doth not abolish a mans naturall constitution, whether cholericke, melancholly, or the like, yet it alters and changeth it to that which is better: whereas in others it is not so, there is no notable change to be discerned in their preuailing humour and inclination.

3. It is humbling. It makes a man thankfull to God, mercifull to men, and more basely to thinke of himselfe then of any other: As on the contrary, common grace is boasting, censorious, and puffes men vp, as saith the Apostle, knowledge puffeth vp, and the same is true of a spirit of restraint, as is to be seen in the Pharisee, who blessed God, he was not so bad, and so bad being too too wel conceited of his owne goodnes.

4. It is diffusiue and spredding. A new man would haue all the world new, and goe to heauen aswell as himselfe. On the other side, an old man may haue much light in his head, but little loue in his heart, he may be restrained and tied vp as it were from the doing of any great euill, but yet hee will take but a little paines in his family or with others to make them better.

These are the negatiue notes of a new man. The positiue follow, and they are these drawne all from the effects (those from the causes being too light for the capacities of the bulke of this Congregation.)

First, this new Grace is operatiue, and hath its worke vpon both the in-side and out-side of a man; And first vpon the vnderstanding, it sets vp
a new light therin, causing a man to know things more perfectly and distinctly then euer hee did before, it makes him see an vglynes in sinne, a beauty in grace; which another man cannot see, &c: so for persons, he sees now nothing in man to be admired but the new nature, and as any one excells others in the Image of God, by so much doth he prize and esteeme him.

Secondly, it works vpon the spirit and minde of man, and stablisheth that another man hath no command ouer his thoughts and fancies, but they run and roaue any way in despight of him: wheras a new man is able to pitch his thoughts about heauen and the things therof with some stedfastnes. Time was, when he only minded himselfe & the earth, but now his mind is rightly set, he thinkes of God, he sleepes with God, wakes with God, his thoughts in the first place in a morning are of God, & puts not quite off earthly businesses, yet he goes about them with an heauenly mind.

Thirdly, as it strengthens and stablisheth the mind, so it works vpon the memory too, seizing vpon that for holy vse onely, that it may bee as a chest to reserue such things as are good and profitable. Mans memory by nature is like a grate, through which when water passeth, it lets go all that is pure and thinne, and retaines onely that which is thicke and filthy; but when it is renued once, it striues to straine out all the filth, and keepes that which is holy and vsefull: Such a mans care is to treasure vp knowledge, wisdome
and experiences there, that may guide him in the way to heauen, and whereby he may furnish himselfe with matter of meditation. And howsoeuer in the best mens memories is found, that which is corrupt and euill, yet doe they labour to rid it out, that better may take place. It may so fal out, that in the best chest a spider may set vp her Cobwebbe, or dust and filth may creepe into it by some way, but then a man will not suffer it there to rest, but ridde it out assoone as may be: so it is here.

And 2 this new spirit strengthens the memory alway for practice, though it serue it not alway for matter of discourse, some men haue such happy memories, that when they haue heard a Sermon, or read it in a good booke, they are able to make rehearsall of whatsoeuer they haue heard, or reade, but when it comes to a matter of practice once, they are no body. Others you haue very able men of discourse, can speake largely of good things out of memory and inuention, as of patience for example, and yet let them be neuer so little prouoked, and they will be as violent, and as disordered as any other,: But now the Newman, though he forgets much of that he heares, neither is able to goe along with the minister from part to part in that which hath beene deliuered, yet, when it comes to a matter of practice, then his memory befriends him greatly. Now I call to mind, saith he, what I long since heard such a man deliuer concerning this sinne or this duty, and now is the time come to practise it.

Fourthly, this new Grace workes vpon the conscience, reconciling a man to his owne conscience, and making them friends, who of themselues are at variance. Naturally, Conscience brawles against vs, and we on the other side fight against it, and oppose, yea, doe what we can to stifle it and to put it downe; But no sooner is a man renued, but hee and his conscience grow friends: He will doe nothing without conscience, nor conscience without him; when the new man takes in hand to doe any thing, hee first reflects vpon himselfe with, Conscience what saist thou to this businesse? thou seest I could cheate my neighbour by false wares, or setting a faire face on a foule matter, &c. Againe, thou knowest vpon what motiues, with what intent, and for what end I vndertake this businesse, Is it right or is it not? Thus the New-man consults his conscience before he doth any thing: as on the other side, conscience will deale faithfully with him, in telling him what is amisse with him, and in cheering him when he hath done wel, though all the world frowne vpon him for the same.

Fifthly, The like we may say of the will: The office whereof is double. 1. to obey well. 2. to command wel. First, as a seruant vnder God is obedient, this new nature subdues our wil to Gods Will, and makes vs tractable to his pleasure in all things: will God haue me doe such or such a thing, (saith the New-man) no more words, it shall be done forthwith, at least in mine endeauour:
Againe, will God haue me suffer such or such an affliction, Behold, here I am, Lord, thy will be done in earth as it is in heauen. Secondly, as it is an officer vnder God, it commands as a Prince the whole man: It commands the eye what to see, the eare what to heare, the hand what to act, in a word, it hath the cōmand of mans both inside and outside when it comes to a matter of practice: Now this new nature commands all for God, chargeth euery part to bee seruiceable to God, &c: The like we might say of the seuerall affections, but that we are cut off by the time.

So for the outward man: this new spirit works in a man a new conuersation, a new life, new proiects, new ends, new endeauours, &c. All his members are made for God, being become weapons of Righteousnesse vnto holinesse: Rom. 6. Hee layes lawes vpon himselfe in euery part, makes a Couenant with his eyes, as Iob, not to behold vanity; makes a couenant with his eares, not to drinke in iniquity: makes a couenant with his tongue, to speake a new language, euen the language of Canaan: An old man is apt to lye, curse, sweare, flatter, raile, &c. But this new grace giues him to speake in a new Dialect, so that in stead of cursing, he blesseth; in stead of swearing, now he prayes and vtters the words of Grace and wisedome: we may say the same for his life, for his delights, for his desires, for his company and society, all things are become new with him. He hath also a new house; That which they say of the soule, Anima facit sibi domicilium, that it makes
it selfe a dwelling house, the same is true of him and his family, all domesticall disorders are reformed, and a new face set vpon it, that whereas before there was nothing but swearing here, and drinking there, and railing in another place, now there is calling vpon Gods name, singing of Psalmes, and other parts of Gods worship set vp in the houshold: so you see now what wee meane by a new Spirit, namely a new inside, and a new out-side, new all, old things are past, all things are become new.
Now enquire and examine whether you are new or not? What if we be? Quest. and what if we be not? Answ.

If you be not, then labour to get a new heart, old things we are al ashamed of: An old scull, an old rotten coate, wee are ashamed to be seene in it; oh we are not an old inside, an old corrupt heart this is worse then all the rest: we naturally all affect nouelties, and by our good-wils, we would haue new houses, new diet, new fashions, new euery thing; And shall wee then content our selues with an old rotten heart? such is euery mans heart by nature, an vgly thing that renders him odious to God and Angels. Therefore labour for this new Spirit.

What can we doe toward the getting of a new heart? Quest.
Answ.

Though man cannot concurre to the renuing of himselfe as a cause or an agent, yet he must concurre as a subiect; and howsoeuer the new man is no more then a patient in his first conuersion,
yet afterwards being acted by God, hee must vp and be doing. Now for your better direction herein, see these particulars.
1. What this new spirit is, to wit, the frame and stampe of Christ, opposed to the Image of lapsed Adam.

2. Whence it comes? namely, from Christ, of whose fulnesse, wee all receiue grace for grace, Iohn 1. Doe wee want wisedome, holinesse, faith, &c? There 'tis for vs: Christ is made vnto vs, of God, Wisedome, Righteousnesse, Sanctification, &c. Therefore to him must wee goe, to him must wee cleaue, as to the principle of our life, and as the childe doth to the brests, hee lets goe all to lay hold on it: so must we on Christ, cleauing to him by one act of faith, of loue, and other graces, by onenesse, by newnesse, &c.
3. See why God infuseth this new spirit into vs, namely, because it is his couenant, which we may boldly plead vnto him in prayer.
4. See when hee doth it? when it pleaseth himselfe: the wind bloweth where it listeth, &c. so is euery one that is borne of the holy Ghost, Ioh. 3.

5. See where he doth it? in the vse of his owne meanes: hence the Word is called the ministration of the spirit, and the Sacraments are as so many organs, and as it were vehecula to conuey this new spirit into vs, Yee shall be baptised with the holy Ghost.

6. Wherefore giues hee it? That wee may act that which is good in his sight, walke in
newnesse of life, and keepe his commandements.
7. How doth he giue it? successiuely and by degrees, wee are renewed day by day, according to his Image.

Therefore, if you would haue this new spirit, you see what's to be done: waite vpon God in his owne wayes and meanes, till hee please to speake life into your soules: For, the words that I speake, (saith our Sauiour) are spirit, and they are life: hee breaths vpon vs the holy Ghost, &c. Especially apply your selues to the communion of Saints: A dead coale, put to liue coales, will take fire from them, which it would neuer do lying in the dead heape: so here. Awake, therefore, thou that sleepest, stand vp from the dead, and Christ shall giue you light: sort your selues with such as are godly, and frequent the ordinances: And this is the way to get this new spirit. Be exhorted now to lay downe your old spirit with the old yeere, and to be renewed throughout. This is that that must comfort you in life, support you in death, and beare you out at the last day: For, then no thing will endure the fire, but the new man. Content not your selues therefore to be ciuill men, or merely formall, but become other men, new men, and betake your selues to this new course, that you may haue part in the new couenant.

Doctr.
GOds people must haue a new spirit, a new heart. There is a necessity of it: it is all their happinesse that they can arriue at. You haue heard the point already; wee began to make some vse of it.

Vse. 1: If all those that are in speciall couenant with God, haue a new heart, then they are excluded the couenant of grace, that retain their old nature still, that remaine in their former ignorance, in their ancient enmity against the new man, being vnchangeable in their courses, and impotent or vnable to resist any lust, or to withstand any motion from euill men or euill spirits. These are old crazy men.

Vse. 2 Wee put it vpon you (secondly) to examine whether you be new men or not. If so, there is matter of thankefulnesse, if not, then labour for this new spirit, that is, for renewing grace, which is that that makes a man a new man. You come daily to new Sermons, you receiue new Sacraments, you vndergoe new refinings and afflictions, and yet you remaine old still: this goes hard. The meanes to get this new nature, is to goe to the new Adam, Iesus Christ, for it: for, whosoeuer is in Christ, is a new creature, as on the other side, all that are in the old stocke, are dead and withered. Vnite your selues therefore to Christ by knowledge, by loue, by faith, and
so shall you draw from him a new life and vertue, wait vpon him in his wayes and ordinances: and then, as the Prophet Esay speaketh, You shall renew your strength as the Eagle. And as Naaman the Syrian, after that, for the curing of his leprosie, he had vsed Gods meanes, washing himselfe seuen times, that is, often, in the Riuer Iordan, as oft as he was enioynd, his old disease went off, and his flesh returned new, as the flesh of a childe: so, if you apply your selues to Gods ordinances, with all diligence and conscience, the old man shall soone cast his skinne, and you shall renew your life in some degree, which you receiued in your first creation.

Lastly, here is a word of comfort for all those Vse. 3 that find thēselues to be truly renued, with whom old things are past, and all things become new: they can remember, when it was much otherwise with them, then now it is. All these may boldly call God father, and say that they are in Christ: they may safely lay hold on this charter of the church, the new couenant, and pray with confidence, that that God would make it good vnto them by renuing them more and more. Onely, that none be mistaken in the matter, and so comfort themselues falsely, let them secure this maine point, that they are new creatures.
Now,Notes of new birth. there be two things that speake a man to be new. 1. The new birth. 2. New obedience. Try therefore whether, first, you be new-borne or not.
How shall that be knowne, may some say? Quest.

Answ. First, hee that is borne anew, hath a new taste, he beginnes to relish a new food. That note wee receiue from Saint Peter. 1 Pet 2.2. Expounded. 1. Epist. 2.2. As new-borne babes, saith he, desire the sincere milke of the Word, that yee may grow thereby. So soone as any one is borne anew, he is presently carryed to the food of Gods Word; as the childe is carryed by an instinct to the brest-milke, whereby his life is continued: that whereas hee could not brooke the good Word of God; the Bible seemed a dry booke vnto him, and things deliuered out of it in a plaine manner, he held harsh and vnpleasant, it would not downe with him, now it's become his milke, and he cleaues vnto it, as to a principle of his life, without which he cannot subsist.
Obiect. Oh, but an Hypocrite may desire the Word, and therefore this is no good euidence.

Sol.The Text puts a maine difference betweene them: 1. The godly man desires the Word, as the babe doth milke. How's that? hee desires it as his liuelihood, when hee is but new-borne, though afterwards, when hee is growne to some bignesse, hee is more play-full; euery small matter, euery little noyse will take him off, and make him neglect the brest: but when he is new-borne, nothing can giue him content, but milke, he preferres it aboue gold and siluer, and desires it more then all the world. In like manner, an Hypocrite may desire to heare the Word, to read the Word, while there's nothing to call him off, but when it comes to a matter of competition, that eyther he must follow the word, or his profits, lusts, &c.
hee lets it goe, that hee may satisfie them: but now a new creature esteemes the word, as his appointed food, he cannot liue without it, yea, he preferrs it aboue gold and siluer, or whateuer other thing hee holds dearer to himselfe in the world.

2. The new-borne babe desires the sincere Word of God, hee desires the Word, for the Word's sake, hee hath not an end beyond that end: and he desires the Word in the plainenesse of it, hee loues to heare the down-right naked truth, without any mixture, as the childe desires the mothers milke, as it is of it selfe, without sugar: that come naturally to it, and so is naturally desired of it: So here, the new creature, desires the Word for its naturall sweetnesse, and goodnesse, because it tends to the making of him better: Another man may desire to heare a Sermon for the neat composition, for the learning that is shewed in it, or for some other rarity, but not for the sincerity of it, because it chargeth him, and brings him to a better course of life.

3. The new-borne Babe desires it for good ends, that he may grow thereby in sauing goodnesse: Another man may desire the Word, that hee may get more knowledge, and grow in an ability to discourse of good things, that hee may be able to hold argument, or set forth himselfe to the commendation of men: but the new man desires it, that hee may grow in faith, that hee may grow in zeale, that hee may grow in mercy, and in all other parts and limbes of the new creature,
that there may be an vniforme, and vniuersall augmentation in the whole man. Thus you may know a new man by his food, which is the first note, hee desires the milke of the Word, the sincere milke, and therefore hee desires it, that hee may grow thereby.

Secondly, looke how you stand affected to your kindred. First, your heauenly father. 2. Your spirituall brethren. In euery generation there is a terme, to the which that which is generated is brought: and being one with it in nature, it becomes one with it likewise in affection: So hee that is borne anew, is brought home to God, and to all his people, so that he can weepe with them, bleed with them, suffer with them, reioyce with them, his very heart is tied to them. Try therefore by this, whether you are made partakers of the diuine nature, and borne a new, how stand you affected to God, in his nature, in his ordinances, in his children, &c.

Lastly, the new man is a strong man, the old man is weake and impotent, as yee heard before, but he that is renewed, is strengthened in the inward man, as saith the Apostle. Hence St. Iohn, so often in his first Epist. He that is borne of God, hath ouercome the world, and he that is of God, hath ouercome himselfe, is not ouercome of sinne, and again, he hath ouercome that euill one. These the new man so ouercomes, as that by them, hee is not ouercome. Now, in a conflict, hee is said to ouercome, that so holds out, as that hee is not ouercome. No more is the new man ouercome
of the world, of his owne corruptions, or of the temptations of Sathan, by vertue of this new strength and spirit put into him; this renders him victorious. Search into your selues now by these notes, whether ye are borne anew or not.

Secondly, he that will proue that he hath this new spirit, must inquire into this, and make it good that he hath a new life and conuersation: For, by Christ, we are brought not onely to a new birth, but to a new life, to new obedience. 1. When a man is once become a new man, hee proposes a new scope, a new end to himselfe in all hee does. Once indeed, hee onely studied himselfe, serued himselfe, did all in reference to his owne ends; but now he hath publike ayme (which he preferres before all priuate respects) euen the glory of God. 2. He walkes by a new rule. An old man makes reason, custome, the fashions of the world to be his rule: but no sooner is he renewed, but he makes the Word of God his rule, he squares out all his actions according to Gods Law, and so performes new works in a new manner, that is, 1. In humility. 2. In sincerity, with which two graces, when a mans obedience is attended, then it is new.
How shall I know that that I doe, is done in humility?

Thus: first, that which is begun in humility, wil also end in humility. A new man is most of al humbled by his best seruices; the more he praies, the more he heares, the more he reads, the more hee followes his calling, the more humble he is:
For, the more he deales in these things, the more he discernes still his own defects, & weaknes, and nothing more humbles a new man, then his ouer-slight and formall performance of holy seruices.

Secondly, when a man is humble, he will be thankefull, wondrous thankefull for this, that God would giue him a heart to serue him, and then accept of his poore and slender performances: See this in Dauid, Psal. 66.1, &c. Blessed be God, that hath not turned away my prayer, nor his mercy from me. And so when he and his people offered a present to God, how thankefull was hee, that God would looke vpon it and accept it: Lo, here the behauiour of a new man in his holy seruices: Contrarily, the old man, the more hee deales in any ordinance, the more hee swells, hee thinkes hee hath obliged and ingaged the Lord, by such seruice as hee hath performed vnto him, for fashion sake hee may thanke with the Pharisie, but indeed he looks that God should thanke him:
Quest. How shall I know, that what I doe, is done in sincerity?

Answ. For this, 1. See what you are in the maine bent, in the chiefe ayme of your life (for it is not what you are in particular actions one way or other, but what you are in the main course of your life) if your chiefe ayme in all be the glory of God, and your desire be in all things to please him, though in many things we faile (as all doe) your workes are done in sincerity. Secondly, looke what you are in your personall calling, and
particular relation: for such is euery man in truth, as hee is in his owne station, and as hee carries himselfe in that relation hee stands in toward others: if he hold not out there, he is in the same degree, but halting and hypocriticall, thogh he haere ten thousand Sermons, and make more prayers. Thirdly, he that is sincere in his wayes, desires nothing more then the light, as on the other side, he that doth euill, hateth the light, Iohn 3. that his workes may not be seene, but light and sincerity accord well together, and hee that is sound at heart, loues that his workes should be sifted and scanned by the light, because they are done in God, the more you represent him to himselfe, the more thanks he returnes to God; and you enquire now for this new spirit by your new obedience (for new sap will yeeld new fruits) and by this new birth, which if you finde in your selues, then conclude; God hath promised to giue his people a new heart, and I finde hee hath done it for me, and therefore I dare goe to him, as to a father, and boldly lay claime to the new Couenant vpon this new edition and stampe.

It followes now to speake of the third thing here promised by God, which is the highest degree of all, and that is, a soft heart, in these words: I will take the stony heart out of their flesh, and giue them an heart of flesh. And here two things offer themselues to our consideration.
First, how God findes the heart of his people,Mans naturall hardnesse scil. hard and stony: I will take the stony hearts.

Next, how he leaues it: of stony hee makes it
fleshie, of hard, soft and tender.
Wee beginne with the first of these: where you are to take notice in the first place, what the heart of euery man is by nature, hard as a stone.

p.hi: Euery man is naturally sicke of the stone, hee hath a stone gotten into his heart, into his spirit, into all his inward parts.
