div.p: That this is so, the Scripture abundantly testifieth, we will content our selues for proofe hereof with our present text, wherein mans heart is compared to a stone, to a rocke, and in other places to the hardest of stones, euen the Adamant which is vntameable, as the name imports, Zach. 7.2. and harder then flint it selfe, Ezek. 5.9. so that man you see now in his depraued estate hath a stone in his heart, and none other stone then an Adamant, the hardest of stones.

Nay, the holy Ghost stayes not there, but goes on to compare mans heart to mettals, that are harder then stone it selfe, Ier. 6.28. euen to brasse and yron, yea, to that which is worse, for brasse and yron may bee softned and wrought vpon by fire and tooles: but the Lord complaines there that hee had wasted and spent vp all his fuell, worne out his bellowes and spoiled all his tooles vpon them in seeking to doe them good, and all to no purpose. The bellowes art burnt, saith he, the lead is consumed of the fire: the founder melteth in vaine, for the wicked are not pluckt away, &c.

This appeares further by these signes and symptoms of a stone, within, that plainly shew themselues in the outward man. His neck is said to bee
possest with an yron sinew, and his brow to bee made of brasse, Esay 48.4. Because I knew that thou art hard, thy necke is an yron sinew, and thy brow brasse. The first of these is a metaphor from a sturdy oxe, or young bullocke, that should frame to the yoake, but will not bow, proues vntractable: and such is man, stubborne and refractory: when he should take the yoake of Christ vpon him, there is no bending, no bowing of him. But besides this yron sinew, the holy ghost tells vs he hath a brow of brasse, a brazen brow, a whores fore-head, as it is, Ierem. 3. In which there is no sense remaining, no feare, no blushing, but that is past shame, as it is said by two seuerall Prophets, Ieremy and Zephany,, The wicked knowes no shame, saith the one; he knowes not how to blush, saith the other.

This truth will yet further appeare, if we descend to speake of some particulars in man. Mark him a little, while we vnbowell him, and you shall see and finde him to be a very Rocke. Locke vpon him in the seuerall faculties of his soule, and (that we may beginne at vpper-end) first, his vnderstanding is a very stone, in respect of spirituall things, for howsoeuer, in things naturall, and pertaining to this present life, he hath some kinde of wit, and can shift for himselfe, yet in grace, and the things of God, he is a very stone, not in property of speech, I would not be so vnderstood, when I say, that man is by nature a stone, for there is the difference, that man is capable of being softned, which a stone is not, but I meane, that he is hard and stony, he hath too great affinity with
a stone: See this first, I say, in his vnderstanding part, how wondrous dull, and vnapprehensiue is he in the things of God. What paines doe Ministers take to beat something into mens heads? how doe they insist and dwell vpon a point? how doe they explaine and illustrate it by examples, comparisons, &c. studying euery way what they can to conuey themselues to their hearers, and yet when they haue done all that may be done, when they haue set things as it were in the sight of the Sunne, and made euery thing so plaine and euident, that he that runnes may read it, yet such a stone there is in mans heart, that they vnderstand nothing, but like the high-way, spoken of in the Gospell, by our Sauiour, their vnderstandings are so paued and hardned, that the things deliuered can take no entrance, make no impression vpon them: hence it is, that many a hearer liueth vnder a powerfull, and profitable ministry for many yeeres together, and yet vnderstands no more in the matters of God and his kingdomes, in the mystery of Christ and the Gospell, then if he had neuer heard a Sermon in all his life, here is a stone in the vnderstandings: So for the memory: Gods Mnisters to helpe men this way, and to fasten some good lessons vpon them, insist long vpon a point, and when that is done, they repeat it againe, goe ouer and ouer it often, laying downe line vpon line, precept vpon precept, here a little, and there a little: and all this with such power, and with such plainnesse, that one would wonder how it were possible for men to make a shift so soone to forget what hath
been deliuered, and yet they do: the word slides away from them as water vpon astone, no foot-step thereof remaines vpon them. The grauing toole neuer once enters them, &c. They will sit vnder a Minister, and look him in the face for an houre together, as if nothing should fall to the ground of that which is deliuered, and yet take them at the Church-doore as they go out, and question them what matter was deliuered, what Text handled, what points raised out of it, &c. you shal find them not able to giue an account of any thing that was deliuered. Lo, there is a stone in the memory.

Passe we on from the memory, to the heart, and will of man: what paines doth God take with men to bring them to new obedience, and to weane them from their sinnes? one while hee deales with them by precepts, another while by threats, sometimes by promises of mercy, and sometimes by iudgements, euery stone is rolled, euery meanes vsed, and euery course taken by God to do them good, but all to no purpose: For, men in the meane while remaine obstinate and vnmoueable; if one would speake out his heart to them, hee cannot speake sinne from their soules: but naught they were heretofore, naught they are now, and as naught they intend to continue, in spite of all that can be said to the contrary. Here is now a stone in the will. So, come we on to mens affections: There is enough said many times by Gods Ministers to worke vpon a rocke, to rent and cleaue the mountaines, &c. to moue and affect any reasonable creature, and yet men goe on in
their sinnes without feare, without shame, without any token of remorse, as if it nothing concerned them, and as if it were not spoken vnto them at all. Here is a stone in the affection, wee had almost forgot that high power of the soule, mans conscience: For there is a stone in that too. God often thunders vpon it by his Ministers, speakes not words, but swords vnto it, threatēs it with deaths, hells, &c. throwes handfulls of hell-fire in mens faces; but what doe they the while? they stand altogether fearelesse, carelesse, remorselesse, set a good face vpon it, as if they were the most innocent persons in the world: nay, you shall haue an honest godly man, whom it least of all concernes, tremble at Gods word, stand amazed and affrighted at that which is deliuered, as knowing the terrours of the Lord, when wicked and gracelesse persons take no notice of any thing, but carry themselues, as if it imported not them at all, when God bends all his ordinances against them, and batters them most fearefully: See, heere a stone also, euen in the conscience. Insteed of prouing the point, wee will for present open vnto you: 1. what is meant by heart in this Text? 2. what, by a stony heart? 3. how many kindes there are of an hard heart. 4. what are the signes of it.

For the first: heart, or spirit (all is one, as hath beene said before, they are vsed promiscuously for the same thing) Indeed heart is taken sometimes particularly for the will of man, namely, when it goes ioyned with some other word of like signification, as minde, soule, &c. sometimes againe,
it is taken for the whole inside of a man, and so here in the Text. All the powers and faculties of the soule are hardned are peruerted, dead and dull in respect of any spirituall goodnesse: his vnderstanding is darkened, his will froward, his conscience brawney, &c. all is stony that is within him.

The second thing is, what is meant by a stony heart? This implyeth two things: 1. A quality, hardnesse. Durum est, quod non cedit tactui; That is hard (in a naturall sense) that yeelds not to any impression, or naturall Agent, that will not yeeld vnder your hand, but makes head and resistance. In a spirituall sense, the heart is said to be hard, when it yeelds not to the perswasion of a morall agent, that refuseth to be wrought vpon, when God deales with it eyther by himselfe, or by an instrument. 2. The degree of this hardnesse, it is hard, euen vnto stoninesse, which implyeth two things: First, a non-yeeldancc (as I may so speake) to goodnesse. Secondly, a stiffe resistance: as in hard wood, that when a man comes to cleaue it, will not yeeld to the stroke, but returnes the edge of your toole vpon your selfe: So when one beats vpon a hard stone, vpon a flint or adamant, there is no yeeldance, but the weapen recoyles vpon a man with a great deale of indignation, as it were. So then you see what is meant by hard, and what by stony. A heart of stone then is nothing else, but an vntractable heart, an vntamed heart, a heart disposed to resist but disposed to yeeld.

Thirdly, for the kinds of it: there is first a naturall
hardnesse, common to all the sonnes and daughters of Adam; this we bring into the world with vs: for wee are all borne with a stone in our hearts, it is our naturall temper to be hard. Secondly, a contracted hardnesse; contracted, I say, by much practice and in long time, (for though the heart of euery man be hard of it self, yet it may be made harder by long custome in sin) when men by foule courses, put out quite that small light that is left in their natures, and doe obstinate themselues by continuance in sinne. Both these kinds of hardnesse may be well included in this Text (for it is God that cures his people of them both) but the former, I take it, is here principally to be vnderstood, yet, so as that wee exclude not the other.

Signes of a stony heart.Fourthly, the signes of this hardnesse, are of two sorts: First, negatiue; Secondly, positiue. The negatiue signes are: First, vnteachablenesse. Secondly, vnsensiblenesse. Thirdly, inflexiblenesse:

For the first, man is naturally vntractable to any spirituall good thing: Hence it is that he is compared to a very beast: Euery man is a beast in his owne vnderstanding, saith Ieremy: yea, to the worst of beasts is he compared: For, vaine man would be wise, though man be borne like a wilde Asses Colt, Iob 11.12. which is a most vnruly, and vntractable kinde of creature, as is well knowne. Yea, the holy Ghost sets man behinde the beasts, Esa. 1. The oxe knoweth his owner, and the Asse his Masters Cribbe, but my people haue not knowne, &c. And the Sluggard is put ouer to the Pismire to be instructed, Pro. 6. So dull, so slow of vnderstanding,
and so exceeding blockish is the naturall man in the things of God, that he is put to schoole to the vnreasonable creatures.

Secondly, as hee is vnteachable, so hee is insensible, and that argues a daele of hardnesse, as is to bee seene in a stone, smite it while you will, beate it as long as you can stand ouer it, it complaines not; lay a mountaine vpon it, it neuer groanes or cries, and grind it to powder, out of the pressure: and so it is with an vnregenerate man, let a mountaine of sinne, let a world of guilt lye vpon his soule, hee feeles it not, hee groanes not vnder it; Sin is in him, as an element in its owne place, and so weyghes not with him, he sleepes, he eates, he drinks, he laughes and enioyes himselfe, as if the matter were nothing so, he goes merrily to execution, and dreads no danger, no more then if hee were as much reconciled to God, as any man liuing; when he sweares he perceiues it not, a stander by is farre more sensible of his outrages this way, and is more grieued thereat many times then he himselfe is, yea, if you offer to charge him with his sin, he wil not stick to sweare again, that he swore not at all: so for lies, they drop from him thick and three-fold, as they say, but he obserues it not: so for the poore, hee can behold their eyes weeping, their toungs crauing, their very faces begging, themselues ready to sinke vnder the burthen of their wants & necessities, but all is one to him, if he may sit warme, and haue euery thing about him, if he may eat of the fat, and drink of the sweet, &c. let other sinke or swim, he cares not.

And so it is with him for spirituall physicke: God giues vnto the sonnes of men, his powerfull word to be as a hammer to breake them, and as fire to melt their stony hearts (as the Scripture termes it) this he heares daily,Ierem. 3. but continues still at a point, no whit bettered: God threatens him one while, perswades him another while, but all is one, hee stirres not a whit, say what you will, doe what you can to him, hee feeles nothing, feares nothing, &c. here is a stone.

A third signe of a stony heart, is inflexiblenesse. A stone cannot bend; breake it you may, bend it you cannot, and so it fares with him that is of a stony heart, he will not bend or bow to God; let God say or doe whateuer hee can that is fit to be done to a reasonable creature, hee is no whit moued therewith. If a man goe about to make an oration to a stone, let it be neuer so pithy a speech, let it be neuer so patheticall or perswasiue, the stone heares it not, neyther is affected therewith: breake it you may by strokes and blowes into many pieces, but yet euery piece remaines a stone still: so let God vse all meanes possible for the reducing of wicked men, let him perswade them, let him threaten them, let him smite and beat them all to pieces, all is as nothing to them: no instructions, no corrections, no meanes, no mercies will worke vpon them: stones they were, and so they will be still. Oh rocky hearts! when nothing will preuaile with them, when nothing will be of force to make them better.

2 Possitiue signes of harnesse.These now are the negatiue notes of a stony
heart: The possitiue follow, and they are these:

First, stifnesse and wilfulnesse in opinion. A stone will continue still like it selfe, talke while you will to it; and so those that haue a stone in their hearts, will needes hold fast their owne conclusions, yea, they will dye, rather then alter their opinions which they haue once taken vpon them to defend: as was to be seen in many of the ancient heretikes, who though they were so plainely conuinced out of the Word of God, and by sound arguments drawne out of the same, so that they had nothing to oppose or contradict, yet so stiffe they were in the defence of their hereticall opinions, that they would rather dye, then be drawne to re-call them.

Secondly, obstinacy and setlednesse in euill practices, when men shall be of their humour, who answered the Propet peremptorily: The word that thou speakest vnto vs in the name of the Lord, wee will not doe it: So when a man is come to this passe, as to conclude with himselfe, I will giue these preachers the hearing, but neuer be brought to leaue my sinne, and to lead so strict a life as they would haue it: they shall neuer make me so very a foole, as to be ruled by them: when a man, I say, is set in his sinfull courses, and will not be remoued; when he hath once made his conclusion, and is as good as hee meanes to be: heere is a stone.

Thirdly, a gaine-saying and contradicting spirit: such as was in the Pharisies: Christ could no sooner propound a truth, but they were cauilling and thwarting him presently: so when men will be fighting against the light that shines in their
faces, when they will be euer obiecting and quarrelling with truths deliuered, they haue somewhat to say against euery thing they heare: no man can tell how to speake to them, but they will fide one exception, one flaw or other with the Preacher; let him bring neuer so sound reasons for what hee deliuereth, they will returne them backe againe in our faces, with a great deale of violence, &. This argues the stone.

Lastly, an easinesse to yeeld, in case a sinfull motion be set afoot, this shewes a stone in the heart: For, euer the softest hearts, are stoutest in standing against motions to euill, as on the other side, those that are hardest of all, are most facile, waxy and yeelding in wicked businesses, you may draw them whither you will by a twined threed; doe but hold vp the finger, and they will be with you streight, &c. This note the Apostle giues vs, Rom. 2.8. They do not obey the truth, but are contentious, impatient, &c. but they obey vnrighteousnesse: Their lusts shall command them, Satan and his instruments shall command them any thing, when God can haue no command at all: So gentle they are, so courteous, so kinde, so good when it comes to a sinfull motion: But, to doe that which is good, all the men, and all the meanes in the world cannot preuaile with them, &c. These be notes of a stony heart.

WE are now vpon the last blessing here promised, & that is a soft and tender heart: where two things come to be considered; first, what mans heart is in and of it selfe; it is an heart of stone. Secondly, what the Lord vndertakes it shall be, namely an heart of flesh.
For the first of these, ye haue receiued the point already, to wit:

p.hi: That euery man hath naturally a hard and stony heart within him.

div.p: Man is to be considered in a threefold estate. 1. as created. 2. as degenerated. 3. as regenerated: we consider him now only in his depraued estate, as he is since the fall: and so, his heart is hard and stony. This point we haue proued by Scriptures, and made good by instance through the seuerall faculties of mans soule.

And the reason is taken from mans fall in Adam whereby he be came depriued of all spirituall life, Reas. and so consequently of all motion and sense in the matters of God, wherein he is altogether stony and sensles.

For vse: It may serue in the first place to teach vs not to wonder that so many sermons are lost, so, Vse, 1 many Sacraments spilt (as I may so speake) so many wholesome instructions cast away in a manner, so many corrections wasted in vaine vpon the sonnes of men, that so many words and blowes work no
more good vpon them: wonder not at this, I say, for what wonder is it to see a stone hard and inflexible, rather let vs wonder at our selues, and at that fearefull hardnes that by our sinnes wee haue contracted, and so cry out of our selues as that holy man in the Prouerbs, surely I am more brutish then any man, and haue not the vnderstanding of a man: surely I haue not the nature of a man, but a very stone within my bosome. Oh what a dull creature am I, that God should take such paines to teach me, laying downe line vpon line, Precept vpon precept, here a little, and there a little, that I might learne somewhat at least, and yet I remaine ignorant and vnskilfull in the mysteries of saluation? how blockish & vncapable am I, that can let go the good things that are taught me as fast and assoone as I heare them? I haue heard many a chapter expounded, many a Sermon preached, haue had many a medicine applyed vnto me, and yet I remaine in my sinnes, no whit wrought vpon or bettered therby, what a wicked froward nature haue I, that I can no sooner heare of a dutie to be done by me, but I haue somewhat to obiect against it straight: no sooner can a Precept come forth from God, but I haue a disposition in me to rise against it and oppose to it: being therfore ready to shew my dislike of a thing, because God commends it, and againe, therfore to approue and practise a thing because God forbidds it, neither fearing nor feeling any thing of all that God speakes or does to me, being as a very stone in respect of mine owne apprehension of things, &c.

And on the other side bee moued to wonder as much at Gods merciful patience and forbearance towards vs, that makes no end of waiting vpon vs, and expecting our returne. It is not so betwixt man and man, as betwixt God and man; we had need shew mercy & euen lend patience to others, because we stand in need of mercy, and must borrow it of others, and yet how little patience doe we shew to those we deale withall? If a man haue taken a prentice that is not apt and able to take to his trade away with him presently, wee will bee troubled no longer with him, so if one hath a scholer that proues dull and vncapable, he bethinkes himselfe presently how to put him off, and rid his hand of him: yea if one hath but a beast that is vnruly and will not be seruiceable, he will not bestow keeping of him: How gracious is God then, iudge you, that beares with vs so much, and exerciseth so large and long a patience toward vs? first he giues vs precepts, and then waites how they will worke with vs: then he giues vs promises, and after this threates and then promises, and then corrections, trying what will be the issue of it. In a word, he leaues no meanes vnused, no course vnattempted, no stone vnrolled, that hee may remoue & roll away this stone in our hearts; oh the wonderfull patience of God, that will beare with such crooked and vntractable creatures as we are! oh his infinite goodnes and mercy, that he will not be wearied, that he will not suffer himselfe to be ouercome of our badnes, but will thus ouercome euill with good!

Vse. 2 Againe, Is it so that euery man by nature is of a hard and stony spirit? Let those then, that are yet in their naturall estate, be admonished not to adde hard to hard, but to take som course to rid their hearts of this dismal disease. It is certaine, you haue the stone in the heart, euery mothers child of you: Be aduised therefore (for helpe) to doe as one would doe that laboures with that fearefull disease, the stone in the reynes or bladder. First, such a one will take heed of the matter that feedes and increaseth it,1. Remoue matter of the stone. hee will abstaine from whatsoeuer he can heare will breed or greaten the stone. 2. he will hearken after and apply himselfelfe to the vse of those meanes and medicines that are good against it.

And so must men deale in this sicknesse of the soule, this stone of the heart: First you must shun all sin, which is that that breedes and feedes this disease: for sin is of an hardning nature; it blinds the mind, hardens the heart, deadens the spirit, benummes the conscience of a man. This is the property of euery sinne, but especially of these fundamentall sins, as we may call them (which wee must therefore with so much the more care and diligence shun and avoid) Hypocrisie, vnbeliefe, Pride, and the like, all these are great hardners.

For pride, you may see it in Nebuchadnezzar, Dan. 5.20. whose heart was lifted vp, and his minde hardned in pride, as the Prophet tells Belshazzar. And the wicked, saith Dauid, is so carried away with pride and selfe-loue, that he blessed himselfe in wayes to be abhorred.

And what we say for pride, the same is true also of vnbeliefe, according to that of the Apostle, Take heed lest there be in any of you an euill heart of vnbeliefe to depart away from the liuing God. Heb. 3. Vnbeliefe in time will make one a very Atheist, not to feare any thing at all, God or deuill, Heauen or hell. The like we may say of Hypocrisie, which makes one first to dissemble with men, and then to halt with God, and lastly to deceiue his own selfe, as you may see in the Pharisees: what a measure of hardnes grew they to by long trading in this sin of hypocrisie!

But much more true is this of Impenitency in euill courses, whereof the Apostle to the Heb. Take heed, saith he, lest by refusing to make vse of the present day, you come to be hardned by the deceitfulnes of sinne Heb. 3.13. And this we see verified in common experience, when a man first ventures vpon sinfull courses, he sweates, he starts he trembles, he thinkes he shal to hel presently: wheras after he hath traded a while in his sinnes, such a senselesnes and carelessnes seizeth vpon him, that hee feeles nothing, feares nothing: such a deceiueablenes there is in sinne, as saith the Apostle. Take heed therefore of this matter of the stone in the heart, this fuell that feedes it, suffer it not to lodge with you at any time, creepe in it will, you cannot preuent it, but then see that you shut it out of your hearts againe by head and shoulders, bee sure you sleepe not in sinne: for it is the nature of it to deaden first, and to harden afterwards.

And what we say of sinne, is true of sinners also
(another matter that helpes forward this stone in the heart) there is a transforming power in wicked company, to make those like them that doe conuerse with them: See it in the Galatians, O yee foolish Galatians, saith the Apostle, who hath bewitched you? why, how were they bewitched, but by the enticing, flattering and perswading spirits of impostors that beguiled them: If a man will sort himselfe with the mockers of iniquity, they will finde, and vse such words to hearten him on to the committing of sin, and when he hath done, to confirme him in it, that hee shall not be able to command himselfe. We see thus much by experience: let a man that is not wōted or accustomed to such wicked practices, come in amongst a company of prophane sweares, heare their oaths, and see their desperate behauiour, he trembles, he quakes to heare and see such things, he euen thinks the very ground will sink vnder him, &c. But, let this man keepe them company a while, let him heare them swear ouer their oaths, a day or two together, and he will away with them wel enough, he heares not their blasphemies, sees not their wickednesses, but can comply with them, and be as bad as they.

Besides all this, their euill pretences and pleas, they will bring for their sinne, as that a great sinne is but a small, and a small sinne no sinne, that God is mercifull, and the way to heauen not so hard and troublesome, &c. together with their euill example, their liuing and dying in such lewd and lawlesse courses, all these things do wonderfully harden, and must therfore be heedfully auoided.

Hauing thus taken heede of the matter of your disease, you must in the next place come on to vse such means & medicines as are prescribed by God for the cure of it. And here, first, take notice of the misery of your naturall condition, that you are euery one of you sicke of the stone in the heart; and therfore, as the Leper in the law was appointed to cry out, I am a Leper, I am a Leper, and so to make himselfe sensible of his stroke, so must euery one of vs of this malady of our soules, taking vnto vs words, and sayng, oh my naturall hardnes, and vntractablenes. Oh what a rock of flint do I feele in mine own soule! this you must learn to see by your selues, & see it you may, if by nothing else, yet by your not seeing of it, feele it by your not feeling of it: for, there is not a surer signe, that a man is wondrous farre gone in this disease, then not to be sensible of his hardnesse. This being done, then as one that is told by his Physitian, that hee hath a stone growing vpon him in his body, he trembles and shiuers at the hearing of it, and enquires presently what is best to be done, is willing to learne what dyet to vse, and what to refuse, hee will be content to doe any thing, or shunne any thing that hee thinkes may proue hurtfull: so must you doe, enquire fo a Physician first, that can doe a cure vpon your soules, that can draw this stone in the heart from you: Now this is God alone, as hee here promiseth: I will take the stony heart out of their flesh, and I will giue them an heart of flesh. It is proper to God to doe this, it is his sole worke, To him therefore must you haue recourse, for recouery,
apply your selues diligently to the vse of all his meanes, for all his medicines are curing. It is not an hayre-cloth, or a chamber of meditation, or any such thing, that can cure a man of this stone in the heart, but Gods reasons, Gods arguments, Gods shewing of himselfe to a man that will mollifie and melt his heart. Be content therefore to vse such meanes as God hath appointed for such a purpose, vse them. I say, and vse them thorowly, let them haue their perfect worke vpon you, if you intend they shall doe you good. When a man findes indeed that he hath a stone in his bladder, or reynes, hee will not refuse to vndergoe any manner of hardship, so hee may be freed of it, though it be to be bound hand and soot, to haue an incision made into his body, &c. He will submit to any dyet, suffer a great deale of misery and torment, so hee may be cured: So must wee here, be content to haue Gods plough goe vpon vs, to vndergoe cutting, launcing, searing, &c. Let God chide vs, threaten vs, bruise vs, breake vs by afflictions, let him vse all his instruments, as it were, let him practise all his medicines vpon vs to get out this stone of our hearts. And if we thus apply our selues to his means, God is both able and willing (for it is his couenant here you see) to take the stone out of our hearts.
Vse. 3 Next, for those that finde themselues in some good measure softned and cured of their naturall hardnesse; these must learne two lessons.
First, how to beare themselues toward God, when they feele in themselues some softning.
Secondly, what to doe in case their former hardnesse returne vpon them againe.

For the former of these, it stands you vpon to beware how you carry your selues, that you harden not againe, which you may easily doe, if you be not the more carefull. For hardnesse, you see, is naturall to vs all, and that which is naturall, is wondrous apt to recurre & to recoyle vpon vs againe, though' it be beaten backe by violence; as on the otherside, that which is aboue nature, is difficult, and requires great diligence for the retaining of it. A bow hath not that bent, that kind of posture of it selfe, but is brought to it: therfore slack the string neuer so little, & it wil soon return to its former straightnes: So likwise, water, the natural property of it you know, is not heat but cold, and therfore do but slak & withdraw the fire from it a little, and it wil returne to its former coldnes.

And so it is with the heart of man: softnes, you heare, is not the naturall property of it but the contrary, and therfore when you feele your selues made tender in any degree, you had need be wonderous carefull, for els you will be apt relapse to fall & off againe to your former hardnes of heart.

Why, but may some say, God saith here, that he will take out the stone, and if he once free vs from it, we are perfectly cured of this disease. It is true that is obiected, that it is God, that both vndertakes and also performes the cure of mans heart, but this he doth in a degree here, not in perfection, and by degrees also he doth it, and not altoge •• er, but by little and little at once. The
heart of man retaines som dregs still of its old disease, euen after the cure is begun vpon it, which are ap • to congeale, and gather hardnes again; like as one that hath been cut off the stone, if he be not the more carefull and obseruant of himselfe, afterwards he may quickly cōtract another stone in his body, as being naturally inclined to it: so if a man be not wonderous wise and chary, this hardnes of his heart will soone grow vpon him againe. And this euery christian finds himselfe too too true by himselfe: sometimes one findes himselfe softned, and in very good temper of soule, but soone after, through his carefulnes and disorder he beginnes to freeze againe and gather hardnes: sometimes euen a good Christian comes to that passe, that he is so lazy, so listles, and so neutrall, as it were, that he cares not for, the time which end goes forwards; he hath no great feeling of his sinnes, no great affection to God or goodnes, hee cares not for it, he desires not after it. It fares with him now as with one that hath taken cold, he eates & drinks indeed, but he hath little or no appetite to it: and finds as little tast or sweetnes in it: So many a good christian when he remits of his diligence, & so takes cold as it were, he reades indeed, and prayes, and performeth other holy dutyes, but it is because he dare no otherwise, and not for any great desire he finds to them, or delight, he feeles in them.

Againe, it may so fall out that a Christian may commit some foule sinne, whereby hee receiues such a knock, such a wound that for the present he lyes for dead, as Bernard speakes concerning
Dauid, who otherwise was a man of very a soft and tender heart, & yet by falling into those grosse sins of adultery and murder, such a crustines for the time came ouer his heart, that he had no feeling of himselfe, and though he heard the Word of God daily by the Prophets, yet it had little or no work vpon his soule. And this may befall the best of Gods people.

Yea, he may goe so far this way as that he may grow froward and peeuish against God and his Ordinances, so that no Preacher can please him: no man can tell how to apply the medicine to him, but this is naught & that is naught, and somwhat he hath to say against euery medicine, and euery Physician too. Thus it fared sometimes with Asa, a godly man, and yet know how he pursued the Preacher that dealt roundly with him, and told him of his sinne. Now therfore sith Gods owne seruants may be thus far left to themselues and hardned, giue vs leaue to put the point vpon you all, and thereby to exhort you to vse speciall care and diligence to keepe your hearts vnbound, as it were, and open, lest by any meanes you should fal backe to your former hardnes. And to this end apply your selues conscionably to those former meanes and medicines: and especially keepe strict watch and ward against sin, euen against your present daily sinnes, your sinnes after profession. A Christian in his first conuersion takes leaue of all foule and euormous sinnes, which in his state of vnregeneracy, were wont to be familiar to him, but yet there be some other sins of lesse note, that
doe follow him close, and wherewith he is pestered and hampered all the daies of his life, such as are formality and customarinesse in holy duties, satiety in grace and goodnesse, a kinde of security and retchlessenesse, a kinde of lazinesse, and listlessenesse, that he cares not greatly how things goe with him, or what become of himselfe. Against these and such like corruptions, and weakenesses, you must remember to keepe constant watch and ward, that they get not into you, at least, that they lodge not, nestle not in your hearts.

Secondly, to preuent this fore-mentioned mischiefe, you must vse conscionably all Gods ordinances: for as sinne is of an hardning property, so euery ordinance of God is softning: the Word softens, the Sacrament softens, prayer melts and softens, conference softens, selfe-examination softens, all Gods ordinances tend to softnesse: therefore vse them all: and vse them first timely, secondly constantly, thirdly conscionably.

First, as soone as euer you finde any hardnesse to grow vpon you, meete it vpon the way, and withstand it in the causes of it for this end, be not strangers at home, but euer and anon, deale with your owne hearts; search your selues euery night, and againe in the morning, and so take notice of this hardnesse, when it first pryeth vpon you. A candle, you know, that is suddenly blowne out, wil as suddenly be blowne in againe, if taken presently, but if you let it alone a while, and suffer it to dye by little and little, the light will not be recouered againe, till brought to a fire, or some new light:
And so it is with our hearts, if we take them timely, they will be brought againe to their wonted softnesse, the more easily; you may see it in the ice, if it be taken as soone as it is congealed and frozen, you may breake it with little adoe, but let it alone a weeke or two, and it growes so hard, that you may goe ouer it with a horse: And so it is with our hearts, they contract hardnesse, by letting them runne long vnlooked vnto. It shall be our wisedome therefore, to preuent this hardnesse of heart in the causes of it: For, as in bodily sicknesses there are certaine fore-runners of it: a kinde of lassitude and wearinesse, a kinde of satiety and fulnesse, which doe plainly foreshew that sicknesse is at hand: so it is in the soule; when men grow carelesse and listlesse, they are as good as they desire to be, they are full, and want nothing, &c. this signifies that men are growing into this stone of the heart: take heede therefore, and preuent this euill betimes, in the very causes of it.

Next, you must vse all Gods ordinances constantly, or else it will be to little purpose. If water haue not a constant fire kept vnder it, it will soone returne to its owne coldnesse, and will be harder frozen then if it had neuer felt the fire. Wax must be chafed and tempered betweene your fingers, if you meane to set an impression vpon it: and if you continue not to temper it, it will be hard againe neuerthelesse, and so it is with our hearts: therefore vse the meanes of grace constantly, doe it day by day, estrange not your selues from God, by intermission of holy duties: There is neuer a
Christian here in the Church, but can beare witnesse to this, that disuse and neglect of prayer, reading, meditation, &c. but a day or two, causeth a hardnesse vpon the heart, and disableth them to the doing of those duties another time; so that the longer he fasts, the longer he may, the longer he absents himselfe from God, the more strange he growes vnto him, and the lesse apt to come before him another time: Take heed therefore, that you lessen not your acquaintance with God by a voluntary estrangement, but be euery day dealing and takings paines with your owne hearts to keep them in good case and order.

Lastly, vse Gods medicines conscionably and diligently. There is nothing more hardens a Christians heart, then an ouer-slight and customary performance of religious duties: when hee doth holy duties, not out of loue to them, or delight in them, but because he hath taken vp such a thing for a custome, or he hath set himselfe a taske, so much hee will doe, because hee dares doe no otherwise, &c. This is a great meanes to harden the heart. Here therefore in vsing of Gods ordinances, you must doe, as when you haue taken physicke, trauell with it, worke with it, giue it all the furtherance you can: so must you doe in taking this spirituall physicke, bee industrious and assiduous in the vse of it; for assiduity, here, is all in all. It is not with the heart, as it is with other ordinary businesses: Those lands that you haue ploughed, to day, or heretofore, yee finde them ready ploughed as you left them, when you come to them next,
but it is not so with the soule: but after that a Christian hath bin at great paines to set all strait within, the diuel comes & puls down all, and puts all againe quite out of order; you husbandmen vse to say, that your worke is neuer at an end: For, first, the good husband fallowes his grounds, and then he stirres it, and then hee sowes it, and then he harrowes, then he clods it, if neede be, then he ralles it, and then hee weedes it, and after hee hath got in his crop, he begins againe, as before, and so goes round in a circle. And so it is with a Christian in husbanding, and manuring this little piece, the heart, it must neuer be neglected, but kept continually in vre, in case you meane to haue any good of it: well, but say these medicines come too late, my heart is already re-hardned.

The question is, what I shall doe in such a case? this is a hard case indeed, when a man is ouertaken by a recidiuation, and seized vpon by a second hardnesse. Naturall tempers and distempers are very hardly remoued. It is a matter of difficulty, to get hardnesse out of yron, because it is naturally hard, to lift a stone from the ground, because it is its center: So the heart of man is euen the center of hardnesse, and hee must lift hard that would get it out.
What is to be done then, may some say, Quest. in this case: First, you must vse your best skill. 2. Answ. Put to your best diligence for the effecting of this businesse.

First, it is required that you vse more then ordinary skill, and 1. To finde out your disease in the
causes of it, whence it ariseth. It may be you were too well conceited of your selfe, or carnally secure, or negligent in the vse of the meanes of likelinesse, or some worldly matter comes betweene that Sunne-shine of Gods fauour, that liuely influence of his louing countenance and your soule, so that God cōming not to you in the testimonies of his grace and fauour, you freeze and harden againe. Labor to find out the cause of your distemper, and then striue to get cure of it, whether it be worldlinesse carelessenesse, ouerlinesse, or the like.

Secondly, you must shew your skill, in taking the fittest times, in making choice of the meetest season for recouery of this relapse: Now the fittest time is alwayes Gods time, then when hee shewes himselfe ready to comply, and set in with you: when he giues an hint, it shall be your wisedome to lay hold on it; you know, for the taking of bodily physicke, all times are not alike, but there is a season, when it will worke best with a man, and doe him most good: And so it is for the soule, in vsing Gods medicines, be sure you pitch vpon the fittest seasons. Sometimes God awakes men with dreames & visions in the night, sometimes hee fills their consciences with feares and terrors: sometimes hee makes breach vpon breach vpon them, by crosses and afflictions: sometimes he warnes and prepares their hearts by some good booke, or powerfull Sermon. Now, when God, by all or any of these meanes shall affect your hearts, and make them yeelding, be sure you strike while the yron is hot, and after a
showre of raine, put in the plough: when God hath once begunne to melt, breake, humble your hearts by any occasion, improue that time for your best aduantage, by laying hold on the present opportunity, &c.

Thirdly, you must shew your skill in making vse of the fittest medicines. All physicke, you know, workes not alike, nor agrees with all bodies, some require more gentle potions, other more violent, if the disease shall be remoued: And so it is likewise with the soules of men. Here therefore you must diligētly obserue, what reason, what Arguments, what Scriptures, what Ordinances doe most of all affect you, and to them especially apply your selues. Euery man must in this case be his owne Physician, and make vse of that meanes that hee findes most beneficiall to himselfe. Generally, and for most part, Arguments drawne from the mercy and kindnesse of God, doe most of all melt, and worke vpon the hearts of men. Hard to hard, you know, seldome yeelds, but lay hard to soft, as a flint vpon a featherbed, and it will the sooner be broken to pieces: So when men set themselues to consider seriously of the singular mercies of God, of the meeknesse of Christ, of the incomprehensible, patience of the Almighty, this, this, if any thing will melt and mollifie their hard and frozen hearts, and make them to fall asunder, in their bosomes like drops of water. Haile and snow falling vpon the hard ice will neuer melt it: but if the Sun once send forth his refreshing rayes, and sweetly smile vpon it, it will soone be dissolued
by its warmth and kindnes; so if when a man finds his heart to be frozen, he feedes his meditations with the consideration of Gods mercy and louing kindnes, it will soone thaw and become soft and pliant.

But secondly, as you must shew your skill in this case of relapse, so you must vse all care and diligence for your recouery out of it: be more earnest in the vse of the meanes, complaine more against your selfe, take notice of, and bitterly bewaile the want of your former softnes, cry out and say, Oh what an vnhappy creature am I, that am thus fallen into this wretched hardnes by mine owne sloth and remissenes! Oh what a good state was I once in? Once the Word was more sweet vnto mee than mine appointed food, but now I find no good rellish in it, no desire after it: once the promises did wonderfully take and affect me: once the meditations of Gods mercy and loue would haue dissolued me into teares, &c; but now, alas, for my misery, I am growne to that hardnes that nothing stirs me, nothing works vpon me. Thus hauing seene from whence you are fallen; in the next place repent of your relapse (as the Lord counseleth the declined church of Ephesus) and doe your first works: Reuel. 3. pray as you were vsed to doe, reade as you were vsed to doe, conferre and meditate as you were vsed to doe, vse all Gods Ordinances heartily, earnestly; and if you finde your selues too weake and vnable to compasse your desired tendernes of heart, then cal in the helpe of others, do herin as the smith do when he hath a very
hard peice of yron to hammer & work vpon, if by his owne strength he cannot master it, he calles in his friends, he calles in his men to assist him: he smites, they smite, and so by often iterating blow against blow, the worke is finished: In like sort, when you desire to subdue your yron hearts, to your owne strength, adde the aide of others, craue helpe of your friends, helpe of your Ministers, &c; you shall easiely find, that all you can doe, will be but little enough to recouer a heart, the second time hard and frozen.

Comfort to all such as finde by experience a Vse. 4 wonderfull change and alteration wrought in themselues this way, that can vpon good proofe assure themselues, that they are healed of the stone in the heart. It is a wonderfull mercy of God for a man to be freed of the stone in the bladder, to haue that remoued; but to haue the stony heart taken out of his flesh, and insteed thereof a heart of flesh, this argues an Almighty Power put forth for the effecting of this happy cure; surely the finger of God is here, you may safely conclude it, for none could possibly doe it but he. Doest thou then feele the burden of thy sinnes? art thou sensible of the least sinne? feelest thou Gods authority in the vse of his ordinances? hast thou a simpathy and fellow feeling of the miseries of the distressed Saints? canst thou bleed with them, mourne with them, weepe ouer them, &c? This argues a soft heart, & that is a sensible heart. A thing that is soft and tender will easiely feele the least pricke of a pinne, &c: which is not so
with things hard and obdurate. So here, those things that other men ieare at, and make a toy of (as it is a pastime to a foole to do wickedly) driue him to God, fill his eyes with teares, his mouth with complaints, &c. Yea, he is sensible of other mens miseries, by the most part little regarded, &c. Doe you finde it to be thus with your selues, as hath beene deliuered? Oh blesse God for this great cure wrought vpon your hearts, now mollified by the oyle of his grace, and with all thankfulnesse acknowledge, that it is hee, and he alone, that hath done it.

But heere, because many deceiue their owne soules, with a false perswasion, that their hearts are softned by God, because they finde in themselues some kinde of softnesse; wee should shew you the seuerall sorts of softnesse, together with their differences: but this would take vp a longer time then is now permitted. And therefore wee reiourne the more full handling of these things, till a more conuenient season.

Onely this, (for the occasion) wee would speak as an addition to a former vse, as concerning the great scarcity and derth so much complained of amongst vs: Take notice of Gods iustice herein and sanctifie him in all his proceedings, laying the blame wholly vpon your selues. These are hard times (it is in euery mans mouth) and euery thing goes hard, hard: And whence is this, trow you? but from the inward hardnesse of euery mans bosome. Therefore if you would that things should mend with vs, you must euery man get the stone
stone out of his owne heart. It is not so much the harnesse of other mens hearts, that maketh things to be at these high rates with vs, but the plague of our owne hearts, as Salomon speaketh in his Prayer, 1 Kings 6. Therefore labour to be more melting and yeelding to Gods authority, more sensible of his hand, more pittifull and compassionate to those that are poore and necessitous, looke about you euery way, and see heere a pale face, there a naked backe, a hungry belly, &c. and stretch out your hand to their reliefe and comfort. Yea, let euer one of vs confesse and say; It is euen iust with God, thus to distresse and plague vs, that hee should make the heauens ouer vs to be brasse, and the earth vnder vs to be yron, as he hath threatned, because our hearts are so hard and brazen, &c. In a word, get a pittifull heart, to helpe them that be in neede; and then, when wee are once cured, all shall be cured. Soft hearts will produce soft answers from heauen, soft seasons on earth.

div.head: OF SOFTNESSE OF HEART.

epigraph.q: And I will giue them one heart, and I will put a new spirit within you, and I will take the stony heart out of their flesh, and will giue them an heart of flesh.

div.p: YOu haue now often heard what it is that the Lord doth here vndertake for his people, viz. that hee will make them to be of one heart, that he will giue them a new heart, and that hee will giue them a soft heart.

We are now vpon the last of these three: where 1. we desired you to consider what mans heart is when God first lookes on
him hard and stony. 2. Next, what heart that is, that he bestowes on his people, sort and fleshy. The first of these, we entred vpon the last iourney, at which time we shewed you, what mans heart is in and of itselfe. In this depraued estate, wherin now we stand, Man hath a very hard and stony heart: We haue shewed what is meant by heart here in the text, what by stony, what are the signes and symptomes of the stone in the heart, &c.
After other vses made of this point, we came at length to a vse of

Ʋse. Comfort to all such as find in themselues a softned heart, and that God hath wrought some cure vpon their inside this way, blesse God for this mercy; for it is he and he alone, that by his Almighty Power can draw the stone out of mans heart, and make it soft and tender.

Onely that we be not deceiued in the businesse; there lyes on euery one of vs a great taske, that we make a right difference betweene softnesse and softnesse:The differences betweene spiritual softn • sse and others, as • . natu • all softnesse. For you must know that there is a foure-fold softnesse of heart found among men. 1. naturall. 2. morall. 3. legall. 4. Euangelicall or spirituall.

This last only is here intended, as being that alone that carries the blessing. The better to distinguish the 4. seuerall kinds of softnesse, it shall not bee amisse to take notice os some particulars, wherein they differ.

And 1. to begin with naturall softnesse of heart, it is in its spheare, and in its own way a thing commendable in a sort: but not as we are to speake of
softnesse in this place; for it ariseth oftentimes from some weakenesse in the body, and not from strength of the soule. An instance hereof you haue in Rehoboam king of Iudah, who though he bee otherwise censured by the holy Ghost, yet was he 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a man of a tender heart, as his sonne testifieth of him, 2 Chron. 13.7. My father Rehoboam, saith he, was young and tender hearted, &c; of a tender disposition, and (as we vse to phrase it) a softly man, he was naturally so. Now the differences betweene this softnesse naturall, and that which we call spirituall, are two.

First, naturall softnesse comes vpon vs without our indeauour, it costs vs no labour: for why? we are borne so: but spirituall softnesse costs a man a great deale of paines; he that gets it, shall know how he comes by it, it will cost him many a Sermon, many a Chapter, many a Prayer, many a teare, &c.

2. naturall softnesse is vsually vniforme, that is, it ordinarily worketh after one manner, is easiely wrought to one thing aswell as another. Moue such a man to goe to Gods house with you, he will go for he cannot deny any thing to his friend Carry him along from thence to an ale-house, hee is content to follow you, if it be thither too. Bring him to a Sermon, if it be well set on, and deliuered with power, he will seeme greatly affected therewith, euen to the shedding of teares sometimes: take him at another time to a play, let him see a Tragedy well acted, and he will bee as ready to weepe there too, as he was before at Gods house:
In short, you may draw him any way, though vsually hee is more inclinable to that which is euill, then to that which is good; as wee see in the said Rhehoboam. On the other side, spirituall softnesse makes a man tractable and malleable onely in that that's good. Bring an argument to moue him to any goodnesse, it swayes him streight: but in case, a motion be set on foot to that which is euill, you shall find him most stiffe against it, most resolute and peremptory. In a word, no man is so easily wrought vpon by a good motion, as he that is softhearted, no man is so hard to yeeld to sinne, to be drawne to wickednesse, as he.

2. Morall.The second sort of softnesse is, that we call morall, and this is somewhat more then naturall softnesse: In some people, breeding and Education doth very much to the mollifying of their dispositions; conuersement with the Heathen Sages, and much reading of their morall writings, may somewhat alter a man, and make him better; It is true of Art in this kind that the Poet speaketh.
div.q: Emollit mores; nec sinit esse feros.
div.p:
It ciuilizeth a man, and makes him tame and tractable: whence it was that that Heathen bringing his child to a Philosopher for education sake, requested him so to order the matter with his son that one stone might not sit vpon another: thereby intimating that he was of a stony and vntractable nature, till such time as he should be grammar'd and grounded in Philosophie; so that morall
softnes doth in some sort alter and ciuilize a man; but it differeth from that which is spirituall, thus:

First morall softnesse seldome peirceth to the heart, it goes not deepe enough; it oyles the face, and smoothes the outside onely, it barbes and shaues ouer sinne (as wee haue often told you before from that author) but doth not pluck it vp by the rootes, and make an vtter riddance of it. This ciuill softnesse is like a ripe plum, smooth and soft on the out-side, but open it, and you shall finde a stone within, &c.

Second, this morall softnesse hath respect to man principally, indeed it goes no higher lightly than man, being wonderous stiffe to motions that come from heauen: it stands more vpon complements and ciuilities toward men, then it doth on duties to God. If a man of this temper chance to passe by such a friend, and forget to salute him, to inuite him home to his house or the like: he is exceedingly troubled thereat; what haue I done? such a one meet me, and I saluted him not, forgot to offer him the curtesy of my house, &c. Thus obseruant is he in points of ciuility toward men: But now for God, tis otherwise with him; he can go on from day to day, yea, from moneth to moneth; and neuer salute his Father in the duty of prayer, or in any other ordinance, and yet at this he is no whit troubled. On the other side, spirituall softnesse, though it will teach one his duty toward man too, according to his education, and make him humble and modest in his behauiour toward
euery man respectiuely, yet it stayes not here; but is most of all busied about duties of the first table, and is especially troubled for his hardnesse, rudenesse and irreuerent carriage toward his heauenly Father.

3. LegallThe third kind of softnesse, we call a Legall softnesse, this is somewhat more then the two former: and it is when the apprehension of Gods dreadfull iudgements threatned or executed, doth break the spirit of a man, melts him with an inward fire, fills him with feares and terrours, &c.

The difference of this from spirituall softnesse is this: First legall softnesse (if it bee meerely Legall, and goe no further) is inuoluntary; he suffers indeed, he is smitten and wounded, but it is against his will, he doth not wound himselfe: he hath some kind of feares in his heart, and legall terrours, but he would faine cast them off if hee knew how; In a word, he is meerely passiue in his softnesse Contrarily, hee that is spiritually softned, is an Agent in the worke, he reacheth after softnesse, he labours it all he can, he prayes for it, he is glad and thankfull, if he can any way come by it and obtaine it, yea, though it cost him some crosses and losses in his outward estate.

Secondly, Legall terrours breake the heart indeed, but doe not soften it, the hardnesse remaines still neuerthelesse, as it doth in a stone that is broken all to shiuers, and yet the hardnesse is not taken off, but disperst rather into the seuerall parcels of it: So it is with the heart of man in this respect. The law may fall vpon it with all its
weight, crush it, breake it, wound it, terrifie it, but it doth neuer melt it: whereas now spirituall softnesse not onely breakes the heart, but changeth it too; it takes out that which is hard and stony, and puts in the roome thereof that's soft and fleshy, as the Lord here promiseth.

Thus you haue seen some differences described bewteen softnes & softnes. Now therfore that we may returne to the vse of comfort. Doth any man feele his heart kindly broken? hath mercy melted him? hath the loue and goodnesse of God led him to repentance? doth hee finde in his heart some loue to God, some disposition to bewaile and mourne ouer those dregges, and that hardnesse that yet still abides in him? Oh blesse God for hauing thus begunne to cure you of the stone in the heart, which is a farre worse matter then the stone in the reynes or bladder. And so wee dismisse this point also

Now see in the next p • ace, what it is, the Lord promiseth to bestow vpon his people in place of their heart of stone, I will giue them (saith he) an heart of flesh, that is, a tender heart (as Austin somwhere rightly expounds it) a soft and flexible heart, such a heart as is opposed to that heart of stone before spoken of.

God bestowes vpon his people in their first conuersion, a soft and flexible heart. Doct.
Deut 32.5. They haue their spot (as Moses speaketh) their mark wherby they are distinguished by God from all others,Gods people haue softned hearts. and that is a soft, a fleshy, and a tender heart. Loe, this is the point: and this the holy Scripture giues witnesse
vnto in many places.

Col. 3.12. There this soft and fleshy heart is described by the Apostle to be in all Gods Elect: put on (saith he) as the Elect of God holy and beloued, bowels of mercies, kindnesse, hu • blenesse of mind, meekenesse, long-suffering, forbearing one another, and forgiuing one another, &c. Hereby the Apostle giues vs to know that whensoeuer God executes his decree of Election vpon any one by an effectuall calling of him, he presently changeth his bowels into bowels of mercy, kindnesse, &c: and giues him a gentle, humble, meeke, long-suffering heart. See a like place, 2 Cor. 3.3. Ye are the Epistle of Christ ministred by vs, written not with inke, but with the Spirit of the liuing God; and where? not in tables of stone, but in fleshy tables of the heart. And when was this? but then when the word fell in power vpon them, and they were effectually called. And this is it that Salomon also tells vs,This softnesse discouers it selfe towards God, man, the creatures. Prou. 12.10. A righteous man (so merciful he is that he) regardeth the life of his very beast, but the bowels of the wicked are cruell, they are as it were made of yron and steele, his whole inside is of stone, whence also it is that, Prou. 17.10. he tells vs that a reproofe enters more into a wise man, then an hundred stripes into a foole. A foole, let a man lay vpon him once, twice, twenty times, an hundred times, he is still one and the same, he regards it not at all, wheras to a wise man, one word of Gods mouth is sufficient to carry him to any good course.

Moreouer, this spirituall softnesse makes a man haue a tender heart toward man, Ps. 112 5. A good
man is mercifull and lendeth, he is gracious, full of compassion and righteous. And as it faceth God, and refers to him, it breakes the hart, and makes a man tremble at Gods Word, Esay. 66.2. to this man will I look euen to him, saith the Lord, that is poore, and of a contrite spirit, and that trembleth at my Word Such an heart had good Iosiah, 2 Chron. 34.27. when the Words of Gods Law were read in his eares, his heart thawed and melted within him, it fell a sunder in his bosome, like drops of water, and he humbled himselfe before God, and rent his cloathes and wept: &c. And such an heart had Nehemiah, Ezra, Daniel, &c; who when they considered Gods Iudgements on the one side, and their owne sinnes, and the sinnes of their people on the other side, they were euen dissolued into teares, as it were, they emptied themselues, and powred out their soules in lamentation and weeping before the Lord.
Now for the better vnderstanding of this point, let vs open it a little, and shew 1. what this Euangelicall softnesse is. 2. what's the seate of it. 3. what are the causes of it.

For the first of these: softnesse,What spirituall softn • sse is. as it here stands in opposition to an hard and stony heart is nothing else but a gracious frame of mans heart, wherby it is easily wrought vpon by God, and is apt to worke that which is good. So that by this description of softnesse, it appeares to be double; 1. passiue, when the heart is apt to be wrought vpon to any good motion, 2. Actiue, when it puts forth it selfe freely, and is apt to set it selfe a work on that which is good.

Next, the seate of this softnesse is the whole man; 'tis true, if wee speake of the chiefe Throne of this grace, it sits eminently in the will, but not onely, the whole man is the seate of spirituall softnesse: The vnderstanding is made apt thereby to conceiue of that that's good: the will is ready to sit downe by it, and rest in it: the conscience being checked for the neglect or abuse of it, will checke vs for the same: the affections will easily turne and stop, and the outward members will concurre obedientially, as men speake.

Now for the causes of this softnesse: the Efficient, you see, is God himself; I will take the stony heart out of their flesh, and giue them an heart of flesh: it is his worke alone. He vndertakes it here in our text, and the same you may reade,God works this softnesse in the 1. generall conuersion of his, 2. in the partiall conuersion of them after. chap. 36. And hee performes it too in the conuersion of his children; See it in a few instances. Manasseh had sanguin'd and flesht himselfe in blood, for hee shed innocent blood very much, till he had filled Ierusalem therewith from corner to corner: Yea, he had hardned himself in his sinne by very strange courses, for he built altars for all the hoast of heauen, in the two courts of the house of the Lord. And he caused his children to passe through the fire in the vally of Benhinnom; yea, he vsed witchcraft, and dealt with a familiar spirit, and with wizzards: thus he wrought much euill in the sight of the Lord to prouoke him to anger. And yet euen this man thus farre gone in sinne as you haue heard, the Lord softens him, by sending him captiue into a farre countrey, casting him into cold yrons, &c: so that he humbled himselfe greatly before the God of
his Fathers, who made him of a lion to become a Lambe, as profitable now, as before hee was mischieuous. The like you may see in Paul, he before his conuersion was euen mad against Gods people, going vp and downe from place to place on purpose to doe mischiefe, to make hauocke of the Church, and to bring bound to Ierusalem all that called vpon the name of Iesus. Loe, this was his errand to Damascus, Act. 9. but God meetes him by the way, as he was going about his mischeiuous intendments, vnhorses him, takes him downe, holds him vpon the wracke for three dayes space together, melts him with an inward fire, and mouldes him anew, in that manner, that neuer any man since Pauls death, was of so tender and gracious a heart as he was. Such a change doth the Lord make in his people, when he takes in hand to conuert them. Neither doth hee thus soften them onely at the first, but when they stand in need of a second conuersion vpon som particular out-let and out-stray, as you may see in Dauid, who grew miserably hardned vpon his fall into adultery, dissimulation and murder, but God so wrought him afterwards, that he became more soft and tender-hearted then euer he had beene before.
You haue seene who is the efficient cause of this spirituall so • tnesse, God alone.

Now for the matter of it; It is habituall grace infused into a mans soule from aboue. Saint Iames calles it the wisedome from aboue, Chap. 3.17. and tells vs further, that it is first pure, then peaceable, gentle and easie to be intreated, full of mercy and
good fruites, &c: In a word, God infuseth into the hearts of his people, such grace as maketh them gentle, pliable and malleable euery way.

For the formall cause or manner, how the Lord softens his people, it is thus: first, he takes the stone out of their flesh, and then bestowes on them an heart of flesh. 2. He not onely giues them reasons to perswade them from their natuarall and habituall hardnesse, but mightily workes softnesse in their hearts: the power of God is exercised in this businesse, he puts to his hand aswell as his mouth, for the effecting of it.

Lastly, for the finall cause or end, wherefore the Lord thus softens the hearts of his people, it is laid downe in the 20. verse of this chapter, that they may walke in his statutes, and keepe thy ordinances and doe them; that they may comply with him, and so they may be his people, and hee may be their God: Hee hereby brings his people home to himselfe, takes off the diuels brand, and claps on his owne, euen that Image of his consisting in holines and righteousnes, and so conformes them to his son Christ, that he may be the first born among many brethren. This is the generall end, why God softens his people, as hath been said in their first conuersion.

In particular, the ends are 1. to make them capable of the good he intends to doe them, which till then, they are not. To what end should a man sow good seed, if the ground be not softned first, if it be not torne vp by the plough, and so made fit to receiue it? or to what purpose should one
goe about to set a stamp on wax that is not softned, and temperd that it may take impression? So here, mans heart must be first plowed, thawed, melted, made soft before the seed of Gods grace be cast into it: for till then, the word cannot haue any sound or settled impression therupon: for man hath naturally and of himselfe a sturdy spirit, a proud heart, such as will not stoope or veyle, no not to God himselfe, till hee hath taken it downe by his Almighty power, it scornes to learne of man, it is too high for heauen it selfe.

Secondly, God softens the hearts of his people, to make them therby actiue in that which is good when mans heart is once growne hard and crusted ouer, as it were, it is quickly off from all holy performances, as euery Christan knowes by daily exrience: then he would pray if he could tell how; he heares and reads Gods Word, &c; but he doth it very vngainely, vntowardly. This God seeth to be the case and condition of his people many times therfore that he may make way to the performing of holy duties with some easinesse and delight, he makes their hearts to become soft and pliable.

This serues first for examination: Is this the estate of euery one that hath right to the new couenant, that he hath a soft and tender heart? then let euery man reflect vpon himselfe, and make triall of his owne heart, whether it be a hard heart or a soft heart, whether it bee made of a rocke or of flesh? For if a mans heart be hard in extremity, so as that he is yet vnder the power of hardnesse, it is certaine, that Satan hath set his marke vpon
that man for his owne; for he writes all his marks and sets all his names in stone, and makes those whom he hath in possession, of a rocky disposition: As on the other side, if a man find his heart softned and kindly humbled and broken within him, he may safely conclude, this is the Lords owne doing, the finger of God hath been here, and I am truly one of his. Now therefore, search and try what is written on your hearts, hardnesse or softnesse; and accordingly your may be bold to make iudgement of your owne spirituall estates: for the estate is, as the man is; the man as his heart is; and that which discernes the heart, is softnesse or hardnesse.

Obiect. This seemes to be no good argument (may som say) sith it is certaine, that a wicked mans heart may bee softned; and on the other side, a good heart may bee hardned: Lord, why hast thou hardned our hearts from thy feare, saith the Church, Esa. 63.

Solut.It is true, that the wicked may haue a kind of softnesse, namely, such as is naturall, morall or legall, as hath been said before; but not that softnesse which we here commend vnto you, for this is of another nature, as hath beene shewed already. All those former softnesses be either inuoluntary, a man is meerely passiue in them, or else they thaw on the wrong side, as we may say, for they thaw not toward God, but toward sinne, and towards man: But now spiritual softnes melts the heart the right way, makes one tractable to that which is hood. No man is so peremptory, so set downne, so resolute against sinne, as he that hath
the softest heart: for euer the more soft, and easie to be entreated by God, the more hard he is and opposite to a motion vnto euil. Try thy selfe therfore by this marke, if thou haue an hard heart against sinne, if thou haue a face to put off a motion that's made to that which is euill, and that tends to the dishonour of God; if on the other side, thou be easie and apt to any worke of piety, to any worke of mercy, to any worke of Iustice, &c: if thou be tractable and facile this way, thy softnesse is a spirituall softnesse, and such as no wicked man can euer attaine vnto.

And for the second thing obiected: that the godly themselues are oftentimes hardned by the deceitfulnesse of sinne, &c: we grant that also to be a truth; for though Gods people are cured of the stone in the heart at their first conuersion, and some measure of softnesse infused into them, yet still there remaine some dregges behind of their old disease; so as they feeele a kind of hardnesse still vpon their hearts, and if they be not wonderous chary, these dregges will congeale, another stone: but yet withall, we must tell you that ther's a great difference betweene hardnesse and hardnesse, in party and party: for there's 1. a hardnes raigning, and such is that in the wicked, who are vnder the power of it. 2. hardnesse subdued and mortified, and such is that of Gods people, who could be content with any paines, with any cost to haue it remoued, and doe therfore trauell with themselues, and do their vtmost endeuour to get it off: or if at any time the Christian be vnder a
temptation, or a desertion, so as he cannot feele his former tendernesse, yet he contents not himselfe with that estate, but is restlesse and vnsatisfied, he blesseth those Saints, that haue soft hearts, as he sometimes hath had, and would giue all the shooes in his shop (as we say) that hee might so haue againe,What a Saints hardnesse is. In short, the hardnesse of a seruant of God is but partiall, and not throughout; it is but graduall, and in som degree only; it is but occasionall, and for a time: wee'll explaine it vnto you by this similitude. There's great difference betweene the hardnesse of stone, and that of water congealed and frozen: This latter hardnesse indeed may bee so great, as that a man, nay, a beast may goe ouer it in safty, but yet it is not intrinsecall to the water to bee thus hard, but onely occasionall: for let but the heauens looke chearily, and the sunne smile vpon it with its beames and warmth and it will soone dissolue againe and returne to its owne liquid nature. But now it is farre otherwise with a stone: for let the sunne shine neuer so hot vpon it, it melts not, it yeelds not, nay, it is made much the harder by the often striking of the Sunne-beames vpon it. And so it is here: The wicked man hath the hardnesse of a stone we thin him and therefore let him enioy neuer so many mercies, he is no whit moued the more to amend his life, let God speake to him, let him smile vpon him, let him frowne vpon him, all's one to him, nay, he growes euery day vnder the best meanes more hard and impenitent. Contrarily, the faithfull Christian howsoeuer like
water, hee may haue an ice vpon him for a time, and so contract hardnesse, yet bring him to the word and ordinances a while, let God shine vpon him once again with the light of his countenance, and he will melt presently, he will thaw, and recouer his former tendernesse, you vnderstand me, I say no more to that. These rubbes being thus remoued out of the way, and our way smoothed, as it were, we now proceed in the vse. The euidence, you see, remaines still very right and sound, if our hearts be spiritually, rightly, kindly melted, we need make no question of it, but that we are in speciall Couenant with the Almighty.
How shall we certainely know, Quest. that wee haue these hearts of flesh, this spirituall softnesse here promised?
Looke to these two things. 1. Answ. what patients you are towards God. 2. what Agents toward God and men, and accordingly make right iudgement of your hearts,

For the first, if you be spiritually soft,More signes of true softnesse. you will easily yeeld to God, and be wrought vpon by euery of his attributes, his power will awe you, his iustice feare you, his mercy melt you, his truth moue and affect you, yea, cause you to secure and repose your selfe thereupon, committing your selfe to him in well-doing. And as his attributes will worke on you, so his word and euery part therof wil make impression vpon you, his precepts will binde you, his promises melt you, his threats affright you, &c.

The like we may say of the works of God. If
you be spiritually softned, corrections will melt you more: a true Christian yeelds and submits so soone as God beginnes to reckon with him, and to shake his rod: And as crosses, so mercies much more affect him, and make him come in, indeed, he hath not a face to stand out against God when he hath tasted of his bounty.

And as the workes of God haue their worke vpon him, so he is very sensible of the contempts that are cast vpon God. The reproaches of them that reproached thee, are fallen vpon me, saith Dauid. If God be dishonoured in his name, dishonoured in his ordinances, dishonoured in his seruants, this galles and peirces him to the heart, as much or more then if himselfe were wounded, reproached, 'tis here as in all other relations, though the entity be not great, the efficacy is much, the husband is wounded most in his wife, the father in his child, the Christian in his God.

Secondly, if you would be sure you are rightly softned, obserue what agents you are toward God and men: for there is an actiue softnesse in euery one of Gods people. Art thou still calling vpon, and stirring vp thy selfe to take hold of God, with awake ô my soule, &c; Lord, quicken me by thy spirit, &c? art thou still lifting at the stone that thou feelest in thine heart, and wouldest faine be more affected with God & enlarged toward him? dost thou continually trauel with thy hart this way, &c? Loe, here a Dauids (that is a softned) heart. Againe, hath this softnesse of heart an influence into thy outward man, and doth it order thee towards others?
Art thou soft in speech? hast thou a tender hand to helpe those that neede thee? canst thou bleed in other mens wounds? be hungry in their staruings? shudder and shake in their coldnesse and nakednesse? &c: Loe, here a Iobs, (i.) a softned hart. Adde one thing more to the former: the more soft any one is toward God, the more he stiffens and obstinates himselfe against sinne. Such a man makes a couenant with his eyes, as Iob did, indents with himselfe, yea, takes an oath of himselfe, as Dauid did, I haue sworne and will performe it: That I will keepe thy righteous Iudgements: And againe, Away from me, ye wicked; for I will will keepe the Commandements of my God. Now therefore, that we may summe vp all in one: If you finde such a tendernesse in your hearts, as that you are easily wrought vpon by the attributes of God, by the word of God, by the works of God: If the contempt cast vpon God do wound & pierce you to the quicke; If you call vp your hearts to be yet more in loue with God, and doe condemne and rate them because they be so dull and slow: If you carry tender bowels of compassion toward others that be in misery so as you can mourn with them, dye with them, suffer and bee afflicted with them euery way, then there's true tendernes, there's this heart of flesh here promised: which if you finde in your selues, see great cause of thankfulnesse: if not, your next worke must be to seeke out and enquire after it, &c.

THat grace which the Lord here vndertakes for his people, is described vnto vs from all the causes of it. For the matter, first, it stands in the goodnesse of the heart: Now the heart is then said to be good, when it is made one heart, a new heart, a soft heart. Secondly, for the manner, how it is wrought, God will giue it vnto his people, and put it into them. Thirdly, for the authour, it is Gods selfe, I will doe this for them. Fourthly, for the end of all this, it is that they may walke with God, and hold communion with him, as it lowes, vers. 20.

We are yet vpon the materiall cause, and now are come to the last thing therein promised, and that is a soft heart; what mans heart is by nature, we haue seene already, it is a heart of stone, a very rock: Doct. what God makes it, we haue now in hand.
The Lord bestowes vpon all his people a fleshy and soft heart.
Wee haue shewed you what is meant by softnesse, together with the seate and the causes of it, &c: we came to the application of the point, and for present made onely one vse, and that was of

Vse Examination, euery man to make triall of his right to the couenant, by the trial of his own heart whether it bee hard or soft: And for this looke
what patients you are toward God, what agents toward God and man, &c. For if the heart be soft, it will be easily wrought vpon to God: Euery attribute of God will worke on it, euery Word of God will make impression vpon it; euery work of God affect it, euery contempt that falles vpon God, falles vpon it, and makes it bleed.

And for the actiue part, see what freenesse of heart you haue to serue God and walke in his wayes, what tendernesse toward the Saints, what mercy toward the miserable, &c; what earnest desire to presse forward and to put on others.

We come on now to shew you signes of an heart that's hard in extremity,Signes of vnmortified hardnesse. that's vnder the power of hardnesse. And 1. of hardnesse toward God. 2. toward men. For the first sort, you may see them all set down and couched together by the Apostle, Ephes. 4.17, 18, 19. This I say therefore, and testifie in the Lord, that ye henceforth walke not as other Gentiles walke in the vanity of their mindes, hauing the vnderstanding darkned, being alienated from the life of God through the ignorance that is in them, because of the blindnesse of their heart, who being past feeling, haue giuen themselues ouer to lasciuiousnesse, to worke all vncleannesse with greedinesse: Out of which words these signes of an hard heart may be gathered.
