First, vanity of the mind and vnderstanding part: when the mind is voyd of sauing light, voyd of conuiction of faith, of humility, and those other graces as vsually are lodged there, and should soften it. Neither is there onely an emptinesse of needfull graces, but something positiue in the
minde of such a man, for he hath his vnderstanding darkned, saith the Apostle, and is estranged from the life of God through the ignorance that is in him, that is, him mind is stuff'd vp with pride, vnbeliefe, selfe-conceit, selfe-deceit, and all manner of presumption and wickednesse: Thus when the minde of a man is voyd of all sauing grace, and stuffed with pride, ignorance, &c; it comes to congeale a stone.

Secondly, for the heart wherby he vnderstandeth the will and affections, hee giues these two signes of hardnesse in those parts. 1. that they are estranged from the life of God, that is, from a godly life, they not onely are strangers to it (for so all men are naturally) but estranged, that is, an enemy thereunto, as the Apostle expounds it, Colos. 1.21. You that were sometimes alienated and enemies, &c: 2. that they are not onely set against good, but seared, and senslesse in that which is euill, being past feeling, saith the Apostle: so that a man that is thus hardned, sinnes, and perceiues it not by himselfe, sinne drops from him, and he is not aware thereof, a world of guilt lyes vpon his conscience and he feeles it not, shrinkes not vnder it. These be the symptomes of an hardned will.
To these the Apostle addes other signes respecting the out-side, for a mans walke and conuersation.

1. Such a one as is thus hardned, hee resignes himselfe ouer to his lusts, he giues himselfe vp to lasciuiousnesse; hee hath no power at all to resist any ill motion, &c, and as he is facile to euill, so
he is obstinate to good, as wee haue shewed before.

2. As he cannot say nay to any sinfull motion, so he cannot satisfie himselfe in sinne, he commits it in despite of all admonition with a great deale of greedinesse, he workes all vncleannesse (saith the text) with couetousnesse, as the originall word signifies, he couets sin as much as any earthly-minded man can couet gold and siluer: These be the notes of an heart vnder the power of hardnesse, in respect of God.

The signes of an hard heart, as it referres to man, are set down together by the same Apostle, Rom. 1.29, 30, 31. where he describes a man giuen vp to his owne affections, and to a reprobate minde, and in that respect hath Gods curse, at it were, vnder seale.

First, they are filled with all vnrighteousnesse, fornication, wickednesse, couetousnesse, maliciousnesse, full of enuy, murder, &c. A man that is vnder the power of hardnesse, makes no bones of any sinne that lyes in his way, hee can swallow them downe easily without remorse, he can digest yron, and neuer straine for the businesse.

Next, he is an inuentor of euill things, for not satisfied with other mens inuentions of euill, hee studies how to discouer new plots and deuises, how to finde out new mischiefes, whereby to vex mankind.

Thirdly, he is disobedient to parents, and to all authority. Let magistrate, minister, father, mother, and all the friends in the world fall vpon
him to aduise him for his good, he stāds inflexible, he knows no more how to yeeld then a very stone.

Fourthly, he takes all that's said or done to him for his good, in euill part, he receiues that with the left hand, which you offer him with the right, being without vnderstanding, hee conceiues not of your good will in aduising him, but interpretes it as an act of pride in you, of busy-bodinesse, of vncharitablnesse; he makes no good construction of any counsell you shall giue him.
Lastly, he is vnsociable, implacable, vnmercifull: he can giue nothing when he looks vpon the miserable, nor forgiue any thing, when he lookes vpon an enemy, &c.

These are the markes of a man that is vnder the power of hardnesse. Now what remaines but that we put our selues vpon the triall, and iudge whether our hearts are hard or not. If we finde in our selues such a minde, such a heart, such a disposition and conuersation, as these two places haue described, 'tis in vaine altogether for such to lay claime to the couenant of grace, for these haue made a couenant with death and with hell It is in vaine for such to pray, Our Father which art in heauen, for they must owne a father in hell, this being the very guise and disposition of the deuill himselfe, for he is a rebell, he is vnmercifull, he is implacable, insensible, committing sinne with greedinesse and delight. Neither let any such man call the Church his mother, but some Tigresse or Rock rather, as the Poet speakes of him, &c. For God giues vnto all his children a soft and tender
heart as here in the text.

Since this is an infallible note of a child of God, Ʋse. to haue a heart of flesh, if euer you would proue that you appertaine to him, make it good to your selues, that you haue a heart soft and tender: This is to be followers of God, as deare children. Hee is so excellent in himselfe, that hee is beyond all passiue softnesse, but actiuely he is soft, kind, tender, gentle, easie to be entreated, full of bowels of compassion, &c. And if you will call God Father, you must looke that you haue a heart like vnto him.

Againe, Christ is both wayes soft and tender, the rebukes of his Father fell vpon him, he wept ouer others hardnesse, he groaned in the miseries of others, and shewed himselfe most ready to tender and commiserate the afflicted, and to helpe them out in their streights and exigencies. If therefore you will proue Christ to be your head, you must be like-minded, as he was.

Againe, wheresoeuer the holy spirit comes, hee turnes the tables of the heart, and makes them of stone to become flesh: And the fruite of the Spirit is in all goodnesse, &c. Eph. 5.9. If therefore you will proue your selues Temples of the holy Ghost, make good you haue a soft heart: All Gods ordinances tend to soften vs, and if we be right, will certainely worke some softnesse in vs: Yea, all Gods people (when they are themselues at least) and all that doe any way come neare them, and dwell in their Sun-shine, are soft and tender hearted, as Benhadad could say of Ahab, who liued onely
within the smoake of the Church, as I may so say, that he was a mercifull man, &c: So that if you would proue God your father, Christ your Sauiour, the Saints your bretheren, &c: you must labour after a soft heart.
Quest. What can wee do toward it? it is not in our power to soften our selues.

Answ. True: but yet it is in our power to harden our selues, to adde a further hardnesse to that we haue all by nature:What man must doe toward the softning of his hea • t. Here, therefore, take heed that when God speakes, you stop not your eares, when God shines vpon you, that you shut not your eyes, that you winke not hard with the Pharisees; doe not receiue the grace of God in vaine, doe not future your repentance, nor make delayes, when called to amendment: you must not obstinate your selues in sinnefull courses, and when God seekes to reclaime you, get not obiections to oppose to his counsels, seeke not euasions, and arguments against your own good, but when the word findes you out in your sinnes, take Gods part against you selues, stablishing your hearts in the assured truth of all the promises of God, of all the threatnings of God, &c; say to your selues: This is the Word of God that is deliuered; and hee is truth it selfe, and therefore all these things will surely fall vpon me, vnlesse I make a timely vse of that I haue been aduised. This you may doe all, and this you must doe, if you desire to be softned, at least you must be of Pauls disposition,2 Cor. 13. we can doe nothing, saith he, against the truth, but for the truth: so here, you must doe nothing against God in the
worke, but plead all for him; strengthening and furnishing your selues with arguments, to make your selues beleeue that it is God that speakes vnto you, that he is in good earnest, and meanes as he saith, &c: and not to pick out arguments to ward off Gods strokes, and to put by that's spoken, so to stiffen your selues in a course of sinne.

Againe, you must present your selues before the Lord in his ordinances, if you intend to be softned: for you must concurre as subiects (as wee haue often told you) you must tender your selues to God in the meanes of Grace, applying the word to your selues, for that hath the power of an hammer (as the Prophets calles it) to breake the stony heart into shiuers, and the property of fire to melt it, when it is broken:Ierem. 17. In which respect also it is compared in holy Scripture to the former and latter raine, the nature whereof is to soften the earth and make pliable: And so will the word of God the hard and stony heart of man, if we doe not ward off the blowes of it, but gather and apply it to our owne consciences.

But the maine thing is here, that yee set faith aworke: Consider that God hath entred into a couenant with thee, euen a couenant of salt, he hath brought thee into his house, sealed vp a couenant with thee, and that not once onely in the Sacrament of baptisme, but often in the Lords Supper, &c. Therefore take to thy sel • e words, and come before him, and say, Lord thou hast promised, nay, thou hast sealed it vp to me by couenant, that thou wilt take away this cold, this frozen, this
hard heart of mine, and giue me instead thereof an heart of flesh. Now sith it is thy couenant, stand I pray thee, to thy word, stand to thy hand, stand to thy seale: Thus if you doe, he will shew himselfe to be no couenant-breaker, he will surely fulfill his Word.

Next, looke wishtly vpon Christ, if you would be softned. The Poets tell vs of some that transformed such as beheld them, into stones: But if we cast our eyes vpon the Lord Christ, of stones we shall be turned into men, of hard, soft and fleshy: If wee but looke on this Sunne of righteousnesse, our frozen hearts will melt within vs, you may reade in Zach when they looked vpon him whom they had peirced, they mourned ouer him, as one mournes for his onely sonne, chap. 12.10. If therefore you would bee softned, thinke much and often vpon the sufferings and passion of Christ, steepe your thoughts in the blood of the Lambe, and this will dissolue your stone and make you relent, when you see a man carried to the place of execution, and behold, how ruefully he lookes, and what moane he makes, though hee be a malefactor, and it is iust vpon him that he suffers, yet the very sight of him will worke vpon you, and euen cause your bowels to turne within you through pitty and compassion: How much more then must you needs be affected with sorrow to see Christ, as he is crucified before your eyes in his ordinances, to looke vpon him, as an innocent person suffering death, and for your sakes too;Gal. 3.1. yea, done to death for vs, and brought to his end for our transgressions, &c. Oh stand awhile
and behold, how he was attached, how he was condemned, how he was executed for me, for thee, for our offences, our transgressions: this will surely wound, this will deepely affect thy heart; especially, if we shall consider his infinite loue in sealing vs a pardon with his owne blood. This apprehension of mercy in God through the merits and sufferings of Christ wil be very auaileable to soften and melt our hearts. Haue not you seene a malefactor goe with dry eyes to the place of execution, but returne againe weeping and full of teares? whence was this? The apprehension of Iustice and no mercy shewed him by the Magistrate, makes him hard and desperate at his going thither: but if being now vpon the tree, and looking for nothing but that death he hath deserued, there bee brought him newes of a pardon beyond expectation and desert, this makes him melt and relent at the consideration of the Kings goodnesse and his owne vngraciousnesse: So here, when a sinner lookes onely vpon the law, vpon God, as a Iudge; or vpon the word, as written in letters of blood, it makes him feare, it makes him despaire, it makes him euen ready to fly in Gods face, and to teare in pieces the sentence of death written against him: But bring him to Christ, and there let him see God reconciled vnto him, through his death, and an offer of free mercy made and applied vnto him: Lo, this melts him, this winnes him, this takes him off from a peremptory course of sinne, and renders him pliable to that which is good. Therefore dwell, dwell much on the passion
of Christ, and see his loue to your soules, if euer you desire to be softned.

Lastly, exercise the gifts that God hath giuen you, blow vp your sparks, awake your sleepy habits, but especially, these of faith and loue, for these doe soluere gelicidium (as one speakes) melt and thaw our frozen hearts. Action breeds heate in a cold body: And running water is nothing so apt to freeze, as that that stands still: so that man that's euer in action, renuing his faith, setting on worke his loue, &c; shall bee sure to keepe his heart in warmth, and to retaine some degree of softnesse.

Ʋse. Comfort to them that can finde in their hearts any measure of softnesse, if it be of the right stamp at least (that is not naturall, or meerly morall or legall only, but Euangelicall and sprirituall) they are happy men, as those that haue right to Gods speciall Couenant.

Obiect. Alas, what comfort is this to me, who finde in my selfe still a great deale of hardnesse, and that I am little or no whit affected with the mercies of God, with the Word of God, with the executions of God, with the miseries of the Saints, &c? what shall I doe in this case?

Answ. How comes it to passe that thou findest this by thy selfe? Corruption discouers not corruption, death is not discerned but by life; cold but by heat, hardnesse but by softnesse. He that feeles this stone in his heart, groanes vnder it, prayes against it, and withall applyes himselfe carefully to the meanes of softnesse, this man hath a soft heart in a
measure, and if he continue to wait vpon God in the vse of his meanes, he will surely soften it more and more.
Oh but here's my misery: Obiect. I can weepe abundantly for other euills that befall me, but in the matter of sin, I am as dry as a stone, I cannot bring my heart to weepe ouer Christ?

But dost thou iudge thy selfe for this hardnesse of thy heart, drinesse of thine eyes, &c?Solut. som men cannot shed teares, as others can, by reason of the temper and constitution of their bodies, &c.

But the matter lyes not so much in shedding of teares, vnlesse it be those inward teares, as Austin calles them, deep sighes and groanes of the heart: As for those outward teares, —Lachrymae simulare docentur. Many men can counterfeit teares at pleasure, as one saith.

Besides, some griefe is bigger then teares, and aboue them, as in that father, who when hee saw his owne sonne led forth to execution, he was so ouer-charged with griefe,Aristitl Rbet • . that he could not let a teare, but at another time, when hee beheld his friend brought to beggery, he wept abundantly. This latter was a thing vnder teares, that former was aboue teares; there, all the griefe went inward, but here, outward. And so it fares eftsoones with a Christian; sometimes he is so surprized with sorrow for sin, so confounded at the sight of his owne vilenesse and Gods deserued wrath, that he is not able to shed a teare, or make his moan to God, and sometimes he can againe, &c. The mater is not much, if his drynesse proceed from his natural
temper or complexion, or if he can groane vnto his God in spirit, if hee can entertaine that rationall sorrow, wee haue sometimes told you of, though he cannot vent himselfe in passionate sorrow for his sinnes, as he desireth.
Obiect. Oh, but yet still my hardnesse continues with me;

Solu.Apply thy selfe to the meanes still, and thou shalt be helped. And here remember for thy comfort, thou hast more strings to thy bow then one left thee in the words of this text, say, thou hast not yet that soft heart here promised, yet see if thine bee not one heart, whether thou hast not pitcht vpon God as thy chiefe treasure, whether God be not all thou desirest in heauen and earth: see secondly, whether thou hast not this new spirit here promised: So that thou art changed from that thou hast beene heretofore, &c. If thou finde in thy selfe this onenesse, this newnesse, in any measure, then though thy heart be not yet a soft heart, or not so soft as thou wouldest haue it, he will in time giue thee that too, if thou be constant in vsing the meanes.

div.head: And I will giue them one heart. &c.
div.p:
HItherto of the materiall cause the of grace of Sanctification, wherein hauing stood ouerlong, wee will make you amends with breuity in the rest followes next to speake somewhat of the Efficient and formall cause, both which wee will put into one, and so handle them together; I will
giue them one heart, &c. I'll do't, 'tis God you see that giues his people one heart, a new heart, a soft heart, he bestowes vpon them all grace from the beginning to the end.

It is God alone, Doct. that from the beginning to the end giueth his people all sanctifying grace; he beginnes it, he continues it, he perfects it, he crowns it: he is the Alpha and Omega, the author and finisher of all our spirituall goodnesse. In the proofe of this point, the holy Ghost is very punctuall. The whole worke is ascribed to God, 1 positiuely Iam. 1.17, 18. Euery good gift, and euery perfect gift is from aboue, and commeth downe from the Father of lights, with whom is no variablenesse, neither shaddow of turning; Of his owne will begate he vs, &c. Note here 1. the thing, goodnesse, perfection, all that tends to perfection, and to amend vs. 2. Note the author and fountaine, it comes from aboue: how is that? from the Father of lights (saith the Apostle) which is in the Church, what the Sunne is in the world, here's the originall. 3. Note the continuance: with him there's no such alteration, as with the Sun, no variablenesse nor shaddow of change, no omission, no intermission. 4. Note the motiue, it is a gift proceeding from his owne will, verse 18. This comes home to all, cheifly for the beginning of Grace.

Adde 1 Pet. 5.10. which is as full for the accomplishment of Grace: The God of all Grace, who hath called vs to his eternall Glory by Christ Iesus, after that ye haue suffered awhile, make you perfect, stablish, strengthen, settle you. Note here, the worke desired
and vndertaken, and the workeman. The worke is confirmation of grace to the end, set forth in a gradation. The worker is God, who will perfect them to the last. And why? 1. hee hath already called them. 2. to partake of Christs eternall glory. 3. he is the God of all Grace: Of grace preuenting, grace regenerating, grace confirming, crowning all. Thus positiuely 'tis proued.

2. This is deliuered exclusiuely also: The holy Ghost thought it not sufficient to ascribe all to God, vnlesse withall, hee did expressely deny all to man. Thence those Scriptures, Iob. 15.4. without me (a new roote, a quickning head and Spirit) ye can doe nothing,Vid. August. Epist. 106. Pauli Rom per totum. and what lesse then nothing? Againe, what hast thou that thou hast not receiued? And if in more common gifts of the Ministry, the highest of ministers, Apostles, and the chiefe of Apostles, Paul his sufficiency reacheth not to a thought, 2 Cor. 3.5. what then can we doe in matters of that life, whereto we are dead, Eph. 2. Surely, if God be the God of all grace, a creating God, and cause of all, then Man is cause of none: If all and euery grace come from aboue, then none from below. If we haue no more then we haue receiued, then we contribute nothing toward it. Indeed the Apostle mought well say, the God of all grace: for grace can haue no author, but God; who workes it out of nothing, and onely vpon his owne motiues, being first and freest, and were any creature able to deriue grace for any other head, in that respect, hee should be absolute and independant in regard of God, and owe him no seruice
with his grace, as I owe no rent or homage to that Lord, of whom I hold no benefit, and from whom I deriue no title: But there's no grace but it tyes me to God, and I am bound to honour him with it, therefore I receiue it from him, for what's for him, is of and through him, Rom. 11. vlt.

But this will not be face to face denyed, let's a little more nearely looke vpon this truth, and consider the particulars that accompany it. That God is the vniuersall cause of all good naturall & spiritual, is in word acknowledged, Pelagius will not deny it, onely the dimensions and motiues haue been doubted of. Therfore, view this worke of grace in the depth, bredth and length of it, and then come to the mouing cause:The manner and measure and motiues in this worke are considered. For the greatest enemies of Grace haue euer yeelded grace in mans renuing; but what grace? A preuenting grace, a reuealing grace, a propounding, perswading grace. This is a grace, but is this all? Doth God onely lay before vs diuine truthes, and giue reasons, why we should follow them, and so work grace onely as a morall Agent? No, he not onely perswades and illightens a man, but passes also an act of power vpon him, hee puts grace into him, he puts his hand into the bowels of a man, and pulls out the stone first, and then puts softnesse in the roome thereof. A morall agent conveyes no real effect, as when I perswade my child to learne, I doe not with those words make him learned: But God workes some thing in vs, and some thing permanent: Therefore, the Apostle resolues it into the power and mighty power of God, and
great and exceeding great, euen that whereby he created the world, and raysed Christ from the graue, Ephes. 1 19, 20. That ye may know (saith he) what is the exceeding greatnesse of his power to vs-ward who beleeue according to the working of his mighty power, which hee wrought in Christ, when he raysed him from the dead, and set him at his own right hand in heauenly Places. Did God onely perswade Christ, to rise or the world to be created? No, but he put forth his Almighty power for the effecting therof, and so stands the case here.

Againe, if God did onely concurre as a morall cause, then man should bee more an agent in his owne saluation than God. For a morall cause is reduced stil to a higher cause, and is not the cheife cause of the effects, but a mouing cause onely: As when I stirre a man vp to works of mercy, the motion is m • ne, the act his: So then, if there bee no more in it, man is the chiefe cause of grace, of saluation, of all; God but an Inferiour Mouer.

Againe, the diuell perswades and iniects ill motions into bad men: Is God no further the Authour of mans grace, then the diuell of mans sin? If so, then as man is iustly reputed the chiefe cause of his own ruine, notwithstanding the diuels perswasion; so good men should be the chiefe cause of their owne happinesse, notwithstanding Gods perswasions. This were horrible to say, yet Bellarmine compares them thus, God puts in good thoughts and desires, as the diuell doth euill imaginations and lusts.

Lastly, if God onely perswade, what's his work
more than mans, than the ministers; betweene which, the Apostle makes so wide a distance? They may perswade to grace, &c.
But God doth it in better manner: Obiect.

This is but magis and minùs, Solu. a difference in the degrees onely of working: But God doth more then so, intùs suadet, intùs docet, as that Father said, there is an inward worke of Gods Power vpon the heart, whereby hee makes vs capable of his owne reasons and arguments. God doth more then stand without doore to knock at mans heart, and perswade him to be saued, he changeth him inwardly, and works him to conuersion, hee translates him powerfully from death to life, &c.

Thus for the depth of this worke of grace: Now for the bredth and extent how farre goes it. Truly all inward worke was not denyed by Pelagius, is not by the Iesuites: They yeeld a worke vpon the vnderstanding, inlightning that, a worke also vpon the affections inuiting them, but the question was and is about the will, what worke God hath vpon that?

Pelagius distinguisheth betweene the power of willing, and the first and second Acts of will. The power he ascribes to God, he hath giuen vs that faculty which is free, yea, God awakens the will, saith he, but the act of willing is mans. And this is the same (I trow) the Iesuites teach:Vid Bellar. do • ib. arb. looke what a lightsome obiect is to the sight, that grace is to the will: A man hath an eye and a seeing power, but seeth not actually without light: So
a man hath some power of will, but acts it onely when the grace of light is presented. The will then is bound vp, till the vnderstanding and affections be wrought vpon, &c: But this I waue, 1. there's no such power in nature, for the heart is extreamely corrupt, Gen. 6. In our flesh dwells no good thing. Rom. 7. and that which is born of the flesh, is flesh, Io. 3. The naturall man neither is nor can be subiect. Ro. 8. This is either a naturall and fatall impossibility (& that's Manichisme) or moral, and then the wil is impotent (willingly I confesse yet) impotent: And either originall sin spred not ouer the whole man, or else it taints the wil too indeed that most, which is the immediate princ • p • e of moral acts, so I should think, but I loue not brawls and disputes de modo.

Secondly, not onely the power, but the act too is from God. 1. the word is cleare, Phil. 2. he works in vs both to will and to doe, &c. 2. else man should do the better part of his saluation, for act is more excellent than power. 3. then mans will is the principall cause of his good, not grace, which onely sets the scales vpright, the will swayes them. 4. then God doth no more for Peters conuersion than Iudasses, for both haue sufficient grace (according to the Iesuites tenets) to conuert. 5. the couenant is for act too, Ezech. 36. And here's the difference betweene the two Adams. 6. then mans saluation and calling depends not on Gods power, but mans will, contrary to Rom. 11.

For the length, see the bounds 1. where it begins, God giues the first grace, the birth of it, Ioh. 3.
Iam. 1. 2. as he puts • i • feare into our hearts, so he keepes and perfects it, how long? to the last, he neuer repents, but proceeds till he hath brought iudgement into victory, the will into deed: Ther's some interruption for degree, but no entire intermission or excision, no dying the second death, such shall neuer see death, they are past it, Christ liues in them, and because he liues, they shall liue also, 'tis his owne conclusion, Ioh 14.

Now secondly, for the mouing cause, whence it is that God giues grace, Pelagius said, that grace is giuen secundum merita, according to mens good behauiour to God, and so the Iesuites hold much what to like purpose,Vid. Becan. they haue dream't so long of a preuision, that they thrust it at length into predestination it selfe. But may Paul be beleeued. Phil. 2.13. It is God that worketh all of his good pleasure. And of his owne will begat he vs, Iam. 1.18. And he hath chosen vs, &c: according to the good pleasure of his will: And, euenso, Father, for it seemed good in thy sight, Matth. 11. And here in the text, I will giue them one heart; I, is emphaticall and exclusiue, I and onely I. And, not for your sakes do I this, saith the Lord God, (in a further explication of this couenant, Ezech. 36 32) be it known vnto you; be ashamed and confounded for your owne ways, &c. The only motiue then is, because it so pleaseth him, we can goe no further, we know his proceedings are reasonable, but it becomes vs to stay here, the rest we shall know at last, as Austin speaks in one place.
These truths we shall do wel to beleeue; the obiections made by Iesuites, we onely touch vpon.
1. If it be thus (say • hey) then man shall not bee the Master of his owne acts, but God shall be said to beleeue, repent, &c: man shall do nothing, but all shall be resolued into God.

1. The denomination is from the subiect and formall and immediate cause. May not man bee said to vnderstand, though God do powerfully inlighten, or to hate, loue, &c: They yeeld that God worketh vpon the vnderstanding and affections, and yet, man vnderstands and affects, and why should not the same be true of the will too?

August. de gra. & lib. arb cap. 61. 2. God works all things 1 in vs and then by vs. He preuents and acts vs, and then we worke vnder God. Hee workes not in vs as brute instruments (as the Iesuites report vs) we will, when we will, but the question is, whence we will, &c.

But then, what neede exhortations or other meanes: True, if God onely wrought, and did not perswade too; but the Councell of Trent can speake to this point. The word shewes, what our power was, our duty is, our prayer must be. And Bellarmine, who makes the obiection elsewhere, makes an answer; for when the like is said against predestination,Lib 2 cap. 15. de lib &c. he can then say, that predestination doth not deny, but confirme exhortations, because he prescribes meanes for attaining the end.
Obiect. This takes away all merit, all praise, from man:
Solut.None, but what's diuine, and 'tis mans happinesse, if he can carry it home and place it where it is due.

Obiect. This takes off all endeauor? nay, this quickens
our care and endeauour, if St. Paul may be heard. Phil. 2.13. Therefore we must worke out all, because we depend vpon God for all, saith hee: but we haue held you ouer-long, and therefore must needes adiourne the application and vses to the next time.

So much for the Doctrinall part, as the Question lies betwixt vs and Iesuites, as for priuate differences betwixt moderne Diuines within themselues, the best answer that my ignorance can make, is silence.

div.head: The ninth SERMON.

epigraph.q: That they may walke in my statutes, and keepe mine ordinances and doe them: and they shall be my people, and I will be their God.

div.p:
WE haue already dispatcht the inward causes of the grace of sanctification, and haue spoken something of the matter here promised by God, of the manner how he will performe it, we haue yet somewhat to say also of the externall causes. The Efficient is God, as hath been said, the finall is in this verse, and that's double. First, the immediate end, and that is conformity with, and subiection to Gods Law; that they may walk
in my statutes, &c; The next is the vtmost end, and that is, cōmunion with God by vertue of the speciall couenant, here in a measure, and hereafter in all perfection. And they shall be my people, &c; touching the manner of Gods working, we will take it in, as we prosecute the externall causes, first then, for the efficient, he that works all grace from the beginning to the end, is God; I will giue them one heart, and I will put a new spirit, &c: and I will take the stony heart, &c. Lo, he claimes this as his sole worke, and his onely priuiledge, to put grace into the soule. The point that from this ground wee commended vnto you the last iourney, but had not time to finish the vses, was this.
Doct. That God is the Author and finisher of all grace in his people from one end to the other: he begins it, he continues it, he crownes it, he perfects it.
This is a point not much denied in words by the greatest Aduersaries of grace that euer liued. All the difference is, 1. in what manner God bestowes grace. 2. in what measure. 3. vpon what motiues.

For the manner; God works grace, not onely by propounding to his people a way of grace, nor onely by perswading them to vse such a course as whereby grace is feisable, but he hath a further hand in the businesse, for he creates grace and infuseth goodnesse into mans soule, whence it is that Saints endued with grace are called the worke of Gods hands, Esay 19. vlt. And the Apostle tells vs, Ephes. 2.10. that we are his worke-manship created in
Christ Iesus vnto good works: Yea, the Lord puts forth in this woke that his greatest power, whereby he made the w • rld, and raysed vp Christ from the dead, Ephes. 1.19. So that he doth more here then man possibly can doe: for hee not onely perswades his people to goodnesse, but remoues all impediments and subdues the spirits of men, and so makes them capable of that grace he meanes to giue them.

Secondly, for the measure, wee told you that God not onely workes vpon the vnderstanding of a man and his affections, to inlighten the one, and to inuite the ot • er, but he hath a worke also vpon the will, for hee takes out what's amisse therein, and puts in what's wanting. Neither doth God onely worke in his people a power of willing, but the very act of it also, for euen the 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , saith the Apostle, the will aswell as the deed is of God, Phil. 2. And indeed the acting of the will of man is more than the giuing of him a power onely to will: for if the act of his will were left to mans selfe, man should doe the more noble part of his owne saluation Therefore, you must know that God hath a powerfull and effectuall influence vpon the will of man, aswell as vpon any other power of his soule: And to speake truth, there is nothing in mans soule that is more out of order then his will, how and whence I dispute not, so long as the thing is yeelded.

Thirdly, for the motiue whereupon God giues his grace to man, there is some difference. The question was of old, what moued God to giue grace to his people? Pelagius answered, that hee
gaue secundum merita, according to a mans good carriage, and behauiour toward God, but the Apostle answers otherwise, of his owne free-will he begate vs by the word of truth, and in another place, he resolues all into the good pleasure of Gods grace, Eph. 1. per totum.

Ʋse. Is this so, that God alone worketh all sauing grace in his people, he beginnes it, he continues it, and hee consummates it? then if euer you meane to haue any true grace for your selues or yours, direct your eyes and your iourney to God, he alone giues it, 'tis his prerogatiue, and none other can doe it for you. It is true, that all other blessings besides this come from God, but not so immediately as grace doth. If a man want money, friends may supply him; if hee stand in neede of counsell, the Lawyers may helpe him; if physick, there be those that can doe him ease; but if hee want power to subdue any corruption, grace to doe any duty answerable to his profession and calling, it is God alone that can furnish him therewith.1 Pet. 5. He is the God of all Grace, as Peter calles him, and hee giues it in his owne wayes, and no otherwise. To him therefore, you must haue recourse, if you would haue grace for your selues or friends.
Quest. Where shall we finde God? and when?

Answ. He tenders himselfe in his owne ordinances, in his own word and wayes, there he is to be found, and there you may expect to receiue grace from him. And for the time, then he is to be found, when he offers grace in the preaching of the word, for then, he euen sues and seekes to you not to receiue
the grace of God in vaine. Now therefore, whiles the doore stands open, and God brings vnto you the Word of his grace, submit your selues thereunto, and wait till such time as he will please to speake life into your dead hearts, and to worke grace in your profane soules.
If man be so impotent and helpelesse in himselfe, Obiect. as you made him the last day, how is this in mans power to doe as you would haue vs?

Though it be not in the power of a man to doe any gracious cts of himselfe,Solut. yet it is in his power to apply himselfe to the vse of Gods meanes, as to come to Gods house, to set himselfe vnder the minister, to heare what is deliuered, to apply his vnderstanding to that he heares, to consult, to compare, and so to see what agreement there is betweene the written word of God, and the things deliuered, &c. Now therefore, when God giues you eyes to see withall, you must not winke, and since God hath giuen you eares, you must not stop them against his word, you must not seeke how to cauill and obiect against that you heare, but be ready to entertaine it, and pray God so to set it on, and blesse it to you, that you may be conuinced and conuerted thereby.

This if ye doe, though we be not of their minds, who challenge grace vpon the supposed right vse of nature; yet we consent to that other rule laid downe by the Dominicans, as generally true, that God in the execution of his decrees (ordinarily) neuer deserts or forsakes his creature, till the creature first deserts and forsakes him: but that if he
be not wanting to himselfe in applying to the meanes of Grace, God although he be no way indebted vnto him, yet ordinarily he is not wanting to giue grace to such a person.Vid. Aluar. Martin. alios{que} aderit tibi si ipse tibi non defueris priùs. Chrysost. hom. quod nemo lad. nisi a seipso.

And what we say for your selues, the same likewise we say for your children too. There are none, but would be glad their children should haue grace; and therefore, you all pray for them, God giue you of his grace: Now, if you bee in good earnest for them, go the right way for the obtaining of it; runne to the God of all Grace: Reprooue them you must, but yet still pray for them, correct them as there is cause, but not without prayer, instruct them the best you can, but still mingle prayers therewithall, giue them good employments, giue them good examples, take them off from euill company and euill courses, but in all addresse your prayers vnto God, that he would second all your endeauours: Thus did that holy man Noah, God perswade Iapheth (saith he) to dwell in the tents of Shem. He had giuen this sonne of his, a great deale of good counsell, no doubt; but knowing well to how little purpose, all this would be without Gods worke vpon his heart, he falles to prayer. Now the good Lord perswade thee, &c: as if he should haue said, I haue aduised and done my vtmost to perswade with thee, my sonne, to dwell in Gods Church, but all this is but lost labour, vnlesse God bring thee in; Now therefore, God perswade Iapheth, &c. Thus should euery father doe for his child, euery master for his family, euery magistrate for his people, euery minister for
those of his charge: for it is the praying father, that speeds best for his children; the praying Minister, that preuailes most with his people, &c: what's the reason that we make so many vnprofitable iourneyes vnto you; but that we are wanting in our prayers. But, when the hearers rest not vpon the parts of the Minister, nor the Minister trusts too much to his owne prouisions, but both go out of themselues, and depend on the blessing and grace of God, when the hearer prayes, and the preacher prayes, then the worke goes on, and not before. But as you must pray for your children and charges, if you would haue them gracious, so you must be no lesse carefull to bring them to the other ordinances: Set them vnder the Ministry of the word, and then pray that it may proue effectuall; for seldome doth a child of many prayers, and of many teares (as hee once said) miscarry in this kind.

Againe, if God be the author and finisher of all grace in his people, learne to depend on him, as for the beginnings of goodnesse, so for the proceeding and perfecting of the same: goe to him for preuenting grace, for confirming grace, for perseuering grace, &c; tearme it how you will, hee is the God of euery grace, as Peter telles vs: Want you faith? want you wisedome? want you meekenesse, &c? to him you must repaire, he is the God of all Grace: He giues both the meanes, euen the word of his grace, and the successe of all meanes is from him alone, Paul may plant, and Appollos may water, but vnlesse God giue the increase,
all's to no purpose. It is he that begins and cōtinues euery degree of grace, euery act of grace, the sense and comfort of grace is from him. Grace may be hid in a man, it may lye and sleepe, it may be raked vp in the ashes, for any comfortable enioyment of it, till he stirre it vp in vs. See then, that our estate is an estate of dependancy; for not onely the beginning, but the continuing, improuing, increasing and getting of more grace, is of God; except there be a continuall influence into vs from him, it fares with vs as with the ayre, in which, except the Sunne shine vpon it, there is nothing but darkenesse, or as with a mill, which vnlesse there be winde or water to driue it, is no better than a dead stock, or as with the body of a man, which without the soule is but a dead trunk. And no better is the soule further than God hath his influence into it. Therefore, learne of the Apostle to worke out your saluation with feare and trembling, sith, it is God that works in you both to will and to doe of his owne good pleasure: sith, hee is the Author of all grace, depend on him with all feare of offending him, care to please him; so workeing out your saluation, that is, going through all the degrees, all the parts of it, though it be begun in vs already, &c: So when any new decay of grace growes vpon you, goe to him for a new supply, when any new breach is made in your soules, runne to him for repaire, so in the vndertaking of any new businesse, in the performing of any new duty, craue his grace, seeke his direction, and his assistance in all, for then, the businesse is sure to
goe forwards, and not before. Happy is the man that knows himself, that feares himself, that hangs still vpon God, &c. A child is neuer so neare knocks, as when he trusts most to his own strength.

Instruction to carry God the whole praise and glory of any grace we finde in our selues, Vse. he giues all; therefore ascribe to him the glory of all; we can giue to God the Father, the entire glory of our Election, to Christ of our Remdeption, why not to the holy Ghost of our Sanctification. Is not Christ by the holy Ghost our Sanctification aswell as our righteousnes? is he not our life aswell as our Redemption? Giue vnto him therfore the praise of al, why should men shew themselues so nice, so shy in the businesse? why should they come off so heauily, as the Pelagians of old, who yeelded God the author of grace, but common grace, which is nature, of the grace of the law, of some kind of grace, also of the Gospell; namely, a propounding grace, a perswading grace, &c: Christ say they, is the Author of grace by way of inuitation, by way of instruction, and as he propounds himselfe, as a patterne and president to vs.

But why should men stand hafting with God after this sort? why should they stand thus dodging and pinching with our Sauiour in point of his prayses? Let vs learne to speake out rather as the truth is, and say, I was lost and vndone till hee found and relieued me, I was blind and lame till he restored me, I was a captiue, till he set me at l •
berty, dead in sinnes and trespasses, till he quickned me: I hated God, till he shed abroad his loue into mine heart, I was bad, till he made me better:
I had an heart of stone, till such time as hee tooke it out of my flesh, and put in the place therof an heart of flesh. Thinke so, say so, let your liues say so, acknowledge him in all your graces, if you haue any wisedome, any faith, any patience, any thing at all in you more then nature, giue God the glory therof praise him in your words, praise him in your affections, praise him in your iudgements,Negat beneficium, qui beneficium non honorat. Tert. De pat. praise him in your liues, be more seruiceable to him more humble before him, more depending on him then euer you were before for that is truely to honour the God of Grace, when wee vse our grace to his honour, and that man doth indeed deny God, the author of his graces, and that vseth them not to his glory, and to the setting forth of the riches of his mercy, but to the priding of nature and flesh.

Vse. Comfort and incouragement to euery poore Christian, though neuer so hardly bestead (as often they are) for want of grace. They want it in themselues, they want it in their children, &c: but the comfort is, that God is the Author and giuer of all grace whatsoeuer, therefore looke vp to him, and you shall be helped; the question is not what are your maladies, what difficulties appeare in the businesse, but who vndertake the effecting of it. It is not how vnable we are to worke it, but how able hee is and ready also to bestow it. This then may comfort vs, as for a child first.

Obiect. Oh, saith one, I haue a froward and gracelesse child, that will not be ruled, &c: I haue spoken to him from time to time, I haue corrected him, as
there was need, I haue set others vpon him, and haue tried euery way both by faire meanes and foule to doe him good, but all in vaine, he is nothing altered, &c.

But art thou in couenant with God,Solut. & dost thou see and bewaile that bad nature in thy selfe, that thou so much complainest of in thy child? doest thou grieue, that thou shouldst conuey so bad a nature to him, &c? and fliest to God for the healing of him? If thus, it matters not what the disease is, but who the Physician is that vndertakes the cure. Though therefore thou canst doe no good vpon him by all the skill and meanes thou canst vse, yet God can; entreate him to conuince him, entreate him to subdue him, beseech him to amend him, and thou shalt see, that nothing shall stand in his way, but the worke shall be accomplished. If God vndertake once to bring Peter out of prison, no bolts or barres shall be able to hold him there: If he take in hand to leade Israel out of Egypt into the promised land, sea shal be no sea, wildernes no wildernesse, giants no giants, &c: so thought thy child be neuer so ill-minded, neuer so desperately bent, if vpon thine entreaty God vndertake to turne him and doe him good, the worke shall goe on, God can doe that in an houre, that neither thou nor any other man or Angell can possibly effect in any time. Therefore, let not thine heart sinke, neuer cast away thy hopes, but worke still, pray still, waite still, God hath his times, &c.

And as for your children, so here's Comfort in respect of the Church, God hath already begun
a Reformation, made a partition in part, and pulled downe somewhat of the diuels kingdome: Looke what he hath begun, he will not faile to finish, onely let vs follow him, as those in Zachary with grace, grace vnto it, &c. This is Comfort also to euery particular Chirstian, who may from hence take courage, in that we haue to deale with God Almighty, to whom nothing is impossible? Therfore, what though your corruption be strong, yet God is stronger: what though the deuill bee mighty and malicious? yet Christ is come to dissolue his works; what though the world be crafty? Christ hath ouercome the world: what though your graces bee weake, your faylings many? the comfort is, you haue to doe with God, who from weak beginnings vsually makes great proceedings, and will not giue ouer till hee hath finished the building, and laid the roofe vpon his owne foundation Therefore, let nothing discourage you, neither things present nor things to come, neither things within, nor things without you, but hang vpon God for perfect deliuerance, waite on him, and you shall haue comfort, God hath here vndertaken to heale you of your infirmities, and to work out all your corruptions, and to bestow vpon you euery grace needfull to saluation, in such a measure as himselfe will accept of; onely looke to the maine, be sure you be in couenant with God, and that he hath begunne a good worke in you: if so, he will also finish, he is not an improuident souldier, an vnwise builder, Luk. 14 he will not cease till he hath brought his building to perfection.

epigraph.q: —that they may walke in my statutes, &c.

div.p: HEre's the conclusion of all, the finall cause of Gods bestowing grace vpon his people, and that's double, as hath beene said before. We beginne with the immediate end, and that is conformity to Gods Law; That they may walke in my Statutes, and keepe mine Ordinances, and doe them. The Law of God hath diuers names giuen vnto it by the holy pen-men, as precepts, testimonies, statutes, iudgements, &c. Moses mostly vses three words for those 3. kind of lawes giuen by God to that people, viz. ceremoniall, iudiciall and morall, for which 3 Lawes: The Hebrewes haue their particular names and tearmes, the Septuagint and Greeks haue theirs too, which schollars know, but I wil not trouble your eares with them. For present it shall be sufficient to tell you, that when many of these tearmes are vsed together, it is a fit season to make a distinction between them, but when some one or two of them onely meete, we should not be curious herein, but conceiue the whole to be meaned by the part named,Vid. Bez in Luc. 1. alios{que} as here by statutes and ordinances, he meanes euery precept, euery law of God, whether it belong to the Decalogue or to the Gospell.

It is the Law of God then, you see, that must be our rule of life, and square of all our actions, that they may walke in my statutes: And this law must be 1. obserued. 2. acted and duely performed, that they may (keep) mine ordinances, and do them.

Here many things might be considered and noted out of the words, as something from the Metaphor of walking, that they may walke in my statutes, and something from this, that Gods law should be our rule, &c. But we will content our selues with this in the generall, to obserue the scope and end of all Gods actions toward his people, and the reason why he bestowes all both temporall (as in the former verses) and spirituall blessings (as vers. 19.) vpon them, which is, that they may walke in his statutes and obserue his ordinances, and doe them: This is the end and vpshot of all. Hence obserue,

Doct. That all the meanes, and all the mercies giuen vs by God doe ayme at this, euen our obedience. He aymes at this in all he does for vs or sayes vnto vs, namely, that we may marke what he sayes, and doe what he bids.

This is the end and summe of all; as wee may learne from a good Arithmetician, Eccles. 12.13. Let vs heare the end of all, saith he, feare God, and keep his Commandements &c: As if he should haue said, it is a tedious thing to write many bookes, and as tedious to reade them: but if a man should write an hundred, nay, read ouer a thousand bookes, this is the vpshot and end of all, to feare God (for his inward worship) and to keepe his commandements (for his outward seruice) loe, this is the end of man, the perfection of the creatures, the maine duty, & as it were, the whole of man. Thus Salomon: Psal. 112. & 119. & 128 in the beginnings. And of the same mind also was his father Dauid, who therefore very often in the booke of Psalmes placeth mans happinesse in the feare of
God, and obedience to his Lawes, which our Sauiour abbridging tells vs, that he is a blessed man that heares the Word of God and keepes it. Now that which was Gods end in accomplishment, the same was his end in intendment and designment, namely, that men should obserue his commandements and doe them. And to this end serue all Gods Words, his precepts, to mound vs and keepe vs within compasse, his threatnings, to restraine and force vs to obedience, his promises to allure and put vs on to duty, all good examples to hearten and encourage vs in a good course, &c: In a word all that's written, whether in the law or Gospell, tends to obedience.

And as his word, so all the works of God, all his acts, whether immanent or transient looke this way, he hath elected vs, but why? that we might obey him; he hath created vs, called vs, sanctified vs, &c; and all to obedience. All that God doth by way of mercy or correction, looke this way: The whole creation teacheth obedience, the Bible teacheth it, all diuinity is practicall, and calles for obedience.

And (to say truth) what can bee more equall then that he that is wisest, best, greatest of all, should rule ouer all, and haue obedience yeelded him by all? then that he that is first should be last? then that he that hath none before or aboue himselfe should make himselfe his owne end, and doe all for his owne glory? then that he that is the Creatour of all, should haue command of the whole creation, sith in him it is that we liue, moue,
and haue our being, &c.

And as it is iust, so it is best it should be so, best for the publike, best for the priuate, best for euery mans own particular, this being the honor and happines of the creature to be employed vnder God.

Ʋse. See here, what the full weight of sinne is, especially presumptuous sinnes, and rebellions. Is it not an vnsufferable iniury, and an vnreasonable thing, that a seruant shall rise vp and rebell against his master? such a thing is sinne, its against all law, whether that written in our hearts, or that in our Bibles. It is against all conscience, whether naturall conscience or that which is sanctified and eleuated.

It is against all wit and reason, that the creature should oppose the Creator, that mortality should stand out against immortality, weakenesse against strength, that man should make head against his maker, in whom he subsists. This vse the Apostle makes for vs; Doe we prouoke the Lord to wrath? are we stronger then he? as if he had said, this were the greatest madnesse in the world. There is now wisedome, no safety in it, for the pitcher to knock against the rock, the lamb to dare forth the lion; for a man to kick against the prickes, &c. There is no profit in such a course: for what gets the rebell that riseth against his Prince, that's potent and able to bring him in and chastise him, but shame, death, pouerty, misery, to himselfe and his? It is against all duty, 'tis against the word, 'tis against the Sacraments, wherin we binde our selues by Couenant to obey God: 'tis against all thankfulnesse,
yea, against nature it selfe, for euery Creature in its kinde and place yeelds obedience to its Maker. God speakes to the winds (though vnruly creatures) and they obey him, hee speakes to the sea, and it obeyes him, he speakes to the whales, to the lions, and they doe him seruice; There's no creature either by sea or by land so sauage or vntractable, but acknowledgeth a Lord, and obeyes him in its kinde and way: what an vnreasonable thing is it for man, that liues in Gods house, that calles God Father, God Master, to shew himselfe, notwithstanding, rebellious and vndutifull? Now therefore, trip not ouer sinne so lightly, as most people doe: Euery man hath his faults, say they, what? so great a matter is it to doe so and so? &c. But presse this point vpon thy selfe and say, Ah what a wretched creature am I? If God had made me a stone, I should haue obeyed him, if God had made me a toade, I should haue done him seruice, and now that God hath made all things for me, and me for himselfe, for me to lift vp my hand against God, to shew my selfe rebellious, vnthankfull, vndutifull, what call you this? Nothing in the world is disobedient, and rebellious against the creatour, but man and the deuill: say therefore to thy selfe, can I finde none in all the world to comply with, but the deuill? If I looke to any other creature whatsoeuer they obey God, must I needs goe to hell for a partner in my rebellious courses, and ioyne with the deuill in disobedience to my Maker, &c?

And (for a second vse) let vs all learne to reflect Vse. 2
euery man vpon himselfe, and there find out a froward nature, a crosse and crooked disposition, a spirit of contradiction within himselfe, that God can no sooner lay a statute vpon vs, but we can presently finde out an obiection against it, an euasion to auoyd it, see this to be in euery one of your natures. And for your practice, looke how you haue carried your selues towards God, consider in what relations you stand vnto him, hee is your maker, he is your master, he hath giuen you a law to obserue and keepe, but what obedience haue you performed thereunto. He gaue you not statutes to bee as pictures to looke vpon, but to walke in them, to obserue and doe them: Hee hath placed you in his vineyeard, on purpose that ye may beare fruit, therfore, let me now take vpon me the person of an husbandman (so you know, we are called in holy Scripture) and call vpon euery one of you for fruit:Matth. 21. you haue been long time plowed, & sowed vpon, you haue had the meanes of grace for many yeeres in all power and faithfulnesse, where now is your obedience after all? what returne of fruites doe ye m •• e vnto God. You that are husband-men, doe not you in time of haruest carry out your sithes and your carts to gather in your corne? you say • ere I sowed my seed, and here I looke for my haruest, &c: And so you that haue orchyards, doe not you at time of the yeare carie out your baskets & other implements to fetch in your fruites, which you expect after all your paines and charges? The same may wee say of you, mades-men, doe not you at the yeeres end
or oftener, haply, cast vp your shops, and say, I haue turned the penny and returned my stock this yeare, &c; what gaine, what increase is come thereof? And the like must we doe for the Lord. The yeare is now more th •
〈◊〉
• bout since wee came first amongst you, 〈…〉 now doe yee bring forth to God? you ha •
〈◊〉 a lecture of humility, what fruite? a lecture of mercy, what fruite? a lecture of meekenesse, of truth, of peacefulnesse, &c: where's now the practice of that ye haue heard? where be your fruites of obedience? It is not hearing (you must know) the Lord stands vpon, but the doing of his will, he requires your hands aswell as your eares. It is not knowlege so much that he looks after, he calles for your hearts aswell as your heads. It is not words that will content him, he requires your whole man, and not onely your tongues. It is not your comming a mile or two to the hearing of the word; that serues the turne, except ye be doers of what you heare. It is not your walking to Gods statutes, but your walking in them that Gods expects and requires; what will it auaile the tree to stand in the vineyard, to haue there the benefit of both sun and raine, to be pruned and dressed, &c; and yet beare nothing, or leaues onely insteed of fruite? No, no, Euery tree that beares not fruite, Matth. 7. and good fruite too, is hewen downe and cast into the fire, saith our Sauiour, if it be not for fruite, it must be for the flame, for why should it keep the ground bar
• en? Now therefore, consider seriously of this, and say to thy selfe. I goe to heare a sermon, but
what doe I practise of it? I haue heard a discourse against swearing, and do I notwithstanding sweare at the very Church-doore? I haue heard a Sermon against lying, and shall I goe presently home to my shop, and 〈◊〉 haue heard a Sermon against Sabba ••
〈◊〉
••• g, and shall I trauell or trafficke vpon 〈◊〉 next Sabbath? I haue heard a Sermon again ••
•• unkenesse, and shall I yet drop into the next ale-house I come to? It is fruit that God expects at our hands, &c. And for this it is that he makes the weather so vnseasonable, and the earth so barren; because of our vnseasonable disobedience and vnfruitfulnesse in good workes. Tell not me what you know of Gods statutes, but what you doe: shew your faith in your workes, your loue in your deeds, your knowledge in your practise: This or nothing will doe you good, and stand you in stead in the euill day, whereas vneffectuall knowledge shall but aggrauate your iudgm •• t. Bee entr • ated therefore for the future, to shew your selues obedient seruants to God and his Lawes; what's the end of your creation? what's your errand into the world, but obedience? what's the end of all Gods workes, of all his wages, what's the end of all Gods sayings vnto you, and of all his doings with you, but to bring you to bee fertile and fruitfull ground? Therefore content not your selues to haue gotten some knowledge or to haue made profession of the truth, or to haue been at paines to come to the meanes of saluation: Obedience is all in all, and the former without this is of no esteeme with God, and for
no benefit to your owne soules. Doth God then bid thee shun any sinne? fly from it; doth he require any duty of thee? set vpon it. 'Tis doing (my bretheren) 'tis doing, that graceth Religion, pleaseth God, encourageth the seedes-men, it is that alone that will honour you, and doe you good another day: when a man is dead, what remaines of him more then his goodnesse? Looke what good he hath done in his life time, that goes along with him, & that stayes behind him too in a good name, which he leaues amongst men, when as all the rest will perish and come to nothing. Neuer tell me, I goe two or three mile to heare a Sermon; this is well, I confesse, and we commend your forwardnesse this way, but this is not all, will you goe as farre to doe a Sermon? there bee many strides to heauen: Hearing is but one step towards heauen, knowledge another, profession another, but that which must iustifie all your grace to bee in truth, is your obedience: If your inside be throughly cured, the outside will be answerable; so much true grace as any man hath within, so much conformity there will be on the outside; at least in desire and endeauour of obedience. Therefore, let few words preuaile with you aswell as many, yeeld your selues tractable and obedient to Gods Commandements, be of Cornelius his mind, we are all here present before God to heare (and not so onely, but to doe too) all things commanded thee of God. If you will bee Gods seruants, you must not refuse any worke that's his, but set your hands to all that hee bids
you doe. This you should do, and this you may do too if you will, not in perfection indeed, but in an Euangelicall manner, and in such a measure, as he will accept of. This God hath vndertaken here to enable you vnto; Looke what hee saith in the text, I will giue them one heart, and I will put a new spirit within you: and I will take the stony heart out of their flesh, &c. And why will he doe all this for them? that they may walke in my statutes, and keepe mine ordinances, and doe them. Now therefore, if you will bee constant in the vse of Gods meanes, and be earnest with him for the same in prayer, he will not faile to fulfill his Couenant, which is to giue you so much grace, as that you shall be able to serue him acceptably,Heb. 12.28. as the Apostle speakes to his Hebrewes, all the dayes of your liues.

div.head: The tenth SERMON.
div.p: WE are now vpon the last of those causes of the Couenant, and that is the end of all. The Lord vndertake, (as you haue heard) to be very gracious to his Church, to blesse them with outward blessings, and with sauing graces: the end of all is, that they may walke in his statutes, and obserue his ordinances, and doe them; this is the immediate end. The vtmost end of all is communion with God, for they shall be his people, and he will be their God.

Wee were speaking something to the former, Doct. the last day; we shewed you whither all mercies, all meanes, all the words, and all the works of God tend, namely, to bring the creature to subiection, to make the Church obedient to God. This is the end of all ordinances, the end of the Magistracy, of the Ministry, of euery particular calling. This is the end of all Gods words, his promises, precepts, threatnings, &c; of all Gods actions, whether immanent, as in our election, or transient in other degrees of our saluation; all that God doth, and all he saith to his Church, is to make her obedient to his Lawes.

For vse: we hence tooke notice of the vnreasonablenesse Vse 1 of rebellion: It is against all law, all conscience, all wisedome, all example, except wee will to hel for example: for no creatures, saue the diuell and man, disobey God in their place and kinde.

Secondly, wee tooke occasion to enquire amongst Vse 2 you for obedience, and (as the husband-men of God) to call for fruites, and we entreate you, call vpon your owne hearts, and say: I haue reade the Word of God, but what do I do of it? I haue heard a Sermon, but what doe I obey therof? I know and vnderstand Gods statutes, but what doe I practise? &c.

Thirdly, we now proceed to call vpon you to Vse 3 performe obedience, to put all you know into execution: this is all that God shootes at. Obedience is that which euery one of vs doth professe, and we seeme to pray for it, when we say; Thy will
be done in earth as it is in heauen, therefore this is it that must be studied.

Now, by obedience wee meane a free subiecting of the whole man to God; when a man bestowes, and giues vp himselfe to God to be orderd by him according to his reuealed will, then hee is truely said to be obedient. The Apostle telles vs what it is in that, Rom. 12.1, 2. I beseech you by the mercies of God, that ye giue vp your bodies a liuing sacrifice, holy, acceptable to God, &c: and be not conformed to this world, but be ye transformed, &c. when he saith, Giue vp your bodies, hee meanes thereby the whole man, like as in the next Chapter by soule, he meanes the whole person: Let euery soule be subiect to the higher powers, Rom. 13.1. Many will submit their bodies to rulers, but the Apostle cals for their hearts too. So in this place, he beseecheth them to giue vp their bodies to God, for most men will professe that God hath their hearts, they haue as good hearts to God-ward as the best, they say; but if it be so as they pretend, their bodies also, and so their whole man must be giuen vp to God. In that Rom. 13. there is an Hebraisme, the soule for the whole man: In this wee now vrge, there is a Grecisme, as wee could shew if it were needfull, and with vs it is ordinary to vse body for the whole man, as when we say; Hee is a very good body, or a naughty body, that he Greeks often put 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for persons vid. Thucy. &c: So that when he willes vs to giue vp our bodies, he meanes our selues, our whole man, soule and body, but especially the will, which is the seate of
all obedience, it is origo facti (as a father speaks) the fountaine from whence all mans actions flow. So that obedience is a conformitie to the will of God, as it is reuealed: 1. In his Word, whether it be in the Gospell, whereunto we owe the obedience of faith, or in the Law, whereto wee owe the obedience of fact. 2. In his workes. The commanding will of God is reuealed in his word: his disposing will is reuealed in the acts of his prouidence. To the former we owe an actiue, to the latter passiue obedience, quietly submitting to his good pleasure in all estate. This obedi- must haue these properties:

First, it must be hearty: the heart must be deliuered vp to the word, as the Apostle saith,Rom. 6. to be framed and fashioned thereby: and then from an inward principle, obedience must be yeelded to the will of God.

Secondly, it must be sincere, for the end of it, whil'st we walke worthy of the Lord in all wel-pleasing, as hee saith to the Colossians, God must be our chiefe aime, and all that wee doe this way, must ence be done to him, and for him.

Thirdly, it must be regular,Colos. 1. for the forme and manner of it, squared out by the Word, which must be a rule vnto vs, both in point of faith, and in matter of practice. The Law it selfe in this respect is not abrogated, but still continues in force, as a rule to liue by: There want not those (tis true) that would vtterly race out the whole second Commandement, as most of your latter Iesuites, like as some others there are that would
doe as much for the fourth, denying the morality of that Commandement, and then comes the Antinomist, and pulls vp all by the roores. And so likewise for the Gospell, some Frier-like fellowes haue not doubted to obtrude a fifth Gospel of their own, & to call in Gods; but we must hold and acknowledge the whole Word of God to be our rule for the generall: and for particular actions, wee haue another rule: as, 1. The rule of discretion, teaching vs to obey seasonably, as it is said of a godly man, Psal. 1. that he brings forth his fruit in due season.

2, Another secondary rule we haue, is a mans calling, within the lists whereof God hath so tied vs, that nothing we doe can be accepted, vnlesse it be by vertu of our calling. And this is that that S. Iames tells vs, cap. 3.12. Can the Fig-tree, my brethren, beare Oliue berries? either a Vine figs? why? what if a Vine doe beare figges? are not figges a good fruite? Yes, but not for a Vine to beare: so if a man do never so commendable an action, if it proceed not from a right principle, if it be not done by vertue of his calling, it is no way accepted.

And for the matter of our obedience, wee must obey in all things: Wee owe that to God our Father, which the Papists teach, wee owe to our Mother, the Church, and that is vnlimitted subjection in all parts and points of duty: A man must winke (as Abraham did) and put himselfe into Gods hands, to be guided and ordered by him, in all things. They goe farre from their visible head of the Church, as they call him, when they
tell vs, that whether hee command truth or falsehood, good or euill, yea though hee should say that vice were vertue, and vertue vice, yet 'twere our part to lay our hands vpon our mouthes, and to set our selues to worke without dispute: But though wee acknowledg no such law, as this, yet for God, it is true, that whatsoeuer it be that hee commends ro our faith, we must beleeue it, whatsoeuer hee commends to our obedience, that wee must practice, and whateuer by his prouidence hee is pleased to lay vpon vs, wee must willingly stoope to it.

And this wee should doe for these motiues: 1. from God: 2. from our selues. For God, first it is that that doth wonderfully honor him, when we can be content to deny our selues, and as it were to dispossesse our selues of our selues, that we may put him into whole possession of our hearts.
Secondly, this hee expects of vs as a father, as a Master, as a teacher, as a King, as a Creator and maker of vs.

Thirdly, this he commends in his people, when they obserue to do his commandements, as when hee compares his Church to the horses in Pharaohs, charet, implying that his people were such as could be content to be turnd, and wound any way by him.
Fourthly, this is accepted of God aboue all sacrafices, as the Prophet tells Saul; to obey is better then sacrifice, 1 Sam. 15.22.
As in respect of God, so in respect of our selues we should shew our selues obedient:

First, because it is possible to obey God in such a measure, at least as shall be accepted: If we are in the couenant, God hath vndertaken to enable vs to obserue his statutes, and wee may attaine to grace, whereby to serue God acceptably, as the Apostle saith.

Secondly, as it is possible, so 'tis profitable too: for euery man shall be rewarded according to his works, And as the Apostle saith, not the hearers of the Law, but the doers shall be iustified, so it is not our hearing of the word, our profession of religion, our knowledge that will carrie it, but as Saint Iames saith, You shall be blessed in the deed.

Thirdly, it is comfortable, as well as profitable, to obey God, it is euen our life. If the Philosopher could say, That our life stands in doing things vertuous and praise-worthy amongst men, how much rather may wee vse the same speach of doing the will of God from the heart. This indeed is to liue, and nothing else but this: This is the man whiles he liues, and this he leaues behinde him when he dies: For then, it is not how great any one hath been vpon earth, or how rich, beautifull, politick, valourous, &c. these respects sway nothing with God: but so much goodnesse as any man hath had, so much comfort hee carries with him, and so much honour, respect and loue, he leaues behind him, when he goes hence.

Now then, if you beare any respect to God, if you would grace the Gospel, glad your teachers, silence your enemies, encourage your brethren, bring comfort to your owne soules, the thing
you are to performe and looke to, is practice. This is it that must iustifie your knowledge, for hereby we are sure that we know him, if wee keepe his Commandements. He that saith, I know him, and keepeth not his Commandements, is a liar, and the truth is not in him, 1 Ioh. 2.3, 4. This must iustifie your faith, for shew me thy faith by thy workes, for faith without works is dead, Iam. 2. This is it, that must iustifie your loue; for he that keepeth his Word, in him is the loue of God perfect indeed, 1 Ioh. 3. 3. Obedience shews what a man is: If then you would approue your selues to your selues, if you would approue your selues to God, if you would approue your selues to men, you must not onely know or professe the truth, but come on to practise: when you heare a lesson deliuered, ye must set vpon it; when you heare a fault reproued, you must set against it; when God by his prouidence laies any crosse vpon you, you must submit to him: This is that the Lord aymes at in all his ordinances. Quest.
How shall we come to this obedience? Answ.

Be sure you be in Christ, settle that, for from the old Adam you can sucke nothing else but treason and rebellion: it is by the second Adam that any one is made fit to obey. This being presupposed then that you are in Christ: First, you must get a treasure on the inside, make the tree good, and the fruite will be good also, according to the goodnes of the sap, will the fruite be. This is it that Peter telleth you, 2. Ep. 1. If, saith he, you adde to your faith vertue, and to vertue, knowledge & to knowledge, temperance; and to temperance, patience; and to patience,
godlinesse; and to godlinesse, brotherly kindnesse; and to brotherly kindnesse, loue: that is, if you get an heape of graces, and if these things be in you (and abound) they shall make you, that ye shall neither be barren nor vnfruitfull in the knowledge of our Lord Iesus Christ: for if there be grace within, it will certainly breake forth and shew it selfe in the outward practice.

Secondly, you must act those graces that you haue, be doing still, vp and be doing; and the Lord shall be with you: Neuer stand obiecting, I cannot doe such a duty, master such a corruption, resist such a temptation, beare such a crosse, part with such a child, &c: but put your selues vpon the worke, and say, God bids me doe thus and thus, and I will doe it, at least endeauour it, I am able to do all things through Christ that strengthens me, saith Paul, Phil. 4. I can both abound and bee abased, &c. I can part with any thing, or doe any thing that God bids me doe. Thus we must stand resolued in point of obedience, and God will be with the couragious.

But especially, make vse of the Couenant. He hath promised here, you see to giue blessings without, and grace within; euen one heart, a new heart, a soft heart, and all to this end, that we may walke in his statutes, and obserue his Commandements, and doe them, &c. Improue this Couenant, make your best of it, and say as the Prophet, Lord, giue thy strength to thy seruant, that I may keepe thy Word, I am thy seruant, Lord, there is a relation between vs, I am in Couenant with thee, and I come for
that strength, which thou hast promised in the Couenant: so say, thou hast promised to take my old, hard, diuided heart, and to bestow vpon mee one, new, soft heart, thou hast vndertaken to free me from my corruptions, and to fit me for holy duties, and all for this end, that I might obey thy statutes, and do thee seruice in an acceptable manner: Now I pray thee make good thy word to thy seruant, enable me to doe thy Commandements, and then command what thou wilt.

div.head: And I will be their God, and they shall be my people.
div.p: THis is now the last clause of the new Couenant and the vpshot of all the rest: And I will be, &c; wherein we haue these two things to consider of, 1. for their part, they must behaue themselues as his people. 2. and for his part, hee will be their God: Wee will not stand vpon the particulars, but content our selues with this one point for present.
That the Lord is very ready (so soone as he hath made his people) to smite a couenant with them, Doct. and to marry them to himselfe. First, he fits them, and then he contracts then.

Thus he dealt with Abraham, the Father of the Church, God calles him out of his owne country, bestowes his grace vpon him, calles for the exercise of it: Walke before me, and be vpright, and then smites a couenant with him, Gen. 17.1, 2. I will make my Couenant betweene me and thee, and will multiply thee exceedingly. First, you see, the Lord
fits him, and then enters into couenant with him. And so he dealt afterwards with his people Israel. He calles them out of idolatrous Egypt, humbles and tries them in the wildernesse, giues them summons in mount Sinai, prepares them before hand, by thunderings and lightnings, and the noise of the trumpet, and the smoking of the mountaine, &c: and hauing thus subdued them to his feare, he makes a couenant with them, Exod. 19. If yee will obey my voice indeed, and keepe my Couenant, then shall ye bee a peculiar treasure vnto me aboue all people, &c Thus he dealt with Israel, and thus also with the Gentiles, as you may reade, Hos 2. which the Apostle also makes vse of, Rom. 9. I will say to them that were not my people, thou art my people; and they shall say; The particulars of this couenant. Thou art my God. And so the Apostle applies it to some particular Gentiles, 2 Cor. 6. Come out from among them my people, and be ye separat, saith the Lord, and touch not the vncleane thing, and I will receiue you: And I will be a father vnto you, and ye shall be my sons and my daughters, saith the Lord Almighty. Thus you see God is wonderous ready to smite a couenant with his people.

The ground of this couenant is Iesus Christ, the Angell of the Couenant, he was God for the businesse with God, and man for the businesse with man, he partaketh of both God & man, that they may both meete in one in him, and whereas there was a difference betweene them, hee reconciles and makes them one again; to this end, God 1. deputes Christ to the office of a Mediator, & sends to his people, this Angell of the couenant, 2. they accept of him
for their mediatour, and say as the people of Israel did of Moses, If wee should heare the voice of the Lord our God, speaking out of the fire, wee should dye; Goe thou neare and heare all that the Lord our God shall say, and speake thou vnto vs, all that the Lord our God shall speake vnto thee, and wee will heare it and doe it: In like sort, the people of God stand affected toward Christ, and say; If God will please to looke vpon them in Christ, and deale with them in his mediation, they will be content to put themselues vpon him, and to obey him in all things. This is the ground of the Couenant.

Next for the motiue, that stirres him vp thus to make a league with his people, it is meerely his owne grace and goodnesse, 'tis because hee hath set his loue vpon them, as he telles the Israelites, Deut. 7.7. The Lord did not set his loue vpon you, nor chuse you, because ye were more in number then any other people (or for any • uch like respects) but because the Lord loued you. Lo, he loued you because he loued you, to shew the freedom & independancy of his loue vnto them. And so he speakes likewise, Ezek. 16. to his Church, vnder the Parable of a forlorne Infant, &c: It was the time of loue, and I spred my skirt ouer thee, &c: yea, I sweare vnto thee, and entred into a Couenant with thee, saith the Lord, when I passed by thee, and saw thee polluted in thine own blood, I said vnto thee, when thou wast in thy blood, liue, yea, I said vnto thee, when thou wast in thy blood, liue.

Thirdly, if you enquire into the order, it is thus: First, a couenant of Grace is made with
