Christ, and next, in Christ it is made with all Christian men and women. The first capitulation and condition is with Christ, as he is head of the Church: God giues vnto his Sonne Christ a people from all eternity, that he should redeem them, and bring them back again; Christ comes in the fulnes of time to performe this work by laying downe his life for his people, and after this sends forth his ministers for the gathering and building vp of his Church: for it is our worke, who are ministers, to espouse you to one husband, that we may present you as a chast virgin to Christ, 2 Cor. 11.2. after which, Christ also presents you to his father in his priestly office, with, Father I will that where I am, there these be also. Ioh. 17. Next, the Lord hauing first couenanted with Christ, he couenants also with vs, hee fits vs in Christ for himselfe, and then brings vs home to himselfe.

Lastly, the end of all this, that God doth for his people, is 1. in respect of himselfe, that he may set forth his own grace and goodnesse to the sons of men. 2. in respect of vs, that he may secure vs of our saluation, in all the parts and degrees thereof.

Ʋse. 1 Is God thus ready to make a league with his people? take notice then in the first place of the wonderfull grace and goodnesse of God, that he should descend so farre below himselfe, as to enter into couenant with such silly wormes as wee. This goodnesse of his appeares especially, if you consider, how 1. he seekes it. 2. seales it. 3. performes it.

For the first, it had beene grace wonderfull in him, if he would haue but accepted at our hands, tearmes of peace vpon our suite and submission, but behold his goodnesse in that hee is pleased to sue to vs for reconciliation. It had beene our part, questionlesse, to haue sued to him rather, as being vnderlings, and farre inferiour to him; besides, we had done the wrong, and wee were in his danger, not he in ours; for he is cleare and free, he is full and abundantly blessed in himselfe, he needeth not vs: for he was many thousands of yeeres, euen an infinite time before wee had any being at all, in himselfe perfectly happy: so that in the couenant he makes with vs, he seekes not himselfe, he serues not himselfe of vs, all that hee aymes at herein, is at our comfort, our safety, our happinesse. It is as if some mighty Prince, that sits quietly vpon his throne, when rebells are gone out against him, though he be out of their danger, yet hee should send out vnto them, and entreate them to come in and accept of a pardon; thus God deales with his people, we haue rebelled, and he, (though he needes not for any harme we can doe him) sendeth out his Embassadours beseeching vs in Christs name to be reconciled vnto him. 2. Cor. 5.

Secondly, hee shewes his loue to vs, as in seeking, so in smiting this couenant with vs, which is a wonderfull grace in him, if you consider 1. the matter that this couenant containes, or 2. the manner of confirming it. For the first, this couenant containes all good things desireable, 1. freedome from all euill that may any way proue
hurtfull to vs, 2. the enioyment of all good things: for God promiseth to giue two worlds, yea, hee will bestow himselfe vpon vs, which is more than all the world besides. Secondly, for the manner his mercie appeares in, that he confirmes this couenant in the Sonne of his loue, whom he sent into the world, not onely to publish the couenant, but also to ratifie and seale it vp, not in wax, but in his owne heart-blood; for he died to ratifie this couenant of grace, which wonderfully sets out the Loue of God to his people: for it is all one, as if some great Prince should do to death his owne and onely sonne, for the satisfying of his owne Iustice, and for the redemption of rebells, that had risen vp against him: Consider in the next place, how hee seales this couenant with vs, wee breake with him continually and proue false in the couenant, he neuer failes towards vs, and yet, hee is ready vpon all opportunities to confirme it vnto vs: he giues vs all possible satisfaction for the present, and for the future, he is ready from time to time, as wee faile on our part, and so are ready to question any part of the couenant, to seale againe vnto vs, this yeare, and that yeare, this quarter, and that quarter, this moneth, and that moneth; whensoeuer we faile or doubt, if we but come vnto him in his ordinances and desire satisfaction, he is ready to set to a new seale for our confirmation; with great men you see it is farre otherwise, who knowes not what a businesse it is to draw them to sealing, especially in gratuities, they reckon it presumptiō and saucines in such cases to cal
vpon them for securitie, if you will trust to their gentlenesse, or rest vpon their bare words, well and good, if not, you may chuse, and goe without: But if at length they be once drawne to seale, you must looke to your selfe for euer after, and not expect a new sealing. But now, the Lord is not onely ready to seale a couenant with his people once, but againe and againe hee seales it, euen as often as his children shall scruple him, or make any question of his loue to them. But, lastly, 'tis nothing to smite and seale a couenant, if it be not kept and performed:Psal. 111.5. therefore God is euer mindefull of his couenant, as saith the Psalmist, hee beares it still before him, and hath it euer in his minde, to make good his couenant in all the particulars, as well on our part, as on his owne; and he takes it wel, if we mind him of his couenant, and presse him with his promise: Great men cannot endure to be so dealt withall, they will soone be out of all patience with the man that shall dare to presse and charge them with their couenants, but it is not so with God, for the more wee vrge him with his couenant, and hold him to it, the better hee likes it and the sooner hee inclines to vs. Thus in the generall you may see the goodnesse of God in this couenant, which will yet further appeare, if wee looke a little to particulars, and compare it with such couenants as God made of old.

And first,The excellency of our couenant beyond that with Adam and with Israel. with that couenant that was made with Adam in the state of innocency: it was a fauor to that first man that God would take him into fellowship and communion with himselfe, and
become his debter, but this was a couenant of workes, not of grace; it was, winne it and weare it, &c. Againe, that was a couenant of amity, not of Reconciliation, for there was no breach made before, as now there is between vs and our God. 3. That first couenant Adam was to make good of himselfe, and by his owne power, he was to stand vpon his owne bottome, and to trust to his owne strength, but here God vndertakes to enable vs to walke in his statutes, &c. 4. In that couenant, God tooke the very first forfeiture vpon the first breach. Adam dyed for it, and then the couenant was at an end: But it is not so here: for though wee breake often with him, yet hee takes not the aduantage against vs, as he might, but repaires our breaches, and confirmes vs in the couenant, so that wee are, you see, vpon better termes with God, then Adam was.

Come on in the next place to Gods couenannt with the Patriarckes, and people of Israel, that was a couenant of grace too, as well as this with vs, and the very same in substance with ours, but yet wee haue very great aduantages, that they wanted:

For, first they looked vpon things as they were to be done heereafter: Christ the Sauiour of the world was promised indeed, but not yet exhibited, but now we look vpon all as done, dispatcht, and finished. It is not now (as Austin saith) Christ shall be borne, Christ shall dye, Christ shall rise againe, &c. but hee is already.

Next, their seales were more painefull and
chargeable then ours are, which in comparison of theirs, are cheape and easie. Circumcision was a painefull Sacrament: the Passeouer, and other sacrifices were costly, and chargeable, besides the trouble of them too, for they were tyed to take long iournies at certaine times of the yeere, vp to Ierusalem.

Lastly, our writing is farre more cleare, and fairelier written then theirs was; theirs was done more darkly, ours is apparent and conspicuous. They had a Mediator, Moses, Christ is a Mediatour of a better testament, and in a more heauenly manner; they had the blood of Christ too, but shadowed onely in the blood of bulls and goates, &c. but we haue the very blood of Christ it selfe, to seale vp vnto vs this couenant of grace.

So that wee are herein beyond, not Heathens onely who were without God, and without the couenant, but euen beyond Adam in his innocency,Heb 1.8. beyond Gods ancient people of Israel, for we haue a better couenant then they had, made vpon better promises, vpon better termes and conditions, vpon better euidences and assurances, &c. Oh see his goodnesse in this behalfe, and be moued to say as Dauid in a case not vnlike, when the Lord had graciously promised to build him an house, and to be good vnto him in his seed, he gat him into Gods house, and sate downe, and bethought himselfe, and said, Who am I, O Lord God, 2 Sam. 7. and what is my house, that thou hafl broght me hither to? so say you with your selues, what are wee more then the heathen, more then Adam in the state of
〈12 pages missing〉
innocency, more then the ancient Israell of God, that hee should make with vs such a couenant of peace, &c.

Ʋse 2 Sith God is so ready, as hath beene said, to make a couenant with vs, learne we to be as ready on the other side: 1. to smite the couenant with God: 2. to keepe it: and 3. to improue it, and make our vse of it.

For the first, hee is ready to make a couenant, why are not wee as ready? why doe not wee salute and imbrace the promises a farre off,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
as those of old did, Heb. 11.13. why are wee not as ready as Benhadad was to catch at any word of comfort. Is my brother Benhadad yet aliue? said Ahab, Thy brother Benhadad, said they? Why, doe wee not lay hold vpon the hint, and euen cheerefully and ioyfully passe into the couenant.

What the couenant is.To stirre you vp the better hereunto, let vs open the point a little, and so wee will shew you first, what a couenant is in generall: secondly, what be the kindes of it: thirdly, what motiues there are to quicken you to embrace this couenant.

A couenant is nothing else but a solemne contract passing betweene some parties, (two at the least) whereby they binde themselues each to other in certaine articles to both their contents, for their mutuall peace and comfort.

The parties, first, must be two at least: the couenant a man makes with himselfe, as when Iob made a couenant with his eyes, is a metaphoricall couenant, not proper, and yet in that case too there are two parties in one person, a couenanter,
and a couenanted; euery new man being two men, &c. But in euery couenant that's formall and proper, there must be two parties at least: two diuers persons if their haue beene no breach, and two differing persons if there hath.

As for the matter of a couenant, it stands in the articles of agreement, in such promises as are giuen and accepted to and fro, if the couenant be kept, together with a certaine sanction and forfeirure, if they keepe it not: For the forme and maner it, must be done with some solemnity. And herein stands the difference betweene a promise and a couenant; euery couenant is a promise, but not euery promise a couenant, for a couenant is a promise made with a great deale of solemnity. The Hebrews (and after them other nations) vsed many ceremonies at their couenant makings, they vsually had a feast thereat: whence it is, that the same word, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is taken for both a couenant, and a feast: there passed also many pawnes and pledges on both sides, &c.

The end of all was for the establishing a mutuall peace betweene the parties, for the perpetuating of peace where it was, for the repairing of it where it had beene interrupted, for the setling of it, where as yet it hath not beene.

For the second couenants are either, 1. ciuill: these we haue here nothing to do with, and therefore passe them by: 2. sacred: These againe are eyther personall or publike: This we now speak of is a publike couenant: and here God tenders two instruments, as it were, to his people, a double couenant:
one of workes, and the other of grace, which two are now incompatible: If a man will be saued by the couenant of grace, hee must let goe workes, I meane, in point of Iustification, and an opinion to be saued by them: But if any will needs be saued by workes, hee is falne from grace, as Paul tells the Galatians: For if saluation be of workes, it is no more of grace, else works should be no workes, &c.

The couenant of workes stands vpon personall obedience to all Gods Commandements, the sanction of this couenant is, Doe this and liue, faile in doing of it and dye. The seales of this couenant were the tree of life, in case man obeyed, the tree of knowledge of good and euill, in case hee brake it.

The Couenant of grace is this: be content to accept of anothers obedience, and to lay hold vpon the righteousnesse of Christ for Iustification. The sanction of this couenant is, Hee that beleeueth in the Sonne of God, hath eternall life; hee that beleeueth not, is condemned already: The seales of this new couenant, where 'tis accepted, are Baptisme, and the Lords Supper. The punishment, in case men obey not, are the censures of the Church, excommunication, and that great Anathema Macanatha.

And this is that couenant we now speak of, that God is so ready to make with his people, euen a couenant of grace and peace, they cannot performe legall obedience in the couenant of workes to be saued thereby: God would haue them therefore
to make a choyce of Christ for their sole Sauiour, to cleaue to him, and to rest vpon him for safety and saluation.
And now that you haue seene what this couenant of grace is, what neede more words to perswade you to imbrace it; and yet there want not many motiues hereunto.

1. It is greatly for our aduantage to make this couenant with God. For: 1. what an honour is it to vs, that God should vouchsafe to enter into bond, as it were, for our security? 2. what a benefit? I will be your God &c. as if he had said, Accept of Iesus Christ for your Sauiour, and then I will bestow my selfe vpon you, looke whatsoeuer is mine, my goodnesse, my wisdome, mine happinesse, &c. All is yours, I will communicate my selfe vnto you, so farre as you are capable, and throughout all eternity, I'll be your life: Princes may couenant with their subiects for peace, for liuing, for liberty, but none besides God can make a couenant of life with any: it is hee alone that can say vnto vs, liue and neuer dye, as in that place of Ezekiel forecited, I said vnto her, liue, viz. the life of grace here, and the life of glory hereafter. It is God onely that can speake life to his people: and what so sweet as life? whan can there be better then eternall life?

2. Next, see how free a couenant it is God makes with vs, euen a couenant of grace: there is nothing required of vs more then this, to disclaime our selues, and to make Christ alone our Teacher, our head, our all-sufficient
Sauiour, for in him wee shall be beloued.
3. Consider how full a couenant this is; hee vndertakes with vs not for our selues onely, but for our seede after vs: for, I am thy God, and the God of thy seed.

4. As it is a full, so 'tis also a firme couenant, euen such as shall stand vnalterable to all perpetuity;Ierem. 31. Esay. 54. Heauen and earth shall passe, but not one title thereof shall fall to the ground; 'tis an euerlasting couenant.

Lastly, see how desirous the Lord is to enter into this couenant with you, for he sent his Sonne into the world on purpose to make this couenant, and now still he sends abroad his ambassadours in his name, to entreat you to accept of condition of peace, and to be content to be reconciled vnto him.

Now therefore, as Ioshua sometimes spake to the children of Israel, when hee renewed the couenant betweene them and God: Feare the Lord, saith hee, and serue him in sincerity and truth, &c. And if it seeme euill to you this day to serue the Lord, chuse you this day whom you will serue, &c. So say I to euery one that heares mee this day; make your choyce, and resolue whom you will cleaue vnto, and which way you will take for your owne safety: But if it be so, that there be no such God as the Lord, no such Sauiour as Christ, no such couenant as the couenant of grace, no such performance as Gods, no such worke, no such wages, no such plaine-dealing in all the world as with him, be you entreated to bestow
your selues vpon him, let him haue your hearts; we beg it of you, we beseech you in Christs steed be reconciled vnto God, let him haue loue for loue: He hath made you, he hath bred you, he hath fed you, he hath taught you, he hath done all for you; therefore, let him haue all, yea, bestow your selues also vpon him; Nay, this you haue done already, the couenant is not now to make, it was made long since euen in your Baptisme: The tender of our selues in that Sacrament was a reall passing ouer of our selues to God; Baptisme was the seale of the Couenant giuen on Gods part, and taken on your part: And euery time you come to the Lords Table, you renue this Couenant, you take the Bread and wine vpon it, you seale to it that you will be Gods people, &c Now therefore, see that ye be men of your words, and keepe the couenant you haue made with God.

And that's the second thing we propounded to be done by euery one of you, keepe couenant with your God, we haue the aduantage of it, we shall be sure to haue the comfort, the safety, the happinesse; in doing of this, there is great reward; for God cannot lye, he cannot deny himselfe, he cannot but make good vnto vs, whateuer he hath vndertaken to do for vs, therfore hold him to't; And that you may not faile of the promise, mind your selues often of your Couenant in Baptisme, remember what you there receiued and promised, consider that in comming to the Lords table, you renued this couenant, you receiued the seale thereof: hee gaue his earnest-peny to you to hire yo •
for his seruants, & you accepted it, so that the bargaine now is made, there's no starting, no flinching from it; when therfore at any time you are tempted to the committing of sinne, say; no, I must now lye no more, sweare no more, breake Gods Sabbath no more, trade in any of those dark courses no more; it is against my bargaine, &c: such a Sabbath, in such a congregation, before such and such witnesses I tooke the Sacrament vpon it, that I would doe so no more, &c: So likewise, when you finde your selues backward to any holy duty, slack to doe God seruice, say, what? shall I dodge and falter with God? No, I tooke the Sacrament to doe otherwise, I tooke it vpon my saluation, that I would performe my best seruice to God, and vpon my damnation, if I did it not, &c; shall I therfore falter with God? dodge with heauen? faile of that I haue promised, bee worse then my bargaine? No, it is my couenant, and therefore I will hold me to it.

Lastly, bee you all exhorted to improue this couenant for all good intents and purposes, but especially, for the confirmation and strengthening of your faith: Say I haue Gods hand, Gods seale, Gods oath, that he will be my God; why should I not then take heart and comfort? Hee willingly made this couenant with me, and aduisedly he did it, therefore he will surely make it good vnto me.
• biect.If I cound doe m • part of the couenant, should not doubt, that God would doe his.

Solu.It is a couenant of grace that we are entred into, a •• God hath vndertaken for vs aswell as for himselfe,
that he will giue vs a soft and tractable heart, &c; that we may walke in his statutes, &c.
Oh, but I finde that I cannot doe thus, Obiect. I do not walke in Gods statutes, and keepe his ordinances?

Legally thou canst not,Sol. but an Euangelicall obedience thou canst and doest performe: for there is truth and vprightnesse to bee found in euery one of Gods children, and this is all the condition that God requires of his people, as in that couenant he made with Abraham: Walke before me and be vpright, and then I will be thy God, &c. And this euery child of God is able to say of himself, either I leaue all sinne, or I would leaue it, either I performe all duty, or I would doe it: wherin I come short, I am humbled, and do bewaile my faylings, but verily this is the marke I ayme at, this is the white I shoot at, in all things how to please God, and this is accepted of him.
I am ready to fall from this couenant euer and anone; Obiect.
It is one part of Gods Couenant to hold vs on,Sol. to keepe vs safe and entire to his kingdome, and in case we straggle: to fetch vs in againe

Oh, but I breake promise with God euery day, Obiect. I come indeed to the Sacrament, and there I promise, at least I purpose to leaue such a sinne, to do such a duty, and within a day or two I am quite off againe?

You must distinguish of sinnes:Solu. some are grosse and soule, these you must beware, take heed you step not beyond your bounds in this kind. Some againe, are lesser infirmities, our daily vnauoidable
faylings, these though they make a breach, yet they forfeit not the couenant, they make not a nullity. It fares herein as betweene the Land-lord and tennant, euery petty offence doth not make forfeiture of the estate, and as it is betweene husband and wife, not euery small offence betweene them nullifies the couenant made in wedlock, but such only as strike at the marriage knot, and break it, as adultery: So here, not euery small fayling shall seem cause sufficient of a diuorce from God. He hates putting away, but if wee goe a whoring from vnder God after other louers, if we suff • r other gods to creepe in betwixt Christ and the heart, if we dote vpon any thing, prize any thing, if wee set vp idols in our hearts, and preferre any thing in the world before our husband Christ, before our Father, God; this makes a grosse breach in the Couenant, and if God should take the forfeiture of vs, hee is at liberty, he might doe it: And yet in that case too, he hath not left vs cōfortlesse, see what he saith, Ier. 3.1. They say, if a man put away his wife, and she goe from him, and become another mans, shall he returne vnto her againe? shall not that land be greatly polluted? but thou hast plaid the harlot with many louers, yet returne againe to me, saith the Lord. Now, if in sinnes of this nature God proclaime mercy to his people, how much more in case of ordinary infirmities? The Christian man failes in his loue, failes in his faith, failes in his prayer, he is troubled at, humbled for it. Now let him flee to God, seeke to be found in him, and not in himselfe, &c; and so shall he be accepted.
Only be sure you be in the couenant, and then God will be a God to you; then the which, what can be said more to your comfort, though we should speake vnto you this twelue moneth. Quest.

How shall I know that God is in couenant with me? He hath indeed smitten with me an outward couenant in the Sacrament of Baptisme, but how may I come to know that God is in speciall Couenant with me, and that he is my God?

For your satisfaction herein, see first, Answ. how this couenant workes vpon you, and affects you. Doth it driue you from sinne, and make you diligent in duty? doth it (as the Apostle presseth the point and makes this vse of the couenant, 2 Cor. 7.1.) cleanse you from all filthinesse of flesh and spirit, so as you perfect holinesse in the feare of God, as he saith; Hauing these precious promises compiled, as it were, and composed into one body of the Couenant, purge your selues from open filthinesse, and from secret sinnes, and endeauour perfection of holinesse more and more.

Againe, see whether you haue the counterpane of Gods Couenant within you or no: for he hath promised in this new Couenant to put his feare in our hearts, and write his lawes in our inward parts &c: these are as a paire of Indentures, whereof he keepes the one, and giues vs the other: So that euery child of God hath this couenant written vpon his heart (they are all taught of God) he finds this onenesse, this newnesse, this softnesse of spirit, in himselfe aswell as in the text, hee hath the minde of God, his minde is as God is, his life as
Gods is, hee walkes as Christ walked, &c: he is conformed to the will of God, made partaker of the diuine nature, he hath a diuine stamp set vpon him, so that he is wholly a New creature.

Lastly, see what you doe in the Couenant: doe you endeauour to keepe touch with God and to please him in all things? and when you faile and come short of that you should do, haue you no rest your soules, till you haue been with God, & there shamed your selues in his presence, and made your peace? well and good then, for this you may trust to: If your greatest care be to please God, your greatest feare lest you should offend him, if you loue him best, rest vpon him, and cleaue to him most, if you make choyce of him for your life and happinesse; so as you had rather haue him, then a world of worlds, &c: if thus ye keepe touch with him, hee also will make good his couenant with you in all the particulars, so that your hearts shall be amended, your corruptions cured, your graces encreased, and all things needfull for life and godlinesse shall be confirmed and made good vpon you.

WE are now come to the close of the Couenant, the summe whereof is deliuered in these tearmes They shall be my people, and I will be their God. We spake the last time vnto you of this Couenant, & shewed what a Couenant was in the
generall, what kind of couenants God hath vouchsafed to make with his people, together with some other particulars then mentioned. It remaines now that we should proceed to speake of the persons concurring (although differently) in this couenant, viz. God and his people. Something hath beene said already of the people of God in a former point; therefore, we passe by that part, and come to the last of all, which is the vpshot of all, and that that doth consummate mans happinesse, and cheifely seale vp Gods Loue vnto him: I will be their God, that is in short; I'll binde my selfe to do for them, all that can be expected from a God. Doctr.

The point we would hence commend vnto you, is: That the height of mans happinesse lyes in this, that he hath God for his God; that God is reconciled vnto him, and become a father, that God is pleased to be in couenant with him. Hence is it that this concludes the couenant here this is the end of all, and crownes all these former mercies aboue-mentioned. Wherefore doth God seuer a people to himselfe from the rest of the world, wherefore doth he worke a cure both vpon their inside and outside? all tends to this, I will be their God, &c. Lo, this crownes all the rest, and is the top of mans felicity, when God takes him into couenant.
For proofe of this point, we haue a double testimony, 1. from Gods selfe (and that should bee sufficient) 2. from the people of God.

God, when he had spoken much by way of promise to his Church, as that he would giue them raine
in the due season, Leuit. 26. &c: so that they should eate of the old store, and bring forth the old because of the new: yea, that he would set his tabernacle among them, &c: at length he concludes all with this, ver. 12 I will walk among you, I wil euen neighbour with you, as it were, and I will be your God, and ye shall be my people. So 2 Cor. 6.17, 18. Come out from among them, and be ye separate, saith the Lord, and touch not the vncleane thing, and I will receiue you: And I will bee a father vnto you, and ye shall bee my sonnes and daughters, saith the Lord Almighty. Loe, when God inuites a people, and speakes all mercies to them in one, it is thus; I will be a father vnto you, &c. As on the other side, when hee would shew himselfe most of all displeased with a people, and seale vp greatest wrath against them, he calles them Loammi, Hos. 1.9. Ye are not my people, and I will not be your God; as if he had said, I am now diuorced from them, I haue discarded them, and turned them off; I'll owne them no longer, let them labour vnder this curse; I'll be their God no more.

And if with this Testimony of God, you ioyne the testimony of the Church, the point will be yet more plainly proued, Ps. 144.15. Happy is that people that is in such a case, yea, happy is that people whose God is the Lord. They had spoken before of som special mercies, but this is it that crownes all, when God is pleased himselfe to come along with his mercies. See a like place, Psal. 33 12. Blessed is that • ation, whose God is the Lord: and the people whom he hath chosen for his owne inheritance. The honour and happinesse of a nation and people lyes in this, that
they haue God for their God. And the same is true also of particular persons, Psal. 65.4. Blessed is the man whom thou choosest, and causest to approach vnto thee, that he may dwell in thy courts: we shall be saisfied with the goodnesse of thy house, &c: ther'es beauty, goodnesse, fatnesse in Gods house, such as will fill the soule of a man, and giue him as much as he can desire.

Thence that exclamation of Moses, Deu. 33.29. Happy art thou o Israel, who is like vnto thee, O people, saued by the Lord the sheild of thy helpe, and who is the sword of thine excellency, &c: wherein stood the happines of Israel aboue other nations, but in this, that God was so neare them, God had made a special couenant with them? so that whether you aske the voyce of the people of God, or of God himselfe; it is granted, that the top of mans happinesse is to haue God for his God.
This you will more easily beleeue, if you consider the Reasons.

And first, when a man hath God, he hath all: Reas. 1 for God is blessednesse it selfe, and all blessednes in the world is but deriued from him. God is, as essentially in himselfe, so causally the root and fountaine of all happinesse in the creature, and euery thing is so farre forth happy, as it partakes of God. Thus, those creatures that haue a being, those that haue life, those that haue sense, are so farre happy, and no further then as God pleaseth to impart himselfe vnto them: so much of God as any hath, so much happinesse. But as this is true of the rest of the creatures, so especially of
man, a creature capable of true happinesse, and indeed made to bee happy in the enioyment of his God. For it is God alone, that can free him from that that makes a man miserable, sinne and the curse: and it is God onely that can bestow vpon him, that will make him truely blessed, Grace and glory. So that mans happinesse lyes in God.

Reas. 2 Againe, when God comes into the heart, all other comforts come along with him. If God once be your God, then Christ also is your Sauiour, the holy Ghost is your comforter; the Word is yours, the Sacraments yours, Angels, Saints, and al creatures are yours: whether it be Paul or Apollo or Cephas, or the world, or life, or death, or things present, or things to come, all are yours, both worlds are yours, and why? because ye are Christs, and Christs is Gods, 1 Cor. 3.22, 23. such an vnion there is between God and all the creatures, that in hauing him, a man comes to haue all.

Adde hereunto, the immunities and priuiledges Reas. 3 of those that haue God for their God. Wee haue spoken of many of these heretofore: The Prophet speakes all in short, Psal. 84.11. The Lord God is a Sunne, and a Sheild, the Lord will giue grace and glory: and no good thing will he with-hold from them, that walke vprightly: Looke whatsoeuer thing is truely good, and tends to the making of them happy, they shall haue it, as on the other side, whatsoeuer is truely hurtfully vnto them, and preiudiciall to their happinesse, God will certainely preuent it, therefore they must needs be happy, whose God is the Lord.

If God be the happinesse of the creature; Take Vse 1 notice, first, of those that seeke for happinesse in other things. These mistake themselues in the maine marke, in their vtmost end, and therefore must needs wander all the world wide. And this is the estate and condition of euery one of vs by nature; we all fumble indeed and grope after happinesse, but few pitch vpon it, through mistake of the thing wherein it lyes, and of the place where it is to be found, we seeke it, where it neuer grew, not in God, but in the creature. We deny not, but there are some delights and contentments to bee found in the creature, but not so much as can amount to true happines. The comforts that come this way are poore, leane, miserable, a very dream rather then any thing else, as the Prophet saith of the hungry man, that in his dreame he eates, but at his awaking, behold, he is hungry; and findes it was but a dreame, and is therefore so much the more tedious to him: so those that seeke, and found their happinesse vpon the creature are sure to be deceiued. They fancy to themselues a kind of content, but 'tis but a dreame, a delusion, ther's no such thing there to be had.

But if there were any such thing in the creature as these imagin, yet in things comparatiuely good it is the part of a wise man to make choyce of the best. Now there can be no such happinesse in the creature • , as in God; sith the creatures receiue all they haue at second hand, but God is essentially happy, the fountaine of all comfort, the God of all blessing. The creatures can giue no better
then they haue, they are imperfect, they are vncertaine, they are vnsufficient, therefore the comforts they yeeld, must needs be so too. The creatures are inferiour to man, and below him, therefore they cannot raise a man to true happinesse, which is to be found in God alone: Here then is discouered a double folly in the sonnes of men; according to that old complaint by the Prophet Ieremy, Be astonished ô ye heauens at this, and be horribly afraid, be ye very desolate, saith the Lord: For my people haue committed two euils, they haue forsaken me, the fountaine of liuing waters, and hewed them out cisternes, broken cisternes that can hold no water. Ier. 2.12.13. here's a madnesse in men that they will leaue the fountaine, and goe to a cisterne, forgoe liuing waters for those that are dead and vnsauory, forsake that that alwayes holdes water, for that that leakes, for broken cisternes: And yet this is the course of the world, they leaue God the fountaine of all felicity, and runne to cisternes that hold nothing, nothing at all. It is a great disualuing of a cleare and liuing fountaine, when a man shall leaue it and cleaue to a cisterne: And no lesse dishonour is done to God, when a man shall runne from him to the creature for happinesse. Esau heares profane to this day amongst vs, and for what? why, for that he would sell his birth-right (the seale of Gods Couenant) for a messe of pottage. And so for the Gadarenes, we look vpon them as men worse then swine, because they preferred their swine before God incarnate. And Iudas remaines a curse amongst vs to this day for this, that
he rated his master Christ at the price of a slaue, he sold him for thirty peices of siluer. And what lesse doe we then Esau, Iudas or the Gadarenes did when we passe by God, forsake God, and, as it were, kick vp God for a toy, for a trifle, for a thing of nought? For what are all the creatures compared to God, but as the drop of a bucket, or dust of the ballance, as saith the Prophet, Esay 40.15. what's a drop to the whole bucket? what's the bucket to the well? what's the well to the sea? Againe, what's the small dust of the ballance, to the ballance it selfe? what's the ballance to the earth? what's the earth to the whole vniuerse? what's all the world to the great God, who made all with the breath of his mouth? Now therefore, to set so light by the Almighty, for that that is not as the drop of a bucket, or small dust of the ballance (for all nations laid together amoūt not to so much as that comes to, saith the Prophet, how much lesse any one or some few of the creatures?) is the greatest vnthankfulnesse, the greatest folly and ouersight that can be imagined. And yet how many haue we amongst vs, that for a very trifle, for a groate, for a peny, yea, sometimes for a farthing will deny God, hurt their consciences, hazard the losse of heauen, &c. Let the heathen blush at this impiety: would any of them euer sell their Gods, and that for a bable, a thing of nothing: what a madnesse then is it in them that for a very trifle will forsake God, and endanger themselues to his fierce wrath for euer?

But if they be so much to bee blamed that preferre
earth before heauen, what shall we thinke of such as preferre hell before heauen, such as rather then they'll deny themselues in any sinnefull lust or passion, will let conscience goe, God go, Christ goe, yea, heauen and all goe: These what doe they else but preferre hell before heauen, Satan before God, &c: whilest they will needs seek happinesse in darkenesse rather then in light, &c.
Vse 2 Be wee all exhorted to resolue at length where true happinesse lyes, namly in God, if we seeke it any where else, wee doe worse then loose our labour.

This exhortation must be addressed to two sorts of people: First, to those that are yet to come in, young beginners that haue not yet married themselues to God. And for these, let mee perswade them to resolue vpon this truth, that there's no happinesse to be had but in God: for a great part of their time is runne out with many men, before they know where their maine businesse lyeth. Man was made for happinesse, neither can his heart euer bee at rest till it hath pitcht vpon something which (at least in his imagination) can make him happy: only herin lyes his misery that he mistakes himselfe in the matter of his happinesse, whilst he vainely seekes it in the creature. Men might take Salomons word without trying any further conclusions. Vanity of vanities, saith hee, all is vanity, he spake it vpon experience: and when men finde themselues (as they shall) disappointed of their hopes and expectances, they will then say they are vanity and something else too, namely, vexation▪
For 1. the creatures are all finite, but man hath something in him of infinitenesse, neither can hee rest satisfied till hee finde that that's infinitely good. 2. The creature laboureth vnder Gods curse vnto this day, and therefore cannot possibly make man blessed. 3. The creatures are all cumberous and troublesome, so that a man had better not stand in need of them, then haue them, and therefore in heauen it shall bee our happinesse not to need these present comforts, as food, clothes, &c: how then can they make vs truely happy? 4. These comforts that come from the creature, are meerely partiall and particular, they serue not to all turnes, they cannot supply all our wants at once, money serues onely for one vse, food for another, clothes for another, &c: but nothing for all.
Yea, but if a man put them all together, Obiect. he may extract out of them a compound of true happinesse?

First,Solu. shew me the man that can thus compound the comforts of the creature: who is hee that can say, that he hath a body to his mind, a heart to his minde, a house to his minde, that hath an estate, a wife, children, friends, neighbours, all to his minde.

But secondly, if such a thing could bee, yet all this without God would yeeld no solid content. See it in Adam; hee, when he had fallen from God, was yet in paradise, a place of pleasure, and for wealth, he was heyre of all the world. But what was all this to Adam, when he had lost God
once? Looke vp to heauen and see it in the Apostate Angels, they were in heauen when they sinned, where God is specially present, and yet when they had lost God, heauen it selfe was a very hell vnto them: I doe verily beleeue they had rather a great deale haue beene in hell then in heauen; when vpon their sin they beheld such an infinit distance and disproportion between God and themselues: you see that though a man had al the world, nay heauen, heauen it selfe would be a very hell vnto him without God. Therfore, let no man seeke for happinesse in the creature, but sit down by this conclusion: All the creatures are very vanity and vexation of spirit without God.

Secondly, when you haue gotten thus far, conclude with your selues, that you must haue God, if euer you shal be happy. Indeed, al the world is in a manner conuinced of this, that there is no happinesse without the hauing of a God, and therefore rather then man will want a God, he will make himselfe his owne God, as hauing this principle within him engrauen, no God, no happinesse. Neithe • will euery God serue the turne for true happinesse, safety and content. A false god makes but a false happines, an vnsufficient god, an imperfect happines: so then if you would haue happinesse you must haue the true God for your God: for til then the heart of man, that was made for happines, can neuer be at quiet. For, as the eye being made for light is neuer at rest till it be brought to the light: and as the stomake, being it was made for meate, is neuer at rest till meat be giuen vnto it in due manner and in due season: so also the soule of man is
neuer at quiet, it is not vpon its center, it takes no content till it hath God (for whom it was made) and not euery God neither, but that God that is described in the Bible, to be a God of al mercy and consolation, an infinite, all-sufficient Maiesty, hee that made heauen and earth by his word, that gaue vs our soules, and makes things to suite with our dispositions, &c. This God we must haue, or we cannot be happy.
How haue him? haue we him not already? Quest. Are we not in couenant with God as his people? Doe we not professe the true religion of God? Where is God to be found, if not amongst vs?

It is one thing to haue God in outward profession, Answ. and another thing to haue him in respect of propriety, as our God: We all haue God in regard of the profession of his truth, and the enioyment of his ordinances, and this is our happinesse aboue other nations. But this is not enough to proue vs happy, vnlesse we be in speciall Couenant with God: for these two are set together by the Apostle, without the Couenant and without God in the world, Ephes. 2.12. so that till God become his, by a propriety, a man can haue no sweetnesse, comfort, happinesse in any thing. Therfore striue to be able to say, God, euen our owne God shall giue vs his blessing. In other matters, we are all for proprieties. If a man see a faire house, he wisheth to himselfe. I would it were mine, so, if a fat pasture, a handsome horse, &c: he can scarce looke vpon any thing excellent or desirable, but he couets it for his owne. These wishes are sometimes sinfull and
vnwarantable, alwayes they are bootlesse & vnsufficient: But it is both lawful and profitable to wish, Oh that God were mine! oh that he would please to receiue mee into the number of his people, to blesse me, and to take me for his seruant.
And this I dare vndertake that neuer any man desires in good earnest, but, he obtaines it, God bestowes himselfe on that man, that in true desire would haue God for his God.

Therefore, labour all you can to get him for your owne; but how your owne? first, get God reconciled vnto you, otherwise hee is a consuming fire, not a Father, but a Iudge; not a friend vnto vs, but an enemy; he that hath not God for a Father, hath him for an enemy: and oh what an vnequall match must that needs bee, when mortality must wrestle with immortality, when the pitcher shall striue with him that made it, and dash against the Rock that will certainely breake it in peices. It cannot but goe hard on mans side, when God shall set against him: And yet this is the case of vs all; either God is our God or our enemie. Therfore labour to be reconciled to God, and make peace with him: you know what a fearefull thing it is to fall into the punishing hands of the liuing God; when the best men apprehend him as displeased, and frowning vpon them, and that he will not looke sweetly vpon them and receiue their prayers, this kills their very hearts, insomuch as some wisht to endure hell rather then Gods displeasure; yea, they haue held it much better to lye in hel a thousand yeeres, if then God would smile vpon them,
and shew them fauor, then to haue his displeasure: Therefore labour a reconciliation, goe to your peace-maker Christ, take him vp in your armes, set between him God & your soules, pray him for Christs sake to be reconciled vnto you: And take bold of the word of reconciliation committed vnto vs, who are Embassadours of Christ; as though God did beseech you by vs, we pray you in Christs steed, be ye reconciled to God, 2 Cor. 5.20. Loe, God intreates you for a peace, oh take the hint, and say, Lord, thou suest for a peace to me, I also sue for peace with thee: thou entreatest me to be reconciled, behold, I entreate thee, I entreate thee, that it may bee a match betweene vs, and that there bee no longer strangenesse.

Secondly, rest not in being reconciled, but striue to be vnited vnto him, get a vnion with God, not a vnion of peace onely, but of grace too; which is the foundation of the other, it is knowledge, faith, loue, dependance vpon God and such like graces, that doe vnite vs vnto him: by these you must go out of your selues, and cling fast vnto him, as your life and happinesse, in whom you liue more then in your selues.

And this Vnion once made, come on to a communion with God, for it is that that makes a man happy. Indeed Vnion with God giues vs right, but communion giues the fruition and sensible enioyment of all; what is a man the better for hauing a brother, if he neuer see him, if hee neuer make vse of him? what good is it to haue a friend in the court, and neuer receiue any benefit by him:
so what is it to haue God for our God, if we fly not vnto him, if we make not vse of him. Therfore be much in Gods presence, runne to him by prayer, heare him in his word, reade him in his bookes, peruse his promises, euery day let him heare from you, looke him in the face, visit him often, walke with God in the light as he is light,1 Ioh. 1. for herein stands your happinesse and comfort, because hereby you haue communion.

Secondly, for such as are already in couenāt with God, and so haue laid hold of true happinesse in him, let them be exhorted to deale as good husbands vse to doe in like case, when they light vpon a good bargaine, they step not backe, they slip not the opportunity, but labour to get all good assurance thereof, and to bind it as fast as they can for present, and afterwards more, as counsell shall direct them. Here you know what a man will do, lay earnest of the bargaine, draw writings, call in statutes, leuy a fine, &c; make all as sure as possibly he can. The same must wee doe here, wee haue God in bonds to vs, if we goe not back, hee will not onely make the matter as sure as you can: giue ouer these May bees, leaue this houering, these vncertaineties; I cannot tell what to say of my selfe, I dare not say, I am not a child of God, and yet I rest somewhat doubtfull thereof, &c: but driue it to an issue, secure this maine point, yea, adde to your assurance of this, that you are in speciall couenant with God, and that he is yours: get more and more euidences of this to your selues. This is needfull to be done, this is comfortable
to be done: for all the particular promises depend vpon this maine charter, that God is our God: therefore put it out of all question.
How should this be done? Quest.

We told you before in part. First, Answ. you must deny your selues 1 in euery sin, for while wickednesse pleaseth a man, and is held as sweete meate vnder his tongue (as the Scripture speakes) he cannot be secured of Gods fauour. 2 as you must deny your selues in your lusts, so in matter of merits too: The Papist is therefore so vncertaine, and hangs loose in this maine point, because he founds his happinesse vpon himselfe, and seekes it by his owne good workes. 3. deny your selues in your sense, consult not with carnall reason, but go quite out of your selues, and rest wholly vpon the word.

Secondly, these things thus done, build forward: Looke 1. vpon such signes of saluation as are most generall, and most sensible; as 1. for your company, what side doe you take? what company doe ye delight in? 2. for your affections (they are sensible things) see whether ye hate sin, whether you loue goodnesse, what doe yee most thirst after, what doe ye prize most, delight in most, &c: and accordingly make iudgement of your selues.

2. Then adde hereunto those other notes of stronger Christians, of a man in Christ, neuer ceasing till you haue settled this to your selues, that God is yours. This is that wil stand you insteed in
the euill day. Now, while the season is cleare, and all things goe well with men, God is of no reckoning with them, they can shift well enough without him; but when sicknesse comes, when they shall lye vpon their death-beds, and at the day of Iudegement, when the fire shall be about their eares, then God will be God to a man, then Christ will be Christ, then it will appeare what cōmunion with God is worth, &c; and things should Vse 3 be prized now as they will proue then.

Instruction how to iudge of mens happinesse, namely, by their relation to God, and cōmunion with him. As any man hath more interest into, and acquaintance with God, so is he to bee esteemed more or lesse happy. Neuer aske the world who is the happy man, for this is (saith a father) as to aske a sicke mans opinion of the relish of meats,Ambr. or a blind man what he thinkes of colours. The world vsually speakes in this question according to its wit, oh such a one, say they, is an happy man, he doth gayly well, for he hath a great Liuing, a faire house, &c: Againe, such a one is made, for he hath a great wind-fall of late, he hath wonderous luck, he hath met with a great match, &c. A third cannot doe amisse, for he is held vp by the chinne by such and such good friends, and how can he miscarry? &c.

How's this? how's this? my brethren, is a man therefore happy, because he hath such goods and so much money, because hee hath a little land, a few sheepe, a daily friend, &c? I would faine know what sinne these can keepe from the soule, or what
soule they can keepe from hell? (and can a man be happy in hell?) No, but he alone is to bee reputed rich and happy, whom God loueth and fauoureth, neither can that man euer doe amisse, that hath him for a daily friend: Other friends, though neuer so kind, may be dead; or their affections or their abilities to doe vs good may be dead: onely God is constant in his loue, and for his power, he is still one and the same; therefore, he is an happy man that hath God for his God, that is in speciall couenant with him, and he alone.
Yea, Obiect. but many of these you call happy men haue wants enough?

It is one thing to be without,Solu. and another thing to want, Gods people neede not many things, and therefore they want them not, although they haue them not; we said before that it is a greater happinesse, not to be in need of these outward things, then to haue them in all abundance.
I, but they want necessaries, many of them? Obiect.

One thing onely is necessary,Solut. and that they are sure to haue, besides God will withhold from them, no other thing that's good for them, that serues to make them good; as on the other side, they are sure to feele no euill that shall impeach their happinesse. Therefore, let vs blesse such men as the richest, greatest, happiest and most honourable of all men. Christ is not ashamed to call them brethren, saith the Authour to the Hebrewes, God is not ashamed to be a Father vnto them, and shall we be ashamed of them whom God doth honor? The righteous is more excellent then his neighbour,
saith Salom. of greater parentage, of greater place, of greater expectation here, and shal be of far greater entertainment at the last day this is true in the spirituall, not ciuill regiment, and so take it.

Comfort to all those that are in Couenant Vse 4 with God, that haue the Lord for their God, &c: when ye shall heare men boast, and say: This ground is mine, or this lordship belongs to me, you may speake all in one, and say: God's mine, God's mine; he is my portion, he is mine habitation, he is my life, all that I trust to, all I stand in need of: If God be thine; al that's contained in this couenant is thine, all in the Bible's thine, all comforts, all creatures are thine in right, and thou shalt enioy them, when thou shalt most need them: All in Christ is thine, his loue, his graces, his merits, &c; what should we say more, God's thine, God's thine, and al that is in God is for thee, his truth for thy security, his loue for thy comfort, his power for thy protection, &c, in a word, all Gods excellencies and perfections are thine.
Obiect. How then is it that I suffer want of these outward comforts?

Sol.What father doth not chastise and restraine his child during his minority. A Prince is not set vpon the throne presently, so soon as euer he is born. God bestowes good things vpon vs by times, and as we are able to receiue them, and in the meane time, we shall haue all things so farre as may conduce to our eternall happinesse.
Yea, but for spirituall things, God hath vndertaken to mend our hearts, Obiect. and to make a supply of all needfull graces, &c?

Here's a couenant you see,Sol. that God makes with his people, and there is euer some distance of time passeth betweene promises and performances. No man entreth into bond for the payment of money, and payes it presently, God will do all in his time.
Yea, but I sue to God for grace & obtaine it not? Obiect.
And sue still,Sol. for thou neuer suest for grace but thou gainest somewhat. Grace is a precious thing, and God bestowes it vpon vs, as we are able to receiue.

It is one thing to drinke a cup of beere; and another thing to drinke a cup of spirits or of hote-water, for this must be taken in by degrees, by little and little. If God should giue vs all at once, we should be in danger of being drunk with pride, security, &c. Besides, we haue been sick men, and being hardly recouered are still very crazy, therefore God sees it but needfull for vs to eate a little and often: but if ye be in couenant with God, and make your vse of it by presenting it to God, and pressing him with it, hee will surely stand to his word, and be as good as his bargaine.
But how shall I know whether I am in the couenant, Quest. and that God is my God?

We haue answered it already: Answ. Take this for present. First, God conueyes himselfe to such,God takes & we giue full possession. and makes them partakers of his holinesse. Hast thou then of the diuine nature in thee? hath God conueyed into thee, of his wisedome, holinesse, mercy, meekenesse, &c? hath hee giuen thee a new iudgement, a new will, new affections? hath hee
taken possession of thine heart, and is there something of God put into thee? &c.

Secondly, hast thou put God into possession of thy soule, dost thou resigne all to him, layest thou all thy comforts on him, so as thou resoluest to haue no God, no husband, no father, but him? God is thine.

Thirdly, see what vse thou makest of the Couenant, how dost thou prize it? (indeed if thou well vnderstandest the worth thereof, thou wilt set no price vpon it.Psal 119. Thousands of gold and silver, what are these to Dauid? one word of Gods mouth is much better then all, when a Christian soule is drooping vnder some temptation or corruption, there comes a word of God, a promise as he is reading or hearing, which is more worth to him then ten thousands of gold and siluer, &c: Doest thou finde it to be thus with thee, be of good comfort, thou art a right happy man, for God is thy God; and therefore in his due time, all the distempers of thy soule shall be healed and remoued, he is stil in curing them, till he haue perfected the cure; where he lights on a bruised reed, hee breakes it not, where he findes smoaking flax, he will not leaue till he hath brought foorth iudgement to victory. Art thou so weake, that thou canst not stand high-lone, he will make thee to walke in his statutes, &c. In a word, if ye wil heare my voice indeed, Exod. 19.5. not in flourish and complement, but in good earnest, and keepe my couenant, then ye shall bee my chiefe treasure, euen a kingdome of priests, and an holy nation: And ye shall be my people, and I will be your God.

but vpon one part of it, where note: 1. The preparation to it: 2. The prosecution of it. We beginne with the first, where the motiue first offers it selfe, his sight of an Auditory, and that great, that's the first thing, and the second is the manner of our blessed Sauiours behauiour and deportment: First, hee takes the hill, and being there settled, Secondly, he sits downe, and being so sate, and his hearers placed, hee opens his mouth, (in the third place) and falls to worke. The first word that falls from his blessed lips, is a blessing, but of the matter anon. Meane while, let's looke vpon the particulars already mentioned, where, before I goe any further, I craue leaue to vse mine owne method (without the least contempt of others) and my liberty (with fitting modesty) in taking vp such interpretations and collections, as shall seeme to mee most agreeable to the Text in hand, and the auditory in sight. I am very sensible of the richnesse of this Scripture, and variety of mens conceits about it; you will giue mee leaue to follow what I conceiue fittest, and, to speake popularly in a popular auditory, once for all let mee tell you, I reuerence antiquity as much as who doth most, and make vse of as many ancients and moderns as my purse can buy, and my strength will beare; if I rather read then name them, it is for your sakes, and so I pray you take it.

For the words, many things are disputed, touching these beatitudes in generall,Vide Caietan: in lentac. Pareum in loc: alios{que}. which wee will passe by, we onely touch vpon such things as giue light to the words, and way to instruction,
and that's all, First, where 'tis said, Of which, Vide Aug. Hilar: &c. ascendere dicitur qui ad summum peruenit, qui in medio subsistit. Chamier.
• . 12. c. 10. Tom. 3. De consens. Euang. l. 2. c. 19. Bunting, &c. that our Sauiour tooke the mount, it is questioned wherefore hee did so, and wee thinke it safest to shunne doubtfull mysteries, and to say as the Euangelists doe. Hee went vp, 1. to pray, and then to preach; that's in Luke, this here. Next 'tis questioned how the Euangelists must be accorded, when one saith that he came downe the hill, the other, that he went vp; the answer is, hee went first into an higher hill, or place to pray, and after came lower to preach, that's the last, and (I thinke) the best of Austins resolutions; as for the hill its selfe, and the stone where Christ is said to sit, I heare what men say, and trauellers yet report, but I loue not heare-sayes in grounding points. Well, we find him on the mount, what's his gesture and behaour there? 1. He sits: 2. He opens his mouth, &c. I'll deale plainly, I abhorre mysticall senses and allegories, where the holy Ghost is not our warrant; I dare not say, that our Sauiour sate in a mystery, as some Ancients doe, nor can I ground a generall instruction, vpon an occasionall gesture, more then this: Our LORD sate preaching, therefore 'tis lawfull in it selfe, whether necessary, let them consider who thus inferre, the LORD sate at Sacrament,Pro hic & nun • Dr. Denison de Sacr. therefore wee must whether hee sate at (our) Sacrament, is more then I know, whether hee purposely sate to binde vs to the like, is more then any man (I thinke) knowes, and till that be cleared, I dare not vrge necessity; necessity? What? Praecepti or Medij; but our Sauiour opens his mouth, and teaches; what's that?
I will not descant, it is true, our Sauiour taught with his hands,As Chrisost. and Thophy. Comment. as well as with his mouth, an • it is as true, that many open their mouths, and y •• doe not teach, at least the people; but m • an •
〈◊〉
Matthew so much? I trow not; what then? doth this phrase necessarily imply this to benis first Sermon,Vide the Iesuites ad locum. o • that now new matter comes to be broched, n • uer before vented, touching euangelicall counsells, &c. No neither, but the speech is Ebrewish, and sounds as much as hee beganne to speake, or if there be any more in it, it denotes: 1. The deliberate and aduised: 2. The cleare and free manner of our Sauiours, speaking, as the like phrase is vsed. Pro. 31.26. Act. 8.35, &c. Well, hee sits, hee teaches that people, lets vs now (after him) teach you, wee will but touch vpon the circumstances, because wee hasten to the Sermon it selfe.

Doctr. 1. Our Sauiour sees, and then teaches: Hence conclude, that. The sight of the auditory quickens the Preacher, the obiect quickens and affects the sense, the sense the vnderstanding, the vnderstanding the will, the will the whole man, and namely the tongue, hence this sight hath such an influence into these speaches; the Lord Christ, sees and speaks, and would all his messengers see their people oftener, perhaps they would speak oftner too, but what affects in an Auditory? 1. Fulnesse and greatnesse, who would not cast his net amiddest multitudes of fishes, this our Sauiors motiue here, argument else-where, both for Praying, Math. 9.38. and Preaching, Act. 18.10. Secondly, alacrity
and readinesse, when they come vpon the wing, as the doue to the window, this opened Peters mouth, Acts 10.3. Attentiuenesse, and tractablenesse, when they hang vpon the Ministers mouth, as birds doe vpon their dammes, Luk. 19.48. 4. Fruitfulnesse and growth in knowledge in obedience, this puts life into our prayers and studies at home, into our labours and application abroad, this opens the heart, the eye, the mouth, all, and the contrary to this, kills your teachers, a thinne, heauy, sleepy, froward, fruitlesse people stops the mouth, straitens the gifts, dead the spirit of a Pastor; and a people enlarged in their gifts and affections, carry a Preacher beyond himselfe, and make him more then himselfe; I haue heard much talke of barren Ministers, of silencing Ministers and the like: shall I tell you; a barren people make a barren Ministery, a cold auditory, a cold Sermon; a dead Parish, a dumbe Minister; nothing shuts our mouths and silences vs so much as our own auditories were they quick and nimble in finding eares & hearts, the great Bishops of our soules would soone finde his tongue, as you finde it here.

You see what occasioned this Sermon, now Doctr. 2 looke vpon our Sauiours pulpit, hee sate on an hill: when the heart is willing to goodnesse, it will finde meanes and opportunities of doing it. A good heart is a good contriuer, it will not be to seeke of time and place, and other fitting circumstances: witnesse our blessed Sauiour, it was his meate and drinke, to doe his worke, and therefore
an hillock, a ship, a table, any place (almost) shall serue for a pulpit, for a chappell: witnesse Saint Paul, his heart was prepared, and then hee could pray in the goale, sing in the stocks, preach at bar, and can you maruell? the heart or will is a great Princesse, and hath a great command; shee sharpens wit, Reas. quickens sense, employes hand, tongue, foote, all the man, all about the man. Againe, the Lord who eyes the heart, answerers men according to their heart, free hearts with faire opportunities; when a heart is present, occasions shall be offered on Gods part, and will bee taken on Vse. 1 mans. Therefore,

This takes off the idle excuses of all sluggards, one would preach, but hee hath a bad memory, an ill vtterance, a dry body, a worthlesse people, and that is the reason of his negligence: the reason; nay, that is the pretence, the reason is, hee wants an heart: another would pray with all his heart, but his house is too too incōuenient, he hath no priuate place; a third would read, but he hath bad eyes, and no fitting booke; a fourth would heare Sermons, but he hath ill legs, and wants a seate, a fifth would gladly doe some good, but he cannot light vpon a good opportunity and fit subiect: iust so your idle vagrant, hee would worke for his liuing, but no body will hyre him; hee would worke, but he wants cloathes, cloathes you giue him, but then he wants tooles, you supply him with tooles, but the truth is, he hath an infirmity, he is lame in his limbs and sickly, nay, the truth is, he is lame in his will & sicke of the lazies;
were the will right, these excuses needed not; mark it in your children, when they go to schoole-ward, somewhat is euer in their way, now they want their hats, and then their books, and then paper, and then quils, and next their breakefast, something still when their errand lyes that way, but when they come homeward, how then; they can play without hat, neuer dry or hungry, then there is no lamenesse, sickenesse, nothing wanting but time and day light; the reason of this, they want affection to their books, none to their sports, hence the difference; it is so with men also, thou wouldst pray, but thy house is open, &c; heare, but thy seate is farre off; reade, but thy leisure is little, &c: heare me, mend thy will, and all this is holpen; did that stand rightly disposed, a barne, a stable, a bush, a furrow should serue for an oratory and a closset to pray in; thou wouldst spare time from thy meate, from thy sleepe, but thou wouldst reade, a mat should be thy seate, thy legs a pillar, thy feet a pew, but thou wouldst heare; therefore fault not occasions but thy selfe, a sluggard neuer wants an excuse, lions be in the street, as Salomon saith of him; and a willing mind neuer wants meanes in some measure.

2. Therefore mend the will, and all is mended, as the soule doth not find but make it selfe an habitation, and fit it selfe with organs: for it is true in naturall respects, so doth it in spirituall too; a willing preacher carries his pulpit in his heart, a willing hearer his seate, a good stomacke wil make a table, a stoole, a cushion of the ground,
giue him meate, and hee will tell you that knees were made before stooles and tables, hands before kniues, thinke the same of spirituall affections; edge and whet them, and they will supply or dispence with other necessaries.

You see his pulpit, his cloth and cushion, this serueth the turne vpon occasion, but this is no rule in a setled Church: they that thinke any barne, house good enough for God, any board, stoole, table, pulpit good enough for his messenger, haue no more religion in them than what they put into their purses: But now see our Sauiours gesture, he sate, and so they doe in some Churches, and so should we, if the argument were concludent from a feast to a sitting; for sure Christ feasts vs in the Doctr. 3 Word, aswell as at the Sacrament, but we touch'd that before, all that now we note, is this: The holy Ghost obserues the very gestures of Christ in Gods worships, his sitting, standing, leaning, Ʋse. 1 groueling, but why? 1. because euery action of his is for our instruction, though not imitation euer. 2. because God would doe vs to know, that his eye is vpon all his worshipers: here wee mought fall vpon Popery, w • ich brings vp an ill report vpon the sacred writings of God, as if they smelt of some vnsufficiency, were but a partiall rule, and had not in them a full and selfe-sufficiency: what? doth God descend to circumstantials, and is he defectiue in the substance? Doth hee so often repeate ex abundanti the same thing, and in the meane forget any maine point? Doth hee acquaint vs with the very gestures of our Sauiour,
and in the meane leaue out some doctrines and articles? Doth he record these Sts. saluattions one to another, and ouer-slip necessarie instructions of his owne? Let bastards emplead his last will and testament, whilst they please, as if it were imperfect, euery true sonne will say with their elder brother, I adore the fulnesse of the Scripture. Ierom.

But I had rather speake to you; hence see what an eye is vpon you in Gods worship, true, he is a Spirit, and desires such to worship him,Ioh. 4 24. who doe it in Spirit and Truth,: but withall, he that made thy body aswell as soule, and redeemed that, and will glorifie that as well as this, hath said, that euery tongue shall confesse him, euery tree bow to him, and hee will see it done: There ore looke thou to thy foote, to thine eye, to thine eare,Rom. 14.11. to thy head, to thy knee, to thy gesture in Gods presence, for the Lord doth: And doe not vnder a pretence of superstition proue thy selfe prophane, nay, vnmannerly and clownish as many doe, who come before God, as he before Caesar, fearing nothnig, but that they should be too mannerly.

The Preacher hauing taken his place, the hearers Doctr. 4 (the Disciples first, the people next) take theirs: so it should be; the preacher once settled, the schollars should place themselues with best conueniency, this preuents confusion and disturbance,Nehem 8.4. & 9, 4. conduces to both order and edifying, hence this obserued of old in Ezra's dayes, & elsewhere, and since in the new testament: Wee onely touch vpon it, in regard of the new disorders; if you repaire to Cities and more populous places, you
shal sooner see the face of a Faire than of a Church such tumbling, brawling, clapping of pues, as little beseemes such assemblies, 2 if you looke vpon your Country-meetings, you shall finde that many come more for mans law, than Christian Gospell; to see rather than to heare; so they bee Church, and keep their own seate, it matters not, what they learne whether they heare; And hereof is it, that they profit so little; profit should they be examined by their Pastors, as the French man was by his Preacher, what they heard, they might truly answere what he did, that they knew not what language the preacher vsed, French or Latine, Latine or English: It is a blushfull thing to be vnciuil in the congregation before men and angels, and the Lord of both, but to take Gods name in vaine, to come in vaine, to sit and heare in vaine; this is horrible and neare to cursing.

The last circumstance (he taught the people) here is a preachers worke, he must haue a mouth, that must be opened, and so opened, that he teach and the people may learne: Such a one was Christ Iesus,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . such a one would S. Paul haue to receiue orders, 1. he must be apt to teach 2 he must actually teach,Discendum propter docendum. hee is Christs mouth and deputy, and must represent him to the people, and this is his errand and office, hee must learne that he may teach, as the Hebrew prouerbe runnes, but whom must he teach? the people, the flocke depending on him, what? the whole Counsell of God, so farre as concernes them; how? freely, plainely, as they are able to beare it, so did our master, and this is to teach,
as Austen notes in that excellent discourse, &c.Non dicitur quod non intelligitur. vid. August. de Doctr. Christiana. Here is our worke, and here must we sweate, but what must you doe? 1. you must learne, come and sit at the feet of your Gamaliels, as schollers, not as Masters, as many doe, and 2 your must reciprocate; if we giue you spirituals, you owe vs temporals, Cor. 9. were wee but Catechists, you heare the Apostles Canon, Let him that is taught or Catechized, Galat. 6. make his teacher, partaker of all good things; you haue the best of our time, of our wits, of our inuentions, of our blood, of our spirits, you owe vs of the best of your temporals in St. Pauls iudgment; consider of it, you looke for food, and so do wee, we must not starue soules, neither must yee starue bodyes, you expect plentifull teaching, performe plentiful meanes, men cannot liue without bread, nor study without bookes, nor preach without study, vnlesse you hold boldnesse, zeale, prating, preaching. Ob. Wee giue them what law affords them: whose Law? Gods? we aske no more, mans? take heed of pressing too much statute-wages, lest Ministers resolue vpon statute-worke: let the strife rather be, who shall exceed other in feeding, in doing duty, you or we. But we haue stayed longer than I meant in the preparation; the Lord saw fit to premise it, and we did not dare to neglect it. Trow wee come forward to the Sermon it selfe, wherein our Sauiour declares himselfe, a most wise and skilfull builder wisedome stands in sorting things to their right ends, by the fittest meanes, the end whereto all men are carried, and whereat they aime, is happinesse,
herein all concur,Vid. Seneca de vit. heat. Ca. 1. at least formally (as they speake) though not for matter; I meane, all men would bee blessed and happy, though they doe not all seeke it in the same thing: hence our Sauiour beginnes here, and proiects this first, and then 2. for the obtaining of this, propounds the right way and meanes, suiting supernaturall meanes to a supernaturall end and blessing. Touching which end wee haue somewhat to say in generall before we descend to the particular; we will not trouble you with the infinite disputes and discourses, which are extant vpon this subiect, but confine all that we meane to speak, vnto two heads, wherof the first is this: Happinesse is yet feisable and attaineable by man in this life. The next this:

It much imports and concernes man to know, where this his happinesse lyes, and is to be found. It was my meaning to haue handled one at least of the twaine at this time, but I see the time spent, and finde my selfe ouer-matcht with a Church, therefore I adiourne both.

div.head: The second SERMON.
div.p: The last day wee laid downe two conclusions, whereof the first is this:

There is blessednesse or happines as yet attaineable in this life; It is yet possible for man to be blessed, and that in this world: we first explaine our selues, and (that done) we make good the point. Possibility implyes power; power is either actiue or passiue; the conclusion is, man hath no inherent actiue power of his owne, whereby he may aduance to happinesse, onely a passiue power or capacity he hath. 2. happinesse is either full,August. de Ciuit. Dei l. 19. cap. 20. 27. entire and compleate, or else is onely substantiall and initiall; happinesse, for substance, is here attaineable, though not in fulnesse of degrees, and this appeares by testimony of God, who affirmes it of men, here for the present, and of this estate which is onely viae, euen in this our pilgrimage, thus the poore (a pilgrims estate) is blessed, the mourner (the pilgrims case) is blessed, the hungerer, the persecuted blessed, blessed for the present. as well as in reuersion, so saith God.

2 Of men first wise men,Ʋid Arist. Ethic. vlt, all your Philosophers yeeld an vtmost end, a soueraigne good (1. an happinesse) and here attaineable for substance, though not in perfection of degrees 2. all men, though they agree like clocks about particulars
(where so many men,Vid. August. de Ciuit. Dei. l. 19. cap. 1. Vinere omnes heatè volunt &c. Vid. Senec. de vit. heat. ca. 1. so many mindes) yet they concurre in the maine, all would be happy in the Generall, and God and nature which doe nothing in vaine, haue not for nought emplanted this desire: euery creature is made for an end, and that end is its happinesse (I meane) its perfection; man is the King of Creatures, and therefore made for, and capable of an higher happinesse, he is here capable of vertue, of grace, of holinesse, therefore of happinesse, he is here capable of greatest misery, therefore of felicity, hee here works for an end, and ends (one or many imply an happinesse) he is here capable, nay possessed of Gods Image in part, there is some maiesty in his face, lustre in his complexion, Lordship ouer the creatures, there is somewhat diuine in his vnderstanding, in his spirit, and this naturall Image (as some call it) conclude a capacity of more, and surely, if God hath communicated to euery species, so much happines, as he hath fitted them for, wee cannot conceiue that man amongst the rest should be quite excluded; nay, why did Christ Iesus become man; but because that whole species (mankind I meane) should not be quite abandoned: but why stand I vpon these discourses? man in this life may haue heauen in his heart, faith, loue, feare, ioy, &c; may haue Christ his head and husband betrothed, the holy Ghost his inhabitant & cōfort, God his Father, therefore in this life he may be blessed.

Vse. 1 Is man capable of happinesse? First, let iniquity stop her mouth; say, man fall into misery, whose is the fault? not Gods: Nothing comes from
God, but Goodnesse; from happinesse, but happinesse.
Secondly, he hath giuen man a nature capable of felicity, hee at the first put him into possession of happinesse. And settled him in a blessed condition: He vndid himselfe alone. Obiect.

How could he choose, Answr. when God had ordained and damned him to misery? First, its not so, for there is no damning to misery, without relation to sinne: so first, he had destroied himselfe, and then God left him vnder his owne ruines. 2. If so, yet decrees do not compell to sinne (being secret; And this presupposing sinne) no more, then a capitall law, necessitates to murder. But the matter is, God did not decree him to sinne; if we speake properly of decrees.

Obiect. But God deserted him, and then, Obiect. hee must needs fall? Ans. There is a double desertion; one such, as that he cannot but fall (2.) Such, as that he may fal. God made it not impossible to him to stand; but onely possible to all or stand: But God foresaw the issue? True (1o) but foresight is not causatiue; Ioseph, he foresaw a Famine, but caused it not: God was not bound to giue and keepe a stocke both. Ob. Vid Aqui quod lib. 11. art. 3. But his not preuenting it, argues his willingnesse of mans misery? Ans. It argueth his delight in glorying himselfe by manifesting his excellencies. As for misery, its not any obiect of delight or desire at all. Ob. But, what is this to vs, we are now depriued of possibility of saluation. Ans. Our nature is not, if any person hath depriued himselfe,
whom will hee blame, but himselfe, who is still vnwilling to blessednesse in Gods way: Why will you die, Vid. Caiet. in Rom. 9. quam optime oh house of Israel (saith God) yee would not; saith Christ: we may resolue all mans misery into that principle, mans will, and speake and walke according to the rule prescribed vs, and not foolishly and saucily charge God, as Iob did not. ca 1. when we vnderstand not our selues.

Vse. 2 Here blesse Gods goodnesse, that hath not left vnder his owne curse and misery; this goodnesse of his is commended; First, from the motiues, God did this freely, when wilfully wee chose death, catcht our fall by rebellion, did not desire God. 2. from the meanes, by plunging Christ into misery, all our ioy flowes from his sorrow, our cōfort and honour from his shame. 3. from the matter, hee made the bone stronger then euer it was made, I meane, vs more happy then other creatures, whereas we were more miserable. A toade was a man to vs, and wee the toade once: but now we aree more happy then they. Nay 2. then the Angels, they being seruants, we sonnes, married to the heire. Thirdly, more happy then Adam, his estate was happy, but vncertaine in his owne keeping, his was good; but not so good as ours, God was not so neare to him, as to vs, who haue Christ (God incarnate) an head and husband.
