And now if all creatures, if Adam was thankfull much more must we if the prisoner be thankfull, for bare liberty, if the malefactor for life alone, what we, who for d • ath haue life, for shame honour, Obiect. for a prison, pa • a •• e. Ob. But how
shall I know that I am blessed? Anws. Looke to the Text hereafter, and thence gather it, wee passe. Secondly, seeke the blisse, make out as the sicke man doth (if any hope) for health, the poore man for riches, the pain • d man for ease, the oppressed for right: If they doe this for priuate, and partiall goods, shall not wee for an vniuersall good? all other goods are lesse then man; this of happinesse matches, nay, exceed him, all other are mingled, vncertaine, vnsufficient, vnsatisfying, all other receiue their perfections from this, this is the end that crownes all, and therefore this must chiefely be sought.

Now, to expedite and quicken this persuite, let vs take into our consideration these particulars, as they follow First, consider the point, happinesse is feisable and hauable, for first our nature is capable of it, as w • e haue said, and as wee see, for some men are actually, and truely blessed, wee iustly blesse their estate in life, in death, in the middest, of their afflictoins, and next, the blessed promises, (though they be not euery way, and simply vniuersall, yet) are they generally and indefinitely deliuered, so that no one particular is by name excluded. Adde to this in the third place, that there is nothing within vs, no creature without vs which can keepe vs from happinesse. Originall sinne cannot, sinnes actuall cannot, men cannot, diuells cannot; happinesse rests in Gods hands, and at his dispose, If he giue quietnesse, who, saith, Elyhu, Iob 34.29. can make trouble. Fourthly, the Lord delights in our happinesse, hee ma • e
vs for it, hee calls vs to it, hee perswades acceptance, and teaches the way, &c.

Secondly, Consider it is desirable, namely, that which necessarily drawes the heart after it, none can desire misery, none can but desire blessednesse in the generall, though he faile in the particulars.

Secondly, that which makes other things desirable. Nothing else hath any worth in it, any further then it makes for happinesse, or any power at all vpon the heart, any further then it hath its prospect that way, why doe men desire, wealth, ease, health, &c. Why doe they indure paine, sweate, or any other hardship, but in relation to happinesse.

Thirdly, it is happinesse that quenches the thirst and quiets the appetite; it is the center of the soule, which neuer rests, vntill it rest here, where it receiues its perfection. It is the food of the soule, other things no more satisfie the soule, then ayre the stomacke: To make short, it is (as Salomon calls it) the whole man or, his perfection. The truth whereof will yet further appeare vnto vs, if we lay to the effects named, the parts also of happinesse. First, there is (let mee so call it) a negatiue part; full happinesse, excludes both all kindes, and all degrees of misery, it expells from its presence all darkenesse, like the sunne in his strength, and so much Schollars conceiue to be implied in the word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,Phanorinus of
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 & 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . true happinesse excludes, though not the presence, yet the poyson of all wants and crosses whatsoeuer. A man that is once pronounced blessed of God, is past all harme,
no affliction can hurt him. Nay, hee is blessed in all, because all sets him forward to happinesse, and is subordinate to it. Hereof is it that a Christian is vnder the blessing, aswell in prison as in a Palace, in a suite of leather, as in cloth of gold.
Secondly, there is a positiue part, happinesse includes all good things in it, and denotes two things.

First, a plurality, Secondly a perfection of good things; so much some thinke to be implied in the word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 being plurally vsed. So much the thing it selfe speaketh, being the vtmost end of man, which virtually contains, and finally perfects all. An happy man then is truely inuested into all things and rights truely good, with sufficient security of being saued harmelesse from the contrary, all which good, hee shall fully inioy (in the quintessence of them) when he is compleatly happy; by thus much spoken, wee finde the estate first hauable, secondly desirable; therefore now what remaines, but that wee enquire into two things. First, where mans happinesse is to be found, secondly, by what meanes it is to be attained; for the first, our Sauiours silence tells vs where it is not, his Sermon where it is; for the negatiue, mans happinesse lyeth not in outward things: Blessed saith our Sauiour are some, but who? here is no blessed are the rich, blessed are the faire, blessed are the merry, blessed are the mighty, no, nor yet blessed are the witty, the deep, the worldly lear • ed men, much lesse blessed are the proud. Happinesse lyes not in carnality, in morality,
within the reach of nature, or verge of the whole creation, in the disquisition of true happinesse, we must leaue all these things behind vs, as labouring with vanity and vexation, as Salomon doth in his discourse vpon this subiect, thorowout his Ecclesiastes, a • d fasten vpon his affirmitiue, which is our second thing, and what's that? God inioyed, is mans happinesse; hence Salomon, feare God, and keepe his commandements: for, this is the whole man; hee attaines not his perfection, that is, his happinesse, till he come home to God in this holy communion. Obiect. But how (will some men say) can this be? God in in himselfe is indeede blessednesse it selfe. But how is hee mans blessednesse? lyeth mans blessednesse out of himselfe?

Answ. Obiectiue happinesse lyeth out of man, out of euery creature, and the more happy and excellent he is, the more he fastens his happinesse vpon the obiect without himselfe, thus the angells behold Gods face, not themselues, this is their happinesse, thus the eye is perfected by light without, the soule by Christ and God, and then man is at the best, when he is rapt out of himselfe, and when nature sleepes and ceases from naturall acts, as it shall in heauen. But, Secondly, consider that we doe not make God simply considered and abstracted, mans happinesse, but God enioyed (as I said) that is, God, 1. reconcilest. 2. vnited and communicated to vs; and when God is both for vs, and with vs, and in vs, then our happinesse is brought home to vs, for this is that vision and fruition of God, which makes vp mans formall happinesse,
as men call it: whosoeuer then will haue happinesse, he must haue God, as is said, Psal. 144. last verse; Blessed is the people whose God is the Lord: Read the words how you will (by way of correction, or by way of confirmation, or amplification) the thing is cleare; our blessednes is in, and of, and from him the first blessednesse, as things retailed come out of the chiefe store-house, as all heats come from the prime heat, fire, all lights from the prime light, the Sunne: so 'tis heere, no blessednesse can be had without God, who is essentiall happinesse. But how doth God become ours? hee must be ours (if wee will be happy) 2. waies. First, ours by couenant: Secondly, ours in communion; but now to passe to the second thing, whats to be done on our parts for the putting of our selues into a couenant and communion with God? Surely God begins to vs, and we must answer him in his call, in his meanes, we must 1. see what our danger and misery is, so long as God and wee stand at termes of enmity and defence; Oh vnhappy creature, who hath to encounter the wrath of an infinite God, who knowes the power thereof; beleeue it to be more then hell, and neuer rest till thou hast thy peace; begge, cry, flye to Iesus Christ the Peace maker, flye to the word of reconciliation, the precious Gospell, and entreat the Lord for his Words sake, and his Christs sake, to saue thy life, and to accept of thee, vpon thy submission, thy comming in, and casting away of thy weapons (I meane) thy sinnes, and when thou hast purchased thy peace, and begg'd
thy life, then in the next place, apply thy selfe to God in all his meanes, and endeauour 1. an vnion with him (an vnion I meane of quality) standing in conformity with him and his holy Image: 2. A communion, the first is obtained by the hauing, the latter, by the exercising of the heauenly graces. Labour these, get knowledge, whereby the vnderstanding vnites it selfe to God, get faith, get loue, truth, &c. whereby the will is carryed to him, and pitches vpon him, and when you haue the habites and graces themselues, then exercise and act them,1 Iohn 1. Walke with God (as Iohn calls it) in light, and so you haue communion with God, as with a father in Christ; walke? how is that? Micah tells you, in the daily exercise of humiliation, as there is daily occasion offered, and in the constant imployment and emproouement of our graces; for happinesse stands in action, (and that action must be of the noblests parts, in the highest operations, vpon the highest obiect, God) the more you dwell vpon him, the more you feede vpon happinesse, the more you liue. Goe therefore to him in the constant vse of all his meanes, thence draw and sucke sauing grace, and learne of him, who is not onely the obiect of our happines, but the teacher also, nor so onely, but the Author and worker too.

Vide Bonavent in Prooemio, ad Pet. de Combis, & Sananarol. de faelic. vitae Christian. &c.In the next place, let this serue for the incouragement of the staggering, the comfort of the resolued Christian. For the first, 'tis true, when wee looke downeward, we finde as little comfort (the best of vs) as Noah saw in the floud, let Noah
looke forth, and there was nothing but feare, and death, let him looke inward, there were no neighbours, but Beares and Lyons, and other beasts, but yet hee had his Arke, a pledge of Gods care, and presence: so stands our case; looke wee inward into our selues, theres nothing but guilt, sin, death, rottennesse, corruptions, crawling in euery roome of the soule; looke we outward vpon the creatures, there's nothing before our eyes but confusion and destruction, euery place is a sea, a dungeon filled with darknesse, misery, death, what not? All things threaten hell, destruction, God is gone, heauen is shut vp, happinesse is forfeited, no meanes of recouery left in vs, in the creatures. How then? why, yet then there's an Arke, a Christ, an heauen, yet happinesse is hauable, yet 'tis possible for mee and thee (wretches though wee be) to be happy, and to be saued. Possible? what now after all this sinne? this misery? yet possible still; what for me? for thee; why, my conscience curses me, Satan doth, man doth, God doth; I am encompassed with curses in my estate, name, soule, in all the ordinances? well, yet (notwithstanding all this) 'tis possible for thee, for me to be happy; how? Nay, first grant me the generall, may some be happy? are some? haue some beene so? why then, thou and I are not excluded from the possibility, and therfore let's not cast off endeauours, cast away our hopes, but hold at least this twigge, 'tis possible, 'tis possible, there's nothing yet said, or done by mee, but 'tis possible for God to pardon it, for Christ to expiate it, lay
hold on this sprig first, that so thou sinke not, and then catch at another, say 'tis not onely possible, but probable; why, else, doth God spare mee, speak to me, inuite me to the accepting of Christ? and when thou art got vp so farre, climbe vp by these steps, here deliuered to a third degree, that is, to a certainty, meane while, let not this goe, 'tis possible. As for such as are already enrolled within the couenant, and beare the marke of God vpon them, let their hearts be enlarged into ioy and reioycing, there is not onely a possibilty, but a certainty too of their blessednes, the blessing is already put vpon them, and that by God, and certaine it is, hee is blessed whom God blesseth, blessed then they be, not in hope onely, but in act also, blessed euery way, and euery one who feareth God, blessed in all estates, liuing, dying, and how not? in all ages, in all places, at all times; doe yee whom this concernes enioy this, and make not your selues miserable, God hath not made you miserable, creatures cannot, men cannot, diuells cannot, things present cannot, things future cannot; God hath set on the blessing, and none can take it off, onely be sure that God the father hath form'd and begotten you, that Christ hath vnited you to himselfe, redeemed you from this present euill world, and renewed you to his Image, that the holy Ghost hath seized vpon your iudgements, and made them poore, vpon you affections, and made them yeelding, vpon your wills, and made them flexible and vpright, and then come pouerty, yet you are blessed, come sicknesse, yet yee are
blessed, come death, wet, bloudy death by persecution, yet blessed, your leaues and blossomes may be stricken off, but there's a substance remaines, as Esay speake, the maine inheritance, blessednesse still holds.

Lastly, here's the reason of our tendring happinesse to all in our ministry, first, wee know that mans nature is capable of happinesse without any varying of his species, which cannot bee said of stocks and stones.
2. Mans present estate and condition is capable of happinesse, for asmuch as he is here a viator and pilgrime capable of blessing, graces, faith, loue, &c.
3. Our errand and message is to men within the Church, who are vnder the meanes, and in the walke of blessednesse,
4. We speake his Word, and come in his name, who is of infinite power, wisdome, mercy, whose spirit breatheth, where he pleaseth.

5. We follow our rule, and attend our cōmission, preach to euery creature, Mark. 16. not in a frier-like sense, to wolues, birds, &c: as they say of some, but in our Sauiours sense; to euery reasonable creature, to euery man, who will giue vs the hearing, vpon these grounds wee are ready to tender happinesse to all thus farre, that 'tis possible for them (for ought wee see and finde in our commission, the written word) to bee saued, to bee blessed, and here an end of the first point. The second we hau • taken in by the way, whilst we prosecuted the former, and therefore we now hasten to particulars, wee may not at this time enter vpon
them, onely in that our blessed Sauiour first propounds the end (blessednesse) and then the meanes, we see,

Doct. That mans chiefest aime should be at his vtmost end, happinesse, this though last atchieued must be first proiected, and this load-starre must be stil in mans eye, hence it is, that our Sauiours Sermon takes beginning here, and the holy Ghost founds many an exhortation vpon this bottome: and indeed God made him for happines, and propounds that first to him, and therefore he must propound it first to himselfe, as his end: Againe, the vtmost end is that that formes all mens actions and qualifies all things, all which are so farre good or bad, as they more or lesse conduce to this end of his: 2. that which quickens all obedience, the end flowes into the meanes, and men worke no farder in them, than the end enliuens them. 3. That which sweetens all the meanes, and makes them amiable, & which crownes all our endeuours, perfecting both them and vs. Now, here we mought tax our folly, who stay in the mid-way, flag and take vp our rest before we come home, that is, rest in subordinate ends, not in the supreme, stay in things of an inferior alloy, which are desirable f • r others sakes, not their own. Thus one man aimes at this, to be rich; hither tend all his thoughts, cares, labours, he layes all that hee is worth vpon this purchase; another doth as much for pleasure, a third for honor, a fourth for worldly wisedome, &c; but all these are propter aliud, vndergoods, owing tribute to an higher end, not simply
good, and therfore not for their own sakes desireable, but onely in a degree and respect, as they speed vs hom-ward toward happines; the thing to be studied is, what's blessednesse? wherein stands that? which way goes that? or which way leads to it? and in truth a man can neuer know the way, till he agree vp on his end, neuer prize the meanes and giue them their iust valuation, til he know the end, neuer vse the meanes aright, till he resolue vpon that end which regulates all, quiets all, bounds and commands all: Therfore (good my Brethren) lets not loose our selues, and forget our errand; our Father Adam lost our happinesse, and we are sent to seeke it; seeke it, where it is, and goe handsomely to worke, say, I am not made for riches, they are made for me; I am not made for creatures, they are mine; and I am their Master: Therefore these cannot make me happy, I am made for eternity, for euerlasting life and happinesse, therefore, let me study that, mind that, see that end beyond inferiour ends, why, do men seek wealth, but to bee happy? why pleasures? why honours? but because they would be happy: if these cannot blesse and enhappy me, why should I burne day-light? why should I not off them, as the bee gets off the plant, that yeelds her no hony: and once, at last see where my businesse lyes in pursuing happinesse, and where my happinesse lyes in Gods wayes, the first step wherof is pouerty in spirit, of which hereafter, for now we haue exceeded the houre beyond my present purpose and future resolution.

div.head: The third SERMON.
3 Blessed are the poore in Spirit, for theirs is the kingdome of Heauen.
div.p:
De hisce beatitud videatur Bernard in festo Omnium Sanct. HItherto of generall instructions, and the Euangelists introduction: Now wee come to particulars. Blessed (saith our Sauiour) there he takes his beginning, the first thing he intended was blessednesse, the first of his works blessings, the first word he vtters, is blessed; this is his primary and direct worke, to bring man and blessednesse together, but where rests the blessing? on the poore, but spiritually poore; here's a paradox, the foundation of mans happinesse is layde in misery, Gods courses and wayes are high, not against, but farre aboue mans particular reason, but to the words; in them see, 1. the persons in speech, and then the thing affirmed first, confirmed next, the persons are poore, beggers, pouerty imports a want or scarcity of things, necessarie to life and liueli-hood, euery want of superfluities is not pouerty; then one is said to be poore, when he is destitute of things necessary to life, that is, truely liuely; life is either naturall or spirituall (Carnall life is but death, and therefore we bury that) when a man is destitute of meanes, which tend to the preseruing and cherishing of either life, then is he said to be poore, poore in purse and in the world; if hee be scanted in the one, poore in spirit, if in the other, now the question
is, of which pouerty our Sauiour here speaketh,Vid. Estium ad loc. and our answer is this, first, we take the Iesuits word, that vowed pouerty, or outward pouerty voluntarily vndertaken is not here spoken off, for first, the particulars instanced are duties commanded, not perfections onely perswaded, and secondly, if vowed pouerty were the thing here blessed, the blessed Virgin and her blessed Sonne were not vnder the blessing here pronounced, if the wisest of themselues and least partiall may bee heard. Secondly,Vid. Caiet. & Guliel de Sanct. amore apud Sixt. Senes. in Biblioth lib. Sext. anno. 18. outward pouerty imposed by God, we doe not vtterly exclude, for though it be neither a blessing in it selfe, nor a cause of blessednesse to man, yet may it befall a blessed man, and bee made an occasion of spirituall pouerty, and thus we yeeld the Disciples, to whom these words are applyed, Luk. 6. to bee in some degree both wayes poore, and to say as the thing is, there is no man becomes spiritually poore, til he be poore either in his outward condition, or inward disposition and opinion, touching externalls; that is, till he hath emptyed himselfe of all conceit of, and and confidence in his wealth, and findes himselfe poore for all his riches, and willing to part goods for grace: But all this will amount to no more, but a bare occasion of blessednesse, and nothing is more cleere then this, that a man may be both outwardly poore and euerlastingly miserable, our third answere therefore is, that spirituall pouerty (which fals vnder precept, and is not a meere councell) is here meant; and so our Sauiour expounds himselfe, when he addeth poore (in Spirit)
and this pouerty is so tearmed, first, in respect of it's subiect, to wit, mans spirit, chiefly his vnderstanding and iudgement. Secondly, of the obiect, namely, spirituall things; not outward goods. Thirdly and cheifely in respect of the author, the Spirit of God, which first conuinceth a man of the excellency of heauenly things, of his owne vtter emptinesse and want of them, of his extreame need, and strickt duty of hauing them, of the great benefit of getting them, and to conclude of the impossibility of compassing them by his own strength, & possibility of attaineing them by Gods mercy and meanes. Secondly, the same spirit subdues the will, and perswades the heart to a cheerfull vse of Gods meanes in obedience, and with s • me assurance of acceptance. The party then here described is (at the vtmost) one, who being outwardly humbled with the want of riches, or wants in riches, inquires thereupon into his spirituall estate, and there finding himselfe worse then naught, thereupon makes to God for a spirituall supply, and is willing to take it vpon any tearmes; this is the man: Now what is it that tis affirm'd of this man? hee is (blessed) blessednesse is a concurrene of all excellencies and requisites to mans wel-being without mixture of their contraries, 'tis properly appliable to persons, first, to God, as the Author of all happinesse, and at second hand to man, as the subiect of some, man I say, as he holds communion with God by the graces of the Spirit hereafter metioned, and commended to vs, either as parts, or as signes; or
as meanes, or as effects of our blessednesse: The matter then is, that the spiritually poore is in a blessed condition. But now in the third place, how is this proued? thus, hee is blessed who hath the Kingdome of heauen; and this is the poore mans portion: Therefore, this Kingdome is the blessed estate and gouernement of Christ in grace and glory, one Kingdome, but the roomes are two; an vpper and a lower, knowne by the name of the Church militant and triumphant, the state one in substance, degrees onely varying, this Kingdome, in regard of the quality of it, is tearmed heauenly, in regard of the author and giuer of it is called God's, Luk. 6. as also the poore's in these respects, first 'tis theirs by assignement, 'tis appointed of God and set out for them from all eternity. Secondly, theirs by right; they hauing a right to their Christ. Thirdly, theirs by actuall possession in their head Christ, who in their names stands seized of it, and in themselues; so far as they are spiritually poore, that is, emptied of themselues and filled with God, and this for the words; Doctr. Now to the matter.

Where God intends happinesse, he begins with spirituall pouerty: herein, God deales like a wise Physician, who first makes sicke, that so hee may make whole, like a good Chirurgion, who first cuts, and then cures; like a good builder, who digs downe-ward, that hee may build vpward, thus God vndoes a man before he saues him, marres him, before he makes him; takes him all to peices, and then ioynts him for euer; this to
be his method is soone seene: if you trace either his prescriptions or practises, in a plethory or fulnesse he prescribes phlebotomy or some euacuation, thus the rule runnes, is any man (conceitedly) wise, he must empty himselfe and become a foole, that he may bee truely wise, 1 Cor. 3.13. Is hee falsely merry? he must be seriously sad, that he may be sollidly merry, Iam. 4. Is he high? he must be humbled, that he may be high: So runnes Christs bill to the Church of Laodicea, he first sets downe what they were in conceit, they were rich, wise, wanting nothing, secondly, what they were indeed, poore, Reuel. 3. blind, naked, wanting all things, and that done, he aduises them to take vp of him receipts, and eye-salue; that so they might know themselues, and vnderstand their beggery; thus hee prescribes, and accordingly he practises, his first worke is conuiction and downe-casting, this we see in Manasses, first, he claps him vp, and hangs irons enough vpon him, and then comes vpon him with a pardon and saluation: thus he dealt with Paul, first, hee vnhorses him, keepes him vnder darknes, & on the racke, and when he had master'd him, then hee makes him; this was his course of old, Iob 33. he affrights a man with dreames, afflicts him with paines vpon his bed, and hauing thus plough'd him, hee after sowes him, and this is his course still, he entertaines vessels of glory, as the goldsmith doth his battered plate: first, beats it all to peices, and then casts it into a new mould, and burnishes it againe. And this method is most rationable, for;

First, till a man be thus poore (that is taken off Reas. 1 from himselfe and all creatures) hee will neuer come where happinesse growes, hee will seeke it eyther in the creatures where it is not to be found, or in himselfe, where it cannot be had; so long as hee is any thing in himselfe, his mind must needes be restlesse, his thoughts boundlesse (for mistake hath no bounds) and therefore hee must needes out of himselfe, if he will be quiet, that is, happy, for what is man in himselfe, but a compound and bundle of sinne and misery? and when would hee make out, if hee were not conuinced of this? Or should hee, yet (secondly) hee would neuer goe to the price of Christ and spirirtuall Reas. 2 graces; 'tis pouerty that enhanceth prices, plenty brings downe the Market; the strong man knowes not the price of health, the full man the worth of bread, Christ is Christ, grace is grace to the poore alone, another man hath too many pearles to giue for that one Pearle, Christ; euery sinne is precious to him, euery creature his, euery courser blessing, his goods, his name, his life, all these are his Iewells, and men will not part with their Iewells till they are pincht with wants. Thirdly, could hee prize it, yet would hee neuer prosecute it in the vse of all the meanes; 'tis neede that sets men on worke, and driues them abroad, as it did Iacobs children for bread, Ahab for water: Take me 2. men that are going the to market, the one whereof hath neede, the other hath none; the Reas. 3 first must to the Towne what weather soeuer fall out, though it should raine frogges and toads (as
they say) the other cares not whether hee goe or no, hee can goe, or he can chuse, and why? because he hath no such need; if hee goe, for fashions sake he walks about, and it may be cheapens commodities, but if eyther the price be too great, or his opinion of the thing too little, he knowes how to stay longer, and cares not much for further proofe of the Market, but now the former (whose wife and children call on him for bread) must to the place, and to the price too; bread hee wants, and bread he must haue, though he lay his coat to pawne: so stands the case here; the full Christian can go or not go to the Market of his soule, can buy or not buy, speed or not speed, as he likes the peniworths, but the poore empty soule must haue Christ in his bloud, Christ in his graces, Christ in his ordinances what euer it cost him, thus 'tis with him, when he is once poore, but neuer thus Reas. 4 till hee be poore. In the fourth place, would hee vse the meanes, yet were hee not capable of the thing, I meane happinesse, till hee hath emptied himselfe, and voyded the room, there is no roome for God, he pleaseth to dwell eyther very high or very low,Esay 7.15. as Esay saith, He inhabites eternity, hee dwells also in the humble and contrite heart, if we will haue God (and haue him we must, if we will be happy) we must be poore and low, then hee will dwell in vs, and if we meane to inhabit his eternity, we must be nothing in our selues, till a man be at this passe, there's no passage for him to heauen, he must be vntwisted, before he can enter that narrow passage, as Chrst tells vs, nay, the poore onely
receiue the Gospell, which points vs that way, the poore onely will accept of heauen as a gift, as an almes, the proud will not claime it, vnlesse he can purchase it, or contribute towards it. Lastly, put Reas. 5 case happinesse stood before him, and were ready to drop into his mouth, yet could he not relish or enioy it till hee were poore in spirit; this pouerty of spirit, is the sauce of the soule, Plutarc. in vit. Alex. as Alexander was wont to say, that his hungry dinner was his suppers sauce; vnlesse a man bring this sauce with him, Christ will be no Christ, sweetnesse no sweetnesse, heauen (as I said) no heauen, as wee see in the diuells, whom heauen it selfe could not content, when once they had lost their dependency vpon God, and reacht after a selfe-sufficiency.
You haue heard the point proued, now let's bring it home in the application.

Let euery man now examine and try his owne Vse 1 estate and Title to happinesse. Wee vsually blesse the rich, and hold the poore miserable; it is otherwise in the inward condition: here only the richest is poorest, and they alone that are spiritually poore, are the blessed of the Lord. Of this spirituall pouerty, there are signes of 2. sorts. Some are false: lay them by. These are 1. outward pouerty; some would perswade themselues, they are poore in spirit, because they are poore in purse; but pride oft peepes thorow ragges, dwells in a low cottage, &c. There may be a rich (i. e. an high) heart, where is but a poore estate.

2. Legall pouerty is a false signe: this is when
the heart is beaten downe with legall terrors. The difference is, 1. legall pouerty is painfull, and inuoluntary, but spirituall is voluntary, &c. well apayd that God should carry the purse; placeth it's happinesse in God. 2. legall pouerty makes a man despaire, but spirituall lookes to God, and sees remedy. 3. legall driues from God, spirituall drawes to God.

3. Deniall of Gods graces is not this pouerty; as some, because they may not be so rich as they would, will be nothing at all: they see an vnworthines in themselues, and because they are poore, they will needs haue Christ so too; this is hypocrisie, or vnthankfulnesse, or vnbeliefe, but not pouerty.

4. The denying of a mans selfe the comforts, that God hath giuen him in Christ, in the word, in the creatures, this is no spirituall pouerty; if you will giue it a name, call it pride. These are the false signes: The true are these:

1. Spirituall pouerty is instructiue, conuinceth a man of his owne insufficiency, lets him see an all-sufficiency in God, takes him off from's owne bottom; lets him see that there's nothing in the creature, but he must to God, shewes him the infinite distance betwixt God and himselfe; by this the prodigal is said haue to come to himselfe, Manasses to know God himself: For pouerty of spirit, is the sobriety of the soule, makes a man set a true estimate vpon himselfe, rate himselfe as God rates • i • ; and euery one is iust so much worth as God tates him at. Try your selues now by this note.
Most men place all substance and tack in wealth, honours, pleasures, &c: see nothing but emptinesse in God, Christ, grace, &c. He that is spiritually poore, is of a contrary iudgement; Spirituall pouerty is humbling, casts a man downe, makes him submit to God both in his direction and correction, lay his face in the dust, see reason, why God should afflict him, say, I doe or I would resigne my selfe to God: So for spirituall things, he will be content to take Gods comforts vpon Gods tearmes, at Gods times, and by Gods meanes. An humbled begger will stay your leisure, a sturdy rogue snuffes and raile if you serue him not presētly. Try your selues now by this no •• : The most when they are afflicted, bustle, storme, see no reason why they should be so hardly dealt withall, especially, when God smites them by an instrument, they cannot take it so: likewise in spiritual things, those that cannot submit to the foolishnesse of preaching, goe about to establish their owne righteousnesse, will needs bring something of their owne toward their saluation, cannot yet haue the comfort of being spiritually poore.

Spirituall pouerty is a sensible thing, it pinches, and makes a man complaine, not against God, but against himselfe. Thus and thus hee might haue beene, and so much good he might haue done, had he been but worth his yeeres, or taken his opportunities. The poore man (you know) is euer querulous, you shall haue a whole oration of his wants, if you'll giue him the hearing; others haue this, and others haue that, but hee hath nothing:
So a man that's spiritually poore, he wants faith, he wants patience, &c: Search you now by this signe; most complaine of outward wants, as of wealth, &c; but where's the man that's sensible, and cries out of his want of grace?

4. It is subduing, and makes one thankfull for any thing, as a begger that's hunger-staru'd, giue him but of the coursest, or but a little, Oh 'tis good, Master, 'tis good: but a sturdy rogue grumbles, if you giue but a little, and hee must haue drinke too, or he is not contented: so he that is spiritually poore, if God afford him any answer, shew him any fauour, oh how thankfull is he; lesse he thinks himselfe, then the least of all Gods mercies. when he that is high in his owne eyes and vnbroken, thinkes euery thing too little, or not good enough; but wee can stand no longer vpon the search. Let a second vse be

Vse 2 To perswade vs to this spirituall pouerty, the high-way to happinesse: Cast away not your purses, but your pride; empty not your coffers, but your mindes, you will say, alas, we are empty already, we haue nothing to be proud of: but looke well to the businesse; pride, like the Chamelion will liue vpon ayre: the more empty a man is of grace, the more conceited; commonly as empty vessels sound loudest: By perswading vs to this, Obiect. you would makes vs loose all our comforts, all our hopes.
Sol.Not so. but hereby you shall establish them, whiles you fix your selues on God, place your All in him: heereby the soule comes to be at rest.

Here begins all a mans comfort, holinesse; pouerty of spirit is the bud of Grace, Christ here beginnes with it, as the foundation of holinesse, and first step to happinesse. Misery came into the world by swelling of Spirit, happinesse comes by pouerty of spirit: God deales with vs herein, as men doe with frantick persons: that are runne besides themselues through pride, or otherwise, and are brought again to their senses by low-diet, and hard vsage: so he reduceth vs to our right mindes, letting vs see and sigh vnder our owne vilenesse, naughtinesse, nothingnesse. the lower the foundation, the higher the roofe.

Here, for your more happy proceeding, wee will shew you: 1. what this pouerty of spirit is, and 2. how it may be attained. For the first, hee did not much mistake the matter, that made it the same with humility: but pouerty of spirit is a larger thing, reacheth to all creatures, to all conditions, when a man hath no sufficiency of his owne, but is conuinced of all fulnesse of strength and comfort in God. The Spirit tells a man, 1. That grace is fundamētally necessary, 2. That it is not in any creature. 3. That there is help enough in God, and that he is willing to impart it. 4. It subdues the will to take it vpon Gods termes, and by his meanes, so that God will saue him, hee will refer all to his mercy, owe all to God, nothing to others. And this is spirituall pouerty: a man may be spiritually poore, vtterly voyd of true grace, and yet not poore in spirit; as on the contrary, he may be poore in spirit, which yet is rich in grace.
As for the means to attaine this grace, obserue that some things do onely feede pride: auoyd these: as 1. Ignorance: therefore men must get that eye-salue, Reu. 3. that they may see themselues, and other things, as indeed they are, and so be humbled. 2. selfe-loue, selfe-conceit, breeds selfe-deceit: 3. flattery (this is without vs) 4. idlenesse.

The meanes to be vsed are: 1. Compare thy selfe with others, that came in after thee (who yet haue out-gone thee) with great Paul, with Christ, with God, and seeing the infinite distance, fall downe before him in thy thoughts, as Peter, and say, Depart from mee, for I am a sinfull man. The creature, set in comparison with Gods do vanish, as starres before the Sunne.

2. Apply your selues to Gods meanes, to the Word of God preached in the power and life of it: liue vnder a searching Ministry. let this glasse alwayes stand before you, this lets a man see God, and himselfe, as he is: and truth humbles a man. So in affliction, close with God, when he smites you, take his part against your selues, and doe yee smite too; like as the smith and his man, the master strikes, and the man strikes: so when God corrects vs, we must set in and ioyne with him for the breaking of our owne hearts, making vse of the opportunity.

3. Examine your selues often, and make diligent search into your owne hearts and liues, hee that lookes often vpon his sinnes and his best seruices, how he failes in the manner, by performing spirituall seruices carnally, shall haue enough to
humble him. There is nothing more shames and deiects a good heart then this, I haue praied, heard, read, &c: 'tis true, but how haue I done it? full poorely, slightly, slubberingly.

Comfort to those that are poore in Spirit, they are in a blessed estate. Wee are apt to thinke that God will vndoe vs, when indeed he will make vs: he breakes vs outwardly, that he may build vs inwardly; and then indeed, a man becomes a man, and neuer before: when once a man is become poore in spirit, the worke is halfe done, the foundation layd; the hardest work of a Christian is to pull downe himselfe, wee all prize our selues at a high rate, howeuer others prize vs. 2. 'tis a safe estate; he that's poore in spirit is past harme, obtaines that which Austin praied for, neither to deceiue, nor be deceiued: for scuh a one will very hardly bee drawne to hold any thing against the Truth. 3. he is at peace at home, others cannot thinke or speake so meanely of him, as he of himselfe, he easiely agrees with them. That which breakes a proud mans heart, will not breake his sleepe, &c. Obiect.
Oh, but I finde I grow worse and worse!Sol.

This is thy growth in Religion, to finde thine vnprofitablenesse: for here, the better any man is, the worse he iudgeth himselfe to be, the richer, Duarenus, so a • Athens 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , &c. the poorer. As Duarenus saith, of such as come to the Vniuersity, the first yeere, they are Doctours, in their owne conceits at least, the next yeere they come to be Masters, the thi • d yeere, they are content to bee Batchelours, and the fourth,
schollers: so Christians at their first conuersion are high in their owne eyes, know all things, censure all, &c: but afterwards, the longer a man liues, the lower he growes, till with Paul he come to be of sinners the grea • est, but of Saints the least; Therefore be not discouraged, so long as you continue constant, and conscionable in the vse of the meanes, your growth is to see your vnprofitablenesse. Quest.
But how shall I know my spirituall pouerty to be right? Answr.

By these marks. 1. It is peaceable. A horse that's fed at full, and does nothing, will grow so feirce and vnruly, that none shall come neare him with safety: but a poore lade that's hard-fed, and hard put to't, creeps by and steales his way without hurt done to any: So that man that's lofty and vnbroken, carries himselfe so proudly in his place, and is so insolent, that none of his poore neighbours can liue in peace by him: when hee that is poore in spirit, and priuy to his owne vnworthinesse, is at peace with all men, disquiets none.
2. 'Tis praier full. The poore man speakes supplications, saith Salomon: so the poore in Spirit powres forth prayers, with ease and freedome.
3. 'Tis thankefull, for any thing, as we shewed you before.
4. 'Tis mercifull to others, not censorious, cruell, harsh.

Lastly, 'tis emptying, it rids a man of all selfishnesse, selfe-conceipt, selfe-loue, selfe-pleasing, selfe-dependancy, selfe-sufficiency, once for all, it
willingly empties it selfe, and ascribes all fulnesse to God, speaking in Pauls words: And so we come to speake of the reason in these words,2 Cor. 3.5. for theirs is the Kingdome of heauen.

Theirs it is, 1. in right. 2. in possession also, so farre as they are dispossest of themselues, and filled with God: The first thing we note here, is the strength and truth of the Argument, which stands thus. They to whom the kingdome of heauen belongs, are blessed. But such are the poore in spirit: therefore they are blessed. Now in that he thence inferres their happinesse, because theirs is the kingdome heauen, we note, that

They are in a blessed case to whom heauen belongs, Matth. 5.10. Blessed are the persecuted, &c: for theirs is the Kingdome, so vers. 12. Reioyce, for great is your reward in heauen, they are pronounced blessed, onely in relation to the reward, in that they are heyres of heauen, so Mat. 25.34. Come yee blessed of my Father: and how blessed? receiue the Kingdome: The same you may see, Reu. 19 9. Blessed are they which are called to the Supper of the Lamb; vnderstand it of heauen. It implies indeed the state of grace, but that other of glory is primarily here meant, and intended. Reas.

The tru • h of this will appeare, whether you look to things or persons; for the first, heauen is the best estate, and the best kingdome; 1. it is most ample, boundlesse, Reuel. 21.7. He that ouercommeth, shall inherite all things: such shall be Princes in all Lands, Psal. 45. Secondly, tis a most rich kingdome: there is no want of any thing vnder or aboue
heauen. Thirdly, it is most safe, for they are all friends there; the gates alwayes open. 4. durable, an inherirance incorruptible, vndefiled, and that fades not, but is alwayes fresh and flourishing. Now, if those were accounted happy that liued in the land of Canaan, or in Salomons Court: what must they needs bee, that liue in such a kingdome, as heauen is?

Reas. 2 But secondly, if wee turne vs to persons, they must needs bee happy, that haue part in heauen. The King thereof is happinesse it selfe, the subiects all happy, in him their Light, strength, &c; and t • rough him also: Happy they are, 1. in their company. 2. in their condition; for company, there's happy Dauid, happy Abraham ther's Christ, God blessed for euer: the lowest person there, is an Angell. 2. for their condition, they enioy the lamb, are the spouse, free from sin, temptation, &c; filled with all grace and happinesse, as full euery one, as his vessell can hold: The very place is truly beatificall. The properties of a place are 1. to preserue euery thing safe, as fish is safe in the waters, birds in the ayre, &c; heauen also is a place of safety, there is no feare or suspicion. 2. to quiet things, as we see euery thing rests in its owne place: this is most true of heauen, there's no need of stoole, chaire, bed, or whatsoeuer else here we rest vs on. 3. to giue content, as a bone is at ease in its owne place; if out, restlesse. Heauen is our place, countrey, &c; where is all manner of content, fountaines of comfort, riuers of pleasure, full, and fresh.

Ʋse. 1 Make out after the Blisse (as they spoke
in Popery, though in a wrong sense) labour for part in this happy inheritance. Before, wee perswaded you to be poore, nothing in your selues, &c. Now wee come with a crowne in our hand, loose this, and you loose more then your selues: for happinesse is the perfection of your selues. But where shall you finde it? It growes not on earth. Not euery one that hath an earthly kingdome, is thereby happy: Herod was a King, so was Ahab, yet neither of them happy: Iezabel was daughter, wife, mother, sister to a King, yet a cursed woman. Though a man had as many crownes on his head as Ahashuerosh had, all this would not proue him happy Alexander will weepe, that there is not yet another world to subdue. 'Tis heauen only that can make happy, that's our Countrey, there's our Father, our husband, our inheritance: goe then a pilgrimage to this holy land for happinesse: heauen is feisible, and more easie to get then an earthly kingdome. Here we cannot be all kings: there are not kingdomes enough. but there, there is none vnder a King. Yea, if men would but take the same paines for heauen, that they doe for hell, they might haue it; And then it should bee no more Good-man or Good-wife such a one, but King and Queene such a one: Now to atcheiue t • is kingdome, 1. marry the heyre (not kill the Heyre, as those in the Gospell) and then the inheritance shall be ours. Accept of Christ, and let him haue your loues, your hearts; you cannot match your selues better. 2. Beare Christs Company in the way to the Kingdome; There
be wayes that lead to all great Cities: God also hath chalked vs out a way to heauen, namely, his Commandements, and hath told vs the by-wayes; walke now in this holy way, and so finde rest to your soules. 3. Take hold of heauen here, lay hold vpon eternall life, 1 Tim. 6. We must haue liuery and seison of it here; how so? by adding to the graces of the Spirit, as St. Peter hath it 2 Ep. 1.5. to faith vertue, to vertue knowledge, &c: whereby an entrance shall be abundantly ministred vnto vs into the euerlasting kingdome. Thou must bee poore in spirit, pure in heart, meeke, mercifull, &c: by these staires thou must climbe vp to the state of blessednesse, as for the cause meriting it, cry out with the Martyr, None but Christ, None but Christ: I'll be his in life and death, and hee is my gaine and hope in both.

See here the wofull misery of blind man, that iudges amisse altogether, and greatly mistakes himselfe in placing his happinesse in earthly vanityes: like as children whose cheife delight is in toyes and gawdes; set a child on horse-back, and you put him into heauen, hee is then in his kingdome, take away his cherristones, and hee cryes out as one vndone. And such is the iudgement of the world. Let a man haue losse in his estate, &c: we thinke him miserable; but if hee meet with a good bargaine, a happy windfall, &c; wee hold him happy. But the truth is, that he onely gaines, that gets God, Christ, peace, heauen, himselfe, though otherwise he bee neuer so great a looser. So long as a man looseth not the whole of his estate,
hee doth not account himselfe miserable in some lesser losses. So long as a man hath interest into heauen, he cannot be vnhappy, whatsoeuer outward losses or crosses he vndertakes.
But who be those that shall misse of heauen?

Comfort to those that can cleare their title and right to heauen, that haue their euidences in readinesse, Ʋse. 3 that are in a blessed case: Therefore feare not little flock, it is your Fathers good pleasure to giue you a kingdome. I may say the same of other passions, grieue not, faint not, little flocke, the kingdome's yours: Oppose this to all hard-ships, miseries, disasters, and be comforted: Say here, indeed I am poore, vnder winde, nobody, but hereafter I shall haue the Kingdome. And let
this stay and satifie you against all the brags of the wicked, what great matters they haue, one heauen is more worth then all these; As the story reports, that when Charles the fift in a challenge to the King of France, commanded his herald proclaime it with all his Titles: Charles Emperor of such a place, King of such a place, Duke of such a place, &c. bids defiance to the King of France: The King of France on the other side, bad his herald proclaime; The King of France, the King of France, the King of France bids battell to Charles Emperour of Germany, &c: intimating that one kingdome of France was more worth, then all those empty Titles: So may we oppose the Kingdome of heauen to all their vuants of greatnesse, as being far more then all theirs, and when they cry out, money money, pleasures, honours: cry thou, Heauen, heauen, heauen; that answers to all.
Qest.But how shall I know my Title to heauen?

Answ. 1. See how farre you'll deny your selfe for it, what wilt thou do or suffer for a kingdome? canst thou part with an arme or an eye for heauen? be at any paines for • he getting of this pearle? He that will doe nothing, part with nothing for heauen, is not worthy of it.

2. Be sure you haue the earnest of heauen here, euen that Spirit of God, whereby we are sealed, Eph. 1 13. Looke then into your selues for pouerty o • spirit, purity of spirit, meekenesse of spirit, &c.
3. Haue your conuersation in heauen, Phil. 3. place your thoughts there, your affections there, your comforts there.

4. Be still adding to the graces of the spirit, degree to degree, and act to habit. Hereby you shall haue one foote in heauen, and be sure neuer to fall away, but haue an entrance into the euerlasting Kingdome, 2 Pet. 1.5. with 11.

div.head: For theirs is the Kingdome of heauen.
div.p: WEe haue spoken already of the first step to Heauen, pouerty of spirit. Our Sauiour layes his foundation low, but sets vpon't a glorious roofe, euen heauen it selfe: Blessed are the poore in spirit, for theirs is the kingdome of heauen; We haue already spoken of the strength of our Sauiours argument; now of the certainty of it: heauen is assured to euery one that is poore in spirit; theirs is the Kingdome of heauen. From the closenesse of the connexion, Note that

Grace and glory, Doctr. holinesse and happinesse goe alwayes together: hee that hath the one, hath the other also: Thus 2. Pet 1.3. God (saith the Apostle) hath called vs to glory and vertue: through the Temple of vertue must we passe on to glory. And hence it is that S. Paul, Rom. 8 30. saith, that whom God hath iustified, them he (hath) also glorified: hee deliuers it in the time past, to shew the certainty: for this it is also, that he couches sanctification, and glorification vnder one word, (glorified) Indeede God hath subordinated them the
one to the other, there being not any specificall difference, but onely graduall: for what is grace, but the beginning of glory? or what is glory, but the perfection of grace? glory is gracious glory, and grace is glorious grace; we shall haue in heauen the same life, the same loue that now, &c. but onely made perfect. Hence is that speech of our Sauiour, Ioh. 5. he that beleeueth hath eternall life, so close a connexion is there betwixt holinesse and happinesse, that being the meanes, this the end.

Vse 1 Take heede you feuer not what God hath set together, the meanes and the end; to sunder these is the diuells sophistry, by which hee deludes those naturall bruite beasts, made to be taken and destroyed, 2 Pet. 2. for thus they reason. If God haue elected me to saluation, he will saue me howsoeuer: But these must know and obserue these two rules: 1. that God brings no man to heauen, but he first makes him willing, accordig to that of a Father,Austen. Hee that made thee without thee, will not saue thee without thee. Secondly, that whomsoeuer God brings to heauen, hee brings him in his owne way. Of that golden chaine, Rom. 8. two links hee hath let downe to vs, namely, that of vocation, and the other sanctification, whereby to climbe vp to the state of glory: the first linke of his secret will, hee hath reserued to himselfe. Make then your election sure, by becomming sure of your calling: and as our Sauiour here bids, be poore in spirit, that you may be enriched with Gods Kingdome: mourne, that you may be comforted: for otherwise, by soaring
aboue your measure, and seeking to pry into Gods eternall purpose, you may Icarus-like leaue your name for a Prouerb, and your selfe be drowned in the sea of perdition.

Let all such as haue true grace, be hereby encouraged Vse 2 to goe on cheerefully in their course, looking to the recompence of reward set before them, euen the Kingdome of heauen, which is certainly theirs, euen as many as haue grace in the truth of it. Common graces indeed are looseable, and are often lost: but sauing grace, howsoeuer it be in it selfe looseable, because a creature, yet shal not be lost, because the Creator vndertakes it. The Apostle calls them graces accompanying saluation,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 things that haue saluation, that include it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 that is, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 as the Scholiasts giue it. Now, sauing grace may be thus discerned. it is 1. humbling, makes a man nothing in himselfe, low in his owne eyes, meane in his owne account. 2. purging, it purgeth out corruption, purifies the heart. 3. Edifying; the good man would haue all men good, and come to heauen aswell as himselfe, all should be saued by his good-will. To a man thus qualified heauen is assured: for such graces can neuer be lost, the exercises of them may be intermitted for a time, as the leaues of a tree may be shaken off, and are, but still the sap is in the root. Motion may cease in the body, yet life not be extinguished: as a man in an apoplexy, stirres not for the time, yet we say, he is inter viuos, to be reckoned among the liuing: So he that hath true grace, he
may lose his sense, and fruition of his good estate, neuer his right and Title thereunto: the sonne abides alwayes in the house, though the seruant abide not euer. A Leper in the Law, had not alwayes the enioyment of his house, for hee was for the time excluded the camp: but returning clean, hee needed not to sue for a new Title, but tooke possession of his house, being his owne, as before. Therefore get sauing grace for a Title, and then Peter secures you of two things: 2 Pet. 1.10, 11. one, that you shall neuer fall away, ver. 10. the other, that an entrance shall be ministred abundantly into the euerlasting Kingdome of our Lord and Sauiour Iesus Christ. vers. 11. the Kingdome is kept for you, and you for the Kingdome, as it is, 1 Pet. 1.4, 5. and both you and it in Gods keping, and that, in so safe a place as heauen. And thus haue we gone up one round of the ladder, euen pouerty of spirit: The second is spirituall mourning in the 4th verse.

div.head: An addition to what is said, touching the Estate or Grace (terme it as you will) of spirituall pouerty.
div.p: REader, the notes vpon the third verse, are too too short; that subiect requires a larger discourse; all that for the present will be said, is this:

1. For the order, I conceiue that our Lord and Master beganne with spirituall pouerty, for two maine reasons: 1. Because hee would beat off his Disciples from those dreaming thoughts of high worldly preferments by him, a thing which he minded all his volunteers of, yet still they had crochets that way, and could not lay them
downe with Christ in his graue, Acts 1.

2. Because the case is now much altered with man, he hath emptied himself of God, of heauen, and filled himselfe with hell, with earth, with creatures of Gods, or of his own making, and must be re-emptied before he can be filled, outed, and dispossessed of all that is his own, and the diuels, before he can be re-enstalled and restored in his blood, and setled in his primitiue goodnesse.

Hence, as in philosophy, the Naturalist layes downe his priuation amongst his principles of nature, so the Lord Christ beginnes with a kinde of priuation and pouerty, and premises this as a fore-runner and disposition, if not as a principle of mans blessednesse. The truth is, spiritual pouerty is another thing than a bare priuation, as descending from a cause transcendently positiue, and hath more in it than can be easily expressed. Hee did well, who distinguished betwixt pouerty in spirit, and a poore spirit;V. de Caictan in append. ad summul. in Jentac. 4. a man may be rich in grace, yet poore in spirit, because he owes it all to God, and wholly depends vpon him, for the hauing and the vsing of it, and he may be worse then naught; worse for spirituall things, and yet be rich and high in spirit, because he may looke vpon grace as a thing meane, base, worthlesse, needlesse, or at least a thing that hee may get when hee will, and keepe and vse, and enioy it at his owne pleasure, and indeed, • he emptier the soule is, the more it swells this way, and the more 'tis laden with treasure, the more it feares it selfe, suspects thieues,
desires helpe and company. The question is not here, what grace men haue, but what opinion they haue of grace; whether they place their riches and happinesse in it, yea, or no; and what they conceiue of themselues, and of creatures, and meanes for the compassing and enioyment of it; hee that holds himselfe neuer the poorer for spirituall wants, or referres ought to himselfe in the obtaining of grace, is a poore fellow indeed, but not in our Sauiours sense: but hee who resolues all into God, and into grace, who sees grace to be all the grace and glory of the creature,Who is poore. and owes all his graces to grace, and liues a life of meere dependency, this is a man poore in spirit, rich in grace: for spirituall pouerty is not a nullity or vacuity of grace, but a free and willing acknowledgement of our indebtednesse and dependency on Gods grace for grace,The parts of pouerty. and is made vp of these two: 1. A thorow (yet free) conuiction of our owne nothingnesse in spiritualls, and 2. (vpon the like conuiction) a cheerfull dependency vpon Gods sufficiency for all goodnesse. This, as other pouerties, mostly results from comparison,Whence it a
• ises. for when a man hath eyes to see God in his fulnesse, and himselfe in his emptinesse, and so layes himselfe by God, the standard, then hee sees his pouerty, and cries out, I am a sinfull man, as Peter did; and with Iob, I abhorre my selfe in dust and ashes:The seate of pouerty in the vnderstanding. Howbeit conuiction of iudgement is not all, there's many a man empouerished, yea, who knowes himselfe to be naught worth, who yet is not poore in spirit
and disposition, he frets, he bussles, he beares a great outside, and can in no wise stoope, begge, be beholden: and so 'tis here also; we all are bankrupts in grace, that's confessedly cleare, and some are conuinced of their emptinesse of grace, and inability of getting it, who yet are not poore in spirit, for the spirit frames the will2. The will. (as Caietan well) as well as the vnderstanding, subdues that, as well as it conuincces this, and makes a man glad to be nothing in himselfe, so God may be all: for the poore, with St. Paul, would be found in Christ, hee would not be found in himselfe, he would be wise, iust, holy, strong, &c, in Christ aboue, and would haue Christs graces, and Christs selfe vpon Christs termes, vpon free grace; without all contributions of help, or attributions of worth, seene or fore-seene in himselfe. And when a man is wrought to this, that hee willingly disclaimes all helpes and hopes of his owne, and the creatures, and freely casts himselfe vpon Christ for all, finding all grace in him, none without him, then hee is poore in spirit. And this the first worke of the spirit, Ioh. 16. It conuinceth, (that is, it clearely concludes the contradictory to that we naturally hold to be most true) it conuinces man that he is sinful, and Christ only righteous, and vntill a man sees this, hee is his owne Christ, his owne God, his owne hope, and cares no more for Christ, than a loyall subiect doth for a pardon which he needs not. It is not therefore without cause, that our Sauiour begins here, that hee vses a method (as I may so say) analyticall,
vnrauells, vntwists, vndoes all that man hath done, and deales with him as you would with a glasse of precious water, 1. empty it to the bottom, of all that was formerly there, and then fill it with what is sweet; happy is the man who is thus taught of God, who is brought backe a quite contrary way to his primitiue estate; mans misery came in when he shooke off God, and would stand by himselfe, when hee would be no longer dependent, but absolute; and then beginnes his happinesse, when hee is content to strip himselfe of all, and to expect all from God in Christ, when once hee can disclaime all selfe-conceitednesse, selfe-wilnesse, selfe-worthinesse, selfe-sufficincy, selfe-dependency, fleshly selfe-loue, and in one, all selfishnesse, and can yet at the same time say, Gods mercy is my merit, Gods power my strength; God is my hope, my life, my fulnesse, in him I see and find riches in my pouerty, wisdome in my folly, all-sufficiciency of grace and helpe, in my vtter emptinesse and vnsufficiency, then he is poore, then hee is happy, for his happinesse, life, abilities, all lye out of himselfe, lie in God originally, immediately in Christ: Now because this is the hardest thing in the world, for a man thus to deny & resigne himselfe, and to be wholly dependent, for euery man would be some body in and with himselfe, nay, euery man would be absolute a King, a God (for still that first poyson conueyed into Eue, runs along in the blood, and being bred in the bone, will neuer out of the flesh) our blessed Sauiour
therefore puts on the duty, and perswades it from the most pressing arguments, Blessed (saith he) are the poore, they haue the spirit in them, and the Kingdome is prepared for them; Blessednesse, what can be more? the spirit, what greater guift? what better guide? the Kingdome! Luke 11. what greater estate? the Kingdome of Heauen, what higher Kingdome? as if hee had said, you all reach at a Kingship, you would dwell as high as God himselfe, here's the way; hence take your first rise, be poore, and then you shall be rich; low, and then you shall be high; bee nothing in your selues, expect all, all grace, all ability to get, vse, encrease, keepe grace, from me, and mee alone, and you shall be happy now, and glorious hereafter: Onely remember, that as I speake of spirituall abasements, so I vndertake for spirituall aduancement; a Kingdome you would haue, and a Kingdome I promise you, but a Kingdome not of mans, but of Gods, not on earth, but of Heauen; there be not enough on earth, for Saints to haue, euery one one to himselfe, but there's one in Heauen which is sufficient for you all, that you lost by seeking it out of God in your selues, that I restore to you, in case you be thus poore, that is, if so be you will lay downe all hopes of your owne, and receiue it as a meere gift of mine, who come not onely to prepare a place for you there, but to paue you a way, and to lead you by the hand, till you come thither.
Thus much I adde, because the notes of the Sermon (taken onely in the deliuery) are too short, and so too darke; wee goe on.

div.head: Blessed are those that mourne, for they shall be comforted.
div.p: POuerty of spirit, respects the iudgement of a man; but mourning the affections: as Chrysostome said, that God in the creating of the world, built downe-ward: So our Sauiour heere first layes the foundation of happinesse in the iudgement, and then descends, and builds downward vpon the affections. Blessed are those that mourne; mourning is a contraction of the heart, as the Apostle calls it, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 2 Cor. 2.4. a contraction or coarctation of the heart, vpon the apprehension of some present or pressing euill, or the absence of some desired good. This mourning is alwayes found in pouerty, and is therefore heere set next it by our Sauiour, although in Saint Luke, hee interpose those that hunger, and therefore I stand not much vpon the connexion.
In the words we haue the point and the proofe. The point: Blessed are those that mourne; the proofe, for they shall be comforted. We will take the words of Christ for our point.
Doctr. Hee is a hapy man that can mourne well.

Here, before wee goe any further, somewhat must be said by way of explication, and so wee'll
proceed to the vse: The persons are said here to be mourners; in Luke, to be weepers. Sorrow is as the tree, & that's opposed to ioy; the next & immediate bud is mourning, opposed to reioycing: the next to that is weeping, opposed to laughter; The sense is then, hee that is in a mourning case, is an happy man; not simply for that he mournes (for that implyes a contradiction) but in a sense, namely, as it presupposes some good, and promiseth more.

But are all mourners happy? No, for there are 1. carnall mourners, that mourne because goodnesse is so neer them, and sin so far off. 2. Natural, that mourne onely for the presence of some temporall euills, or the want of some outward good. 3. Spirituall, for the want of some spirituall good, or the presence of som spirituall euill, and such are here intended: as if our Sauiour should say, they are happy men that can mourne in spirituall manner; and for this wee haue Christs owne word, both heere, and Luke 6 21. In both places he not only barely affirms it, but also backs it with a reason: they are blessed, for they shall reioyce and be comforted. This reason holds in spirituall things; mourners are therefore blessed, because they shall be comforted; not so in outward things, as to say, to those that are sicke; Blessed are yee sicke, for yee shall be visited, restored: Blessed are yee poore, for yee shall be relieued, your wants supplyed, &c. The argument is not good, for here the griefe of the present, exceedes the ioy of the future, the comfort quits not cost of the affliction:
but it holds very well in things spirituall, as heere, yee mourners shall be comforted, and are therefore blessed: for as your sorrowes abound, your comforts shall superabound: so that although spirituall mourning be not comfort, yet it carries comfort along with it, and inferres happinesse; which will yet more plainly appeare, if wee consider.

Reason 1 First, that it flowes from a good fountaine (a cleare streame, you know, argues a cleare spring) This is first a sound head, a wel-composed iudgement, the affections are blinde, and doe follow as they are guided: If they be put into the hands of a bruitish leader, as sense and appetite, they prooue bruitish; if into the hands of rationall guides, they become rationall; if of spirituall, spirituall; when therefore the mourning is spirituall, it shews the iudgement also sound and spirituall, that sees euery thing in its right colours: and so it argues a sound head.

Secondly it argues a wel-temper'd heart: such an heart as is 1. soft and fleshy, yeelding: A stone, you know, will neuer yeeld, no more will a stony heart relent. He that can conceiue deepe sorrow for sinne, and powre out himselfe into teares, that man hath sure a soft heart. And 2. a sound heart, set against sinne, and for that which is good. All sorrow growes from an antipathy betweene the party grieuing, and the cause thereof, as on the contrary, delight shewes a conueniency and agreement with the thing wherein a man delights.

Secondly, that this mourning is of good quality, 'tis a diuine sorrow, 'tis 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a sorrow according to God, as the Apostle calls it, 2. Cor. 7. Such as works repentance▪ tends to life, (whereas worldly sorrow worketh death) is neuer to be repented of: worldly sorrow is to be vnsorrowed. The sweetest thing in sinne, must end in bitternesse, the pleasure in sorrow; yea, the sweeter it is in the act, the more bitterly must it be bewailed. But here 'tis otherwise; the bitterest thing in this godly sorrow is sweetest of all: the more a man can teare his heart therewith, the more comfort he hath; he onely sorrowes, because he cannot sorrow enough; mournes, because he can mourne no more, can entertaine this guest no better; if naturall teares ease (as Aquin. 1.2. q. 38. Art. 2.) nedum spiritual. And this is the quality this spirituall mourning.

Thirdly, that it hath good effects: For, 1. it is preuenting, 2. reforming. First, it preuents all other needlesse sorrowes; Naturall sorrowes it moderates and boundes, as suspected; carnall and hellish sorrow, it banisheth as an enemy; Godly sorrow is a diuersion of other sorrowes, toward the right obiect: As Chirurgians, when a man bleeds dangerously in one place, they open a veyne in a • other; so to turne the course: So when a • an bleedes, mournes too much, for worldly things, it lets him bleed elsewhere, turning the course of his sorrow vpon his sinne. Secondly, it is reforming, produces those good effects of carefulnesse, apologie, feare, desire, and the
rest, as they are reckoned vp, 2 Cor. 7.11. It mends the foule much, makes a man better, and so sets him onward toward happinesse.

Reason 4 Lastly, if we consider the issue of godly sorrow, 1. it tends and bends to happines, not simply and of it selfe, for the Angels mourne not, and yet are happy, but respectiuely, as the state now stands with vs; wee went away from God by sinne, and must returne againe by weeping-crosse: And yet not directly now, neyther doth spirituall mourning make a man happy, but onely as it makes way for Christ (as the needle makes way for the threed) that we may be reunited, and pieced againe to God: so that as the case now stands, godly sorrow is necessary to our happinesse, and tends vnto it, seruing, as the opening of a veyne, to let out the sicknesse,Psal. 126.5. Psal. 97.11. and to bring in ease: 2. It ends in happinesse: for, they that sow in teares, shall reape in ioy; and light is sowne for the righteous, and ioy for the vpright in heart. Now men sow alwayes for increase; they expect not onely their seed againe, but many for one: so they that sow in godly sorrow, shall reape a ioyfull haruest of happinesse; it is with this sorrow, as with the silke-worme, which spends and workes out it selfe, till at last it end in a soft silke: so doth this consume and waste it selfe, till at length it end in euerlasting ioy.

Vse. 1 It may serue to bewaile our vnhappinesse now adayes, that run a course quite contrary to that of our Sauiour, he blesseth them that mourne; the most are of another iudgement, and hold such of
all other the most vnhappy; and as we vary from him in iudgement, so likewise in prescription; he saith mourne, that you may reioyce; weepe, that you may laugh; the world on the other side saith, be merry, that you may not mourne; laugh, that you may not be cast down; the Apostle bids turne all your laughter to mourning, your ioy into heauinesse, Iames 4. Men now adaies turne all heauinesse to laughter, are afraid of mourning, put it farre from them, looke on it as on an enemy, make account, if they should goe about it, they should neuer haue merry day more; Nay, Nehem. 1. they vary also from the practice of the Saints, in sad times; Nehemiah, though for his one particular hee were in good estate, and sufficiently well prouided for, yet he could not enioy it, so long as the Church of God was in heauinesse and affliction; but prouokes himselfe to mourning, and applies himselfe close thereunto: So Vriah, 2 Sam. 11. seeing the people of God in hazard, refused vtterly to goe into his house, to eate and to drinke, and to lie with his wife; so sensible haue the Saints of God euer beene of the Churches afflictions, but especially for the sinnes of the times haue they been greatly humbled, as Ezra, who in this case, rent his garments, pluckt off the hayre of his head, and of his beard, and sate astonished, Ezra. 9. And Riuers of teares ranne downe Dauids eyes, because men kept not Gods Law. Had Dauid but liued in our times, walked in our streetes, to haue seene our pride, heard our oathes, lies, &c. euery where
vttered, hee would surely haue washed our streetes with his teares. But what doe wee? see these things in others, yea, act them our selues: wee our selues sweare, lie, drinke, reuell, &c. and yet wee mourne not, It is for that we want matter? Is there no cause of mourning amongst vs? Surely, if wee looke vpon Gods gracious dealing with vs, we haue had blessings in abundance, vnder a peaceable and quiet gouernment: but wee cannot but know there are stormes abroad, and who can tell where they will light in the end? Heere wee haue no townes, but Shalems; no men, but friends. Goe into the fields, no speares but standing corne, no drummes but tabrets, no out-cries but haruest-homes, all matters of reioycing: but looke abroad a while, and you shall see all places become Acheldamaes, houses of blood, fields of blood, ditches of blood, townes of blood, Churches of blood, and can we yet finde no mater of mourning? or if wee see no misery, is there no sinne in the world? tell me? Can wee see no sinne in the heart, none in the house, none in the towne, none in the Church, none in the State, none in the Land, none in the world? Oh the ignorance that is yet found in many places, amongst vs, in such abundance of the meanes: Besides, many will come indeede to heare, but they haue made their conclusion before-hand, how farre they will goe, they are euen set, and as g • od as they meane to bee. There is a name of Religion amongst vs, and 'tis but a name, as appeares when
it comes to meum and tuum. What is the reason then that wee mourne not? weepe not? 1. some pleade they cannot haue while? and this excuse is worse than the fault, q. d. my brothers house is fired, but I cannot haue while to quench it, 2. others will say, they cannot weep; but that's but a false plea: for they can command teares in outward crosses, or vnkindnesses from a friend: yea, they can weepe oftentimes of meere curstnesse of heart, and thinke they haue reason for it too. Although these teares hurt them greatly, and the other helpe, yet, those they giue way to, and these they abhorre; so taking cordialls for poison, and poison for cordialls: and therefore no maruell they haue no more comfort of their teares so ill-grounded, so ill-bestowed.

Giue way to this mourning: it hurts no man, Vse. 2 but makes for his happinesse and comfort. Wee haue laughed too long already, and mourned too much for temporal crosses: Turne now the streame into the right channell, set your sorrow vpon the right obiect: then it is where it should be, when bent against sinne, and then 'tis comforable.
But how shall I know my sorrow to bee sound and spirituall? Quest.

First, if the obiect be spirituall, Answr. the absence of some good, or presence of some euill. The chiefe good we know, is God. The good man mournes & laments after God, as the Scripture speaketh, when he withdraweth himselfe either in the light of is countenance (which a Dauid holds better then life, and the want thereof more bitter then death)
or in the graces of his Spirit, or in the ministry of his Word, when wee haue not our signes, see not our visions, or in the losse of his seruants: So for sinne, the good man lookes vpon sinne (both his owne, and others) as vpon the greatest euill, and is thereby moued to mourning, but for his owne most. And as for sinnefull, so also for painefull euills of the Saints abroad, or at home, or for those personall miseries, which grow out of his owne corruptions &c.Vid. Aug. sermo: 7 de tempore.
Secondly, it may be knowne by the spring and motiue of it: namely, loue to good, whence comes griefe in the want of it: and hatred of euill, whence sorrow in the presence of it.

Thirdly by the effects, which respect, 1. God, 2. our neighbour, 3. our selues: for God, spirituall mourning sends a man to heauen, with prayers, confessions, suites to God. 2. It sends a man to his neighbour; makes him mercifull, not pettish, censorious; &c. It makes him also iust to his neighbour. If I haue wronged any man, I'll bee ready to satisfie him, to make him restitution. If I haue runne away with his goods or good name, I'll carry them home againe, &c. 3. for himselfe, it sets a man further off from his sinnes, nearer to God; emptyes him of himselfe, inflames him with zeale for God, and a greater loue of goodnesse. And thus you may know spirituall mournning,

The next thing is how to exercise it. And here 1. get the instrument set in tune, goe to the heart-maker, and heart-mender, God, and pray him to
giue a soft heart: Take his Couenant, Ezek. 36. and plead it to him, say: Here's thy owne hand, Lord, thou hast promised to take away the stony, and to put in the place thereof an heart of flesh. He will not eat his word, deny his promise. 2. Keepe the wound alwayes open and bleeding, as it were, by the constant practise of all the exercises of Religion, but especially of humiliation, reckoning often with thy selfe; so to see what thou hast done, that thou shouldest not, what thou hast not done, that thou shouldest? how slightly and slubberingly thou hast posted ouer the duties of each day? 3. Vpon extraordinary occasions set thy selfe to a more than ordinary mourning. And here 1. vse a good method. 2. thinke of good motiues: for method. 1. Take a fit time, when God hath any way mollified thy hart, and made it in a mourning case, close with him. After a shower the husbandman puts in the plough, 'twill not vp else; so when we finde our selues any whit softned, take the hint, improue that opportunity.

2. Betake thy selfe to a fit place, where thou mayest freely and without distraction mourne before the Lord. Peter went out and wept bitterly; the hall was no fit place for such a businesse. Get into some corner, and there weepe thy fill betweene God and thine owne soule, see what reason thou hadst so to offend thy Father, wound thine elder brother, grieue Gods Spirit, thy comforter. And thus much of the method you must runne. Consider next of the motiues, and see what reason you haue to mourne, (for indeed a man
wil see a great deale of reason before he will yeeld to entertaine this guest.)
Godly sorrow is 1 needfull. 2. profitable. 3. comfortable.

Needfull it is 1. in respect of others, they will not doe it, haue not hearts to doe it, some must: therefore mourne thou. 2 in respect of our selues it is necessary, and that 1. to preserue vs from the common contagion and destruction. How was Lot preserued from both in Sodom? hee vexed his righteous soule at their vncleane conuersation, he set him selfe a weeping daily for their sinnes: and so he was neither infected by them, nor destroied with them. 2. A man shall neuer be able to pray for others,— si vis mestere, dolendum &c. or to admonish or reproue to purpose, vnlesse hee haue first beene a mourner for them before God, bled before God himselfe for that sinne, which he reproues in others; what likelihood is there, that that reproofe shall take, or worke vpon another, when thy selfe art not affected? Vse. 2

Vid Chrysost. in P • al. 51. Homil. 2.—Secondly, it is profitable as well as necessary. Naturall sorrow heales not, payes no debts; but godly sorrow cures the soule, sets off wi • h God, makes one alway better when it leaues him, then when it findes him. And for the publike, such a one may stop a common plague, stand vp in the gap, diuert a iudgement, make all the towne, countrey, kingdome where he liues, beholding to him: for he preserues the Iland,Io • 22.30. as Iob in one place hath it, after some translations.

Thirdly, it is also maruelous comfortable,
lightens the heart, pulls out the sting of all crosses. It is not a vexing, blubbering sorrow,Vid. Aug. Confess. lib. cap. but rationall, quieting, and such as giues content. A Christian could liue and feed vpon these teares, hee weepes and is glad, hee can doe so: Yea, when he hath wept one houre, he would giue all the money in his purse, hee could weepe another.
