Now therefore make no iugdement of thine estate by these deceiueable notes, but search into thy selfe by those that are
true, and if thou finde that thou art vnder the power and raigne of hypocrisie, neuer giue rest vnto thine eyes, nor sleepe vnto thine eye-lids, vntill thou hast gotten out of this shamefull, miserable and cursed estate.

div.head: The fifteenth SERMON.

epigraph.q: Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God.

div.p:
ALl vpright men are blessed men; that was our first point from these words obserued. This we haue proued al
• eady, and made some inference and vse of that discourse: as, that wee would therefore make a true iudgement euery one of his owne estate.

For this purpose, we laid you downe diuers characters from our Sauiour, Math. 23. and out of the Psalme we shewed you signes of an hypocrite in state, as that first, he soothes vp himselfe in his sinfull courses; whereas it is the care of an vpright man to find out his way, as Salomon speaketh: Secondly, he is at paines to deceiue and coozen others, as well as himselfe: whereas the vpright person is plaine, simple, and open in all his courses, so farre as may stand with the rules
of discretion: Thirdly, the hypocrite (for goodnesse) is at a stand, he sees as much light as he desires, but the vpright man can neuer haue light enough. Againe, he is as good as he meanes to be: but the vpright presseth on still toward the mark: Fourthly, the hypocrite (for badnesse) he plotteth michiefe on his bed, whereas the vpright is best alone: Againe, the hypocrite obstinates and stiffens himselfe in a wicked course, and loues those sinnes, which he dares not but leaue: the vpright person, otherwise, as hath been shewed at large.

Vse 2 For a third vse of this point: Is it so, that the vpright man is a blessed man; let vs all be exhorted to affect and follow after vprightnesse, if we would attaine true happinesse, and to make out for truth, that we may be blessed. Me thinkes I should not need to vse many arguments to perswade you hereunto. Truth is of it selfe: 1. most desireable and amiable, as the contrary is lothsome and detestable: That which lookes like gold, or beares a shew of Pearle, but is not so, we hate it so much the more, as it hath a resemblance, and blush more of gold or pearle: so the counterfeit of truth is so much the more odious as truth it selfe is louely, and by a secret power, attracts the heart vnto it selfe: of all meats, those doe most please the stomacke that are most simple; and of all speeches and actions, those giue the best content, and affect vs most, that are most naturall, and least strained: Hence is it, that wee loue to heare the prattle, and see the behauior
of children, because a man may see a childs heart in his actions, and heare a childs heart in his speeches. Therefore labour to be true of heart, because truth is louely, and desireable. 2. It is also needfull to take paines herein, for as much as we are all borne hypocrites, crooked, and peruerse: 2. no man knowes the turnings and windings of his owne heart. Dauid was an excellent man, and yet he discouerd much hypocrisie. Did Dauid thinke (trow yee) that he should euer haue dealt so treacherously with his faithfull seruant, Vriah? so basely with his neighbors wife? so absurdly and indirectly, in the court of Achish? So prophanely, as for so long a time to abuse the Sacraments, and other holy ordinances of God, all the time that he lay in his sinne? Oh, the depth of hypocrisie that lodges and lurks in the heart of man! so needfull is it, that wee should be still cleansing this poole, this guzzle, as I may so speake, of the heart.

Thirdly, as it is needfull to make out for vprightnesse, so it is also comfortable in all estates, as is to be seene in Hezechiah, now lying vpon his death-bed, what was it that held vp his heart in comfort, vpon the receit of that sad message? not his wealth, not his state, not his crowne or scepter, but this, that he had walked before God with an vpright heart. Esa 38.3▪ This also was Iobs comfort in his greatest distresse, and what else is it that vp-holds a Christian, when the diuell roares vpon him? what hath he to oppose against his fiery darts, when he shall obiect, Thou stand • st guilty of many
sinnes, and dost faile very much in thy best duties? what supports a man in this temptation, but this, I meant it well, I did it in vprightnesse, and wherein I haue sinned against God, it was against the generall bent and purpose of mine heart? And this is my comfort; thus there's reason why we should seeke truth: now before we go further, it shall be necessary, that we shew you, 1. what truth is: 2. what are the kindes of it. And, 3. what are the marks whereby it may be discerned.

For the first: Truth (we say in schooles) is nothing else but an agreement of things with their first principles as that is true gold which is of the true Oare, that's true wine, that's of the true grape, that's a true counterpane, that agrees with the originall, that is a true measure, that is suitable to the standard: So likewise truth is that in a man, whereby he comes to agree with his first coppy and originall,Acts 13.22. God. Thus Dauid, for his vprightnesse is said to be a man after Gods owne heart, his heart was suitable to Gods heart, his will conformable to Gods will: Lo, here, an vpright man, when a thing is according to the patterne, to the standard, then 'tis true.

Now for the second thing we propounded; truth is of two sorts: First, of the heart: Secondly, of the life. That of the heart is when the soule eyes God, lookes full vpon God, and stands as it were in a frame toward God. Truth of life, is whereby a man bends himselfe to please God, and to be conformable to his will in all
things. Of both these kinds there are two parts: 1. a profession of goodnesse: 2. an answerable affection and disposition: Hypocrisie hath the former of these two, as hath bin shewed, it makes large profession, but it comes short in the second, for the hypocrite practiseth not so much as he might: As on the contrary, truth of heart hath indeed a profession, but not a meere name and shew of Religion, that's not all, it hath a desire too, to be the same inwardly that it seemes to be, and is willing to leaue more sinne, and to doe more duty then it is able to doe. He therefore who makes shew of no more then is in him indeed, he whose inside and outside are matches, and fellowes, agreeing betweene themselues, and both with the Rule, he is the vpright man. But this is not vnderstood by euery body, therefore we will deliuer our selues in some plaine marks: first, of vprightnesse of heart: secondly, of vprightnesse in life.

For the first:Signes of a true heart. an vpright heart is first a perfect heart (as the Scripture termes it) it is an entire whole heart, which is, when all the powers goe one and the same way, when the whole soule is bent after God, and driues at this only, to seeke and set vp him. You may best know it by the contrary, the hypocrites heart is a diuided heart, he lookes two waies at once, there is one power and faculty of the soule against another, one affection against another, &c. There is ('tis true) a fight in the best, but then it is betweene grace and flesh, betweene a
man and his enemy: but in the hypocrite, one faculty takes part against the other, here's Reason and Conscience against affection, and one affection against another. There is a wide difference betweene ciuill warre, where there is one neighbour against another, and a nationall warre, where they all ioyne together against a common enemy. The Christian mans fight, is of the whole regenerate part against corruption: but in the hypocrites heart there is ciuill warre: the powers are altogether by the eares among themselues, as if one member in the body should fight against the other, or one subiect in a Kingdome against another: passion commends a thing, reason condemnes it: lust affects a thing, conscience refuseth it; one part would haue one thing, and another another: whereas in the vpright man it is farre otherwise, his heart is entire, and goes all one way, he desires in all things to please God, and get strength against sinne.

Secondly, an vp-right heart is described in Scripture to be a pure heart, free from forraine and base mixtures. To expresse this, the Apostle vseth a fine word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 by a metaphor eyther from such things as are tryed by being held vp against the beames of the Sunne, to see what faults or flawes are in them, or else from such things as are purged and clarified by the heat of the Sunne, from the grosse matter that is in them: So true grace purifies the heart, and takes corruption off the soule, whereby it becomes pure, cleane, simple, which in Scripture
phrase import one and the same thing. The vpright heart then is a pure heart, such as mingles not with corruption. To haue any thing to doe with sinne, it is altogether vnwilling, but it cannot entertaine it, or bid it welcome. A traueller, though he cannot but meet with dirt in his way, yet hee will not suffer it to mingle with him, hee keepes it off all that hee can, and what he cannot, he gets it off as soone as may be. But now it is not so with a Swine, he seekes the mud, followes after it; and delights in it, hee knowes not well to be without it. And so the case stands with the vpright person, and the hypocrite. The first is indeed defiled with corruption, though he doe what he can to the contrary, but he seekes it not, hee allowes it not, and makes all speed to wash himselfe from his pollution: but now for the other, hee delights in sinne, watcheth his times to commit it, takes speciall content in it, is neuer well, but when hee is in sinning. It is here as it is with the stomacke of a man. If the stomacke be weake, it affects and longs after trash, and things vnwholesome, swollowes them greedily, and keepes the bad meat it hath taken, whereas the strong stomacke refuseth to take that which doth not agree with it, or if it doe, 'tis neuer well, till eased of it againe, eyther vp-ward or downe-ward, or if not so, it thrusts it out as it were by head and shoulders through the flesh and skinne by botches and biles: and so it is with the vpright heart, if it haue surcharged it
selfe any way with sinne, it cannot be well till it be disburdened: whereas the hypocrite hides sinne vnder his tongue as a sweete morsell; giues it entertainement, and keepes it with him, not desiring to part with it. The good heart though it cannot be free from sinne, yet it is working it out still: It is here as in a liuing running spring, which, though it be sometimes mudded, yet it workes out that mud, and cleares it selfe againe: but it is not so with a standing poole, that gathers mud, and keepes it: so the vnsound heart falls into sinne, and delights in it, retaines it, whereas corruption in the vpright man sleepes not, rests not, hee is euer striuing with it, struggling against it, and casting how to get riddance of it out of his soule.

Thirdly, an vpright heart is a willing heart, plyant and flexible to goodnesse, as Dauid on his death-bed chargeth his sonne Salomon to serue the God of his fathers with a perfect heart and a willing minde, and the Apostle speaking of himselfe and of his company, saith, wee trust wee haue a good conscience, willing in all things to please God: True grace corrects the will, and makes a man doe what he doth, willingly, because he workes from an inward principle. The hypocrite on the contrary, moues vpon an outward principle: some outward respect sets the will on worke: as profit, credit, safety, or the like: so long as these may be furthered, he wil do something: as a wind-mil wil worke so long as the wind driues, but if that faile,
it ceaseth grinding; so if there be a gale of vaine-glory, commodity, safety, &c; filling his sailes, somewhat the hypocrite will be content to doe; but if these faile, his worke's done: But now the vpright man works out of loue to God, and therefore is willing to doe any thing he can, yea to doe more then hee can, as the hypocrite on the other side, doth more then hee would, but that hee is prickt on by his sinister aimes and by-respects.

Fourthly, an vpright heart is one heart, it is a single heart, as the Scripture stiles it, It pitcheth vpon one obiect, God is the vpright mans obiect, God is his end, God's his motiue, God is all in all with him. He lookes not at by-respects in his seruice; God is his vtmost end, that bounds all he doth. 'Tis true he respects his owne good too, but this is in a second place, and in a subordinate sort. He lookes what God would haue done, and do's it, what God would haue left, and leaues it, &c: his heart is one, whereas the hypocrite hath an heart and a heart, he is double-hearted in all his dealings, as Saint Iames speaketh, hee lookes not at God as his vtmost end, hee hath something behind God, and beyond the glory of God which hee aymes at: but the vpright man looks still at God, and so his heart is vnited, and but one.

Fifthly, the vpright heart is a stable heart,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
constant in its course, for it goes vpon constant principles, hath constant motiues, constant ends, &c: but the hypocrite is vnstable, vnconstant, as saith Saint Iames: A double-minded man is vnstable in all his wayes, chap. 1. to day he is all for the doing of
good, hee loues good company, good purposes, good practices, in time of extremity seemes to set vp God in's house, in's heart, but to morrow, hee forgets and forgoes the good he had begunne, he falls quit off, because hee was not wel-bottom'd: whereas the vpright man is constant in his way; onely he may be blowne out of it, and put out of his course for a while by temptation, desertion, or so; but his heart is still toward God, and when hee is put by at any time, he recouers himselfe, and comes in againe. It is with him, as with a streame that hath made it selfe a channell, wherein to run: It may indeed by a strong hand be turn'd out of his course, but yet it is still bending toward its owne way, and neuer leaues working, and winding till it be where it was before: so howsoeuer the vpright person may bee vnsettled for a time, and put beside his course, yet hee striues and labours to be where he should be, and neuer findes himselfe well, till he be in his first-path. Contrarily, the hypocrite hath his by-courses, and blind wayes wherein he is commonly found, as a thiefe, that seldome keepes the high-way, vnlesse it be for euill purpose, as to take a purse or the like, but otherwise, crooked wayes, by-wayes, vnknowne wayes are his wayes, so the proper tract of an hypocrite are the dark by-paths of vngodlinesse, that leade to the chambers of death, & when he turnes at any time into the wayes of God, it is for some ill▪ and odde end, whereas the vpright mans way, is the way that is called holy, out of which howsoeuer hee may turne by some occasion (as a
true man may bee sometimes out of his way. yet with no euill intent, as through earnest discourse or deep musing, or to call vpon a friend, &c.) yet ordinarily hee holds the way to heauen, out of which, if he be drawne aside, or haue strayed by any meanes, he leaues not till hee hath recouered himselfe. Loe, these are the markes of an vpright heart, it is an entire and whole heart, it is a pure heart, a willing heart, a single heart and a constant heart. Iudge now aright of your selues by these notes, and if your hearts be vpright within, the I • dge pronounceth you blessed.

But as there must be in vs vprightnesse of heart, so there is required that wee finde in our selues also vprightnesse of life: for these must necessarily concurre to the making vp of a blessed man. And of this (that you may be able to passe a right censure of your selues) the signes are of 3. sorts. First either they respect God, or other men, or our selues. First, for God. 1. he hath Gods stamp imprinted on his soule, the spot of God is vpon him,Deut. 32.5. so as he liues to God, seekes God for Gods sake, according to that of the Psalme, this is the generation of them that seeke thee, this is Iacob. Psalm. 24. The vpright man aymes at God in all, sets him vp, and seekes him, not for his portion, but for Gods-selfe. 2. as he seekes Gods face, so he seekes him in his ordinances, and in the meanes of grace. And here 1. he seeketh the Precepts of God,Psalm. 119. aswell as the promises: the hypocrite is ready to lay hold on the comforts of Gods Booke, and to misapply the promises, neuer regarding the commands, and what
God requires to haue done: but the sincere Christian hath his eye vpon the precepts also of Gods Word, and thinkes that he can neuer doe God seruice enough, neuer leaue sinne enough, informe himselfe enough of his duty toward God. 2. he iustifies Gods Word and wayes, wisedome is iustified of her children, Matth. 1 • . saith our Sauiour, and we preach wisedome to those that are perfect (that is, to those that are sincere) saith the Apostle: such a man see's and findes safety, profit, wisedome and comfort in all the wayes of God. 3. as he applies himselfe to Gods precepts and iustifies them, so he grows and profits by them ordinarily, as the Lord saith by the Prophet, Are not my words good to them that are good, Mic. 2.6. when the good word of God meetes with those that are good, it mends them; when this good seed is cast into good ground, it brings forth fruit also that is good. 4. he resignes himselfe vp to the Word,Rom 6. that's his rule, he obeyes from the heart the forme of doctrine, whereunto he is deliuered: thus did Dauid, concerning whom the Lord giues this testimony,Acts. 13.22. that hee had fulfilled all Gods wils, Act. 13. And in this obedience of Dauid you may obserue 3. notes of vprightnesse couched together in that one text. 1. Dauid was vniuersall in his obedience, he did not execute Gods will to the halues, as Saul did (for that's the opposition) who would leaue some sinnes, but not some; banish so witches, but not all; offer sacrifice at somtimes, not at others: but Dauids hath this testimony there giuen him by Gods own mouth, that hee would fulfill (all) Gods wils, and for this is said
to be a man after his owne heart, vers. 22. But 2. Dauid, as he was vniuersall in his obedience, so also sincere; for he is said to fulfill Gods will,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
hee therefore obeyed▪ because God willed, and bad him so to doe. That's motiue enough, and is instead of all other to an vpright person (so farre as he is vpright) he neuer stands to thinke or weigh with himselfe, whether the thing that God commands be hard or easie, cheape or costly, painefull or pleasant; but will God haue him doe't? hee'll doe't, whatsoeuer it stand him in. And this was Dauids resolution and practice, when God set him vpon any manner of emploiment. He neuer stands to picke and chuse, as Saul did, what he will doe, and what he will not: but he will fulfill whatsoeuer God bids, and because hee bids, that's argument enough to him. If God bid him fight the Lords battels, hee'll fight: If hee bid lay vp good store of treasure, for the building of the Temple, it is done; if God bid him lay downe his kingdome, hee'll doe't: And here was the sincerity of his obedience 3. constancy, where it is said that he (will) fulfill all Gods will, hee will effect it, and goe through with it, not doe it by the halues, but finish and fulfill. Here's now an vpright man in his carriage toward God.

Secondly for men, and those whether 1. good men or bad men. 2. whether strangers, or those of his owne. For good men. 1 he hath an high esteeme of the godly (such as are truely so) aboue others. And as his heart rises against an hypocrite, when he can detect him to be such, so hee can see
an excellency in those that are pure in heart, which he esteemes and honours. This note you haue laid downe, Psal. 15.4. In his eyes a vile person is contemned, but hee honoureth them that feare the Lord.

Secondly, the vpright person as in his iudgement he prizeth good men most, so he affects them most for his companions, as Dauid, Psal. 16. All my delight, saith he, is in the Saints, those excellent ones of the the earth. And in another place, Companion am I to all them that feare thee, and to them that keepe thy Precepts, Psal. 119.63. whereas the hypocrite is alwayes at war & oddes with most vpright men, and his nearest companion is one halting, dissembling fellow or other, like himselfe.

Lastly, as in his iudgement hee preferres good people, and in his affections makes choice of them, so in his deeds, he carries himselfe proportionably toward them: for according to that wisdome, which he hath eeceiued from aboue, hee that is pure, is also peaceable, gentle, easie to bee dealt withall, full of mercy and good fruites, without wrangling, and without hypocrisie, Iames 3.17. hee is faithfull not onely with God, but with the Saints, Hos. 11.12. And this is the vpright mans carriage toward good men.

Secondly, for bad men 1. he dares not returne them like for like,1 Sam. 24.13. (when they deale hardly with him) railing for railing, reuiling for reuiling. Let wickednesse proceed from the wicked, saith Dauid in his speech to Saul, let them discouer their folly and malice, they doe but their kinde, as it were, but let not Dauid stretch forth his hand to wickednes,
to requite euill with euill, it becomes not him. 2. he sets himselfe to doe good to them that do hurt to him, to pray for them that curse and traduce him, he desires nothing more then their saluation, as we see in Paul, when the Iewes were ready to stone him through madnesse and ill-will, he seekes to winne them to God, and therefore begins with men, fathers and brethren, &c. Acts 22.1. so when he stood at the barre to pleade for his life, so much sought after by his aduersaries, hee could wish that all there present (how great enemies soeuer to himselfe) were euen as he was, not only almost, Acts 26. but euen altogether Christians, partakers of the same hope, &c.

Thirdly, toward strangers, he carries himselfe. 1. charitably, hee is not suspicious or iealous of those he knowes not, as the hypocrite, who suspects others to be like himselfe, and thinks all the world to be made of hypocrisie, because himselfe is so:Prou. 1 •
whereas the vpright person though hee bee not ouer-credulous, as a foole to beleeue euery thing, ye hee is not forward to haue others in suspect, till there appeare to be sufficient ground and reason. 2. the vpright man as he is charitable, so he is also humble in his dealing with others, that whereas the hypocrite thinkes himselfe the best man in the company, and the most gracefull speaker, the vpright man, on the contrary, holds himselfe the worst in the company wheresoeuer he comes, and as Paul in his owne esteeme, he is of all sinners the greatest, but of all Saints the least. And this is the carriage of the vpright man abroad.

Fourthly, at home, 1. though hee hate sinne in
all, yet especially in his owne, in himselfe most of all, and next, in those that are nearest vnto him, as Asa in his mother, whom for her idolatry he deposed from her regency. The hypocrite on the other side is worst at home, the edge of his displeasure is bent most against others abroad that are furthest from him, whiles he can suffer his owne children and family to goe on in sin without restraint or controll, yea himselfe often drawes them on to sinne. 2. The vpright man as he doth his vtmost to hinder sinne in those about him, so he is no lesse careful to put them on in goodnesse, for he would gladly haue all his goe to heauen. That husband, that father, that master, that's vpright, doth greatly desire and endeauour the saluation of all such as are vnder his charge. And this hee makes his speciall worke, his chiefe businesse lyeth at home.

As for himselfe in the last place, the vpright man is still pressing forward toward the mark, stil watching ouer his owne heart, still spurring on himselfe to the doing of duty, encouraging and calling vpon himselfe to fulfill his Couenants, and to make good his vows and promises to God.

Thus we haue stayd long vpon this point (perhaps to tediousnesse) in describing and differencing the pure in heart from the hollow-harted hypocrite, that you may make a right iudgement of your selues, and may moreouer be stirred vp to get this truth afore described.
Quest. What meanes must we vse for the attaining thereof?
Answ. I can scarce stay to tell you: briefly thus.

First, you must make a iourney to heauen for it, (for euery good gift and euery perfect giuing comes from aboue) goe to God and entreate him to straighten your crooked hearts,Meanes of truth. and to work in you this truth in the inward parts, which hee so much delighteth in. And that you may be sure to preuayle, take the new Couenant with you, and plead it; the first article wherein is that the Lord will giue you one heart, that you may feare his Name, Ez. 11. that is, a single heart, an vpright spirit. Goe to God now vpon this ground, and say: Lord, I well finde that I haue a double heart, a deceitfull crooked, false heart, I pray thee renue it, and make it one. Here I bring and vrge thine owne couenant, whereof I haue already receiued the seale in the Sacrament, therefore I beseech thee, make good thy word, and stand to thy bargaine.

Secondly, if you would get this truth and vprightnesse, it is necessary that you bring your selues often to the touchstone of the Word, and that you worke by rule, as you see a mason, when he hath a businesse in hand, hee often applyes his rule to that he works vpon, and by laying therunto his line and plummet, he tries whether his work be strait first and last, and whether it lye streight in the building: euen so must wee deale for the rectifying of our hearts, bring them often to the Word, that will purge them, straighten them, draw euery thing to the light, that we may passe a right censure on it. In other matters, men are vsually very prudent this way. If you doe but buy a beast, you'll take a full view, and make full triall
of him before you strike the match; Nay, if you buy but a coate, or a peice of cloth, you'll tosse it, and turne it, and hold it vp against the light to see what flawes you can finde in it, &c: that you bee not deceiued. Nay, if you buy but a bushell of corne, you'll take it, and view it, and smell it, and taste it before you will lay money vpon it. Nay, if it be but a pound of cheese, or a penni-worth of fruite that you haue need to vse, you will not take it till you see it be good. Oh bee not now penny-wise, and pound-foolish, to vse all this care in trifles, and to be carelesse of that, which most of all concernes you to looke to, but try your selues throughly, what you are by the Word of Gods truth, and how the case stands with your soules, why you performe holy duties, and how you doe them. Thus put your selues often to the line, and this shall be a speciall helpe to vprightnesse.

Thirdly, begin with simples (for all truth begins with simples.) A man can neuer write true ioyning-hand, till hee haue first learn'd his letters, he can neuer reade well and surely, that hath not first learned to spell. And so it is here; would you therefore get truth, take and single out your seuerall graces, your faith, loue, humilty, and the rest: and doe the same by your duties, as hearing, prayer, almes, and such like: single them out I say, consider them in seuerall, and see what they are; for if those be all in truth, you need not doubt. In receiuing of money, you'll not take the whole sum in grosse, but you'll draw out shilling after shilling, and one piece after another, and then if euery
peice be right, you cannot be cozened in the maine summe. The same course must you likewise take here, if you would be secured of this, that you are sound and vpright; make narrow search into your selues, try euery of your graces, examine euery suspected action, and then you cannot bee deceiued.

Fourthly, borrow what helpe you can from others, as you vsually doe in other cases of your owne accord; when you are darke your selues, you call in the light of your neighbours: so it must be here, get more light then your owne, when you buy a beast, you'll entreate others helpe; Good neighbour, let me haue your opinion in this businesse, foure eyes see more then two, and six then foure. And so must we deale in this behalfe also, say; Neighbour, what be your grounds, what be your marks, &c; pray'y let me haue your helpe: foure eyes see more then two, & six see more then foure. And thus, if we doe according to the former directions, it is possible, doubtlesse, to auoyd and frustrate Satans cunning wiles, and the deceitfulnesse of our owne treacherous hearts: This we should the rather endeauour, for that we are all afraid and careful of being cozened in other things, how much more here, sith of all deceits, selfe-deceit is most odious, as of all murtherers, he is most to be detested that murthers himselfe.

div.head: The sixteenth SERMON.

epigraph.q: Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God.

div.p: Doct. 1 ALl vpright men are blessed men.
Doct. 2 Mans blessednesse consists in the sight of God.
To these 2. points may be reduced whatsoeuer is contained in this eight verse.
For the first, we haue shewed it, and made som inferences and vses already.
That which yet remaines to be spoken, here, is a vse of consolation▪ and then we shall haue done with the point.

Vse. Is it so, that all they are in happy estate, that are pure in hart? let it serue for comfort then to al those that this haue testimony in their own soules, that they are vpright: be it they haue faults, yet they hate them; faylings, yet they earnestly endeauour all holy obedience, the blessing is here set vpon all such by our Sauior, as can approue to God and their owne soules, that they are vpright. Here such a one will be ready to obiect against himselfe (for as the hypocrite deludes himselfe by false signes of truth, so the good heart is oftentimes troubled with false signes of hypocrisie, and thus he obiects.)
Sure I am not right, Obiect. I haue but deceiued my selfe hitherto, for men censure and condemne me for an hypocrite.

What men are they that censure you so? Answ. one rotten-harted person (likly) or another. And if so, then know that such men cannot censure any better, cannot make any better iudgemēt of thee; so being vnder the power of hypocrisie themselues, they think all the world besides to bee made of hypocrisie. Therefore neuer care what others thinke or say of thee in this kinde vnlesse they bee iudicious Christians, and such also as haue a full and through knowledge of thee, rather see what the word of God, and thine owne conscience saith to thee.

I, Obiect. but the deuill layes it hard to my charge that I am an hypocrite, and what though men know not what I am, yet he doth, & therfore I feare I am so? Nay probably thou art not so, Answ. because he accuseth thee, for he is a liar from the beginning. And he doth not vse to molest his owne, whom he possesseth in peace with doubts of this nature. Marke what his title is in the Reuelation, an accuser of the brethren, such as are not of the brother-hood, of the Saints of God, those he troubles not in this manner, they are the brethren whom he accuseth, as he did Iob, whom he slandered to God, and yet Iob was an vpright man, God himselfe giuing witnesse thereunto, Iob 1.24.
Yea but not men and the deuill onely but mine own conscience also chargeth me with hypocrisie. Obiect.

To this we answer, Answ. that there is no man liuing so vpright, but his owne heart may truely charge
him with hypocrisie, but that is not the point. The question is whether hypocrisie doth raigne and rule in you, and whether you be so far vnder the power and dominion of it, as that it doth denominate you. Besides you must know that Conscience is but a subordinate Iudge, and must proceed by the rule of the Word, if it will deale aright. It is as a clock, that must be set by the Sun of Gods word. If it bring not the Euidence of holy Scripture for what it saith, it is but a temptation, and no testimony that it bringeth against vs: so likewise, if that place of Scripture whereupon it groundeth, bee such as may vpon like reason bee brought against any other of Gods sincere seruants euen the best, it is no better neither then a temptation, and not to be credited, see what Dauid saith to this, Psal. 73. His heart would needes perswade him, that inasmuch as the wicked flourished, and were in great prosperity, when himselfe in the meane while was plagued all the day long, and chastned euery morning, and therefore, surely he had cleansed his heart in vaine, and washed his hands to no purpose. But hee quickly corrects this errour in himselfe, and saith, that if vpon these grounds hee should thus conclude, he should not onely wrong himselfe, but also offend against all the generation of Gods Children, sith it may befall the dearest and best of them all to bee diuersly afflicted, when the vngodly meane while prosper in the world, and increase in riches.

Obiect. I, but not only my own conscience, but God also chargeth me with hypocrisie, and God is greater
then our heart, as saith Saint Iohn.
Doth God charge thee for an hypocrite? Answ. where is it that he doth this?
Why (you'll say) 1. in mine owne heart. Obiect. 2. in his Word: First, hee filles my heart with many terrours, feares, and horrours of Conscience.

For your satisfaction herein, you must know 1. that euery scruple of mind comes not from God, Answ. some come from Satan, and some from our selues through misprision. Againe, you must be aduertised, that it may befall the most sincere Christian, that you speak of, witnesse Iob, against whom the Lord himself seemed to fight, with breach vpon breach; so that he chose to dye rather then to endure it: witnesse Paul who had terrours within, and troubles without, witnes Dauid in many passages of the Psalmes. So long therefore, as these feares and doubtings do make vs better, and driue vs to God, it is well, and we need not be deiected thereat, seeing they are wholsom, howsoeuer they may be troublesom.
Yea, but not onely in mine own soule, but also in his holy Word God saith, I am an hypocrite. Obiect.

Nay, then we haue no more to say to thee: Answ. for if that be true, we haue done: if God say so in his word, we must consent, and say so too; but where is it that God in his word chargeth thee for an hypocrite? Why (you'll say) the vpright man is still going on constantly in his course, Obiect. and aduancing forward with a stedfastfoot toward the high prize that is set before him, but I, alas, am very vnconstant and dissettled, assoone off and assoone on, euery foote out of all good order and off th'hooks. Answ. There is a double constancy, the one while we are
here in the way (as they tearme it) and the other when we shall be in our country, when we shall be no more trauellers, but Citizens, when we shal be Comprehensores, as they say in schooles, wee are not, while we are here, to expect any such constancy, or settlednesse in a good estate of soule, as shall be fixed and vnalterable, That's reserued to the making vp of our happinesse hereafter. Here so long as we abide, we shall be still subiect to manifold declensions, manifold desertions, manifold stops and stayes in our course toward heauen, but so long as wee haue our faces set thither-ward, though the wind may violently carry vs sometimes beside the way, it should not dismay vs. If it bee with vs as with a running riuer (as was before said) which howsoeuer it bee diuerted and turned out of its course and channell, yet neuer leaues working and winding till it fall into the same course againe: so if when we are put beside our way, wee make toward it againe, and like the needle in a Card, though we be iogg'd aside for a seasō, yet we haue no rest or content in our soules, til we be where we should. If it be thus with thee, as hath been said, feare not, thou needst not be discouraged, thy ease is good.
Obiect. Yea, but the Scripture telles vs that the vpright person is still thriuing and growing, and continually addes to his strength, as Iob speaketh chap. 17.

Solu.There is a double growth, 1. in quantity. 2. in quality, the 1 when a man doth more duty then before, the 2. when though he performes not more then he did, yet he doth it better, in a more spirituall manner, with strayning out more corruption,
&c. Now if we grow any way, it may be sufficient vnto our comfort.

The vpright person is euer growing in the root (he becomes more settled and stablish'd in good courses) if not in the fruit; he still growes one way or other, and beares fruit answerable to his place, to his age. There be many valiant and worthy captaines, that cannot beare armes indeed in their old age, and doe their Countrey seruice that way, as they could haue done in youth, who yet haue as much valour, and are euery whit as able to direct and guide an Army, as when they were at thirty, or forty: So, many ancient Christians cannot haply shew forth so much grace as they could haue done in times past, nor make so good expressions of themselues, who still are on the growing hand; and howsoeuer they grow not, haply, in euery actiue grace, yet they grow in the habites of those, and in the passiue part of Christianity.

Yea, Obiect. but the vpright man is still purging himselfe, and getting ground of hypocrisie, but alas! I grow worse and worse this way, I discouer daily more and more hypocrisie in my selfe, it followes and haunts me wheresoeuer I goe, and whatsoeuer I doe, it troubles me in my study, in my closet, in my most secret works and duties, whether to God or man.

Why, let not this discourage thee, Answ. that thy corruption is more and more discouered: For, this is a signe of growth in grace, if this sight of thine hypocrisie be ioyned with an vtter hatred
and detestation thereof. The clearer any mans sight is, the more euill he discerneth by himselfe. The hypocrite is so blinded with pride, and selfe-loue, that he can see nothing but truth in himselfe: but it is purity of heart that helps ones sight, and the more any man discouers his owne hyporcisie, the more vpright he is; for it is not by corruption, that corruption is discouered, but by the light of true grace.
Obiect. Yea, but the Scripture tells vs, that there is ioy in the tabernacles of the vpright, and the righteous sing, and are glad; now, I am for most part heauy and vncomfortable, sad and pensiue?

Answ. The meaning of those places, is, that there is alway matter of ioy and comfort, where there is vprightnesse, if such would not suffer themselues through weaknesse and want of wisedome to be robbed and bereft of the consolations which yet must be so taken, as that wee vnderstand, that there is not any so vpright, but that his Sunneshine of comfort may other whiles be misted, and ouer-cast, and then hee droopes and goes mourning and disconsolate, although there be in all this no cause why he should be so cast downe: For so long as we can finde by our selues that we loue truth, and hate hypocritsie, and disclaime it, we should not suffer our selues to be beaten and baffled out of the comfortable assurance of our vprightnesse, but resolue with Iob, I wil neuer part with mine integrity, lose mine euidence, yeeld my selfe otherwise then vpright, and so consequently blessed, for my Sauiour hath
said it: Blessed are those that are pure in heart: i. e. vpright in heart, for they shall see God.

div.head: For they shall see God.
div.p:
ANd so wee come in order to the second Doctrine: Doctr. That mans blessednesse consists in the sight of God. The point is cleare: God seene, is the heighth of mans happinesse: the Text shewes it, the Scripture proues it, Psal. 16. vlt. In thy presence, Lord, is the fulnesse of ioy, and at thy right hand are pleasures for euermore. Here it appeares, that in the persence and sight of God, there is pleasure and ioy (and what else is ioy, but happinesse enioyed?) and of this ioy there is fulnesse, and freenesse, for there are riuers thereof running at Gods right hand, and eternity, it is for euermore. And for this cause it is, that the Scripture bids vs so often to seeke Gods face, as the chiefe good, yea, Saints and Angells haue this for the heighth of their happinesse: the Angells, Math 18. that they stand before the face of our heauenly father, as our Sauior speaketh in the Gospell, and the glorified Saints that they are euer with God, 1 Cor. 5.8. 1 Thes. 4.17. And surely if they be so blessed, as Dauid esteemes them, that dwell but in his courts on earth, Psalm. 84. How much more they that enioy his presence aboue in all fulnesse. Blessed, saith our Sauiour, are your eyes, for they see, and you eares, for they heare: Verily,
I say vnto you that many Kings and Prophets haue desired to see the things which you see, and haue not seene them, &c. If to see God here, where we behold but in a glasse, and as it were, in a shaddow, obscurely, be a blessed thing, what shall it be, thinke you, when we shall looke vpon him with open face, when we shall see as we are seene, face to face, this must needs render vs most blessed. You heare what the Queene of Sheba could say, concerning Salomons seruants, that were euer in his presence, and attended vpon his person, Happy are thy men, and happy are these thy seruants which stand continuall before thee, and heare thy wisedome. If this were true of them, then certainely, such as stand in Gods presence, and behold his face, must needes be most happy.
Here our intent is, first, to say somewhat for exposition of the words: secondly, to giue you the grounds and reasons of the point: thirdly, to make application.

For the first, two things we must tell you, first, there is a double sight of God: first, naturall, as that which we atttaine by sense or discourse of reason: secondly, supernaturall, which also is double: First, lesser, which is attained vnto by the light of grace: Secondly, greater, by the light of glory.

Secondly, you must be told, that there is a double consideration of God: God may be considered by vs, either first abstractiuely, and simply, as he is in himselfe and in his owne essence, and so
he is inuisible to any creature; or secondly, Vide Aquin. 1. 2 q. 5. Art 5, &c. Relatiuely, as he hath pleased to manifest himselfe vnto vs, eyther by taking our flesh vnto him in his incarnation, or by cōmunication of his grace vnto vs. These things being thus premised, our first conclusion is, that there is no sight of Gods essence to be had and attained by the meere light of Nature, forasmuch as there is no proportion betweene the eye and the obiect, as there must be, you know, in all sight. The second, that God is to be seene only in the rebound, by way of reflexion, and this eyther 1. by the light of Nature, and so God is to be seene in his workes: for there is a 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , something that may be knowne of God, some impressions and foot-steps,Rom. 1. as it were, of the wisdome, power, goodnesse, and other properties of God are to be found in his works of Creation and Prouidence, and some knowledge of him is to be had this way, but not so much as is sufficient to saluation, but onely to leaue men without excuse: 2. Supernaturally may God be seene, here more darkly by the light of grace, there more fully by the light of glory; but neuer perfectly, for we cannot behold him any otherwise then according to our capacity, now, we are finite, and he infinite, and therefore, as it is impossible to bring the body of the Sun within the compasse of a chamber or any other roome, so it is to comprehend the great God, as he is in himselfe, within the compasse of our narrow and straight hearts: And yet doth hee graciously
communicate himselfe to the pure and vpright, in such a way as shall make for their eternall comfort and saluation.

Now for the Reasons of the point, they may be taken: First, from the nature of seeing God. Secondly, from the parts: Thirdly, from the effects. For the first of these, it will easily appeare, that it Reas. 1 is a most blessed thing to see God, if we consider, that whereas three things must concurre to the making vp of sight: 1. an obiect: 2. a medium, a middle: as the water or ayre enlightned: 3. the faculty of seeing; in a word, there must be a double light, the one without a man, and the other within: here the 1. of these: 3. the obiect of this sight is most glorious, euen God himselfe. Now, the more glorious the obiect of sight is, the more the sight is reioyced and gladded, so long as it is not ouerwhelmed; as it is in created light, the more light the eye hath, if it be sound and right, the better pleased it is: but God, wee know, is beauty it selfe, light it selfe, and therefore must be a most amiable, and delightfull obiect to the eye of mans soule. Hence is that of Dauid, Psal. 27. One thing, saith he, haue I desired of the Lord, that I will seeke after, that I may dwell in the house of the Lord, all the daies of my life, to behold the beauty of the Lord. This was the thing that he both had desired, and would yet still goe on to desire, as that wherein consisteth the chiefe point of his happinesse: for there is that beauty, excellency, and glory in God, that would euen rauish
any heart that knew it; and could men but see it (as he said of his vertue) it would transport them with greatest loue and admiration.

Secondly, as the obiect of this sight is most glorious, so the meanes are heauenly. These are: 1. Christ, who is that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as the Apostle stiles him, the very beame, splendour, reflection of his Fathers glory, and the expresse image of his person, Hebr. 1.3. So that he that hath seene the Sonne, hath in that one sight seene also the Father. He is the best glasse wherein we may come by the sight of God, we see him best in his Sonne: 2. his Word and Ordinances, which in the Reuelation are fitly set forth by the name of a sea of glasse, first for largenesse, secondly, for steddinesse, thirdly for clearenesse, as giuing vs a cleare sight of God, in which respect, also, they are in the same booke compared to christall. Now it wil easily be granted a blessing to enioy Christ, and to see Gods face in his Ordinances, which are the meanes, therefore it must be the heighth of mans happinesse to see God.

Thirdly, the light in vs, whereby we see God, is supernaturall and heauenly. Indeede, by the light of nature, wee may come to see God in a sense, as Creator and vpholder of all things: but as our God fauouring vs, or blessing vs, wee cannot possibly behold him by Natures light, when it is most of all eleuated and enlarged, though you intend the spirits of Nature as much as may be, you cannot by the helpe thereof see God to your
comfort. It must be by a supernaturall light, that this must be attained vnto: as the Sunne is not seene but by the Sunne; the light, but by the light; so neither is God to be seene, but by the light of his owne grace, which must needs make a man most happy. And thus stands our first Reason, drawne from the nature of sight.

Reas. 2 Adde to this in the second place, a reason from the parts: For, what is it to see God, but, 1. to know him? And therefore knowledge is so often set forth by the sense of sight, which is the learned sense, and the most certaine of all the rest: 2. to see God, is more then to know him, it is to enioy him, that is, to be so neerely vnited vnto him, as to loue him, rest in him, and euen to passe into him (as Austin speakes) so as that it is not we that liue, but God that liueth in vs, &c.

Reas. 3 For the effects of this sight of God, thus: 1. It takes vs off from sinne, and from the creature, it lets vs see the vglinesse of sinne, and how extremely contrary it is vnto God: and so makes vs to loath and leaue it. This effect is wrought in Ephraim, Hosea. 14.8. We haue seene God, say they, what haue we then to doe any more with Idolls? So some read the w • rds. Yea, it will cause vs to account euery creature base and contemptible, in comparison of him, as it did Michaiah, who, when he had seene the Lord sitting vpon his throne with all the heauenly hosts about him,1 Reg 22. the greater Maiesty so darkens the lesser, that hee thinkes it nothing to face two Kings in all their pompe and Maiesty, with all
their traine and attendance. 2. It workes strange rauishments, it transports and carries a man euen out of himselfe, as you may see an example in Moses, who when hee had once seene God not with the seeing of the eye, (for so no man can see him and liue) but with the hearing of the eare; (for so God is seene by the eare better than the eye) as hee pleased to proclaime himselfe, Exod. 34. The Lord, the Lord God, mercifull and gracious, long-suffering and abundant in goodnesse and in truth, keeping mercy for thousands, &c: when hee had thus seene the Lord, oh, saith he, if now I haue found grace in thy sight, O Lord, let my Lord, I pray thee, goe along with vs, and why should we goe without thee? so greatly was Moses rauisht and affected with that blissefull vision. 3. This sight of God changeth and transformes a man into God. That sight which wee haue of him in the glasse of his Word, assimilates vs vnto God, and conformes vs vnto him, as the Apostle speaketh, wee all with open face beholding, as in a glasse, the glory of the Lord are changed into the same Image from glory to glory, euen as by the spirit of the Lord, 2 Cor. 3. how much more shall it bee so with vs hereafter, when we shall be swallow'd vp, as it were, of immortality, and shall be euen acted and enliued by God himselfe. Now let schooles goe and languish in vaine and spiritlesse disputes about the beatificall vision of God, as whether it consists in loue, ioy, knowledge, &c: the experienced Christian is able to tell you, that 'tis wisdome, ioy, loue, and all that good is.
But hitherto be spoken for the explication and confirmation of the point, wherein (it is true) wee haue beene somewhat darke, but could not helpe it; we hasten to the vses now.

Vse 1 And first, Is it the height of mans happinesse to see God, how great then must needs be the misery of all those that liue in darkenesse, and are shut out from his blessed sight and presence? All drakenesse makes one miserable: Throw a man into a dungeon, you doe, as it were, bury him aliue: digge out his eyes (as some Popes and Emperours haue beene anciently serued) and you leaue him vndone: take away the Sunne from a man, and you take away his wife, you take away his children, you take away his land, and all hee hath, in respect of any cōfort hee can take in them. But there is a spiritual darkenes and blindnes that's worse then all the rest, and that is when a man hath a veyle, as it were, of ignorance, wickednesse and vnbeliefe spred ouer the eye of his soule, a thicke curtaine drawn betwixt him and the face of God, so that he cannot see his father, he cannot behold Christ, who is the Light, that illightneth euery one that commeth into the world, who is that Sun of righteousnesse, that hath health vnder his wings. Take away this light from a man, depriue him of the benefit of this blessed Sunne, and what is hee better then a very Polyphemus, a monster of mankind, being full of ignorance, errour and superstition, full of groundlesse hopes, causelesse feares, hee goes hee knowes not whither, hee does hee knowes not what, hee gropes, as in the
darke; and (which is his greatest misery) hee cannot see his misery. But yet this darkenesse, so long as men liue here, is curable, and it may be done away and expell'd, as it certainely shall be, if euer the day doe dawne, and the day-starre arise in their hearts: But now further, there is beyond all this, an hellish outer darkenesse, to which all such are reserued, as loue darkenesse better than light: they shall one day haue their fill of that darkenesse, which they so much affected: there they shall meete with flames of darkenes to torment them, chaines of darkenesse to entharl them, spirits of darkenesse to tyrannize ouer them, a night of darkenesse, after which no day, no light euer followes: if three dayes darkenesse were so terrible to the Egyptians, what shall the case of those be, who shall neuer, neuer see light or life?
I, but who be these, you'll say vnto me, Quest. whose condition is such, and so miserable, as you speake of?

I answer (my brethren) first, Answ. all those that liue not in the knowledge of God in Christ: for hee that hath the Sonne, hath light; and hee hath not the Sonne, that hath no light; (i. e.) that hath no sound and sauing knowledge of God, as he stands reuealed in his word.

And againe: This is life eternall, saith our Sauiour, Iohn 17. to know thee, and whom thou hast sent into the world, Iesus Christ: so that they that are without the knowledge of God in Christ, haue no interest in life eternall; but are, as it were, shut
vp in darkenesse, and in the shaddow of death.

Secondly, all such as hauing attained to some light of knowledge, doe not walke in the light, but please themselues rather in the deeds of darknesse. Marke what the Apostle saith, Heb. 12.14. Follow peace with all men and holinesse, without which no man shall see God. So that euery vnholy person is by this text excluded from the vision of God. God shall see him (as Austin hath it) but hee shall not see God, see him indeed hee shall in a sense, not as a pardoning and pittying Father, but as an angry and seuere Iudge.

Thirdly, all impure persons are shut out from the sight of God; for if it be so, as our Sauiour here affirmeth, that the pure in heart are therefore blessed, because they shall see God; it will easily be concluded on the contrary part, that all impure ones haue no share in that happines, whether they be 1. negatiuely impure onely, that is, such as see not into the hypocrisie and rottennesse of their own harts, so as to bewayle and oppose it: or 2. whether they be positiuely impure, namely such as ouer and aboue the former, haue a disposition against holinesse, purenesse and vprightnesse, so as that they doe deride it in others, oppose it, persecute it. These are they that shall neuer see the face of God to their comfort, though to their terrour and confusion they shall one day see him. Let all such take notice here of their own wretchednesse, and acknowledge their condition to bee, as indeed it is, truely miserable and accursed. Cursed they are in life, for that being excluded
from the sight of God, they can finde no sweetnesse in the Word, no marrow in the Sacraments, no comfort in prayer, &c. Cursed they are in death, because they dye without hope of being present with the Lord, when they shall bee absent from the body, and therefore they dare not dye, they cannot liue, &c: Most cursed are they after death, when there must be made an euerlasting separation of both soule and body from the presence of God into the burning lake. If Absolon could say, that it were farre better for him to loose his life, then to bee debarred the kings presence: Oh who can conceiue the extreme misery of such as shall neuer see the pleased face of God in heauen! How much better were it for them to be euen dead, as beasts dy, and neuer to rise again, or that the mountaine should fal vpon them, & the hills couer them from the presence of the Lamb, that sits vpon the throne, &c: you know the misery of Haman, when once he fell so farre into the kings displeasure, that his face was couered. Hesther 7. For then there was no more hopes left for him, sith hee should neuer see the kings face any more, nor the king euer looke sweetly vpon him againe. This was euen the very height and vpshot of his misery: And so it shall be likewise of all ignorant, vnholy and impure persons, that they shall neuer, neuer see the sweet and glorious face of God in the kingdome of heauen.

For a second vse therefore of the point, let it serue for a two-fold exhortation, and 1. to all wicked and vnrepentant persons, to cast away their
sins, that so they may grow into acquaintance with God: sith they are the pure in heart onely that must be admitted into his sight and presence. Oh consider that your very l fe stands in his fauour, in his smiles, as on the contrary, there is death in his displeasure, neither can it be safe to liue vnder his frownes. Therefore, labour all you can to get your hearts purified by faith. The heart is the kings bed-chamber, as it were, and must be trimmed vp for his more honourable entertainment. The heart is the chiefe doer in man, and hath an influence into all his actions: it is the source and spring from whence floweth all we do. If the fountaine be empoysoned, if the heart be not clean, nothing that comes from it can be acceptable. If the water be foule in the well, it must needs be foule in the bucket. Now therfore, let S. Iam. his counsel be taken by you, Cleanse your hands, ye sinners, and purge your hearts, yee double-minded, and thus if yee draw neare to God, God will draw neare to you; being purified in heart, you shall see the face of God to your comfort, and not to your vtter confusion.

Our second exhortation shall bee addressed to such as know, what a sweet & comfortable thing it is to see Gods face, and to enioy his fauour, and let these bee exhorted in the words of Saint Iude, to keepe themselues in the loue of God, looking for the mercy of our Lord Iesus Christ vnto eternall life, verse 21. doe what you can to keepe his fauour, for in his fauour is life. The experienced Christian stands not in need of many motiues to incite and stirre him vp hereunto: for he knowes with Dauid, the sweetnesse of his loue, and what a blessed thing it
is to enioy his fauour, the onely want whereof hee findes more bitter then death. Indeed, he that was borne in hell (as the prouerb runnes) knowes no other heauen; hee that neuer tasted how sweet the Lord is, sets little by his loue, makes no reckoning or account of his countenance, but hee that hath euer been acquainted with God, and seene the light of his pleased face, had rather dye a thousand deaths then forfeit his fauour, or incurre his displeasure. A little child that alway beene vsed to the house and cradle, may easiely be kept within doores, but after it hath once beene vsed to the light, or taken a custome of going abroad into the open ayre, it growes tedious vnto it to bee confined to the cradle or house. So till a Christian haue had experience of Gods louing countenance, he cannot so much esteeme it, but when he knowes it once, and hath had the sweet feeling of it in his soule, he cannot, he cannot liue without it. You see what the Church saith, Psal. 80. God had made them to see and suffer much sore affliction, yet all this seemed a small matter vnto them, if God would but smile vpon them, and continue his countenance toward them. Turne vs againe, O Lord God of hosts, cause thy face to shine, and we shall be safe. If God would but doe this one thing for them, they cared not how much sorrow they otherwise sustained, as one the other side, if hee should deny them his fauour, they should not take cōfort or enioy any thing that they had. Now the way to keepe your selues in the loue and fauour of God is 1. to walk with him in humilty:
for though he dwell in the high and holy place, yet is he also with him, that is of a contrite and humble spirit, to reuiue the spirit of the humble, and to reuiue the heart of the contrite ones, Esay 57.15. And therfore doth he eft soones hide his face from his people, that he may humble them, and so prepare them for his returne, would you then see God, and enioy the light of his countenance, walke humbly before him, and worke out your saluation with reuerend feare, 2. Put your faith into act, 'tis not the hauing, but vsing of faith, that brings vs into communion with God: would you therefore haue and keepe a comfortable sight of God, set your faith on worke, for faith is the euidence of things not seen, and by faith it was that Moses saw him that was inuisible. 3. walke in vprightnesse, so shall we behold Gods face, as Dauid did Psal. 17.15. As for me, saith he, I shall behold thy face in righteousnesse, I shall be satisfied, when I awake, with thy likenesse. Those then that would see Gods face to their comfort, must purge themselues from their owne sinnes, and from their other mens sinnes too (as Saint Paul exhorts Timothy to take heed how he partake of the sinnes of others, if he would be pure) and set themselues to walke before God, in the constant exercise of all the duties of righteousnesse and obedience: so shall they keepe the sweet sense of Gods loue and fauour in their soules, and this is to liue, this is to liue in deed.

Vse 2 Comfort to al vpright persons, they shal see God. Indeed, as the case stands, and as the times now are, we had need to make Apology for purenesse
of heart, which is generally by the most so much opposed, and spoken against, that wee may iustly take vp that speech of the Poet, and say: Simplicitas, cuius non audeo dicere nomen.

For it is now come to that passe, that if any one giue vp his name to Christ, or but looke toward religion, hee is presently branded with the infamous name of Puritan. But the truth is, it is no disgrace to be so stiled, but rather as now, it is an honour.Downam on Cen. 22. Once (as a learned Bishop could say) only such passed for puritans, as opposed the Church-gouernment, and cryed out for Discipline, but now to be truly religious, is to become a Puritane presently, yea, to be a meere, morall, honest man, is incurre that censure. Yea, if a man bee but Orthodoxall, Euangelicall, Papists will not doubt to load him with names more than a few,So Bellar. in recognit. & spalarensis. and to let passe our Heresies, Turcisms, Atheisms, as they please to talke, with them a Caluinist and a Catharist are termes conuertible.Vid. • pfford, Posseuine, &c But what agreement haue we with Catharists, as they are described vnto vs by the Ancients?Vid. Cypr. Papin. in Epistola. doe not the Papists themselues (that lay the fault to vs) comply and iumpe with them in many of their opinions. As 1. they would giue the Sacrament to such as would become their followers, and cause them to sweare neuer to forsake them. And doe not Papists deale euen so with theirs?

2. They disallowed and condemned second marriages (as Austin reports it of them.) And
doe not the Papists so with some?

3. They defended this, that a man might here attaine to perfection, and freedome from all sin? And do not Papists hold the same thing, at least more than wee? wee? what haue we to do with Catharists or Nouatians? doe wee barre the doore against the lapsed, as they did 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , saith Epiphanius. Doe wee rebaptize the lapsed? separate from the Churches, hold our selues onely pure, as once they? no, let any man iudge betweene vs, who be the true Puritanes, whether we or they come nearest to Catharists. And yet a vaine affectation of purity, a meere name of Religion, is that I loath in any one. And the truth is, some there are that by their talking onely of holinesse, and empty profession without the power and practice of godlinesse, haue brought an ill name vpon those that are pure in heart, and rendred religion infamous. But let not this discourage or be an hindrance to such as are true of heart in their course of holinesse: but let them bee exhorted, 1. to begin at the root, at the heart, to wash the too inside aswell as the outside, to bee the same on both sides, and euery where suitable. 2. to proceed by the rule of the Word, going no slower and no faster, then as the word prescribes and directs them. 3. to end all in humility and mercy, for so the vpright person euer ends, he is not censorious, bitter, opposing. Thus bee, and then (these directions obserued) runne as fast as thou canst, in the race that is set before thee: for thou hast a marke, an example, euen Christ, whom, though
thou runnest neuer so fast, thou canst not possibly ouertake or attaine. But so much be spoken by way of Apology, we now returne from whence we digressed, to the vse of comfort we propounded before to al vpright persons, that they shal see God. Here in this life they see him in his ordināces they see their teachers, they can see God in euery word of his mouth, whether it be of reproofe, exhortation, comfort, &c: thus they see God in his word, they see him also in his works, in his works of mercy, in his works of Iustice, of prouidence, &c: they see him also in his attributes, they see him to be wisedome to them in their follies, power in their weakenesses, life in death, comfort in distresses, &c.

But greater comfort abides the vpright man hereafter, in that other life, where he shall see God after another manner then here hee can see him. Here his sight and knowledge of God is imperfect, as of a little child; wee see but as in a glasse, in a riddle darkly, being euery way feeble and imperfect: but then he shall see, as he is seene; see him as he is, and be as full of hapinesse as possibly hee can hold. If Paul preferred Christ crucified before all the world, and cared to know nothing else but him, how happy must they needes bee, that shall see and enioy him (as now he is) glorified, and comming with the glory of his father vpon him; to be made glorious in all his Saints. If in this life it be such a glory to be the sonnes of God, howsoeuer the world knowes vs not, nor once takes notice of it, what shall we be when we shall be like
vnto him at his appearance, when we shal see him as hee is, 1. Iohn 3.2. Oh what a glorious thing is a Christian! Euen here hee hath those ioyes that eye hath not seen, nor eare heard, neither hath it euer entred into the heart of a naturall man to conceiue, 1 Cor. 2. but what shall he haue then, when God shall bee all in all, when he shall haue no need of the Sunne nor of the moone: for the Glory of God shall be his light, he shall be immediately filled with his light, and be crowned with such comforts as cannot be conceiued, much lesse expressed, nay they that now enioy them, cannot vtter them. Comfort thy selfe therefore in this, if thou be pure in heart, though thy out-side be not so braue as som others, thou shalt see God, and so see him as that thou shalt neuer but see him, and yet neuer bee sated or satisfied with seeing of him.

div.head: The seventeenth SERMON.

epigraph.q: Blessed are the peace-makers: for they shall be called the children of God.

div.p: WEe have spoken of purity of heart: To this our Saviour subjoynes peaceablenes. and the order, and connexion is very good: for all contentions and brawles do arise of the impure lusts that are within, as saith S. Iames, chap. 4.1. From whence come wars & fightings among you? come they not hence, even of your lusts that warre in your members? As on the other side, upon purity of heart followes peaceablenes, Iam. 3.17. The wisedome that is from above is first pure, (of that we have spoken) then peaceable, as in the text. Blessed are the peace-makers, &c.

For the words, they containe in them these two parts; first, an assertion, or doctrine, Blessed are the peace-makers. Secondly, a confirmation or proofe in that which followeth, for they shall be called the children of God. For the first; the words are diversly
extended, and interpreted by diverse Expositors: The most approved Authours of both ages, and of both sides, as well Papists as Protestants, agree in these two points, namely, that hee intendeth, first peace-keepers, secondly peace-makers: so that hence these two points doe result,
Doct. 1 1 That Christs Disciples, that is, all true Christians, must be keepers of the peace: they must bee in themselves peaceably disposed.
Doct. 2 2 That all Gods children must be peace-makers: they must not onely bee peaceably disposed in themselves, but doe all they can to advance peace among their brethren.
Wee'le begin with the first.

All Christs disciples must bee peace-keepers, peaceably disposed, men of peace. They must give themselves to it (as some of our Interpreters, and the Iesuites expresse it) they must study it, and labour nothing more than peace. For confirmation hereof, the Apostle tels us in two severall texts, that God hath called us to peace, 1. Cor. 7.15. Col. 3.15. If wee looke to particulars, our Father is the God of peace, our Gospel a Gospel of peace, our law a law of peace, our titles titles of peace; among fowles Gods people are called peaceable Doves, and among beasts they are called peaceable sheep. They are charged to pursue after peace, not onely to follow peace with all men, but to seeke peace and ensue it. To this our Saviour exhorts us, and the Apostles very often in all their Epistles, and that earnestly too. Indeed there is no one duty in all their writings that is more put on, either for
strength of reasons and arguments, or for earnestnesse of intreaty. Follow us a little, and you shall see it made good. Have salt in your selves, and have peace one with another, saith our Saviour. Mar. 9.50. And in Iohn, By this shall all men know that yee are my disciples, if ye love one another. Now there can be no love, where there is no peace. So the Apostle, Rom. 12.18. If it be possible, saith hee, as much as lyeth in you, live peaceably with all men: As if he should say, Let there be no default in you, let not the stay be on your part, let it not sticke there, but doe you diligently endeavour a generall peace with all sorts. So likewise, Heb. 12.14. Follow peace with all men, and holinesse. So farre as you may with a safe conscience, be ready to entertain peace with all men. And, Phil. 2.1. speaking there of Christians among themselves, see how earnest the Apostle is in the point, If, saith he, there be any consolation in Christ, if any comfort in love, if any fellowship of the Spirit, if any bowels and mercies, fulfill yee my joy, that ye be like minded, having the same love, being of one accord, of one minde, doing nothing through strife or vaine glory, &c. So 1. Pet. 3.8, 9. and so downeward; Finally, be all of one minde, having compassion one of another, love as brethren, &c. And how often are we pressed to the duty of love (which, what is it else but the strength, and perfection of peace?) that it bee not in word and in speech, but in deed and in truth, that it be a burning love, a pure love, an effectuall, working, hearty love: that is, that there be in us peace in all abundance, that wee follow after, and ensue it, that
